After drinking this I imagine I know what the bottom of an ashtray taste like because that is the aftertaste.  I know its a classic but, not bad but not good is as far as Im willing to go here.  Thank You Fullers.  2009 12oz.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2016 Brown with great ruby highlights and thin off-white head. Medium body with medium-high co2.

Aroma: brown malt, cacao, subtle licorice, soy sauce notes, very enticing.

Taste: bready malt, mocha, charred grains, faint fruitiness.

Complex and layered, yet easy-drinking.
Dark ruby /black color.  No real aroma that I could tell, though it has a definite flavor of chocolate, which lingers but dissipates quickly not leaving any noticeable aftertaste.
One of my favorite porters.  A great toasty, chocolaty aroma with the taste balanced toward the sweet side.  It feels creamy in the mouth.

Aroma: caramel coffee, Appearance: black, minimal head, Taste:  medium bitterness with a hint of coffee, Palate: full body, thick feel, fizzy, Overall: This is a great beer to drink while watching some good classic movies.

Clear, very, very deep ruby/brown.  Creamy roast aromas with hefty cream and light wood smoke. Deep, intense and strong.  Wood again with a light metallic edge and slightly eucalyptus notes. Complex yet very drinkable.  A lovely milkiness envelopes the whole thing. Delicious

bottle: poured into snifter. pours dark mahogany. with no head. Really nice arouma, chocolate and prunes. Taste of sweet roasted malt and dark fruits. Smooth mouthfeel and light carbonation. Finishes with mild hops.
Bottle. Nice black pour with a light tan head. Aroma is very chocolatey, some malt. Taste is chocolate with some alcohol presence. Mouthfeel is just a little watery.

Dark and headless. A spicy scent. Coffee, mocha, liquorice and slightly sweet, with roasted tastes. The bitter comes from the burnt malts and less of the hops. Creamy mouth feel and shortly lasting after-taste. Only the wringing mouth feel resides for longer.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2010 Bottle at Olearys Örebro 2010-12-23
F: more of honey sweetnes still 3,7!


Another bottle bought in Horstens, Denmark 2010-04-12
AR: Coffey and soe grainy chocolate
AP: Dark redish brown body, 3 cm high steady ofwhite head
F: rich coffey flavor - bitter and long lastng, some cholcolate, a wee bit more bittter then the sweetness I remember. Still  3,7*.

Porterfestival, Göteborg, 2009-11-14, Bottle
AR: Coffee and chocolate
AP:Black body withe high but fast diminishing head
F: Coffee, chocolate, fudgy sweetness

poured from a 50cl bottle into a pint glass. Very dark with caramel coloured head. The aroma is slightly coffee with some chocolate undertones. Taste is sweet, not too bitter at all. An excellent porter.

Bottle into a pint glass.  Pours brown with shimmering red when held to the light.  The aroma is mild coffee and lots of milk chocolate.  The flavor is smooth milk chocolate with a nice coffee touch and a hint of porter sourness.  This is some good stuff!

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2013 500ml bottle from SAQ.
Appearance : Deep black with medium creamy brown head.

Aroma : Chewy roasted malt with light chocolate, light coffee and very light smoke. Very light piny hops. Slightly mineral.

Taste : Light roasted malts with light caramel. Light coffee and chocolate on the finish with light smoke. Late finish has some more smoke with coffee and roasted malt. some herbal hops all along. Hint of acidity.

Palate : Fairly soft carbonation.

Overall : Not bad. Highly drinkable and quite flavorful. Slightly mineral which I dont particularly enjoy. Nice malt profile. Well balanced. A nice go to porter thats readily available but Ive had more than a few better ones. Id love to have it on cask though. Rating stays the same.

500ml bottle best before 20/Jun/10 from SAQ. Pours black with a medium head that diminished fast. Nose has lots of roasted malt with hints of smoke and hops. Some coffee and chocolate as well as some sweetness. Taste is quite mellow. Great roastiness. Quite malty. Small chocolate bitterness on the finish with some hints of butterscotch and hops. Dry finish. Rated Nov 2009. 8,4,7,3,15;3.7

Near black pour with just faint hint of mahogany highlights and a big, frothy, tan head.  The aroma smells like malted chocolate milk with a fair amount of roast and a hint of coffee.  The malted chocolate milk flavor really continues through from the aroma with a few notes of coffee, brown sugar and dark fruit.  The body is a bit on the thin side but has a nice creaminess to it and soft carbonation.

Had a few of these on tap at Elephant & Castle in Chicago. Came out a deep black color with a small tan head. The aroma consisted of roasted malt and coffee. It was very simple but was very pleasant. The taste was a wonderful mix of roasty malt, light coffee, and a sweet taste that may have been a hint of chocolate. This was very easy to drink. The only part of this beer that could be improved is the mouth feel. It could have been a bit heavier. Overall, a great beer though!

Pours coal black with a light head.  Mild, but flavorful, aroma of coffee malts.  The flavor is classic porter - smoky, coffee notes with noticable chocolate sweetness.  There is a good amount of hoppy tingle as well.  Fullers London Porter manages to be bitter, sweet, robust, and mellow all at the same time.  It goes very well with the freshly baked apple pie that Im having with it.  I hear that this used to be in RBs Top 50, and it is still the #2 ranked porter.  This certainly seems like a gold standard porter to me.  Is this the beer that made London famous?

Dark brown thick viscous liquid with a brown head.  Aroma is coffee, malt and dark fruit.  Taste is rich, with chocolate and malt with a full finish and a dry mouthfeel.  Quite the porter, I really enjoyed this.  Although Fullers rarely does anything wrong!

500 ml bottle. Dark reddish brown colour with tan head. Cocoa, chocolate, coffee and dark fruits in the aroma. Flavours of chocolate, lactose and prunes with hints of iron (from the water?) and dark bread. Finishes quite dry in spite of sweetish elements in the flavour.

Dark amber brown pour into thick foamy tan head that dissipates into sticky lacing melting down the glass leaving behind a heavy ring of foam and a swirling pool of creamy bubbles. Aroma of dark chocolate malt, roasted coffee, and sweet milk chocolate. Initial flavor of dark chocolate, buttery cream with a taste of toffee and nutty caramel fading to a mildly bitter hoppy finish.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2009 Bottle from Bath Waitrose (first time Ive seen it for sale in the UK). Mahogany with ruby glints appearing pitch under an uneven yellow-tan head, following the beer to the bottom of the glass. Enticing aroma mashing up high cocoa, old leaves, prunes, smouldering wood and Bovril. Rich malt loaf character dusted with carbon; soft lactic, iron and prune touches. Sweet initially with Double Choc slickness before the burnt toast, bonfire and punchy bittering hop kicks in. Satisfying.

(16oz nitro can) pours very dark opaque brown with creamy head. Nose cream, sweet chocolate and coffee, and light brown sugar. Taste roasted cane sugar, coffee with cream. Lingers with toastiness, and more coffee with cream. Tasting some nuts in this as well this is a world class porter.

This is a nice creamy porter that has a well balance of dark roasted maltiness and hop finish.  The head is perfect on a good pour similar to a Guniess.  It has good chocolate-toffee aroma. and flavor.
UPDATED: NOV 5, 2009 Bottle. Aroma of dark chocolate, coffee, toffee, and prunes. Wonderful range of flavors. A great porter.
theres nothing to say about this.  drink it and then you will know what quality is.

Very dark brown with ruby highlights. This tan head. Sweet malts in the nose with coffee, cigars and thorntons toffee.. Flacour is smooth and creamy buy robust. Tons of tobacco and coffee. nice bitter finish. sugestions of roastiness Really good well balanced  robust porter
50cl bottle, Alko. Pours dark almost black color, chocolate, malt aroma.  Creamy, with some coffee flavour. Good as dessert!

Ive been looking for this for a while, and I have to admit to being underwhelmed slightly.  The nose is a nice chocolate, nutty, roasty experience.  the appearance is dark drown/black, which permits dark red light through it when held up to a lamp.  The flavor is a tad more complex, chocolate, nuts, vanilla, roasted coffee, brown sugar.  Roasted malts, resiny hops on the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium, even a tad on the thin side.  Too thin for the style.  Decent porter overall, not I good as I had expected.

50cl dark brown bottle. Impenetrable, pitch-black colour with medium beige head, generous lacing. Even when cooled-down this bear has a powerful "double chocolate" aroma with vanilla and roasted, coffee-ish malt notes vying for attention in the background. Low carbonation, thick, very creamy mouthfeel. Impressive! Complex flavour has chocolaty and coffee-like notes, with atrongly bitter dominant espresso taste on top. Dry, fresh finish balances the initial heaviness - how could a dark beer be better balanced. Another characterful, but well-rounded winner from Fullers. Heavy-bodied but never oppressive, this is the kind of beer they could serve at an Italian café!

Dark brown to black body with a small tan head after an aggressive pour. Great lacing. Smell is mostly of a slightly sweetened chocolate with notes of hops, malt, and herbs. Taste was the same with a low carbonated rich creamy mouthfeel. This was a great find in Cologne! This drink leaves a mild lasting bitterness that is quite pleasant and an enjoyable chocolate aftertaste.

Serving: 330 ml. bottle.
Appearance: Cola colored with a creamy, tan head.  Good head retention and lacing.
Aroma: Chocolate, a bit of coffee, and roasted malt make for a very nice nose.
Flavor: Dried fruit, particularly raisin, some burnt notes, roasted malt, and a slight mineral taste.  I think it is well rounded with a great flavor.
Palate: Medium carbonation with a medium mouthfeel and a medium-long, roasty finish.
Overall: A damn fine Porter for sure.  Definitely worth a go if you are a fan of the style.

Poured with a thick brown-tinted head that settled out after a few minutes, nice dark brown color.  The nose had notes of roasted malts, plum, and maybe chocolate.  Definite chocolate flavors, and roasted malts.  Medium-full bodied, the flavors linger for some time.  I did not expect a porter with so much chocolate flavor, maybe because I am used to American Porters.  I like this beer.

tap at fiddlers hearth.  Pours dark brown and delivered to me with no head.  One of the best sessionable beers Ive ever had.  Really nice roasted malt and chocolate.  very smooth.  Great all around beer.  Would be happy to drink again.

Bottle. Pours deep, dark ruby brown, almost black with a short light tan head. Roasted malt aroma with hints of dark chocolate, coffee beans and vanilla. Flavour is pretty much the same as the aroma but with a sweeter milk chocolate instead of the more bitter dark chocolate. Exceptionally smooth, creamy mouthfeel with a long finish, this is a great porter.

Nice tobacco and dark chocolate aroma. Mocha coffee and raisins.

Deep chocolate brown look, with red highlights when put up to the light. Puffy, pimply head. Looks really nice.

The flavor is coffee grounds and leather.Sweet plums and dates. Feint (unobtrusive) butterscotch. Great balance of sweet stone fruits and bitter, roasted malts.

Feels ashy, but buttery after the swallow. Stands up to any American porter. None of the English over-sweetening I feared. An outstanding beer.

Dark, almost black with reddish tinge and a large white head.  Dark fruit and coffee aroma.  Rich and complet flavourof coffee, caramel and chocolate malt with a sligh hop character adding smooth complexity.

Pours an inky dark brown, with a one-finger tan head, very fine and lasting lacing.  Aromas of espresso, chocolate, and toast, slightly woody.  Medium body, smooth and creamy.  Espresso and dark chocolate notes continue in the taste, finishing with a hint of pine.  Extremely well balanced and drinkable.  A perfectly crafted straightforward porter.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2010 Black with strong, lasting tan head. Tasted of roasted malts with coffee flavors strong here. Also some chocolate and caramel notes. Very smooth and a bit more sweet than most stouts. Finished a bit bitter but not too much. Also not as dry as other stouts. Tasted pretty good and got nicer the more you drank it. Also very well balanced. Overall I recommend!

Can.  Goddamn I hadnt had this in a while, and I dont know why.  This is really, a porter!  Lightly roasted nose mixed with hints of dark and sweet cocoa.  Flavor palate is simply perfect for this style.  Ranges anywhere from sweet chocolate malts to earth dark cocoa, hints at coffee, with a very delicate touch of roast throughout the whole body.  Velvety smooth and just the perfect amount of thickness.  Cocoa lingers through the sweet finish.  Balanced, tasty, sexy looking, and just overall a GREAT beer.  Possibly Fullers best!

!2 oz bottle Pours Chocolate and ruby no head. Caramel and malt to the nose but in a very unique way maybe a bit of well water smell.(mean its metallic in aftertaste). Flavor is Coffee and smoked caramel. very earthy. Damn good taste. Not on flavor killing metallic taste to it. Damn I love this beer. also a slight chocolate taste. Great great beer. Im glad I got this beer! Very highly recommended!

Had this in The Moyles Bar Hebden Bridge: Malt and caramel in the nose,
Tastes of Coffee Chocolateand Caramel
Wonderful light brown head
A fantastic beer in a great place

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2012 Bottled 50cl. The nose is dominated by caramel and fantastic earthy hops. Caramel, mocha, hops and dark chocolate in the taste. Wonderfully balanced. Great hop and malt profile. Smooth. Remarkably long finish which is reminiscent of heather, lime and dark chocolate. Definetely a great beer. Sublime.
Bottle. 12 oz. Pours deep, murky brown with a medium beige head. Aroma of malt, chocolate, and clove. Full body with a heavy, yet surprisingly smooth finish. Good porter.
Bottle, 500 ml. Dark brown, pours a medium light brown head that sticks around. Great chocolate and coffee flavours. Fine indeed.
500 ML bottle. Pours a dark brown with a small head. Smell is very strong of coffee mainly with chocolate. Taste was a little disapointing pretty flat but still very good
Love the Chocolate and Coffee flavors in this beer. This beer could definitely stand up against a bowl of vanilla ice cream.

On tap at The Englander. Pours dark brown with a tinge of ruby in the light. It has a small khaki head. The aroma is a bit tart with under ripe berries, roasted coffee, and a touch of chocolate. Very light on the palate, even for a porter. Fairly complex flavor with coffee, berries, chocolate and a nice roasted quality in the finish. A very traditional porter and a good example of the style, just not all that exciting.
Quick on the tongue. It was preceded by a Belhaven Stout, so my palate might have been overpowered. Worth a second try.

500 mL Can. Rich brown body with a frothy pale brown head. Aroma is rich malt, toffee, coffee, caramel, and a hint of cocoa. Rich malt flavor with a sweet dark malt aftertaste and a sweet caramel / black coffee finish and a smooth silky mouth feel. To that little man down there at the bottom of the label: Ill buy that round!
This beer poured a thick black with a medium brown head. Great coffee flavor and aroma.
12oz - Aroma of dark roasted malts, rusty water and a touch of chocolate.  Flavor matches with a nice chocolate finish. Palate is thin and ashy.  Tasty enough but nothing special.
Pick this up at Stephanies in Doylestown.  One of the best Porters I have had.  Smooth as could be.
UPDATED: DEC 16, 2009 smell of licorice and chocolate, candied brown sugar. it has a creamy but watery body with a head that fades and is pitch black. taste is very burnt, molasses, dark bread

Pours almost opaque, but there is some deep dark mahogany through the middle of the beer when held up to light.  A thin mocha colored head forms on top and soon thereafter, it dissappears leaving some lacing behind.  The aroma is complex of most noticeably - chocolate.  Other aromas follow such as caramel and toffee.  There is a tad of coffee malts as well, but overall, rather subdued and subtle.  Live carbonation on the tongue.  Chocolate really seems to dominate this brew as this flavor is again, most noticeable.  Other flavors do follow such as the deep bitter roasted coffee and toffee.  The finish is the roasted aspect of a porter.  This is a really fine porter!!

Aroma is a very soft roasted barley, could be stronger for my tastes - i like my smells! But it looks great, has an amazing dark appearance and big fluffy, almost creamy, head. Taste is nice and smooth, all barley and malts, very satisfying. Could be slightly stronger, a little wateriness on the back end that makes it more refreshing than I was hoping for. Mouthfeel is great, but again still feels a little watery. But these are small complaints, its still a great brew.

Dark brown pour with a small light tan head. Wonderful chocolate malt aroma. The flavor is even better, chocolate, a little molasses and a nice roasted malt aftertaste. Medium bodied, one of the best porters out there.

Pours dark brown/amber with a nice mounted light brown creamy head. Aromas of burnt malts, some licorice, molasses, chocolate, with a little cocoa. The flavor is smooth with hints of chocolate, burnt malts, touch of hops, touch of licorice and molasses. Hmm. Bitter, somewhat rich and creamy thought a bit on the watery side. A fine porter that has a little bit of a lot of flavors. Leaves that burnt malt aftertaste.
50 cl can. Almost black body with big off-white head. Flavour is roasted malt, coffee and chocolate.

500 ml bottle from LCBO. Nice cloudy brownish black pour, lasting tan head. Beautiful. Aroma of coffee, some roasted nuts and chocolate.  Nice roasted malty start with a bitter coffee and chocolaty finishing taste. Excellent from start to finish.

Ive looked for this a bit in the past, because it is supposed to be easy to get, but never found it.  Yesterday I saw it in our local supermarket, times change.  Strong cocoa aroma.  Also a roasted malt aroma.  Appearance is a reddish-orange-ish tinged brown.  Minimal head.  Palate is a bit gritty, especially as it warms, it is oily, bubbly, and has a bit of a coffee taste and bitterness.  Yes there is a bit of smokiness in there too.  Nice, especially as it warms.

Can. A dark brown beer with a decent head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, & chocolate. The taste was the same as the aroma & was very smooth but was very thin & watery for a porter. For being so high in the rankings I would think it would have a better mouthfeel & be somewhat creamier for a porter.

Bottle, shared with macadem. Pours cola brown, with a thick, wispy off-white/pale tan head that laces passably. Nose is chocolate malt, a hint of smoke. Palate is much more evolved, luscious and generous, plenty ofo cocoa, dry amltiness, smoke, licorice. A very very open and forgiving, and delicious porter.

Dark, dark brown--only a touch of light shines through (and it appears ruby in color).  Dense, one-finger beige head.  Great, thick ring lace on the glass.

Delicious nose of cocoa and cream.  Theres another element that Ive yet to identify, but it is attractive and drawing.  Its almost like burnt toast or a mild smokiness.

Now that Ive identified, I really notice the smoke, although it is subtle (not like a rauchbier).  Some burnt biscuit with a dollop of whipped cream.  The swallow features bitter chocolate and touch of cherry.  Wonderfully complex.  If there is a moderation of the excellence, it would be in the body--modest with an above average level of carbonation.  The aftertaste is more cocoa.

Simply a wonderfully complex beer--exceptional!

16 oz. can.  Pours black with a thick, creamy light tan head.  Aroma of sweet chocolate malts.  Flavor of the same chocolate malts, sweet crystal malts, a touch of hops.  Smooth, creamy mouthfeel.  Kind of bland overall, just a boring porter.
7/4/6/3/13 Ɠ.3/5)

(bottle from waitrose, wymondham) Pours almost black with a large, bubbly off white head. Smell is smoky with coffee and chocolate - very appitising. Nutty malty taste with fresh hops adding a light balance. Bitter coffee and plum very well blended and tasty. Quite drinkable.

Pours out a dark tawny, but appears black in the glass. The bone white head retains well and leaves some spotty yet slippery lace. The aroma is rich and smokey. Lots of roasted malt, pipe tobacco, some brown sugar and a hint of coca. Initial taste is sweet and robust. Kinda watery mouthfeel, but very flavorful.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2012 Bottle. The pour was a very dark murky brown, almost black with an average sized (1-2 finger) medium brown frothy head that diminished slowly and had some really nice lacing.

The aroma was of a cookie malt and a sweet leathery yeast with notes of chocolate, brown sugar, molasses and roasted coffee.

The taste was good and roasty and extremely malty with hints of chocolate and brown sugar from the start, and then had a slight bitterness to it and a nice dose of coffee towards the end. The aftertaste was smooth and roasty with a nice creamy choco-coffee flavor and lasted quite a while, which I did not mind at all. 

Mouthfeel was extremely creamy in texture and full in body with a nice soft carbonation.

Overall this was an EXCELLENT Porter with the flavors blended together so well that it created a very creamy and roasty brew that was a pleasure to drink...
An immediate combination of sweet caramel and dark roast malt is very welcome. Good underlyingsharpness. Ruby tinge just discernible in the darkness. Always a pleasure to see on the shelves.

This is how I feel a UK Porter should be. I was underwhelmed by another "famous" British porter, but the Fullers brought back my confidence in this style. Rich chocolatey flavor, superb head, and remarkably enjoyable. No doubt I will be having this again! 55F in the can.

This was lovely, perhaps the best porter Ive had yet.  The colour was a rich, dark colour hinting at the malts and chocolate within, and the enormous head was also top-notch.  Aroma and taste again featured both the chocolate and the malt, with little evidence of hops.  A most enjoyable, smooth drink.

Looks great tastes great. When I bought this at the local LCBO I really did not know what to expect. Very dark, thin light brown head, big chocolate flavour, with some complexity and a great slightly bitter aftertaste. Hopefully ill be able to find this one again.

11.2oz bottle. Pours a dark brown, almost black body with a reddish tint to it. Thin, light brown head that dissipates quickly and leaves a light lacing. Aroma is medium sweet English malts and roasts with some smoke, chocolate, and fruits. Flavor is roasts and a light smoke, fruity English malts, some licorice, toffees, nuts, and chocolate. A very late hop presence, but not much. Finishes rich and roasty with a medium length aftertaste. Light bodied, somewhat watery but full flavored, and dry. Overall, a solid and classic porter. A bit over-rated, but tasty and full of flavor.

Pours a dark chestnut brown, with a good off-white head. Aromas of chocolate, coffee and malt. Taste a bitter coffee with chocolate highlights and hints of roasted malts and nuts. Finishes dry with good bitterness...it is what it is...

This beer tasted like a carbonated chocolate latte.  It looks great:  a dark brown hue that was slightly transparent at the edges of my special beer glass.  The taste at first was almost too chocolately and coffee-like, but I think I served it too cold.  I had it with spicy-hot BBQ wings and pizza, and it tasted amazing together.  I highly recommend this beer if you can find it.

I shared a bottle of this with BeerBaron617.  Honestly, I didnt like it all too much.  It did pour a nice color, chocolate brown and its pretty transparent.  It had a thin foamy head that made its way into a thin ring around the glass.  It smelled like milk, which was weird and made me uncomfortable.  It did have a nice chocolate taste and a slight bit of coffee in there, but there was only light carbonation and a very weak mouthfeel.  I did not enjoy this beer.
From the tap poured dark brown with a fair amount of head.  Nice sweet malty flavor with a lingering finish.

Dark brown with red tints, a nice milk chocolate tan head.  The aroma is big and roasty with dark chocolate, mixed berries.  Taste is smooth chocolate milk, caramel, fruity toffee, and then a light astringent malt bitter finish.  Nice.

33cl bottle.   Dark brown with red highlights and a lasting beige head.   Aroma of cream, dark chocolate, vanilla ice cream, and caramel.   The flavor has sweet caramel, medium roasted malt, some dark chocolate, lower bitterness, and just a touch of lingering sweet cream in the finish.   Almost like rich chocolate milk.   Medium bodied with smooth carbonation.   I like that this is firmly a porter, and a great one at that.   There is no way you are confusing this with a stout.   I would love to have this on cask or bottle conditioned.

50cl bottle poured into a pint glass.  Dark amber with minimal tan head.  Aroma is dark fruit and caramel.  Flavor is roasted malt, dark fruit, wood.  Medium carbonation.  Medium body.  Long bitter finish.  A nice well-balanced after-dinner beer.

A nice aroma with strong chocolate, toasty scents
A deep dark brown/ reddish color and clear
A medium sweet, roasted chocolaty taste  =chalky finish
Good body
A nice frothy head - dissapated quickly though  
Little alcohol taste - well balanced
poured dark brown with an off white head that lASted half a beer.  smelled of coffee and chocolate. tasted a little sweet at the beginning and faded to bitter coffe taste.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2010 11.2oz bottle, finally tried outside of can! Seriously, made a huge difference. Roasted malts and chocolate flavours are richer, mouthfeel is smoother, richer, the bitterness seems to linger just a little longer leaving a dry feeling on your tongue, the exact same as if youd just eaten some extra dark chocolate. Wonderful!

(bottle) Clear, dark mahogany colour with a big and dense beige foamy head. Sweet and moderately roasted malty aroma with a cornucopia of flavours of chocolate, caramel/toffee mocha, nuts and vague hints of smoke. Pleasantly bitter flavour, medium bodied with a creamy carbonation. Aromatic and complex, moderately roasted and slightly grainy malt profile; long lasting and rounded finish. A wonderful Porter (14.VII.09).
A full flavoured and bodied classic porter, its not entertaining by any means but close to flawless with a perfect balance and generous chocolate flavours.
Pours a clear dark brown body with a light tan head that has legs.  Roasted and toasted aromas.  Flavors of soy sauce, brown sugar, toast, coffee, and some cocoa.  Silky body.

Bottled.
Dark brown with brown head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate and malt. Flavor is caramel with dry roasted malt. smooth palate
A very yummy and rich drink.  But still smooth.  Like the Guinness draft can except more complexity.   Great stuff!
Pours dark red brown with a thin off white head.. Aroma is a little salty and smokey.. Flavor is some light smoke and a little chocolate.. Pretty good.

Bottle from double D.  Clear and very dark ruby red with a moderate tan head that fades back into said ruby rather quickly.  Aroma of dark chocolate, molasses, brown sugar and mild soy sauce.  Taste of dark malt, mild chocolate and brown sugar, light coffee and mild hops.  Fuller bodied than most porters but not terribly flavorful.

Pours black with some off white head.  Faint chocolate coffee aroma.  Body is not as thick as some other porters of this quality. Best thing about this beer was the flavor, which was very chocolaty with a hint of coffee and hops.  This is a great porter and something I would suggest to check out.

Bottle, 50cl. Pours a black beer with a brown head. The aroma is roasted with chocolate and notes of coffee. The flavor is bitter chocolate, followed by a roasted and hoppy bitterness. The palate is dry. Overall a very nice porter.

pitch black with mild white head.  sweet malt and some roasty scents to the nose.  carbonation is moderate for style.  some hop bitterness initially then a lot of caramel sweetness that perfectly blends into some roasty flavors, likely from black patent, which fades into some chocolate notes before a long drawn out finish from some residual sugars and yeasty esters.  first class all the way, the best brown porter ive had with remarkable depth for only 5.4 ABV.  amazing

Colore scuro, con uno spesso strato di schiuma marrone. Aroma di luppolo e malto torrefatto, lieve nota di caffè.In bocca è praticamente un cappuccino,sapore di malto e caffè.Non molto amara se non nel finale.Ottima birra scura.

Very nice dark beer, have yet to pour in a glass, but the aroma is mild.  Plenty of maltiness to the taste.  Can taste the roast.  Not as heavy as some of this style, but a mild porter is still a porter.
Aweseome one, a little sweet a little bitter. It was a marvel when I drank it. And slept like a baby.

Very dark ruby red / black beer with a huge deep tan rocky head and really good lacing. Aroma is appealing with its strong bitter coffee beans and a good ammount of chocolate (a little on the powerdery side). Lots of flavour: bitter roasted coffee beans / malt and some chocolate with a touch of hops (really weak). The alcohol and bitterness blend together well. This is really tasty! For me, the mouthfeel was not terrible but just subpar and not to my liking. Slick, too smooth - dont really like the feel of the hops. Short lived aftertaste. Very good beer none the less.

This beer looks like a giant pint of black coffee sitting in front of me or maybe a glass of coke, very black with a red hugh around the edges and a nice thick tan head about a half inch high. The light scents of chocolate and coffee are very nice, but I would have scored them higher if they werent so weak. Unlike the aroma the taste is very strong, dark bitter chocolate, burnt coffee and roasted malts, I think I can also get some chalky banana in the background. This is a very hard beer for me to describe the taste theres lots going on. The after taste is harshly bitter and long lasting. A very good beer, buts one I could never drink more then one in a evening.
thanks to ouknowo on this one... a dry and a little bitter in a good way... nice easy to drink... another good one from fullers

Could be the glassery, not the quite best for the beer, but the only dislike in the appeareance was the tiny (although lasting and regular) beige to brow foam. The ruby body made me dive. Despite of having a descouraging experience with an english ale last week, this porter did got me into some wild tasting experience. The aroma was astonishing good, with licourous port wine sent, along with dark chocolate, coffee and roasted-it-all: from wood to malt. Into the mouth, you know, angels sang. The chocolate seemed to be already exactly mixed with coffee for the best experience, with dark malts flowing from side to side retouching any possible flaw. Some caramel and molasses came along the ruby wine taste. But the big prize was for sure in the aftertaste, with hints of bitterness from the coffee, the warm good-bye alcohol feel, and some faint nutty flavores mixed with faiting chocolate. Now I can say I tasted a porter.
Bottle. Not particularly impressed. The brown/crystal malt combo was not so good. Gave a dirty/peaty/almost smoked flavor. Smooth but a bit overcarbonated.

11.2 oz bottle.  Dark brown color with a tan head, as expected.  I thought the flavor was a bit of a let down.  Very smoky and roasted with coffee flavors brimming through; also light hints of chocolate and sweet malts.  Decent, but not my favorite.

Pours a black that looks clear ruby red when held up to the light.  Foamy head with moderately long retention.  Moderately thick lacing.  Nose of rich dark malts.  Flavor of black coffee with distinct notes of molasses and caramel.  Mouthfeel is pleasantly thick and creamy.  Coffee-like bitter finish.

500ml bottle. Pours very deep ruby with an average tan head. Aroma is nice coffee-ish and flavor is even nicer with kinda sweet roasted coffee, dark chocolate and maybe some malts. Palate is just great. Overall an awesome, very well balanced porter.
Color is almost solid brown, chocolaty and roasted malty aroma. Almost grainy mouth feel, mild chocolate and caramel flavors. Good bitterness, very well balanced beer.
Pours deep brown with a tan head. Nutty, subtle chocolate flavor. Slightly thin body, but the flavors stay on your palate nonetheless. Very solid.
500ml botle. Pours a very dark brown, head is tan. Malty hoppy nose. Great malty taste and a nice bitterness. Loved this beer from the cask years ago, love itfrom the bottle now.

Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma is deep milk chocolate, coffee, vanilla.  Big roasted malts...chocolate, coffee, some nuttiness.  This almost feels like it should be drank hot.  Bitter hop bite at the end to balance out the flavor.  Well done.

Poured from Can into Pint glass.

Pours a deep brown that has mahogany edges with a creamy light tan head. Aroma is full of milk chocolate, vanilla and a dash of coffee. The flavor has dark chocolate, cocoa nibs, some coffee and nuttiness but its smooth. Its a medium-bodied beer that is slightly chewy but its definitely an easy drinker. This is a classy beer, extremely drinkable and would love to try this on-tap.
Fantastic pour.  The brown malt is balanced nicely with the rich sweetness of the crystal.  By BJCP standards, this is a perfect example of the Brown Porter substyle.

Pours a characteristic almost black with small dark tan head.  Aroma obvious of coffee, chocolate, and a bit of cream.  Flavor matches with the addition of dark dried fruits, but missing that complexity I was hoping for in this.  Nice drink nonetheless.

On tap at the Bier Stein. Dark brown pour with a thick cap of tan foam. Big chocolate and coffee aroma, a little bit of hop at the back. Flavor is very roasty, with some nice chocolate bits and a bitter chocolate finish. Medium bodied and delicious.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a thick tan head, of good duration, minimal lacing, over a dark (SRM 30) clear body.....Nose heavy with aromas of roasted malts, with coffee, cocoa, chocolate, mild molasses, minimal hop floral....tastes of rich malts, again with coffee cocoa, finishing with mild hop bitterness....mouth feel rich and chewy.....a wonderful  brown porter. Meets the BJCP criteria in every way.

Bottle. Dark dark brown with a medium tan head that sticks around for a bit. Tons of roasty toasty malt in the aroma, in the form of coffee, chocolate, whatever else you want that smells nice. Flavor has a lot of the coffee with a good chocolaty finish, complemented nicely by a small bite of hops at the end. The only criticism I have is that I wish the body were just a bit thicker. Then again, though, its a porter, not a stout. Great beer, anyways.

Pours a dark brown color with a tan head.  Amazing aroma of coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, molasses, and a little hop character.  Flavor is similar.  Not over the top and extremely well blended.  A nice porter.
Smells sweet and roasty. Pours with great head and dark with a lot of light at the seams. Tastes roasty and  creamy. A decent stout but lacks some complexity.
Milldly roasty milk chocolate aroma, chewy coffee chocolate taste, nice soft creamy body. Used to love this and it is still very good.

Pours black with a medium tan head. Strong aroma of french roast coffee, some dark chocolate. Flavor is mostly coffee, malt, dark chocolate, toasty. Finish is a nice chocolate bitterness. Medium body and carbonation.  Would be great with a chocolate desert or cookies.

500 ml bottle. pours dark brown with a reddish hue and a spritzy looking tan head. bready chocolatey aroma. flavour is toasty, malty, mellow chocolate (that enhances in the aftertaste). taste a better than in smells for sure. medium body and bitterness

12-oz. Thanks, Skoi! This one had a long and storied history before it finally wandered home with me tonight. Nice to finally crack it. Pours ebony with rubied brown highlights and shows, even after over a year and a half in the bottle, a nice thick and creamy tan head. Nice big coffee nose, black bread there as well. Nice creamy body, substantive without being dense or overly cargo-ish. Plenty of wooly carb showing as well. Coffee, black bread, dark cocoa, and a bit of baking chocolate on the mid-palate. Long cocoa-y finish. Lovely stuff.

Bottle, cherry brown color with a little peach colored head, heavy malty aroma, some roasted notes mainly chocolate, creamy palate all the way that just in the end dries out. very pleasant aroma of brownie, dark chocolate, roasted coffee and fudge, indeed very complex. excellent!

Pours a deep ruby red with a nice medium light tan head with just a touch of lace. The aroma is nice nutty roasty and full of sweet malt. The flavor is even nicer with lots of chocolate molasses and a pronounced nuttiness
There are some good balancing hops here but this is much more about the delicious roasty malts. A very nice porter indeed.

Can...  Poured deep brown with a big, khaki head.  Roasted aroma of coffee beans, cocoa and malts.  Soft, smooth and creamy palate with noticeable coffee notes up front cocoa malts and nutty, earthy hops.  Chocolate, mocha and coffee in the finish.
A dark brown with a thick tan head.  More coffee than chocolate with a slight "off" biterness (not hops).  Also, had a slightly gritty mouthfeel.  Not bad but not the best porter.
On tap at C4. Dark brown body, with almost no head. Aroma is coffee, roasted malt and some chocolate. Flavor is coffee, chocolate, hops and hints of tobacco. Better than expected.

100th rating: I thought about rating the most unsignificant beer but I went with a world class beer instead.  I was sure it would be highly rated on the site but maybe not that much.  It is indeed the best porter I ever had yet.  Aroma of those "brown sweet gummy tool candies" (!), coffee and smoked malt.  Although the taste is deliciously chocolaty (dark) and fruity, and then coffeish with a lot of espresso-like bitterness in the aftertaste, all these well-balanced flavors wouldnt be as impressive without its rich and creamy texture.  I made a rather long car trip in order to get it...  I should have bought more than 3!  3,65$ for a 500 ml bottle.

Dark brown with medium tan head. Aroma roasty, malty with lots of coffee and chocolate. Taste is medium bitter, some sour chocolate and lots of coffee. Good body and a nice finish. Not very complex but a good beer nonetheless. A

pour is a dense black with a foamy finger high head. Aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Palate is a bit smooth....but I need to remind myself its not an Imp. stout...Light notes of milk chocolate, coffee and very faint hints of dark fruit. A bit of nut flavor hiding in there.
Good.

Bottle courtesy of hellbilly.  Deep brown color pour with some red highlights and a small tan head.  Roasted malt, coffee and chocolate in the aroma.  Flavor is big on cocoa and dark roast coffee.  A bit of bitterness on the finish.  Very nice.  Thanks Josh!

Bottle.  Pours clear dark reddish brown with a 2 finger dense tan head that results in chunky lacing.  The nose is milk chocolate and roasted malt.  The taste is ashy cocoa, chocolate, roasted malt and burnt coffee beans.  Medium creamy mouthfeel.  Good porter.
Bottle. Pours with a thick tan head. Plenty of a mild sweet, roasted aroma. Loads of dark coffee and a hint of dark chocolate. The beer finishes with a firm dark chocolate bitterness.
Very delicious.  Let the beer warm so that it brings-out the coffee and chocolate flavors.  Always on my good list.

Finally getting around to rating this classic. Pour is medium to dark brown with a small tan head that fades. Aroma and flavor of caramel malt, roasted malt, and smoke.  Very English tasting. Good, but not my favorite cup of tea.
Beautiful in color. Touch of caramel on the nose @ first sniff. Complex flavors of coffee, caramel, and a hint of smoke fill up the entire palate front to back. A fine, fine English Porter.

I feel like it has been FOREVER since my last rating, and I am pumped about his one. So here it goes: (Bottle) Pours a very dark brown with a thin brownish white head. Looks wonderfully delicious. A sugary aroma, with a bit of coffee and choc coming through. Sweet and brown. A bitter-sweet burst of complexity upon my first sip. Well-balanced with a medium body. Creamy and very refreshing. Such a great, smooth brew. Will certainly purchase again.

Pours almost black with thin white head. Nice lacing.  Aroma is chocolate and malty sweetness with a slight hop character for balance .  Full bodied and creamy. Tastes of chocolate sweetness and roasted malt bitterness to balance.

Creamy beige head, deep brown colour, lacing. Aroma is heavily roasted, dark chocolate, coffee and brown sugar. Flavour is roasted sweet and plenty of coffee and chocolate. The flavour is very well balanced and yet intriguing. Mouthfeel is very very smooth with small bubbles and it is almost a bit oily.This is a great porter, met my expectations and then some!

Serving type: bottle

Draft.  A dark chocolate colored beer with a thin tan head.  Aroma is malty with some chocolate and a slight smoke.  Flavor is roasted/burnt malt, nutty, light smoke and wood.  Towards the end I got much more chocolate.  Body is medium and creamy.  Finishes with a very mild bitterness.
Black with a creamy beige lasting head. Full, complex aroma of cocoa, coffee, just an hint of fruity. Very mellow as the flavour, velvety, medium bodied, extremely balanced.

33cl bottle from Total Wine (Tampa, FL). Pours a slightly hazy dark cola brown with reddish highlights with a one finger tan creamy head that settles slowly. Aroma is roasted and malty with notes of burnt caramal, honey, chocolate, some hints of vanilla and anise. Flavor is roasted and malty with notes of sweet cream, caramel, chocolate, smoke, wood. coffee, brown sugar, molasses, and hints of toffee. Generally medium to full body with a pleasing coffee chocolate finish.

Dark red with a nice creamy white head. Nose is sweet roasted malt with a hint of vanilla. Very good. Complex flavors of roasted malt, chocolate, butterscotch and vanilla without being too sweet. Finish is very clean. Didnt expect a beer you can find anywhere to be this good!

From bottle, dark-brown with medium tan head that lives a beatiful lacing, aroma is malt like with a deep chocolate and caramel, notes of clove and some pleasant roasted malts, flavors of smoked tobacco, coffee & chocolate, pleasant syrupy texture, and hoppy smokey clovey finish. As a good beer it is getting better from one sip to the other. dont drink it too cold or you might miss the show. A top balanced porter.

Lovely porter- great nutty/chocolatey smell. Only problem I have is the smokiness- never liked smoky beers. Luckily, that seems to fade as it warms, allowing more caramelly flavors to take over. $4/bottle at Zekes on Miami Beach

Pours dark with a tan head.  Aroma is very much roasted malts with a little vanilla and maybe a hint of coffee.  Flavor is very nice with the roasted malts being the most abundant in presence along with some chocolate and vanilla.  Really quite tasty.  Very nice full mouthfeel for a lower abv beer, or for any beer for that matter.  Its just a little more unexpected and thus pleasant here.  Really good beer.

pours very black with a thin light mocha colored head.  aroma has roasty malt, coffee and vanilla.  flavor is very malty and roasty with coffee, caramel, fig, and chocolate...maybe some dark fruits too.  mouthfeel is creamy and smooth with a roasty finish that has subtle coffee.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a foamy tan head. Heavy carbonation. Aroma is of coffee, malt, vanilla, brown sugar, and chocolate. Taste is of malt, lightly roasted coffee, chocolate, vanilla, and brown sugar. All of the flavors blend well without anything being too powerful. Body is light due to the carbonation. Mouthfeel is very creamy thick. A very drinkable porter.

Like an e e  cummings poem unexpectedly uttered by a coal miner on a bitter cold day. Looks like a glass of liquid obsidian and smells like black coffee and burnt oak. You brace for a harsh taste, but instead it comes on gently, warming you with a chocolate flavour. Leaves a bitter aftertaste that reminds you of better times. This is what unrelenting, stubborn hope tastes like.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2009 Pours a dark brown with copper edges. Minimal brown head. Roasted chocolate aroma along with a good roasted taste and creaminess. Finishes with a bitter coffee flavor. A bit  thin but it is English.
Nice, full body.  Almost too creamy, but still very good.  Incredibly smooth.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2015 ( bottle).   r8 .  If I buy this beer these days it is for the purpose of a black n tan mixed with something else american .  without the cross pond intertwining its still pretty good shit .  nose of milk chocolate malts , coffee roast , slight hop. deep brown with a nice beige foam head.  its drinks in a simplistic and easy to slam vibe . tastes of coffee roast and dark chocolate .

Dark brown pour. Lots of milk chocolate in the nose, along with some cream and roast. The flavor is mild, but very tasty milk chocolate with a mild hop/burnt kick coming in at the end. Maybe a bit of coffee in the finish too. Mouthfeel is on the light side, but velvety smooth. A very good, very drinkable porter, though not quite the greatness that I was expecting.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2011 Very dark and very strong porter. Coffee flavors are the most prominent present on both the nose and taste. Bit of a surprise kick too. 4.6 
RE-RATE 3/31/11 Bottle from World Market.  I decided to pour this beer into a glass of fellow UK brewer Wells.  It pours a very dark brown color with some reddish colors.  There is also a nice foamy beige head.

Wow what a great aroma!  I can smell loads of sweet and dark chocolate, with a fair amount of coffee on the nose.  Dark and roasty with sweet notes of chocolate malts.  Awesome aroma!

The flavor is very roasty as well.  Lots of toasted dark malts with some bitter Bakers chocolate.  There is a fairly bitterness that lasts all the way through to the finish.  Some bits of coffee as well, roasted grounds.  The flavor isnt quite as good as the aroma but it still remains nevertheless a very tasty beer.  Let it warm before enjoying.

Tin. Foured brownish black with frothy beige head.  Some lacing.  Aroma of milk, chocolate, malt and roast.  Full malty and milk chocolatey flavour with a lingering milk finish.  Theres a bit of hop there too to keep things from getting too sweet.  Worth drinking and repeating.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: UPDATED: APR 22, 2009 (bottle) pours the darkest ruby-brown colour with a dark frothy head and great lacing. aroma of dark toasted malts, strong notes of coffee and light chocolate, with a hint of smoke. flavour is the same, with lots of chocolate and dry toasted notes. medium body with smooth carbonation and a velvety, light roasted-bitter finish.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2016 "this is Porter done to perfection. just the right balance of sweet and roasty malts...goes great with a cigar. never had a bad one, and cant think of a way to improve it!...now it comes in a six-pack. Yeah!!!"
This is a very drinkable beer.  Great with meat, particularly steak.  Creamy malty chocolate taste.  Not particularly sweet.  Dark brown with medium tan head.  A good one.

330 mL. Pours a clear deep ruby with a one-finger tan head that settles quickly to nothing. No lacing. Aromas of Worcestershire sauce, soy sauce, milk chocolate, raisins, toffee. Taste upfront is mild coffee with chocolate and crystal malt then moves to dark chocolate and creamy caramel with some noticeable balancing hops. Dry finish. Velvety mouthfeel. Really nice all around.

4-pack of tallboys from the corner pizzeria. Nice, though short, head, aroma more coffee than chocolate. Tastes more chocolate than coffee, with a little bitter undercurrent. Maybe some butterscotch hiding way in the back. Definitely better than the dollar-a-pint price tag  woud make you think

11.2 oz. bottle. Pored a dark rich black with little head. Sweet malt aroma. Tasted how I remembered it when I was back in England. Nice malty beer with a good mouth feel. Left a nice lacing on the glass.
12oz bottle from BevMo.  Pours dark brown color, with small brown/tan head that diminishes, but lasts . Lasting flavor of toffee, chocolate, and coffee. Rich in flavor, great beer.

Bottle. Dark, dark red brown, almost black body. Pale brown small nice head. Quite heavy sweet malty aroma, some chocolate. Also some fresh hops. Light sweet flavour. Chocolate dominates. Very balanced sweetness. Not very heavy. A light bitter, fresh and dry finish. Amazingly easy drinking, to be a sweet porter. (The Blackbird, Earls Court, London, 03.12.08)

Bottle: malty, dark chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, burnt toast, some molasses, some cigar like smoky notes, some date like sweetness, good bitterness, dry finish, medium-full bodied, rich, satisfying beer, ive wanted to taste this beer for a long time and i wasnt disappointed.

Bottle.  Pours black/brown with ruby red hues and a small, khaki head, dissipating to a filmy, fizzy wisp.  Big nose of caramel and chocolate covered raisins.  Also some mild roasted coffee.  Taste is caramel and dark chocolate with mild fruit notes, a solid bitter and surprisingly dry finish.  This, as the bottle says, is rich, dark and complex with a medium-full body and mild carb.

On tap at the Ye Olde Falconers pub in Fort Lauderdale.  Poured a dark black color with a foamy tan head.  The aroma was chocolate and coffee.  The flavor was chocolate, coffee and roasted malt.  The chocolate flavor lingers for some time.  The body was a little thin, but otherwise this was a very good beer.
Dark black in colour with thick toffee coloured head. Chocolate coffee flavours and settles in mouth for ages.

Pours a nice dark brown with a tan head that begins two fingers wide and then settles nicely into a thin layer that remains nearly till the end.  Small amount of lacing.  Aroma has dark chocolate and roasted malts.  Flavor also has coffee very upront with chocolate and smokey notes on the finish.  Soft carbonation with a nice milkey mouthfeel.  A very solid porter.  Would buy again.
On tap at British Beer Company. Very drinkable porter. Tastes of coffee, chocolate with subtle smokiness.  Excellent.

Pours a deep dark brown with a thin tan head... Huge aroma of roasted malts, coffee, and chocolate... Nice flavor of roasted malts and coffee, though the flavor doesnt hold up to the aroma... Medium thin mouthfeel, finishes a bit dry... would like it to be a bit thicker... Very excellent....

Bottle bb 20/10/09
Poured browny,red and black.
Aroma chocolate,caramalt,sl raisin with a hint of floral fuggles hop.
Flavour is full bodied smokey caramalt,chocolate with mid bitterness finish.
Overall a very good porter.

bottle. dark with ruby highlights, small, foamy head. wonderful aroma of dark chocolate and roast and coffee. the taste easily matches the aroma, smooth chocolate with a slight coffee finish. just the right touch of carbonation. excellent!

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2009 bottle - Pours dark mahagony color with small head.
Aroma - musty chocolate coffee scent, also roasted nuttiness. Very soothing pleasent aroma.
Flavor - This is one fine Porter with this smooth roasted chocolate coffee taste. 
Palate - soft, smooth and light on tongue with great roasted nutty finish.
Overall - Fantastic Porter. This is not my favorite style beer but I enjoyed this beer immensely. Easy to drink for any beer lover.
Fullers London Porter is one of the best Porters out there. Can taste the Chocolate malt and the Fuggles hops. Complex, smooth, wonderful.

0.33L bottle, small thich head, clear dark mahagony brown with some burgundy taints. Aroma of dark brown bread, scenty light roasted coffee, whiff of nutmeg. Taste of dark sweetish bread with a touch of sourness, date and dried fig and some  light coffee.  Overall a little tool dry with a long sour aftertaste highlighting the dried fruits, body is medium. An extrermely good porter of the shy, understated kind.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2009 330ml Bottle:  Lightly sweet aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, and a hint of caramel.  Poured dark ruby/brown in color with a small, creamy, tan head that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Very sparkling.  Very good lacing.  Flavor is light to medium sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of roasted malts, chocolate, light coffee, toffee, cocoa, light tar, caramel, and some cream.  Medium body.  Smooth, creamy texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  Chocolate, roasted malt, caramel and cream finish is sticky and a bit dry.  7/4/7/4/14=3.6

Nitro:  Aroma of slight chocolate.  Poured dark brown/cola in color with a large, dense, beige head.  Very nice looking head.  Slightly sparkling.  Clear.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet.  Tastes of chocolate, cream, slight roasted malt, and a hint of wood.  Medium body.  Thin, creamy texture.  Nitrogen carbonation.  Chocolate and roasted malt finish.  4/4/7/3/13=3.1

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2009 A great porter, sort of like someone who brings your bags up quickly and doesnt harass you about leaving a lousy tip. Dark brown color with substantial tan head.  Strong aroma, coffee and chocolate - chocolate malt is especially noticeable. Smooth and very well-rounded flavor: roasted malt, coffee, smoke and some milk chocolate.  Not too heavy, really drinkable.

Acheté à la saq et dégusté dans un verre newcastle. De couleur noir au reflet caramel cuivré avec une mousse légère. Arômes de noisette, chocolat au lait, de COFFEE CRISP et une touche de vanille et de caramel légèrement fûmé. Un goût délicieux de chocolat au lait crémeux et de noisettes grillées et fûmées au café. Wow! quelle combinaison magique. Une bière avec du style et du savoir faire de longue date.

~Pours black with reddish tint and small creamy off white head.
~Woodsy chocolate scent with roasted malts.
~Burnt roasted malt taste, some coffee and chocolate, good strong flavor.
~Medium feel, bitter finish.
~This is a very good strong porter.
Dark brown color with a nice head.  Malty aromas that are very inviting.  Taste is a malt balance that has chocolate and roasted characters in it.  Overall a very good beer.
Really, really, solid porter. Dark pour. Big, chocolatey nose. Nice, roasty, chcocolatey flavor. Really nice to drink, especially after a long day of law school.
Fullers is a great Porter, it is full of flavor and armoa. It is dark with a slight head.  Very easy to drink as good as any English Beer I have had.

Pours Dark brown with amber highlights, and a 3 finger creamy tan head that lasts and leaves lacing. Aroma is lots of roast, chocolate, a suprising amount of smoke, hearty medium roast coffee, hazelnuts, a little toast and plenty of burnt sugar. Flavor is super smooth, creamy hot cocoa, roasted nuts and lightly roasted malt at first. Then comes the stronger flavors: dark chocolate, roasted nuts, smoked almonds, brown sugar covered squash, a hint of espresso, lots of beautiful roast and a hint of smokey char. Finish is roast, planty hops, a bit of char, bitter hops and a toffee like fade. The flavor profile suggests a beer with a fairly thick body and a higher abv than 5.4%. The fact that Fullers can get this kind of flavor out of a beer that is light enough to be a great session is simply amazing.

33cl bottle, best before 01mar06.  Dark black with hints of brown.  Creamy, off-white  head.  Huge cocoa, peat, roast, burnt chocolate, and more cocoa in the nose.    Deep roast,  big mocha, like coffee ice cream.  Like eating the perect coffee bean.  The perfect bean covered in  high percentage cacoa chocolate.  Lighter bodied than the flavor profile, alowing this an eay drinking beer.  Every Porter follows this beer.

Pours a dark chocolate color with almost no head.

Strong porter like aroma.  Very malty.

Deep, smoky, bitter beer.  A bit weak on overall flavor.  Complex but too tame.  The reputation is not well delivered with the flavor.

from the bottle. Pours thick and dark with thick head. Comlex aroma, roasted malt and chocolate. Flavor is very nice, a little bitter, chocolate, and raisins in the after taste. I like this porter, its well balanced and very drinkable.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2011 Re-rate 7/24/11: Bottle sample at a Fullers tasting at Porter & Sons. Roasty, coffee, milk chocolate. 7/4/7/3/14=3.5

(11/2/08) Bottle at Hamiltons in San Diego. Dark brown to black color. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and cocoa notes. Sweet roasty flavor with some chocolate, coffee hints, some dark fruits notes and a bit of caramel. Full-bodied. Good stuff. 7/4/7/4/14=3.6

Pours a dark brown with a creamy disappearing head.  Pleasant aroma heavy with malt and some coffee notes.  Smooth as can be with a flavor dominated by roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, and coffee.  A really top-notch porter.  Deserving of its hype.

bottle poured a cola brown color with a thin light tan head. aroma has chocolate malt, light roast, underlying sweetness, and mild coffee. mouth feel is medium and coats well. flavor hits with chocolate and brown malt, slightly roasted, bitter coffee  hit, and some light nuttiness. super smooth and easy drinking with a nice coffee and chocolate play. i could see this being real special on draft.

Dark brown color, fluffy creamy, brown colored head. Intensive aroma of chocolate, light sweetnes, light notes of burnt malt, caramel and  a hint of coffee. Flavor is medium bodied with some acid, velvety texture with chocolate, some coffe and burnt malt. Dry, roasted malt bitter finish with some dark chocolate flavor. Long finish.

16oz can poured into an English pint glass.  FLP pours dark brown with a medium-sized persistent head that is creamy and nitro-like.  The aroma is heavy in rich chocolate, very mild coffee and light hops.  The body is moderately thick and extremely smooth.  The creamy head adds a wonderful quality that is very difficult to beat.  The taste follows the aroma closely and includes chocolate and cappuccino.  This is probably the best porter I have had.
Pours a deep dark brown color with a reddish tan head.  Inviting aroma of chocolate, malts, and coffee.  Easy on the palate with chocolate, coffee, and malts pleasing the tongue.  Just phenomenal!

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2009 Bottle shared by robert at SL. Dark brown in color with a red-ish hue that lets light through. Decent head. Nice aroma of coffee, chocolate...Taste is rich, sweet with some dark chocolate. Thin in texture, almost watery. Which isnt really fair since I (we) drank and Bells expy stout next to it.... Overall a solid beer, that I will have to give its own chance.******Re-rate... Nice aroma rising out of the snifter... Chocolate and coffee on the nose. The texture looks a little thin but doesnt taste that way. For a "Light" beer it does have a ton of flavor.. Lotsa chocolate and coffee.  Doesnt taste that light it texture this time. Overall a solid beer, and good example of what a porter should taste like

Canned(500ml). -Almost black coloured, medium to big creamy pale brown head, coffee cocoa nose. Roasted malt, roasted coffee chocolate and notes of smoke. Bitter finish and aftertaste. Easy drinkable and well balanced porter.

Bottle from Total Wine in Roseville, CA.  I poured this brew at the sub 50s, so I figured that the palate would be artificially improved.  As it warmed, it stayed remarkably smooth.  The flavors were of chocolate and slight cigar smoke.  This beer was excellent, one of my new favorites.

Picked this up at the Party Source in Bellevue KY . Not as good as I expected it to be for a 99 rating. Not as smooth as a Founders or Olfabrikken. This is good dont get me wrong but it just wasnt as smooth the other 2 top porters.A little more bitter and not near as creamy. Chocolate is present but more along the lines of coffee.Slight nuttiness and slight roastiness a little more bitter than what I like. This is a good brew but there are a couple others  that clearly are better choices.

Bottle from Waitrose. Near black colour. Chocolatey, vaguely nutty aroma. Fairly sweet, milk chocolatey flavour. Only a hint of roast. Moderate body, hint of earthiness. Finishes with some chewy, molassesy accents in the chocolate. Good but when on form, the cask version is better.

Pours a dark chestnut brown, with a good off-white head.  Aromas of chocolate, coffee and malt.  Taste a bitter coffee with chocolate highlights and hints of roasted malts and nuts.  Finishes dry with good bitterness.  Very pleasent overall.

Chocolat, avec un peu de bruler. Tres bonne.

Chocolaty with some burnt notes. Very good.

Bottle at the Winking Lizard Crosswoods location.  Pours dark brown with some white head.  Rich roasty flavor.  Very malty and bock-ish, but has some coffee aroma as well.  Flavor is coffee and chocolate with a dry hop finish.  Just what a porter should be.

(Draught at Hilpeä Hauki, Helsinki, on 2008-12-13) Almost black. Clear. Dense and long lasting a little bit tan coloured head. Roastedness and coffee in nose. Full bodied and dryish palate with medium carbonation. Coffee, roastedness, bitterness, liquorice and coffee with milk in taste. Fine porter.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2009 Aroma is filled with coffee and chocolate. The color is dark brown, with a small head that disipates quickly, the body is moerate and is well balanced between the coffee and chocolate malts, very smooth with a slight aftertaste of coffee. Not overpowering at all.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2009 50cl Bottle. Deep dark brown to black colour, light beige head. Aroma of chocolate, cocoa, liquorice, roasted malts. Flavour is malty, liquorice, roasted coffee bitterness, moccha, cocoa. Slightly sweet with a bitter finish. Medium to fullbodied. Good stuff. 7 4 8 3 16. Re-rate: On tap at In de Wildeman. A bit more roasted flavours come through. Very well balanced, really nice flavours and texture. Outstanding porter. 8 4 8 4 16
Taste is very caramely and chocoatey. Has a very candy-like aroma. Sweet, sugary and smooth like candy.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2010 500 ml bottle. Finland. (Re-rating: 500 ml can).
Dark reddish brown almost black colour with big creamy soapy tan head. 
Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and hints of bitter hops. Coffee, chocolate, roasted malt in flavour. It is very pleasant even if I do not like coffee. Smooth and creamy but also slightly watery. After all an excellent porter.

Can. Pours a nice dark brown with a creamy lasting forever head. The aroma is a nice mix of English Malts, chocolate, and nutty. Chocolate, English malts, sweetness, and roasted nuts. Some lingering medium sweet chocolate. Creamy and smooth. Incredibly drinkable. I could drink this all the time, everyday, with every meal. Like water.

500mL Bottle as i the picture. Dark almost black Porter. Malty aroma, definately chocolate detected. Very smooth and creamy in the mouth, initial taste of mixed malts, with the chocolate the lingering and dominate one. Sweet finish. Not nearly complex enough to be one of the better Porters.
Bottle...poured into pint glass, dark brown with thin off-white head.  Choclatey and nut type flavors.  A little sweetness, medium bodied.  Enjoyable

Can. Malt, chocolate and raisins in aroma. Very dark clear brown colour with small light brown head. Plenty of roasted malt in flavour mixed with some bitter dark chocolate. Slightæy fruity aftertaste. Low carbonation.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2009 THE perfect porter! Stout notes include sesame, chocolate and caramel. Ale notes include grassy hops and that sour bite. Pours a blackish brown with a tan head. Flavor is always pleasant. Like I said, the perfect porter.

Couleur noir  pas trop epaisse    Gout de cafe qui reste sur la langue   un peu de choco et a peine melasse    Difficile de ne pas aimer    Merite d etre consommer  encore et encore   par tout le monde

[Tap] Pours a dark brown color with a perfect amount of tan head. Aroma of dark malts and dry powdered cocoa. Taste includes some molasses and milk chocolate. Roasted nut and very light coffee/smoke finish. Creamy mouthfeel and great palate. Quite a good beer!

Good Porter, Beautiful dark color, nice carbonation.

Nice coffee/ toasted malt flavor.

One of the better porters that I have had.

11.2 ounce bottle from Whole Foods Charlottesville. Pours a deep chestnut brown color with a medium frothy head. Good head retention and lacing. Rich chocolate aroma with some roasted malts. Taste is roasted malts, chocolate with a bit of a smoky finish. Full bodied. very nice.

Pours a nice deep brown colour like a stout, but much more translucent with ruby highlights, and a thick foamy tan head.  Smell is a little bit of milk chocolate, some roasty malts, but not overpowering, and just a hint of hops.  Flavour is more of the same.  Not as much chocolate, and a lot more hops, both bitterness and flavour, but still with a nice roasty malt backing.  The mouthfeel is very creamy, and carbonated spot on, not flat, but not sharp enough to actively notice it.  Nice beer.

Draft at Pub Italia in Ottawa. Beautiful deep brownish-black appearance, topped by a nice beige head. Aroma and flavour match, an exquisite example of malts and a nutty accent with hints of chocolate and coffee. Excellent.

On tap. Pours umber with a finger of lacey mocha head. Aroma is chocolate, caramel, roast coffee, and mellifluous malt. Toasty chocolate malt, caramel, toffee, subtle dark fruits, roast coffee, and a soft hop presence. Palate was creamy and smooth. Even better as it warmed up.
This is a dark brown beer with its appealing bubbly head. It was smooth on the palate with a rich, warming flavour of chocolate and toasty malts. More sweet than bitter, it had a slight smokiness.
Near black with a tan head. Nice chocolaty sweet, roasted malt aroma. Smooth medium body. Robust blackened malt flavor with rich milk chocolate. Drys out some for the finish. Classic Porter.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 29, 2010 500ml Bottle - Very dark brown, almost black with a tan head. Chocolatey aroma with some nice roasted malt notes. Fairly rich taste with chocolate, roasted malt and a creamy element with a bitter chocolatey and roasted finish. The aftertaste lingers and is very pleasant.  A great porter.
very malty, one of the better porter’s out there if your looking for an upfront highly malty porter this is for you.
Belting porter. chocolate aroma and a bit of bread crust. Nice mouthfilling roast grain with a hint of sweetness. Delicious.

Can from the LCBO
A more detailed description will follow on a second tasting
I have misplaced my comments for this beer

dark pour on taphere in Boca Raton. Nice firm off-white head nice lacing on the glass. Aroma was Amazing sweet toffee and a hint of coffee.  Flavor is typical porter with a sweet side to it. Palate is just perfect for this style. This was a great find. 
Cheers!

Tap @ OTH , nitro.
Pours a  ruby black, with thick beige head.
Aroma is roasted with some nice coffee undertone.
Taste, malty, roasted very smooth.
Light coffee and chocolate malts just all over, coupled with a nice light hoppy finish.
One amazing porter.
Poured from can. Poured nice with thick head. Nice dark color. Lots of flavor. Rich taste with a bit of sweetness. Very impressed.

Poured from 11.2oz bottle into pint mug. Dark brown, nearly black with reddish tinges when held up to light. 1 finger creamy, lacy head which diminishes rather quickly, but leaves nice lacing inside the mug. Aromas of milk, chocolate, dark dried fruit, and coffee. Tastes of dark and chocolate malts with notes of coffee. Full mouthfeel, light on the carbonation. Very well balanced. Finishes very nicely. Excellent depth of flavor. Very drinkable. This is what I’ve always perceived a true English porter to be. Cheers!

50 cl Bottle. Dark brown with a quickly disappearing offwhite head. Smell: Malt, Roasted, raisin, plum. Taste: Sweet, roasted, some bitterness, coffee, cocoa. medium carbonation. Very complex. Well balanced. Nice brew.

Pours a deep brown almost black with a quickly dissipating off white head. Aroma is mostly roasted malt and a lot of nut and chocolate. There are also some distinct raisin and plum notes. Flavor starts very sweet mostly caramel and toffee. Rich and creamy cocoa and coffee bean in the middle turns to a burnt malt and bitter black coffee-like finish. Medium to full body and high carbonation. Nice rich porter that has a good balance and complexity. Finishes a little too bitter but otherwise a great beer.

Delicious aroma of coffee and light hints of chocolate. Aroma comes up to greet you and lingers long in the nose. Dark brown with a very light tan (almost white) head. Flavors of dark malts chocolate, coffee and maybe a hint of dark fruit. Mild dark grain dry finish. Maybe a tiny hint of bitterness.
Deep, dark chocolate and roast flavors. Very thick body. Gets better as it warms.
UPDATED: OCT 22, 2008 Near black with red undertones. Roasty, bready, chocolatey aroma. Dry, malty flavor - rich and characteristically English. One of the best porters around.
Bottle.  Pours a brown body with a tan head.  Chocolate, malty fudge, pudding, a bit of a mineral sediment.  Light etoh and a small hop character.  A solid beer sometimes you get an off bottle tho.
Excellent porter. My only complaint is it is  perhaps a bit heavy with the chocolate notes, however as the beer warms beyond a typical temperature it gains better balance.
Bottle.  Given to me by Adamskillin back in July.  A very delicous porter.  Very nice.  Only 1 bottle left, how unfortunate.

An almost black colored beer, with a thick beige foamed head. The aroma caramel, cherries, roasted malts. The taste has little chocolate notes, roasted malts, fruity like cherries and peaches. Smokey bitter and dry. The aftertaste has some bitter and stays for a while.
amberish black (clear) with a good beige head leaving lace.very rich and strong with coffee dark chocolate liquorice hops and lots of roasted malts.

Bottle from Charles Street Liquors in Boston.  Glugs out of bottle a chocolate color, and sits with a one-finger head that dissipates to mere lacing within a minute.  Aroma is semisweet chocolate, charcoal/smoke, coffee, biscuit and some licorice.  Flavor hits your mouth with a crispness of dark flavors that is very attractive.  Palate is dry, with light carbonation.  Primary flavors are roasts, smoke and chocolate, but there is definitely a sweeter component that underpins the flavor profile of London Porter.  Dark, but just quaffable (palate and flavor) enough to keep this from being a one-and-done type of brew.  Highly recommended.

12oz.  Pours black black black with amber highlights and a light brown head.  Wow, talk about smokey!  This beer has smoked action happening in the nose and throughout the body like crazy!  They could easily claim this to be a smoked porter.  There is some chocolate and roasted malt but all I can think about is how smokey it is.  Has a bit of a sawdust aftertaste that I’m not to keen on and is lacking the complexity to be scored like an excellent beer would.  That said it is a very, very, very tasty porter.

Pours a very dark red, almost black. Medium tan head with large bubbles. Aroma is of roasted nuts a dark chocolate. Flavor is of dark chocolate and caramel. Flavor grows on you as you go. Fairly bitter finish. Good mouthfeel. Good, not great.

What an excellent beer. Surpassed as a porter only by the cask version. So raisiny, with a full alcoholic warmth. Can’t believe it’s "only" 5.4. I’d never much cared for porters until this beer, and it’s taken me this long to rate it.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2013 Lovely, smooth moreish beer. Lots of comments about it tasting more alcoholic than it is and I concur. Lots of dark berries and chocolate for such a light ABV beer...go on and enjoy a few

Pours deep ruby. Tall, fluffy lingering tan head leaves intricate lacing.  Aroma of chocolate malt, very malty and somewhat spicy.  Flavor is intricate blend of chocolate, caramel and dark malts, some residual sweetness.  Palate full body, creamy mouthfeel, fair bitterness with average carbonation.  Is this Heaven?
Bottle. Poured dark brown with a medium lasting white head. Roasty aroma with some coffee. More chocolate in flavour but mostly roasted malts.  Medium bodied.
Dark pour with slowly forming, long lasting head. Smooth taste of toasted mocha that builds in the mouth, definitely recommended

A wonderful beer. Had in a 500 Ml bottle. ARoma of roasted nuts, chocalte, malts. Smooth taste and flavourful nuttyness. Dark brown with hint of red or purple throughout. A medium finger tan head. Mouthfeel is complex yet makes the beer iresistable and extermely drinkable. I would suggest that every one trys this even if they don’t like porter
12oz bottle at The Pressroom, Lancaster, PA...dark dark brown pour, tan head...roasty aroma with chocolate, coffee, malts...flavor is much of the same...smooth mouthfeel...good full bodied Porter.

bottle 500ml 3,56 from Alko  EXP 13/03/09 color very reddish dark brown fluffy beige head scent:dry roasted malts chocolate Taste:roasted malts chocolate, coffee,dash of burnt sugar, tickling hops. Pleasant bit burn malts aftertaste.  Sweet More please

(Can).  Roasty chocolate/coffee aroma.  Deep dark brown with thin creamy tan head.  Malty chocolatey taste, also coffee with a slight hint of tangy fruit.  Very nice, although I’d prefer a bit more bite and a longer finish.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2008 Pours deep, dark brown with light beige head.  Roasty malt, coffee aromas, kind of creamy in the nose.  Flavors: coffee, molasses, burnt sugar, chocolate.  Also, oddly enough, beef jerky comes to mind.  Smooth, creamy palate, clean finish, really nice roasted aftertaste.  Complex and balanced, almost hard to believe the ABV is so low.

Nice biege head,big frothy,on a very dark red/brown porter with good carbonation.Aroma,malty,coffee,chocolate,a rich note.Flavour fuggles hops,mild bitter good,chocolate richness,coffee taste,maltiness,then the porter seems to take another angle of bitterness,like some other porters.Starts out well,now it,s very bitter,not good a pity.Finish bitter overdone.
On-tap at Stone. Pours dark brown  with a fizzy, offwhite head. Smells slight smokey and dark roasty malty. Tastes the same with some apple flavor in there as well. Medium body, vibrant carbonation.

Poors dark amber in colour, with a decent head. Nice moderately smokey aroma with herbal and floral notes.The taste is smoothe and almost creamy. There is a lot to taste here, but nothing sticks out harshly. As Porters go, the flavour is reasonably mild, but still rich and complex. Various spices and roasted malts are complimented by honey, chocolate and some very modest fruit flavours. The after-taste is pleasant and lasting. This would be a great beer to have along-side a large meal.

I just had the Samuel Smith imperial stout earlier tonight, and I definitely think this is not as good. It’s a very good porter, with classic taste, as well as color and aroma, but it lacks the character thats so well preserved with the Sammy. I would probably drink this again, but I wouldnt buy it. Cheers!
50 cl bottle, bought in Newhaven, shared with Bjørnar and Roger. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt. Flavor is sweet, dark fruit and roasted malt. Dry finish. Nice, but not world class porter.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2008 11.2 bottle. Very pleasant aroma, lots of roasted mocha and  coffee beans, not much hop presence though.  Decent pour with about a inch of cream colored pillowy head, mostly goes away, very small lacing, 50/50 opaque, dark rust color.  Similar flavor profile to the aroma, with slightly larger presence of floral type hops starting in the middle and finishing nicely in the end with an easy rich malt lingering, smooth and maybe just o so slightly too light, but still a great feel.  Might just barely be too weighted toward the malt side, but overall this a beer made of very high quality and its hard to complain.

Bottle. Very dark colour with a medium sized tan head. Roasted malt aroma with hints of chocolate. Taste is roasted, chocolate and coffee with some smoke. Medium-bodied and smooth mouthfeel. Sweet and chocolaty aftertaste. Delicious, well-balanced brew.

16 oz. can:  Pour is clear dark with a creamy tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, sweet brown sugar, and a little cream.  Has a very creamy mouth feel.  Low carbonation.  Flavors include a full roasted barley, lightly sweet chocolate malt, light cream.  Damn fine brew.  Full flavored and smooth.  Would buy again.
scura buona schiuma mediamente persistente note tostate cioccolto leggero dicetile in bocca cioccolato in prevalenza ma altri sentori tostati e yn finale piacevolmente luppololato abbastanza secca

On tap. Poured black with ruby edges, off white head, fully diminishing. Aromas of chocolate, burnt malt, cinnamon. Flavour is initially sweet, and some hops come through. Finishes quite bitter. Sweeter for a porter but nicely hopped and well blended flavours.

Nice Creamy Porter.  Very Dark Pour.  Medium Head.  Roasty malts.  Dark Coffee with heavy cream taste.  Very drinkable porter.  I think this would go very well with food that is sweet.  Would be a good base in a long cook dish or a braise.
Deep dark red body, almost black, with an almost lasting off-white head. Flat coffee taste that is quite drinkable, smokey notes and thin cocoa. What I expect from a porter and it delivered.
Bottle. Very distinctive aroma.  Head is almost noexistent.  Starts with a strong hint of coffee.  Definitely get the roasty malts at the finish.  Would like to try from the tap.

500 ml can, in Toronto. Thick and rich, aroma and flavor of smokey wood, roasted malts, a bit of coffee, chocolate, and a touch of dark fruit. Very nice, without any major faults, but not as complex as some. I had it from the cask last year, and it was better for sure, but I didn’t take notes.
Bottle and draught. Full roasted flavor comes through in the nose.  The body is nice, full, and creamy.  Well crafted and balanced brew.
Black colored brew, like oil. Roasted, malty aroma, coffee and chocolate. Flavor is roasted too, coffee, dark chocolate. Good bitterness. Very well balanced brew, creamy and pleasant.
Stellar ale.  Great balance. Coffee, bitter dark chocolate and a nice mid-palate with a bitter dry finish.  Had it with oysters mmmmmm!

12 ounce bottle, there is a definite creamy almost thin mouth feel but it’s rich tasting and chocolaty. Some great malt richness, I am eating it with a piece of sweet potato pecan pie and it’s absolutely delicious with that
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Bottle: Poured a dark black with a reddish tint, head is medium and tan. The aroma is light roasted malt. Taste is roasted malt with chocolate hints. Finish is dry and coffee bean.
