Aroma is smoky, bready malts, light chocolate. Flavor has a lot of the same traits. Its also has a light silk palate that i find works well with its body. Now im wondering why i kept putting this beer off. Good stuff.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2008 recommended by the "beer guy" at the evansdale co-op liquor store, Calgary.  Thanks for this one... 
in english pint glass it poured a very dark brown with a light brown head. This beer could have a viscosity rating of 5w30. It clings to the side of the glass. Nice lacing. Got earthy notes in the nose; nuts and caramel.  perfect balance between smooth, sweet, creamy and bitter. Highly recommend this beer.

Bottle. Pours clear dark brown with a dense and lacy tan head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel and roasted nuts. Body and carbonation are both on the light side. Lightly sweet taste of chocolate, oatmeal, figs and just a little roasted malt. Smoky, earthy chocolate finish with light bittering.
Bottle. Poured a dark brown almost black with a creamy tan head. Smelled of roasted caramel and coffee. Tasted pretty much the same. Nice mouthfeel. Smooth drinkable beer, not to thick.

This is real good.  REAL good.  Tastes like a small beer of Victory at Sea - very nice thick coffee, well roasted, sanded down with a very subtle chocolate.  Subtle wood texture gives it a fireside feel.  Cheers indeed.

Great taste, full of favor and beautiful color. Great bottle and great logo with a matching taste. I like all of Fuller’s beers though but I had to talk about this one and recommend this beer to anyone. If you want to find cheap prices on Fuller’s beers go to Bevmo.com as they will price match and even beat any price. Fuller’s can be expensive but if you can find if for a deal, buy it.

Bottle from Auchan, rather interesting that I can’t find this one easily in the UK, but is easy to get in Luxembourg! Dark brown, almost black, thin beige head. Nose is burnt malts, toasted, dark fruit, espresso, some dark chocolate. Mouth is dark chocolate, gently roasted malts some coffee. Slightly smoked. Very good, something I’d drink again, but nothing that makes me think ’wow’.

dark dark brown pour, slight head, tanish.  dark fruits are abundant in the nose, along with small amounts of mocha.  Its so fucking creamy.  holy crap. incredible mouthfeel.  Taste is a mirror of the aroma, mocha and dark fruits swirl around my tongue in a storm of creamy goodness. Second best can of beer ive ever had behind ten fidy.  I love it.

Incredible. Best beer I have had so far, beat out my old fav Guinness. Pours a beautiful black with a thick creamy head, wonderful aroma and taste. Reminds me a lot like coffee. Not too expensive and a must try.

12 oz bottle. Pours absolutely black, almost no head whatsoever. Spotty lacing, but I’m drinking from a Trappist glass. Aroma and flavor dominated by chocolate and coffee. Very toasty. One of the best porter’s I’ve had (cheaper and better tasting than Sam Smith’s!) Definitely the best Fullers brew I’ve had.

Appearance of an imperial stout without the thickness. Aroma was roasted nuts, and cocoa. Flavor was excellent, with a strong blend of mocha and tart chocolate. The only thing this beer was missing was a thicker, chewier texture.
Bottle from 2006.  Definite oxidation on the aroma and flavor.  I need to get a fresh bottle for a re-rate.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2009 Looks like Black Gold. Rich and complex. Here is a suggestion, try it in a cognac snifter, sounds strange, but I did this once and it actually brought out some subtle flavors..like cinnamon and hazlenut, and accented the chocolate tones. I love this stuff, definitely in my top five
Poured from a tap a dark brown.  Wow this stuff is fantastic. Tastes a lot like a mocha blend coffee.  This is the best porter that I have tried.
UPDATED: JAN 20, 2009 old tasting so short notes. dark brown pour, tan head. malty caramel nose with smooth malt flavor. good palate balance.

Had a while back. Pours dark ruby brown with tan head. Aroma is malt,  molassas, caramel and some toffee. Flavor is smooth and creamy with hints of burnt malts and some caramel and toffee. Nice porter and an all time classic.

Not as bitter as many stouts are. I was surprised by the complete lack of head. Appearance: Very dark brown. Nice amount of tan head. Aroma: Coffee, smoke and dark malt. Hint of chocolate. Taste: smoke and coffee.

Pours a very dark brown with some ruby highlights if held up to the light. Little head, and the aroma is mostly chocolate and coffee, more so chocolate. Taste is leaning more towards the coffee though. Very similar to a coffee or oatmeal stout in my opinion, but its very enjoyable and does not disappoint.
Pours a very very dark brown color with a thin tan head. Aroma is of roasted malts, coffee,and some smoke. Flavor is very roasted and coffee but not too bitter, very good porter.

Appearance: Very dark brown. Nice amount of tan head.
Aroma: Coffee, smoke and dark malt. Hint of chocolate.
Taste: Again, smoke and coffee. Malty.
Info: 500ml bottle, 15/4-2008

I love porters and I love this beer.  It is robust, perfect amount of bitterness to balance the sweet maltiness, huge flavor at small alcohol.  A little expensive (I paid almost $12 for a 6-pack the other day!)

Thanks to ghawener.  Drank it during the Eurocup Final 2008.  Wow, I had it in my beer watchlist.  Pours a nice dark brown, almost black color with a tan head.  Medium bodied, perfectly balanced with the caramel malts and the smokiness.
bottle, color is dark brown with crema head,  very pronounced coffer nose, very good  espresso and cream flavors with some chocolate, finishes smooth
Bottle: Another great one from the goods folks over at Fullers. Rich, complex and perfectly balanced. This has the highlight from the Euro 2008 final...Germany lost Fuller won again!

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2016 Gosh, its taken me long enough to find this  Bottle, my rating 1699.  Chocolate and dominant roasted malt nose with just a hint of smoke.  Darker-than-Coke pour with a creamy, rocky tan head.  Silken, velvety texture on an otherwise watery body.  Dry and ashen taste, roast malt and a little cocoa underneath.  Rich, deep, warm, rounded dark chocolate tones.  Touch of nuttiness.  Burned, charcoal, with an enduring light bitterness.  Can actually taste their ESB underneath the roast.  Aftertaste is long and very dry.  Man oh man, could drink pint after pint of this, one of the better sessions Ive encountered, and after around 50 ratings, my favorite English beer.  Absolutely superb. [2008.06.28: 4.3] Bottle.  Rich chocolate, smooth and creamy, just from the nose!  Huge creamy tan head, mouthfeel silky-smooth, not at all acrid or tart, rather milky and downy-soft.  Light bitterness and gentlest hop prickle, clean, fresh, high-quality ingredients.  Chocolate, lighter fruit, dry, tremendously repeatable; I contemplate porters/stouts along a spectrum, from the "brutal" roasty side to the more elegant/smoother examples marked by chocolate, and this one dominates the latter side.  [2016.20.06: 4.0]

Really enjoyed this one!!!  Dark bitter chocolate, roasted malt & coffee in the nose.  Appearance is old leather with a thick eggshell head.  Flavor is oak, roasted coffee and the chocolate is extremely rich.  Somewhat thin compared to others, this is still a classic.

Yes indeed. This is a sexy beer. Black/Brown with a beige head. The aroma is just a mild tease compared to the fullness of the flavor.Which is nice and smooth with an abundant roasted malt taste. Hints of chocolate and coffee aswell. Reall good, not nearly as sweet as some porters ive had.

Un excellent porter qui combine (ce qui est plutôt rare pour une bière noire) les goûts de chocolat et de café et ce en 2 étapes bien distinctes en bouche et laisse, en finale un léger goût maltée. Elle possède un léger col et elle est plutôt crémeuse pour un Porter. On en redemande, croyez-moi!

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2008 Bottle @ Bishops Arms, Karlstad. This is what Ive been imagining a good porter to taste like - quite sweet with hints of chocolate, coffe, roasted malt and some sea salt (which I tend to find in many stout/porters). Well, its really good however. Fullers is a very good brewery, I must say.

500mL can purchased from LCBO in Toronto.  Pours a dark brown with a bit of white head.  Light malty aroma.  First taste is nice, with a solid roasted malt and chocolate flavours.  Nice roasty aftertaste.  The canned version recently fared poorly at a blind porter and stout tasting at Cest What - but its competition was against mainly draught offerings.
Dry, almost ashy porter. Well-textured palate. Very old-school by-the-book example, with a decidedly british character.
Nearly black, with a moderate tan head. Enough body and complexity to keep me interested. Not bad, considering Im an Imperial Stout fan.
A very nice porter. Tastes of bitter chocolate, coffee and ash. Finish is slightly bitter with a smoke aftertaste.

Can from the local LCBO. Comes out a dark brown/black, similar colour to Guinness, has a small white head. Smells of coffee and malt.
Has a very strong bite on the first sip, strong malty/coffee taste, and lingers on your tongue for a while. Creamy texture mixed with a nice alcohol bite make this a good beer, Ill definitely have it again.

On tap at The Olde Ship, Santa  Ana Ca. Pours dark black with a full smooth and creamy white head. Mellow aroma of chocolate and coffee. Flavor of malts, chocolate and coffee. Very nice white lacing down the glass. Flavor is mild and watery, not as intense as its american cousin.

The original is usually the best and in this case it just might be. It never disappoints. It has all the hallmarks of a great beer: flavor, balance and drinkability. Im not a huge fan of fuggles but it surely works in this classic. Pour me another.
Nice smooth porter, typical of what I have had in the past.  I like it a lot because it is fairly inexpensive and high quality

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2008 Somehow I hadnt tried this yet, even though its only $2 at my local.  Poured a deep dark opaque brown with a nice fluffy head that quickly diminished.  Smell was big chocolate and a little smokey.  Taste was much the same, big flavor for a relatively thin beer.  Smooth and really drinkable.  Ends with a nice bitter chocolate note to round it out a bit.  Nice classic example.

pours black with a one finger tan head, the aroma is heavy roasted chocolate, coffee. The flavor is very chocolaty and very desert like and then finishes like a cup of coffee. This is an amazing porter, i dont think i return to the other ones ive had after this!

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2008 (Sample from July 28, 2006 Beer Club Meeting, bottle from Lion & the Rose on June 3, 2008) Rich, dark, smoky coffee/chocolate flavors.  A superb treat fot the tongue.  Aroma of roasted cocoa.  A thin-medium bodied, easily drinkable porter with a sweet, malty air to it.     It would have totally blown me away if it would have been a little less deserty and had a higher alcohol content, but still loved it.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2016 can. aroma unpleasant, notes of aged beer and burnt caramel, instead of "porter" aroma. Appearance is fantastic. dark but not fuzzy, beautiful head. taste is great , although notes of aged beer, but otherwise real good. Got even better as it warmed up. overall great taste but lousy aroma. Could be a bad sample ive got.  best before 25sep08. could be aged.[4,5,6,3,13]. bottle, fresh from shop. clear dark amber, smooth light brown head. aroma of caramel, sweet malts, slightly roasted malts.coffee and coffee grind. Quite flavorful, roasted malts, coffee, faint metallic, very rounded and velvety. however, the beer is no way near as good as the ratebeer rating indicates, ive had much, much better porters if you ask me. Good, but not near-perfect as the rb rating might suggest.

I dont know, I felt really let down by this beer, which is supposed to be a mecca of porters. Pours dark brown, two finger tan crown. Aroma is nothing special. Bitter dark chocolate, a little sweetness, and a bit of tang at work. Mouthfeel is way too thin for my taste. Finish is a bit caustic. Perhaps the beer caught my taste-buds in a bad mood, or maybe I drank it too cold. Either way, I was disappointed and would reach for Anchor or Smutty long before this.
500 ml bottle. Dark brown colour, thin light brown head. Coffee, dark chocolate and roasted malts in the aroma. Flavour is roasted malts and coffee, with a bitter and burnt, hoppy aftertaste.

Dark brown color, almost white head that fades quickly. Exquisite aroma of toffee and burnt caramel. Well balanced and round, this brew is not too sweet. the flavor turn arond toast, chocolate and malt. very good

Color is deep brown. Lacy, beige head. Aroma is nicely coffeey, hoppy and roasty malty. Flavor is smoky, roasty malty with coffee and slightly fruity hoppy. Quite full-bodied and smoothly carbonated palate.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2008 12 oz. bottle from John’s Grocery (Iowa City, IA). Poured a dark brown with some red notes in the light with a decent cocoa colored head that beings to dissipate to a thinner film. Aromas are amazing, consisting of chocolate and other roasted malts, coffee, and a bit of a lactose sweetness that I can smell very easily. Wonderful. Initial taste is of dark rich roasted malts with a chocolatey smoothness that follows. A bit of a bitter coffee finish that ends up smooth and memorable, with an aftertaste that is similiar to the whole taste progression of the entire brew. A medium to heavy bodied brew that feels ich, but still possibly sessionable for someone else that might love darker roasted malts more than I. Still, a top notch brew that I’m glad I tried and still near my tops, despite being a beer style I don’t venture to often. Cheers.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with aromas of coffee, chocolate and roasted malt.  A bit thin on body and aroma, though.  Flavor is thin, but nicely mixes the tastes associated with the aromas mentioned above.  Not bad, but I expected some sort of epiphany or something, so Im a little disappointed.  Seems to lack some of the ABV and plot complexity of my favorite porters.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: bottle. aroma of coffee and fresh malts.dark brown color/a bit of a red tint.small brown head.very creamy brew that tastes like malty coffee YUM! Palate is excellent goes down nice and easy. Not overpowering.Fullers makes some good brew and this might be my favorite from them.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2008 As dark as ruby can get.Thin off white  lacing head. Espresso, malt and mild fruit on the nose. Nice, mildly roasted and gently smoked flavor. Really smooth with lots of character. Very even. Very drinkable. The Cary Grant(sorry I chose an American) of porters.

Pours dark brown with ruby highlights and a tan head. Sweet roasty aroma with hints of coffee. Roasted malt flavor with slight bitterness, coffee and chocolate. Medium to full body with mild carbonation and a smooth creamy mouthfeel. An excellent porter, one of the best I have had.

VERY nice porter...pretty much lived up to expectations. Served from the bottle in a pint glass...almost black, with ruby hints and a small, cola-like head that disappeared pretty quickly. Very easy-drinking, with nose and taste of chocolate, caramel, and brown sugar. Solid sessioner.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 Dark brown color, and chocolate nose.  Roasted malt, caramel, coffee, little dark fruit, little nutty.  Smooth and sweet  with roasted character like dark chocolate with nuts in it.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2012 Bottle at home... Nice Deep red ... big foam head ... Deep roast malt nose ... Nice good roast base ... some chocolate ... quite dry and and bitter ...Decent enough ... but not as nice as the cask... It puzzles me that the bottle scores higher than the cask.



Bottle at home...May 2012 online tasting .. deep brown ... thin tan head ... soft coffee malt ...ovaltine malts ... rich dark fruit plums and mellow coffee nose ... light body ... soft mellow roast malts ...soft toffee ... again more coffee hints than expected ... rich soft and tasty ...
The Porter.  Great aroma of chocolate, caramel, coffee, bread, cake... Just huge.  Not for hop heads.  Light body and low ABV make this a session alternative to most impy stouts.

Tasted 24/05/2008.  Magic nose, reminding me of the dark Orkney beers - very dark chocolate with a little whiff of dark and vinous fruit. Toasty biscuity malt weighs in nicely behind - tending towards burnt.  Superbly integrated in the mouth.  Fruity, biscuity, high % cocoa chocolate... like a nice coffee, from the place at the bottom of The Terrace in Wellington... and then theres more a lingering slightly burnt toast in behind.  Hops barely make an appearance, theyre just supporting in behind with a little bitterness. Perfect weight and carbonation.  Drinks easily, like a beer a full percent lower.  Special.
Dark brown with nice lasting beige head. Very chocolate aroma. Nice medium to full body with lots of chocolate a little coffee. Best porter Ive had.
Pours a very dark body, almost black colour with a full dark brown head. very smooth in the mouth, and creamy. the aroma was very alcohol scented, and sort of tasted like whiskey in the finish.

tap, poured a dark brown color, with a creamy khaki head.  The aroma was awesome with some roasted malts, coffee and chocolate.  Had a great creamy balance on the palate and a perfect finish.  This is a great porter.

muy buena cerveza del reino unido que aproveche a tomar tantas y tantas veces cuando estuve estudiando en la gran isla.  el profesor de economia era tan fiel a la cerveza que habia invertido en las acciones simplemente para poder ir a las reuniones anuales de accionistas, que por supuesto, estaban llenas de cerveza para los asistentes.

A delicious porter, if not my favorite.  Wonderful balance of roasted chocolate, smooth creamy caramel.  Very complex and deep flavors, roastedness is not overpowering, but mingles with slight bitterness and rich smooth chocolate.  A wonderfully balanced and executed porter.

11.2oz bottle.  Pours a dark, cherry-brown color; creamy, khaki-colored head with fine-bubbled lacing; an attractive pour.  Lots of roasted malts, chocolate, and cocoa in the aroma; creamy coffee and soft roastiness.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: pleasant roasted coffee, milk chocolate, and roasted malts; very soft, enjoyable coffee character, if a bit too reliant on that roasted coffee note to fill things out; a touch of smokiness present as well; reasonable, tasty porter.  Medium finish: coffee, roasted malts, chocolate, and a touch of smoke; ends with some dough.
Best porter Ive ever had.  No overpowering chocolate taste/sweetness that you find in a lot of porters.
intence cofee and rye bread aroma. smooth flavor wth bitterish rye bread aftertaste. i think this porter is short of intensity, that is only my opinion of course!

Bottle. Deep brownish-black with reddish tint. Small off-white head. Roasted malts, chicory, cocoa predominate in mild nose. Creamy mouthfeel helps coat the tongue with the sublime chocolate malt flavors. Hops delightfully balanced by a subtle string of sweetness, lingering finish. Great stuff.

Perfect copper/dark amber color with a very thick and full khaki head. Awesome aroma of chocolate malts, a mild roastiness that gives the impression of a sweet coffee. Nice medium body, not too thick. Sweetness really comes through with the initial taste, the finish is what draws out the smooth roasted quality along with the unique porteresque hop flavor.

Pours dark red/brown with white, long-lasting head. Nose is initially more malt roast/coffee, but as beer warms, chocolate scents grow in dominance. Taste was similar, starting off with more roast bitterness, caramel and chocolate developing with warmth, and finally, an exclusively sweet chocolate dominance. I found the body lifeless, probably my least favorite aspect.
Pours brown-black with a small tan head. Nice aroma of chocolate malt and coffee. Flavor starts very sweet and moves to a bitter coffee finish. A bit of earthiness. Good but not exceptional.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2009 Bottle. Aroma is a bit smokey  and sweet with hints of chocolat and coffee. Really nice mouthfeel with flavours of chocolate,coffee and a bit fruity finish. Great english porter!

Bottle. A dark, ruby red beer with a thin light tan head. Combinations of coffee and a fruitiness together with smoked malts on the nose. The flavours develop these characteristics, a mild smokiness, dark chocolate and molasses. Quite a full and chewy palate texture. Full in body and a nice diversity.

Aroma: Smoky and sweet. The most interesting thing I noticed about the smell is that there is a distinctly Scotch ale side to it, with a peaty caramel odor. You can smell it most strongly right as you sip it, which adds a lot to the overall flavor.

Appearance: Looks like Newcastles evil twin, or maybe the bastard son of a Newcastle and a Guinness. Very dark, with brownish auburn tones, similar to Worcestershire sauce. Thin, ash-colored head reminds me of toasted marshmallows.

Flavor: Highly mocha-esque, with lots of caramel coming through. Thats not to say its like a Frappucino or something, because theres nothing sugary about this beer. Its bitter through and through, with notes of roasted nuts. It has a clean, sweet finish, and the aftertaste is all espresso, but unfortunately it doesnt last long.

Palate: Pretty light and creamy, which is rare in a beer with this much flavor.

Overall: Very easy to drink, but I think this might come at the expense of the taste, which deserves to be a little denser and richer than it is. Overall, though, my senses were satisfied without being overwhelmed. Very nice!

(Keg at White Horse, Parsons Green, London, 26 April 2008) Dark brown colour, almost black, with frothy pale brown head. Roasted, malty nose with notes of chocolate. Roasted, malty taste with chocolate, coffee and a nice coffee bitterness in the finish. A classic example of the style. Slightly less complex and fruity than the cask conditioned version, but in great balance. Very nice beer.

50 cL can. Pours dark brown with and orange glare an a creamy and light brown/tan head. Roasted malt, light chocolate note and mild earthy note in the aroma. Amost creay mouthfeel. Flavour is roasted malt, light chocolate and a very mild smoke note. Dry roasted malt finish with a light bitterness.

Bottle, $10.99/ 6pk I believe.  Beautiful dark brown color with cherry highlights.  Minimal off white head that faded pretty quickly.  Chocolate smell dominates, but trace of coffee in background.  Great mouthfeel, very easy to drink for such a complex beer.  Taste is very complex to me, hard to easily describe as a new rater.  Overall it is one of the easiest to drink of the great beers.  How very British.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2008 bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a tan head.  Smell was of roasted malts, espresso and even some smokiness.  Taste was of coffee and chocolate.  Mouthfeel was medium-to-thin and a little watery but similar to other porters in that regard.  This was a very flavorful porter, similar to an impy stout except for the mouthfeel.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with a light tan head and has excellent head retention. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, and a hint of caramel. Flavor was creamy and satisfying with coffee, slight chocolate, roasted sweetness and a touch of smokiness medium bodied with a dry and tasty finish

Great beer.

Poured a chocolate brown color with a small creamy tan head.

The smell was very enticing, coffee grounds and chocolate. My mouth was watering in anticipation.

My mouth was not disappointed. The chocolate and coffee blended beautifully on my tongue. Holy crap, its like my tongue just had an orgasm.

It had a nice full mouth feel, as Id expect from a porter, but the carbonation level seemed a bit high to me - jabbing at my tongue with sharp little bubbles.

Great beer. Wait, did I say that already? Well its true. Definately something Ill be drinking again and again.

Serving type: bottle

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is a mix of sweet and roasted malt with notes of caramel and milk chocolate. Medium, smooth body. Flavor is again, sweet and roasted, but also has a smoky quality. Notes of nuts, caramel, and semi-sweet chocolate. I like the subtleness in the flavor, it makes it very easy to drink. But at the same time it has just enough complexity to hold your attention and keep you searching for more.

Dark black pour with quickly falling tan head.  Pure coffee in the nose...maybe some chocolate.  Coffe on the tounge too, but not quite so much as the aroma suggested.  Fairly bitter, more like a stout.  Thick in the mouth with a long bitter aftertaste.  A decent beer, but Im not too fond of the style.

bottle BB9/16/8 by way of pforei. medium brown color with ruby at the edges topped by a light tan head. aromas of chocolate, cream, light coffee, toasted walnuts, a little wood and near metallic maltiness (the metal aspect disappears as it warms). the flavor is near perfect for a porter (at least a british one!)... coffee, cream, chocolate, wood, light skunky hops, mildly bitter roast and a slight ashiness on the finish. its not overly sour and leaves a creamy coffee aftertaste. medium to full body with soft carbonation which gives it a creamy texture. the flavor gets a lot better as it nears room temperature but the mouth feel suffers...

Another sampler from afire, thanks bud.  Poured dark-coffee like with a medium head, nice mellow carbonation through the taste.  Chocolate and coffee aromas mix into a malty and slight bitter pallet.  Although it has a distinctive character and body it lacks that certain something, rich yet a little week towards the end.  All in all well balanced but not the punch I hoped for.
Rating #400. Aroma has coffee and roasted malts. Nice dark brown colour with a small tan head. Flavour has roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. Excellent porter!

Mild porter aroma but the olfactory is damp and a little more repulsive. Creamy thin head. Blackish dark brown and not opague. Wet burned wood taste with a whack of alky yet not over the top. Has that old ale flavor. Im surprised its classified as a porter. Nice over all with a gentleman finish that lacks any oppressiveness.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Poured a bottle into a pint glass. 

Very, very dark brown brew with ruby highlights. Half inch off-white head after a vigorous pour. Slowly dissipated, leaving only slight lacing on the glass. This was about the only thing I could find not perfect about this beer. 

Smelled of chocolate, caramel, brown sugar, some coffee and cream, maybe even some cinnamon toast. Very complex and layered, and it keeps improving as the beer warms. Boy, does this aroma ever make me want to drink this beer! 

The taste was fabulous. Roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, toffee, molasses, and just enough hop bitterness to cleanse the palate. The flavors are layered and keep evolving as this beer warms. It is quite possibly the best tasting beer Ive ever had! 

Smooth, creamy, just thick enough to provide great body without being sticky or cloying. Enough carbonation to keep it light without being fizzy. A slight lingering flavor of coffee and dark chocolate that leaves you wanting more and more. 

Extremely drinkable. Moderate ABV and awesome flavor makes for a great drinking experience. I wish I had a few more bottles of this available. It is fantastic. 

This ranks as one of the finest beers Ive ever had! I was expecting a good beer, and was pleasantly surprised to find a great beer.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2008 tastes like pain thinner and day old coffee I hate coffee I guess thats why I hated this so much not the worse beer I ever tried but very close stay away from this one if i could have given it a lower score

(Bottle) Poured thick with a creamy, off white head that stuck around for a minute, as does everything with this beer. Scent of deeply roasted malts made my mouth water. Complex, hearty, perfectly balanced taste with a thick, creamy mouthfeel that stayed with me long after the beer was gone. Possibly the best representation of what I want from a beer. Ill let you know if I find a better one!

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2008 (ENGLAND) Dark brown color with a dissipating sm-tan head. Aroma of chocolate / coffee with a rich mocha taste, with some carbonation.There is a slightly bitter finish  to this one but extremely well balanced. This my friends is the real deal !!!!  :)  Get some.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2008 bottle. pours a very dark brown with ruby highlights around the edges, small tan head. smells like freshly roasted coffee beans and toffee. lovely roasted malt/espresso taste balanced by a smooth feel in the mouth. finishes bitter and roasted. oh my, I could drink these all night!

Wow, is that... coffee in my porter? It is! All porters have that smell but this is the one that smells like a coffee with milk in it. Great color. SMooth taste. Little weak in the mouth. So malty and coffee, mildly bitter, just great. Id give it more points if it didnt die on my tongue.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2009 Strong aroma of coffee and roasted malts. Very roasted flavor, definitely a large coffee presence. Flavor is predominately coffee laced with bittersweet chocolate. Mouthfeel  is very creamy and smooth. Finish is slightly dry with minimal bitterness. Fantastic porter overall.

Bouteille brune de 500 ml. Arômes de céréales rôties. On note aussi une légère touche de café et une présence discrète de houblon. Robe noire aux reflets rouges, légèrement translucide et peu effervescente. Belle complexité en bouche oû lon retrouve la torréfaction ainsi quune présence de cacao. Le houblon rend la finale légèrement amère. Très bon

Nice average porter.   Im not as thrilled as it appears others are about this beer.  It has a nice appearance dark brown with a nice white head.  The aroma is a nice chocolate malt smell.  The flavor is of chocolate and coffee.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2008 LCBO can. Dark redish brown/black with a thick off-white head that slowly thins. Chocolate aroma. Mocha taste, easy drinking, pleasant and lasting mocha after-taste. Not too dry, not too swet, nice blend. Id like to taste a higher alcohol version of this, that would be awesome.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2008 ok head, ok lacing, beautiful almost black coloration- reddish tints visible in the depths. aroma has espresso, chocolate, malts- beautiful porter smell. taste compounds the aspects of the aroma into a multi-faceted masterpiece- so enjoyable i didnt want to put it down to type this rating. palate is remarkably smooth, can almost feel subtle coffee massaging your tongue. awesome beer.

Pours with a small, light brown head. Decent retention in the form of a ring around the glass. Ultra dark brown body. Aroma is of vanilla and coffee. Taste is a nice balance of bitter coffee and hops. Mouthfeel is creamy with just a hint of lively carbonation. A decent porter, but I think this is a bit overated.

500 ml bottle. Maedium head is quite creamy, durable and brown in colour. Liquid is very dark brown, almost black. Heavy roasted malts and caramel in malts. Also some good coffee aromas. Lots of carbonatioin, which highlights roastiness. Very enjoyable balance of sweet caramel and dry bitter and roastiness in the finish. Strong and deep aromas make this a diverse porter with lots of character.

Bouteile de 500 ml. La bière est de couleur brune avec des reflets marrons qui réussisent à percer le liquide malté. Une mousse brune moyenne est présente. Au nez des arômes de chocolat, de noix grillés, de café-moka, de vanille, de fumé, de mélasse, de caramel au beurre et de prunes  se réunissent pour marquer mes papilles olfactives. En bouche le corps est moyen et la bière a une texture moyennement crèmeuse. Les flaveurs que ma langue peut détecter sont les noix grillés, la mélasse, le chocolat noir, le caramel au beurre, le café et le cacao. Le tout se termine par une amertume assez prononcée.

Dark brown, tanned quite creamy head. Immense coffee and chocolatey nose. Flavour is malty, heavy on coffee, some cocoa. Finishes with some roasted bitterness. Medium bodied, nicely round palate. Easy and tasty porter.
There is a lovely chocolate scent from this beer when poured and it is quite noticeable on the palate.well balanced with plenty of dryness in the finish.

Smokey!  I lve this beer for its complex start that holds steady through the finish.  Big think dark head, pours dark, aroma is smokey and roasted malt.  Flavor is rich and creamy, with a bit of dryness at the end.  You can really taste the the quality going into this.

Pours an opaque black color with a milk chocolate colored brown head.  Aroma is great of roasted malt... very rich and chocolatey with caramel and coffee as well.  Flavor is creamy and smooth with roasted coffee and chocolate flavors as well as a slight hop bitterness.

On tap.

500ml can thanks to matt7215:
pours with a big tan head that seens very creamy. this sits on a very very dark brown alomost black. aroma is sweet chocolate and malt, roastyness adn small touches of coffee. the flavour is excellent a very smooth and creamy chocoalte with a good mixture of roast and slight coffee. finishes with a good bitter and more chocolate flavour. the palate is also good. a great east drinking porter iwish i could get all the time.
Very drinkable for a dark beer. Not great, but would still be a good choice for someone breaking into craft brews. Step after guiness perhaps.

Fullers London Porter is a very dark reddish brown beer with a light brown head. The aroma is very fragrant and more flowery than I expected. The flavor is very smokey and this is very easy to drink.

500ml bottle from Sainsburys. Dark brown with some reddish hints and a big, frothy tan head. Big aroma of roast malt, coffee, figs, prunes and burnt molasses. Smooth mouth feel with dark chocolate, coffee and preserved fruit flavours. Some underlying spiciness before along dry finish that was marred slightly by pasteurised, boiled sweet flavours. Very good overall.
Great beer.  Some good residual sweetness, and is very drinkable.  Even people who might not like dark beers will find this beer enjoyable.  Delicious!
Pours near black with a thin tan head.  Aroma of milk chocolate, caramel, and coffee.    Taste has strong roasted coffee flavor that slides into a lasting bitter finish.  Very nice beer.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2008 Roasted malty aroma with smooth chocolate, coffee, syrupy-like sweetness and licorice. Finishes quite dry and ashy. Low to medium bitterness. Smooth and creamy mouthfeel. Very enjoyable dessert-like beer.
Bottle. Pours dark ruby black brown, thin off white head. Aroma is molasses, caramel, anise, fudge. Flavor is the same, bitter, roasted and quite robust. Mouth feel is oily.

I consider this one a dependable, well above average, porter.  The creamy consistency of the beer along with the tight roasted, chocolate, coffee taste is exactly what I desire from a porter.  The inch thick head leaves quickly...small lace throughout.  A tad bit more watery that I would like, but all and all - one heck of a beer.  A small amout of bitterness at the end.  On a sidenote, I love the design of the bottle...

Bottle poured into pint glass- poured very dark brown, transparent when held to light, low carbonation, cream-ish head formed and stayed around for awhile.  Aroma of roasted malts with coffee and chocolate undertones.  Hits the mouth with a wide body, malt is very apparent, notes of coffee, smoke, and dark chocolate, finish is complete.  Smoke em if you got em.

I thought this beer looked and smelled great.  It poured a dark porter brown and had a nice brown/tan head.  But, once the beer was in my mouth, I got less than I was expecting.  I love porters, but I couldnt help but feel like this Fullers London Porter was kind of weak.  It tasted almost watery, the palate was not as thick and rich as I had expected for a nice dark porter, and it just seemed generally lacking in complexity.  It was a fine beer, but I felt that it was only fine, and not worthy of the reputation (or the price) that is associated with it.  All in all, I would pick other and cheaper porters over London Porter.  I would try it again if I saw it on tap, perhaps that would make a significant difference.  Cool bottle though...

This dark brown ale poured with a decent tan head and a pleasant roasted malt aroma. This beer just tastes really good. Its got a nice blend of rich malts with chocolate and coffee undertones, and a nice roasted feel to it.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2008 Bottle thanks to dchmela . Pours a dark black with a thick and creamy beige head. The aroma is awesome; coffee, burnt malts and hops. The flavor is mostly a super rich roasted malt. Man, I am a sucker for this style when it is done this well. A coffee and chocolate mix also with hops, brown sugar and some smoke. What a great beer. It is rich and full, but also easygoing and inviting.

extraodinary achievement, another excellent beer from fullers. this one is balanced to the charred molasses side.

on tap at dressels in st. louis.

On tap at The Ginger Man. Has a very dark brown almost black with a medium light tan head. The aroma is roasted dark chocolate and malt. Good lacing on the glass. The taste was like the aroma with a dry finish. A very good porter from Fullers.

Bottle:  Beer number 100.  Pours a very dark red color with a thick light brown head that fizzles away to a light film.  Aroma of dark chocolate, malt and coffee.  Flavor is a light smoky chocolate with a light bitter aftertaste. A great porter!
Draft, pours a very dark almost black color with a thin tan head.  Great aroma of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, licorice & smoke.  Very full flavor with a nice slightly bitter aftertaste.
Dark brown with tiny beige head. Fruity aroma with roasted malt and smoky notes. Sweet flavor with notes of roasted malt, coffee, liquerice and smoke.

Poured a dark clear mahogeny brown with red highlights. The head was thin and disappeared quickly. The aroma was chocolate and smokey. The flavor was initially a smokey flavor then I picked up on chocolate and roasted coffee. There was a nice long finish to the beer with a slightly bitter undertone that lasted well. It had a bit of a dry finish. This was very good

UPDATED: FEB 29, 2008 Dark red/black beer with nice off white head. Wonderful fruity/coffee/woody aroma! Very smooth and crisp! This is the real deal!  Velvety smooth and easy to drink. It has a kind of a smoky taste and nice crisp bitter finish.
Draft. Nice roasty, straight ahead porter. Smells of roasted coffee. Dark near-black color, small head. Extremely easy drinking and a clean, smokey finish. Perfectly balanced and refreshing.

Very drinkable beer.  Color is a near black.  It was thinner than I expected but held its flavor well.  This was of roasted malt and some slight chocolate.  The hops peek through to enhance this nice brew.
Draught. Nose is smoke and chocolate. Deep black color with a thin creme-colored head. Robust and flavorful, lots of chocolate malt character. Very smooth and drinkable.

A full pour, dark brown and tan solid head..aroma of chocolate malts, some yeast, and faint fruit tones. Low carbonated, and extremely smooth and creamy...slightly bitter on the aftertaste, but very pleasant. However, tastes a bit light as well for a porter without the richness of many other porters ive tried. I would prefer it with a little more weight..but that being said, still great.

Appearance: dark brown color with reddish tones. Great head with beige color, dense and very lasting.
Aroma: toast and sweet from malts. Breads smells reminiscences from yeast. Chocolate, coffee, caramel, cream and vanilla smells reminiscences. Too, aromatic fruitiness likes figs, raisins and blackberries.  
Flavor: toast-malts start with medium insensitive and very lasting. Pleasant touch of bitter-chocolate, coffee grains, caramel, toast-bread, truffles, cream and some wood. Fruitiness similar to nuts and toast-hazelnuts; like also to ripe-fruits like blackberries and figs. Dry final with Fuggles-hops taste, but the mainly dryness come from toast. Slight metallic touch. Toast aftertaste.
Palate: medium body with an exquisite smooth and silky texture. Low carbonated.
Good balance, pleasant and lasting toast, nice bitter-chocolate taste. An exquisite beer.

One of my favorite beers to just sit down and down a six pack of either alone or with some friends.  Brown color with a nice head.  Malty aromas that are very inviting.  Taste is a malt balance that has chocolate and roasted characters in it.  Overall a very good beer.

Smoky liquorice aroma. Dark reddish brown with disappearing head.

Tastes of liquorice, roasted color malt and most importantly, almost no sweetness. Incredibly well balanced but not that rich. 100208

Pours a dark brown/black color with a light tan head.  Mild roasted aroma, light chocolate flavor with a strong roast presence.  I like this one cause its not too sweet like too many other porters being made these days.

I DID not find the brew to be very rich. the beer is barley in flavor with light flavors of chocolate. it is toasted and mild and malty. the beer has a moderate body and a coating yet overall clean finish. while it is well balanced i did not find it substantial. refreshing and soft and overall good beer it is mildly bitter.

Bottle.  Pours a rich-looking near-black color with a persistent tan head.  Mild overall aroma, light hints of sweet roast and malt, slight suggestion of chocolate.  Much more chocolate on the taste.  Velvet mouthfeel.  The taste is a subtle balance of sweetness, toastiness, and rich malts.  Ill be returning to this one.
Pours black, tastes of chocolate, and coffee.  Smells very good.  Overall I really like the beer.

Bottle 50 cl. Small, creamy tan head thats diminishing. Fair lacing and black color. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, roasted/burnt malt, leather and smoke. Full oily body, soft carbonation, bitter finish.

Maybe I am off or this is an off bottle, but I just dont get it with this one.  Porter is probably my favorite style, and this is just alright to me.  It just tastes too thin for my liking.  I has some great chocolate and prunes going on in the aroma, and those carry over to the flavor, but it just doesnt have the creaminess and lingering malty and hoppy finish that I associate with a solid example of the style.  Everything is just too subdued for me.  I dont find it nearly as interesting or delicious as the Nogne O Porter, and it doesnt have the weight or richness of Sierra Nevadas porter.  I would much rather drink this than many other beers, but for being number one in the style, I just dont get it at all.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2008 From the bottle, this is nice, rich, and a bit high on the chocolate end for a porter.  It is almost black red-brown with a medium,  dense, long-lasting tan head that leaves some good, creamy lacing.  The smell is at first rich, ceamy milk chocolate, then this becomes more subdued and mocha-like, joined by toasted brown bread, hints of prunes and caramel, being full and sweet.  The taste is predominantly toast and a rich milk chocolate (rather than bitter dark chocolate) mocha, with elements of fruit, especially prunes, caramel, and a hint of coffee.  Despite these traits, and the heavily toasty, caramelized quality, it does not taste burnt at all, lacking any acrid quality, and is very smooth and even throughout, with great sweet-bitter balance.  Its smooth and thick, a bit oily.

Bottle poured into a Cascade lager glass (much like a French verre de biere). Dark rich aromas of chocolate, coffee and toasted malt. Near opaque brown color with a vigorous tan head. Medium body with chewy/creamy carbonation. Nice flavor of dark toasted, near burnt, malt with coffee and arguably a touch  of chocolate. The finish is pretty much toast and coffee with some hop bitter coming forth to help balance. Something of a medium dry finish. Extremely tasty.

Poured into a Rogue pint glass. Nearly black body, completely opaque with ruby hues around the edges. 2 finger coffee-colored head, dense and sticky. 

Smells just like chocolate milk tastes. Caramel, coffee, toast. 

Roasted malt flavor floods over the tongue, followed by a faint hop prod. Notes of burnt toast, dark chocolate, bakers chocolate, cocoa powder, smoke. 

Surprising amount of carbonation, maybe too much for the style, makes quaffing a bit rocky. The dark richness is very enjoyable though. 

At 5.4% abv, this is supremely drinkable.
This is an elegant porter.  The nose and flavor are richly influenced by mocha.  this is a true delight, and a must try for those whom have not.
Exactly what it advertises.  A rich complex beer with hints of chocolate and nuts, slightly sweet with a flavorful finish.

Damn good porter. Here you can see how a porter is different that a stout, and why. Poured a dark, dark brown with a here it is then gone beige head. In the mouth it is smoke, soy sauce and roasted malt. Finish is sweet and a  bit tangy with a light but refreshing mouth feel. I like it, and its still available at Riba Smith for 2.25 a bottle (but I dont know how much longer it will be!)
Bottle.  dark brown with some red and yellow.  this was smokie with some good coffee flavors
Bottle. Dark brown with a big light brown head. Roasted malts, chocolate and earthy aromas. Good roasted coffee flavours, with chocolate and a dry finish. Smooth as velvet. Wonderful.
Bottle/Tap.  Very dark reddish/brown brew with a nice light brown head.  Aroma is a bit smokey and roasted malt.  Flavor is very smooth roasted malt with a touch of smoke.  Very nice smooth drinker.

16.9 oz. bottle.  Pours very dark brown, nearly black, with a thin, dense, tan head that lasted for about a quarter of the glass.  Very pleasant aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, and just a little bit of coffee.  The flavor was equally nice with roasted malt, chocolate and a bit of coffee all present once again.  Just the right amount of bitterness at the finish.  As the beer warms, a bit of soy sauce also emerges in the flavor profile.  This beer is the textbook definition of what a porter should be.  Excellent stuff.
Black with a beige bubbly head. The aroma is earthy and smokey. The flavour is also smokey, dry with roasted coffee and chocolate flavours that are nice but not very assertive. Firm to medium body.

Yes, the reviewers of ratebeer got this one right.  Everything about this exceptional beer is perfect.  Color, lacing, aroma, body, balance.  While some may  say the body is a bit thin this only allows the drinker to enjoy more of this excellent beer.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2008 Dark brown with red tinge.  Lightly roasted chocolate and coffee aroma has slight note of fruit and caramel.  Taste is similar.  Hops add a slightly bitter and faintly herbal finish.  Sweet and smooth.  

Rerate:  Really enjoyed the intense chocolate.

Pours a pitch black with a foamy beige head.  Aroma of rosted malts dark chocolate and coffee.  Taste very similar to aroma with malty dark chocolate and roasted coffee.  Creamy and smooth up front with a dry bitter finish.

Pours very dark brown with a crimson hue and a good sized tannish head.  The aroma with creamy roasted malt, milk chocolate, cream and some coffee bitterness.  Medium / full body that gets a little thinner towards the finish with semi-sharp carbonation.  Starts with some coffee bitterness, dark chocolate and roasted malt.  The finish gets sharper with more pronounced bitterness.  Good beer.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2008 Coffee/cola dark color. Strong oak, smokey wood smell, very nice. Almost has that oak aged taste, roasty, maple, expresso also noted. Meduim body and very easy to drink. Not very bitter and not very complex as compliments. One of the best, if not the best porter i have ever had, great beer!

THOUGHTS: Nothing spectacular, it just does everything that makes a porter good nearly perfectly. No innovations, just making a beer just as it should be.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a clear, dark brownish red with and average light tan had that mostly diminished and left good lacing at first then hardly any then back to fair. The aroma was moderate to heavy roasted malt, mild coffee, bitter chocolate and cocoa powder. The only thing that could be better about the aroma would be for it to be stronger. The initial flavor was moderately sweet and lightly bitter, while the finish was heavily sweet, lightly to moderately bitter and slightly sour. The flavor was mostly like the aroma but stronger. There was sweet malt up front and a bitter coffee finish. The medium body was creamy with fizzy carbonation and a moderate astringent finish.

Pours  a dark color.  Slightly darker than a cola with a red hue.  No head at all.  Aroma is roasty with some coffee notes.  Roasted malt, coffee, some chocolate in the taste.  Very nice...a bit thin...definite coffee aftertaste.  This is a nice porter.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2008 On-tap. Deep dark brown color with a  fading pale brown head. Aroma: Roasted malt, coffee, caramel, chocolate, dark fruit and some smokiness. Flavor: Roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, light smokiness and mild hop bitterness. Dry and creamy mouthfeel. Excellent porter.

Bottle @ The Maltings, november 07. Very dark copper/ black color with some shinny ruby hues and a medium, creamy, beige head. Toasted, roasty flavor with some solid caramel notes, a hint of coffee and some very slight vinous notes. Medium mouthfeel, tasty, malty with a nice coffee finnish. Filling but refreshing and moreish. Some molasses notes on the nose with a slight rasiny touch. Excellent coffesih porter.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2008 Drinking one now. Great aroma of chocolate roasted malt, very slight fruity notes. Taste of a rich dark roast chocolate grains with caramel. Head retention is not what I expected but perhaps unwanted oils from my glass or lips are to blame. This is the best porter I ever had so far. All I can say is "WoW"....The wife liked it because it tasted like fresh ground coffee.
Pours dark brown with small tan head. Aroma is roasty, with chocolate, coffee, molasses. Robust flavor, and a nice finish. Excellent example of the style.

Pours a very dark brown with a couple fingers of quickly fading head. Smells very roasty, some chocolate and a hint of coffee grounds. Tastes of sweet roast, a little coffee grounds show as it warms along bakers chocolate and a minor bite in the finish. Light in the mouth with good carbonation. Easy going session beer with a little oomph.

500ml can 
5.4% ABV 
I tried this beer on October 7, 2007 after purchasing from my local LCBO outlet.  The beer poured into the glass a beautiful, dark, murky brown colour with a large tan coloured head.  The aroma was a combination of malt and yeast with some sweet hints.  The mouthfeel was thick and full with some mild carbonation, almost creamy.  The taste was malty with some hints of caramel (the possible sweetness in the aroma).  This was a very good beer.
Black with tan head. Aroma is a little sweet with some chocolate and coffee. Dry taste, with chocolate and coffee dominating, some sweet caramel also present.
bouteille brune de 500ml. belle couleur brune opaque, mousse brune durable, nez de chocolat, café en grain, en bouche belle rondeur gout de malt chocolat, bonne amertume. très bonne bière,
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Boca Raton, FL for $1.79 Very good!

500ml can, 5.4% a/v

Pours very dark, almost opaque black with a small tan head. Smells of roasted malt, and mild coffee and chocolate. Tastes very dry, coffee and chocolate which is balanced PERFECTLY by the Fuggles hops. Impressive combination, though lacking a bit of intensity.

Porter a meio caminho entre uma Stout e uma Dunkel. Coloração muito preta, creme pouco denso e consistente. O aroma (melhor que o sabor) de café intenso e leve toque de frutas vermelhas. No paladar, decepciona um pouco. Aguadinha, mas agradável. Não impressiona.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Garrafa, 500 ml. Coloração preta avermelhada, com creme marrom bonito no início, mas que desapareceu quase por completo. Notas predominantes de café e malte torrado. Degustada com chocolate (meio amargo), ganhou surpreendente drinkability, crescendo em desempenho. Final seco e amargo, mas melhorado pelo chocolate. Boa cerveja.
Brown color, medium head. Aroma: Roasted barley, coffee, chocolate. Palate: Caramel, dark chocolate, coffee, toast. Creamy.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2010 Essa surpreendente porter inglesa leva a sério o lema de que a primeira impressão é a que fica, com uma belíssima garrafa e rótulo e um surpreendente primeiro gole.
Como toda dark beer que se preze, possui, segundo Luiz Fernando Cavalheiro, grão-mestre da Confraria do Status, "um corpo longo, forte amargor, café onipresente e aroma de trufas amargas".
Assino embaixo e acrescento que, associado ao destacado e inebriante aroma de café, também se percebe fortemente a presença de maltes de chocolate e caramelo. Para os que conhecem a linha eisenbahn, eu diria que essa é uma eisenbahn anabolizada.

Had certainly put a few away by the time this was rolled out, but it still managed to show its worth. Really nice chocolate aroma, with a pinch of coffee thrown in. Smooth flavour, with plenty of depth belying the modest abv. Unfortunately my notes are rather thin, but the beer certainly wasnt. Love to try this again.
Very nice chocolate aroma with a bit of coffee.  Flavor is dark chocolate , coffee, and roasted malt.  Finish is straight espresso.  Very flavorful and very drinkable.

Bottle. I was shocked to find I hadnt rated this one in all this time as I went to check my score after enjoying one while adding lights to the house tonight. I guess Ive missed a couple other from Fullers I will have to sample again like this one. Pours nearly black with light brown head. Aroma is fairly roasty but mostly dark chocolate and maybe a hint of coffee. Flavor is nice and rich with malt and roastiness, light cocoa, and hints of espresso. Finish is clean and light for such a tasty brew with just a hint of bitterness. Smooth and creamy and easy drinking. I enjoyed this one, and Ive enjoyed quite a few others just like it. I drink one of these at least once a year when the mood strikes.

Pours a dark brown that borders upon black. Reddish caramel hues poke out at the corners. Nice tan head that didnt want to stick around for long, leaving a ring around the glass from start to finish. Aromas of bittersweet chocolates, roasted malt, chocolate malt, and espresso are most pronounced, with subtle hints of currants. Flavor is a big rush of roasted malt. A slight hoppiness is first to come with some dark chocolate..chocolate malt, burnt wood, all finished off with freshly brewed espresso. Creamy mouth feel...low carbonation, low booze..amazing drinkability. Instant classic.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2008 On tap; poured a dark cola color with an off white head.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, toffee and dark fruit.  Flavor was similar to the aroma, but dominated more so by a sweet caramel flavor and dark fruit.  Body was a little light, but added a nice drinkability to the beer.  Very good example for the style.  (Rerated it; pushed it up by .1)

Pours dark brown with brown ruby at the edges with off-white bubbles that fade to a few, lots of roasted malt with some dry dark chocolate aromas, 
sweetness in the nose, coffee fragrances here and there, and faint fruit-berry aromas, has the same flavor as the aromas, 
lots of roasted malt, some dark roasted malt flavors with some bitter burnt taste that fit in with the other flavors, faint malt sweetness but more on the dry side of the porters beers,
has a medium mouth feel, faint dark roasted or burnt malt bitterness on the palate at the finish that had some overly roasted coffee bean flavors, 
has a medium mouth feel and is very easy to gulp down.

Nice blend of chocolate, toffee, and currant aromas. Dark mahogany pour with a slow building medium sized tan head. It tastes of smoke, french roast coffee, and charred wood. Sweet espresso finish. Great balance.

Pours dark brown with ruby red highlights and a tan head.  Smells of chocolate, dark fruit (figs, raisins, some plums), some roastiness.  Tastes of chocolate, caramel, coffee, some nice peppery splashes, elements of toffee.  Mouthfeel is full with a finish that yields a nicely balanced roastiness.

Bottle into pint glass. Pours a beautiful dark brown with a light tan head that dissipates rather quickly. This beer has heavy aromas of coffee, camp-fire smoke, butter and roasted malts. The flavor is of coffee, malts, burnt nuts, and a slight hint of toffee sweetness. Mouthfeel is a little on the light side for a porter, but this brew is still excellent!

Bottle poured into a tulip pint on 7-26-07. Dark ruby brown color with a 1 finger dark tan head. Big coffee note that dominates. Dark chocolate, roasted barley and milk chocolate compliment. Coffee taste initially with some dark chocolate. Can you guess? COFFEE with roasted barley. Body was a little watery and carbonation was very light. A bit much with the coffee for me. I like my porters with a more balanced taste. Not bad though.

dark burgundy with medium dense light brown head. dense aroma of roasted dark malt, mocha and a light spiciness. smooth and slightly sticky body. sweet palate with rich chocolate and prune, light bitterness and smoky spiciness

Bottle. Beautiful dark brown color with a small but, tenacious head with good lacing. Smooth flavor of dark malt and coffee. Aroma of rich dark malts and coffee. I love a good porter and this is definitely one to try.
Coffee and caramelick aroma. Huge creamy off-white head. Excellent lacing. Mostly lasting longevity. Clear amber body. Moderate bitter and light smoked flavor. Medium palate with oily texture.

Wow, this is perhaps one of the most wonderful sessions I have every drank. It is a really dark beer, with a standard coffee/chocolate aroma and a taste that is very similar, but there is a certain subtlety extant in this beer. Really smooth at the same time. I liked it a lot and want it again sometime soon.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2008 My favorite English porter.  Nice opaque black pour, one finger tan head.  Scent of coffee, slight mocha.  Flavor is matching with roasted malts, creamy mouthfeel.  Doesn’t stay with you, finish clean.  Great drinkability.  Smooth full flavor, more than usual for a porter.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Pours black with a nice thick head. Big chocolate malt and espresso aroma ith a hint of licorice. Coffee and chocolate malt taste that has the consistency of a stout, but much lighter and smoother. Aftertaste is light and dry. Very good.
Good smell and flavor; however, this beer is too ashy in the aftertaste. Reminded me of a wet ashtray. Watery as well.
user_location: Heart of the Rockies, Colorado, USA

text: UPDATED: MAY 15, 2008 On draught. Dark brown/black color. Medium head. Frothy goodness. Weak aroma of dark malt. Slight, I mean very slight notes of caramel on the aroma. Perfect stout flavor. Rich, sweet full mouthfeel, mild and refreshing.  A great tasting beer. Mild, sweet, dark, moderately roasted flavor. Slight, I mean very slight notes of coffee on the flavor. Consistency is like skim milk. How can a beer focusing on dark malts taste this good? Its a very smooth, full flavored porter. Excellent lacing. Should be enjoyed by everyone.
This smoked my heart! I am sitting here crying it was so good. So smooth and fulfilling. It burned a hole in my soul.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2009 Pours opaque root beer brown with a tan fizzy head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is wonderful, with roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Flavor is beautifully balanced with a combination of the flavors present in the aroma, with a touch of smokiness. Medium mouthfeel. One of the best porters Ive had. Well done!
Wow! What a awesome beer - smooth, rich, coffee and chocolate and deliciously (and dangerously) easy drinking....a perfect porter.
UPDATED: SEP 2, 2008 nearly perfect beer. It has so much flavor for only 5.4% you would think you were drinking a double. I actually prefer this beer next to ice cold.
What a beer! pours an inky black with tan head its so fruity yet dry on the palate with a firm smokiness that makes you want more....i wish i had more so im making this last as long as possible

Pint glass.  Pours with a small, delicate, nutty looking head, and has a ruby to nut-brown coffeeish color.  The smell is amazingly appetizing.  Hazelnut, dark roasted malt, chocolate and a bit of smoke.  There is quite a nuttiness to the aroma which makes it very appealing.  The taste is very full of semi-sweet chocolate, almond, black cherry and dark roast with rich arabic coffee, and has a crisp, yet velvety mouthfeel.  A long, mocha-lke finish makes it very satisfying.  This beer is so bursting with flavor, that you must drink it a sip at a time, as the flavors really begin to present themselves as the beer warms.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2011 Very dark brown beer with slight beige head. Aroma is complex and tastefull, slightly sweet, cholocalate, some coffee and smoke. Complex and interesting aroma. Flavour is smooth, light chocolate, roasted and there is no sweetness. Aroma promises a lot but overall impression is a little mild because of low alcohol procents, I think. However, very tastefull porter if you dont want to spend "whole evening" with one beer.

Very dark brown with an off white head that thins out slightly. Smells and tastes of malts, chocolate, raisin, coffee, nice rich flavour with a good bitter/sweet balance. Fairly watery with very little carbonation, goes down easy. A great porter with very few flaws, Recommended.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with thin light head that stays. Smell is subtly roasted and sweet. Very pleasant strong initial flavour - however feels a little thin in the mouth and slightly too hoppy. Too watery for me. Is quite good as far as the style goes, but seems slightly overrated on here.
bottle.  black  pour with thin off white head.  Great rich chocolate, caramel, maple sugar, toffee aroma.  smooth coffee and chocolate.  richness comes towards the end for a great candy like finish.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2008 Dark brown with a dense greysih head. Subtle aroma of chocolate and roasted malts. The taste is sweet, slightly burned and reminds me of cold cafe latte with a bit of bitterness. This little master piece is wrapped in a thin creamy body, making me crave for every drop of it.

From the awesome looking 12 oz. bottle.  This porter looks exactly what I would expect from a classic example of the style.  Very dark brown, a little dirty looking with a nice white contrasting head.  The aroma is absolutely divine - easily identifiable as Tiramisu.    However, the falvor is quite different, much like black coffee with some 2% milk and very little sugar.  For some reason I was expecting it to be sweet.  Well, I prefer some sweetness, but this was still quite satisfying.  The body was too thin and watery for me, but did not detract overall.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2008 Tap. 9-21-07.  Rerate 1-15-08 tap 
   Ink black color.  Smell is so many different things - it is hard to keep track: weak coffee, figs, freshly cut grass, and roasted pecans to name a few.  Palate is a bit too thin for me - but usually porters seem that way to me. However, there is a very nice smoothness to it.  Light malt flavor.  Little to no bitterness.  Nice smooth finish.  Easy to drink.  Pretty darn good for a porter
Pours nearly black with a small brown head.  It smells of dark roasted malts, toffee.  The taste is very much roasted coffee with some chocolate mixed.  Excellent.

Very, very, dark brown attractive pour with off-white head that lingered for a while.  Aroma is of coffee.  Taste is also of coffee, but this beer is not too bitter.  Nicely balanced.  Mouthfeel is nice as carbonation level is just just right.  A nice sessionable porter.

Very dark pour with a tan head.  Head didnt last long.  Aroma of chocolate milk, dark chocolate, maple syrup, and licorice.  Robust flavor of char and heft.  Malt smoothness at first and a hop bitterness at the end.  It is sharp on the sides of the mouth and tongue.
Pours dark brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma of chocolate malts -- sweet, nearly mocha. The flavour is burnt toasted malt with a bitter hops. Two-tone flavour is executed well. A nice, medium body.
mmmmm. This was good. Jet black brew, with a very small tan head. The burnt coffee, roasted notes really shine through in the aroma. tastes like it smells. very good, one of the best in the style.
black pour with no head at all.  no real scent in the bar.  very sweet roasted malt taste, quite good honestly.
Always glad to see this on the shelf!  Nice dark pour some head and lacing.  Thick malt flavor with a touch of hops to relieve the sweetness.  Nice burnt undertones that make this a good one!
Pours a deep brown colour with a hint of red in the light. The flavour is just bitter enough. It leaves a slight "burnt" after taste but not too strong.

33 cl, bb 03/Jun/07. Nearly opaque brown-black with red highlights. Small creamy head hangs around, leaving nice foamy lacing. Earthy molasses and creamy cocoa aroma.  Flavor is similar with hints of charred wood, campfire, molasses, smoky marshmallow, sourish cream; slight bitterish espresso to balance. The creamy smooth, medium body is awesome: turns just watery and tingly enough on the finish to refresh. The best dessert beer ever.

Smooth, sweet, full bodied, and has just the right touch with the hop.  Bottle procured at Half Time.   Pours a deep brown with amber oily head,  Translucent brown at edges of glass.  Toasty crisp malt nose with hints at caramel. Lacing is sparse and returns quickly to the beer and rings the edge with the carbonation.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2007 I fell in love with this Porter Nicely Balanced, Nice dark Pour, Chocolate and Roasted Coffee, not bitter. Good Cold but I like it warmer. excellent Porter and my favorite of the many Ive tried.Earlier Rating: 10/8/2007 Total Score: 5This was my favorite Porter. One day I visted my local shop and found they didnt carry this fine Porter any longer. I was told to try another store that carried a larger variety of imports. I was advised from the person looking it up in his stock book that Fullers London Porter was No longer made. A sad day for this Porter Lover. I will Not go back to Domestic beer and will try some other Porters or quit drinking all together. If anyone has info on this fine Porter, please post

Bottle. A dark brown pour, average tan head. Chocolate dominates aroma profile followed by roast, coffee. Flavor is malty, roasty but not too bitter; some toasty and bready flavors. Really smooth, really good. Everything from appearance to aroma to finish says this beer is awesome.

Pours very dark for a light brown head.  The head is thick and stays around for a while.  The light coming through the beer is clear, but there isnt much making it through. Smells of roasted malt and maybe some chocolate and coffee.  The aroma is pretty sweet.  The taste is of sweet, thick, chocolatey coffee.  The beer is thick and creamy in the mouth.  This is certainly a heavy beer, but its got a lot of great flavor.

Bottle. Roasted malt, dark cacao/chocolate, sweet. Small creamy brown head, mostly diminishing. Black body. Heavy bitter, a little bit of chocolate sweetness shines through; average / long duration. Medium to full body, oily and creamy texture, soft carbonation. Very nice beer, good one for a rainy day!

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2008 Dark porter with a very slight red tint when held up to the light. Tight off white head that lasts pretty well. Wonderful aromas of rish malt, chocolate, coffee, and caramel. Strong flavours of caramel and roasted malt, with chocolate and perfectly integrated hops. Thick rich mouthfeel with malty finish. This is undoubtedly one of the better porters I have ever had.
Very dark almost black. Aroma of coffee and bitter chocolate. The flavor mimics the aroma and has a smooth mouthfeel and a perfectly balanced finish. One of the best proters Ive tasted so far.
Black colour with creamy beige head,Aroma of rosted coffee and dark bitter chocolate,flavor of raisin and nuts aswell ´Full body and well balanced finish.

Had this beer on 2/19/2003.  Color is deep maroon with great carbonation and fizzy pop like head.  Aroma is a light fresh roasted scent.  Taste is nicely roasted.  Starting with a medium body that has a smooth feel and goes down a mildly crisp feel.  Finish comes in with a bright sweet roasted flavor that rolls into a rich mellow toasted flavor backed by a gentle bitterness.  In the end there is a heavy sweet tone that hangs.  One of the best imported Porters I have ever had.  It is well balanced and some what smooth, but it could have been better if it didnt have the sweet tones at the very end.
Pours a pleasing ruby drink with a small head. Nose of roasted nuts, cloves and raisin. Typically light in body but with some maltiness and a nice bitter finish. One of the great British beers.

Bottle from my local Fullers pub. Pours a deep amber, almost brown, with an off white head. Nose of black coffee and chocolate with some butterscotch hints and a taste to match. Medium body with a malty cocoa finish. Not bad for a brew you can pick up at the local, would like to try a cask version at some point.

From bottle : Pours a deep dark brown color with a small quickly gone offwhite head.   A nice chocolate roasted malt aroma with some caramel.  A roasted malt flavor with hints of chocolate and a very nice caramel finish.  Medium body, creamy feel.
Deep brown almost black, pours leaving small tan head. Aroma is of chocolate/dark malts. Flavour is of chocolate/toffee/hops. Somewhat thin on palate, but very drinkable.

Pours almost black with a small dark tan head. Semi-sweet lactic aroma, with malty notes of melted chocolate, a bit of coffee, and some slight smoky undertones. Flavor follows the aroma quite well, with a bit more coffee than expected. Palate is a bit thinner than than expected, but has a very pleasant mouth-feel, and a decent finish.

11.2 fl oz from Sicilianos Market in Grand Rapids, MI.  Deep brown almost black color with ruby tint and nicely colored small tan head that kind of looks like a bubbling pancake.  Aroma is rich dark malt, coffee, chocolate, a little smoke, and maple syrup.  Flavor is very meaty with a lot of smoke, pretty strong coffee at first that fades and is overtaken by the meatiness, very interesting for a porter.  Body is too thin for me, but British style porters tend to be too thin in general.  Overall a very interesting porter, was actually expecting less.  I guess the only big negative is the body and that Im a vegetarian eating a very meaty tasting beer.

11.2 fl. oz (US) bottle with an expiration date of 16 Apr 08.  Pours an incredibly dark brown with hints of ruby.  Tan head and lots of lacing.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and cocoa and little hint of smoke. Taste is similar with a strong mouth feel.  A fabulous brew.

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep brown with ruby red highlights. Medium tan head.  Nose is Chocolate, toffee and coffee bean.  Taste is coffee beans with some sweetness, chocolate ice cream? The coffe flavor howver, is not overwhelming because its balanced with a nutlike flavor with a dash of hops. This was an outstanding Porter.

12 oz. brown bottle. No freshness date seen. Poured out a dark chocolate brown, with a robust tan colored head. Aromas are of dark malts, some coffee & toffee notes. Flavors are of coffee beans, toffee, caramel, hops. bitter hops bite right at the very end. Decent body. Above average Porter overall.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2008 Pint at Volo and also from cans and bottles. The aroma is of coffee and chocolate, and is very enticing! Very smooth - like drinking an espresso chocolate cake covered in cream. Wonderful dark body with a nice head.

12 ounce bottle in pint glass.  Dark brown/black with flat tan head and some lace.  Aroma of Cocoa Puffs.  Mild roasted chocolaty flavor with slight fruityness and slight bitterness.  Medium body and carbo.  Very quaffable.
On tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. Great porter. chocolate, coffee, toffee. well balanced. medium to full bodied. very well done

So THIS is what a Porter is supposed to taste like.  You could have this for dessert.  The flavors are strong hints of chocolate, malt, coffee, toffee, and toasted varieties.  It pours rich and thick with a pleasant head.  Great aroma as well.

dark brown/black body with a nice brown head that disappears slowly. fantastic aroma. sweet cocoa cake with a hint of coffee and a light touch of some blackberry. meaty notes develop as it warms. deep sweet cocoa cake flavor with tart blackberries spicy black pepper and bitter coffee. great balanced flavor. tart spicy bitter dry finish with a sweet cocoa cake backbone. spicy black pepper lingers. finish almost mouth puckering.....an almost tannic like feel. finish lingers forever spicy and dry with coffee notes medium body. moderate carbonation. great beer. are there tobacco notes in this beer also?.........i could go on forever. yeah pipe tobacco.......this stuff is great.

Bottle courtesy of Piscator34. Pours out a cola redish hue, with surprising clarity.  Excellent head retention, followed by a nice string of lacing.  Nose is of a mild mocha coffee. Taste is medium roast and nuts.  Slightly bitter finish from the roasted barley and some herbal hops.  Not at all sweet and has a nice body to it. Great example of a sessionable porter.

Uber dark pour, with a thinly bubbled head.  Strong malt scent immediately after pouring.  Scent also contains a lot of nuts, nutmeg, chocolat and coffee.  Very rich deep smokey taste.  Lots of coffee and dark chocolat.  A bit of toffy.  A hint of raisin.  Many nuts, definately some hazelnut.  Very apealing taste.  A warm nutty aftertaste is left.  A very fine beer.  Only problem is its a bit rich so not an easy drinking beer.
Wonderfully dark pour. Nice head. Has the roasted malt aroma I expcet in a nice porter. Not to bitter. Good aftertaste. A fine example of an English Porter.
Bottle: Pours back with a small head.  Great malt and roasted smell.  Taste like it smells.  Possibly the best porter that I have ever had.

On tap at Volo. I was happy to finally come across this beer after months of effortless searching. Smell was of roasted barley and cocoa beans. Flavour followed a similar pattern with roasted barley, coffee, smoke and dark chocolate. Here is the weird thing about this beer. It disappears. Upon the first sip, all the flavours can be experimented with, but it doesnt round out, or finish. There is no satisfaction in the swallow, it just disappears and makes me wonder if the beer just vanished on my tongue. Leaves a lingering, somewhat unpleasant bitter taste. Its a good beer, but it would take a really fixed scenario to get me to enjoy this. Figures though, as I greatly disliked Fullers London Pride.
bottle. Black, tiny head.  Black licorice, dark chocolate, coffee. Good mouthfeel and balance.  Like it, but was expecting more.  Maybe better warmer?

Date: 02/07/2002
Mode: Draft
Source: Wild Wing Cafe, Marietta

Black, tan head, rich malt flavor, cots of carmel sweetness, no bitterness

Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 3.4/5.0Score: **4
-------- />
The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Rated from notes from forever ago, but poured into an English Pint from the bottle.  Best served and consumed a little warm.  Dry porter.  Lots of creamy chocolate and coffee flavors, and just enough hops to keep it crisp and make this a very good session beer.

Bottle from Johns grocery.  Best before Dec 9th, 2007.  Extremely dark brown, almost black.  Small quickly fading small bubble head.  Overroasted smokey grain smell and taste I dont like.  Very dry, a tiny bit of sour.  I prefer sweeter beers, so my rating is low.
Bottle. Black with a short beige head. Aroma and flavour of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, malt and hops.

Very smokey and a bit dry , beautiful aroma, very faint and fragile head.









Overall nice.
06 Bottle at Quips in Lancaster.  Black coffee like pour with no head.  Solid hints of coffee and chocolate with a surprising great body yet little carbonation. Went down very fast.  I love it.

11.2 oz bottle. Pours a rich dark brown, no head. The aroma is almost chocolatish with hints of coffee. It has a very full taste- it envelops your mouth. Excellent body but not too overpowering. Very smooth going down and great aftertaste. I like to compare this beer to a good cuban cigar- Full of body and flavor and dosent irritate your thoat or overpower you with its strength. The 99 percentile rating speaks for itself.
Bottle. Very dark with thick brown head. Nose is smoke and coffee. Flavour is coffee, chocolate and smoke. Rich and robust, sweet even. But for some reason this just doesnt work for me.
Poured balck with brown head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate. A big roasted coffee flavor with hints of chocolate. Smooth.

Charred oak pour with a pretty head like a chocolate milkshake.  Nose of cinnamon and molasses sweetbread.  Cranberries, nuts, and outside hints of tomato cream soup and purple onion.  A spot on roasty body with just a killer, thick au jus beef flavor.  Cocoa dusted with the real earthy stuff and the milky stuff.  Espresso, a little vanilla and some perky fruits.  Full and satisfying in the mouth with the right grain of earthiness.  Very little sugary stuff happening, which is lovely.  Pretty much right on form  the one to set the standard.  Thanks Steve!

Pours dark brown, with a small, thin light tan head.  Smells of big roast and nuts.  Alot of dark malts and hints of mild chocolate are there as well.  Very rich and thick mouthfeel, alot of roast and chocolate as well.  Nice body, really good flavor.  This is how I like my porters, thick and toasty.  The finish is nutty, alot of toasted malt and the aftertaste is just slightly bitter, but masked by the roast.  Excellent porter.  Very well done.
Wow.  Dark brown on the pour with a tannish head.  The aroma is strong (I could smell it from across the kitchen!).  Tastes strongly of bitter chocolate and coffee.  Excellent, excellent beer.

Dark brown pour with a nice-sized tan head.  Aroma is roasty and creamy with some coffee detectable.  Flavor is a nice roasty-coffee-cream flavor with some bittersweet chocolate mixed in.  Nice bitterness - always a winner.  Still holds its own against most American craft-brewed porters.

May 2005 - Poured dark brown with a HUGE head. Complex aroma is readily detectable from just opening the bottle. Nice smooth mouthfeel maybe not as thick as Id like in a porter...but there is something to be said for smooth. The taste is complex, but had a metallic aftertaste that reminded me of copper that I wasnt overly fond of....but there is a lot going on in this one. Id have this one again, but it isnt up to the Taddy Porter quality (to piggyback off the last review)
Pours dark brown with dark brown head.  Aroma of chocolate and molasses.  Taste is the same, but not as sweet as youd think.  Amazing stuff!
