11.2oz bottle. Pours dark brown with small brown head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Taste of chocolate and lite coffee with lite bitter after taste.

Pours a nice deep caramel color with a little bit of a reddish tint to it. Small off-white head sits on top and settles to leave a nice layer of foam covering the brew. Some sticky lace is left on the walls of the glass. Touch of sweet malt in the nose. Bit of caramel to it and a hint of fruit. Smooth malty flavor. Nice bit of caramel to it and silky. Much richer then most English pale ales. Nice and filling.

this has one of the best textures of all the dark brews iv ever had, smooth and creamy is an understatement. this beer is not weak in flavour, its just very underlying, and not in your face, you have to sip it and notice the flavours, the after taste brings this up to a 9 in flavour for me, its not a bitter coffee aftertaste like most, but more of a khulula like smoothness.  almost perfect, id give it a higher overall rating, but i just find it a little over pricey.
Thrilled to find this on tap at the Thomas St Tavern in Charlotte.  Very nearly the perfect porter.  I had about 3 of these and could have gone on all night.
pretty nice brew.  good smooth body, has a nice little chocolate taste to it, a tad roast. Jet black colour.
Good, but way overrated. Initial roasted malt sweetness finishes with a slightly bitter chocolate flavor. Mild taste of hops in the flavor. Overall a good but boring beer.
beautiful bottle. Very dark colour, medium-sized head. Hints of roasted malt, malt and coffe, perhaps also bitter chocolate. Slightly hoppy. Full of flavour, really great!

500ml can Very interested in this one...pours to a small, tight tan head. Impenetrable black colour has my attention. Aroma is tons of chocolate and coffee, how can this not be something good! Mouthfeel is smooth, and the body  is far more substantial than I expected. Flavour is a delight - lots of coffee up front and chocolate in the back. Carbonation is a tad distracting, but Ill look past that. This is a great beer

Opaque with a fingers worth of head, a fine looking porter.  Roasted nutty chocolate scents, mocha/sugary aromas as well.  Fantastic raoasted malts and a creamy body make for a nice porter.  Sugars, light caramel, chocolatey malts are all present but there is a quiet hoppy presence which provides a subdued hoppy quality and nice balance to the beer.  Great mouthfeel, fine porter.

Bottle 500ml. Pours a black cherry colour with a good two finger tan head. Toffee and caramel scream out at you as soon as you open the bottle, along with sweet chocolaty hints. The taste is a complex blend of roasted coffee beans, black chocolate and dark molasses. Comes across in the mouth as creamy and full bodied and finishes on a bitter chocolate note. All in all, another winner from Fullers.
UPDATED: AUG 19, 2007 Dåse. Lækker duft af kaffe, med en anelse chokolade. Perfekt konsistens og føling for en porter. Alt i alt en super øl, og sjov at prøve på dåse.

Bottle. A very deep ruby red makes it look almost black, topped by a thin tan head.  The aroma alone sets this beer apart it is amazingly rich milky cappucino like if you were in a european coffee bar. Some hints of chocolate as a complimenting bonus. Flavor is strongly coffee with a smoky finish that coats the tongue. Very easy in the mouthfeel but I would like to find a beer with the same taste but with a thicker creamier character to make it just right.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2007 Re-rate 8/1/07. In the short time between my first and second rating of this beer, Ive come to realize that, while it is wondefully tasty and easy to drink, there are just so many other supremely complex and equally pleasing brews out there.  Im lowering the score sightly for now, with future revisits sure to come.   Original rating  8/4/9/5/18 = 4.4  Rated 7/12/07.  Color is a deep, dark mahogany.  Looks black until you hold it to the light, and then its true colors show.  Head is a nice 1" off white layer of foam.  The aroma is simple.........mocha.  Nothing more.  Nothing less.  The flavor is the same.  It literally tastes like a mocha milkshake.  This is, without a doubt, the smoothest, easiest drinking porter I have ever encountered to date.  I could drink this beer all day long.  Nothing complex, just a perfectly executed, smooth and creamy porter.  Awesome.

Tap at The White Horse, Parsons Green, 17th June 2007. Pours black as night, with very little head. Tastes of a wonderful rich mix of chocolatey malt and coffee with a hint of smoke and it has an aroma to match. The mouthfeel is perfect. This is a very good porter indeed.

[338-20070613] 500mL. Toasted chocolate malt aroma reminds me of fresh moorlands. Dark brown amber hued body with a long-lasting creamy foam light tan head. Tastes like toasted grainy bread dipped in light chocolate sauce with a hint of coffee. Medium-full body was expecting thicker but this is nice. Refreshing, very smooth.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2008 Pours a dark brown/black with small tan head.  Lots of coffee/nutty aroma with a bit of buttery toffee.  Flavor is nice and smokey with a big dark chocolate presence and notes of kahlua.   Mouthfeel is really nice- not too sticky, nor oily, nor particularly creamy, but more towards the creamy end of the spectrum.  Ive been looking forward to trying this one and am not disapointed in the least.
Bottle.  Pours very dark w/small head, aroma is coffee, taste is very rich w/bitterness.  Real good.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2007 Tap @ Gingerman; poured very dark brown/black with a light thin beige head.  Smell was great, and of dark fruitiness, dried fig, alcohol, and a definite mocha coffee smell.  Taste was rich, creamy, and coffee like, with bitterness in the back of the mouth, and mouthfeel was almost a bit oily, and nicely thick.

Pours black with a foamy beige head smells dark chocolate, kahlua, a rich coffee aroma, and some smoke.  Tastes nearly as good as it smells! considering it smells amazing. long lasting flavor, toffee, and the above listed fragrances, leaves the taste buds tingling a bit flat, some hops in the finish with a sharp citrus accent. a great beer.

From a 12oz Bottle.  Expiration date 06 November 2007.  Pours a deep brown, mostly transparent color with ruddy hues and a thick layer of foamy light beige head.  Aromas of lightly sweet malt, soft chocolates, and chewy toffee.  A touch of smokiness and a soft caramel malt presence.  Im getting some buttery diacetyl right away in the nose, which detracts unfortunately from an otherwise nice bouquet.  Light bodied, softly carbonated mouthfeel.  A nice gently toasted coffee maltiness immediately covers the tongue; gentle roast with a hint of earthy smoke.  More diacetyl becomes apparent on the back end of the palate, but not as pronounced as in the nose.  Minus the diacetyl, a pretty good brew, but nothing astounding.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2010 500 ml can. pours dark brown with off white head that stays with you the whole glass. smells of coffee, toffee, chocolate, and slight hops. tatses are the same. very well balanced with a great creamy mouthfeel. the best porter we stock at my lcbo.EDIT EDIT EDIT imo this is the best porter on the planet, id love to be proved wrong.

Bottle at Bier Garden Portsmouth VA. Dark brown pour, minimal head fades fast, some red hues. Malty aroma with notes of chocolate. bitter chocolate flavor, smooth and dry, easy drinking, dry bitter finish, Great brew.
Bottle.  Chocolate and coffee malt aroma - excellent.  Dark brown-black color with minimal head.  Creamy milk chocolate coffee flavor - light hops finish.  A great beer - excellent.

500 ml can: Almost a stout pour complete with cascade. Dark brown colour with thick tan head (almost looks like a Guinness). The nose is of coffee and a slight whiff of sweetness, perhaps chocolate. Complex flavours include coffee and chocolate. This is what the jokers at Mill St. were trying to create when they thought up a Coffee Porter. However, while this one hits the mark with balanced complexity, the Mill St. is dollar store knock-off vile. Not exactly a fan of the coffee flavour but it works in this beer.

Poors dark brown, almost black, with some yeloow head. Superb smell or coffee and burnt chocolate malts. Dark chocolate on the tongue and more burnt flavours, I couldnt help but keep my nose in the glass while I was drinking it. Really nice aftertaste as well. This bottle was much better than one I had tasted a few years back, which was too carbonated, this bottle was comparable with the brilliant cask version.
UPDATED: DEC 8, 2007 Bottle 0.5 l.  Dark and deep, clear red. Chocolate, coffee, bitter, but not too burnt. Pleasant, thick mouthfeel. Very nice, very nice.

Tasted 2007-04-01. Fresh bottle, 50cl. Black beer with light head. Aroma of smoke, roasted malt and a little coffee. A little too mild for my taste.  Taste not that powerfull either; Not exactly bad, but again too mild for me. some notes of chocolate. Its very drinkable, but not overly impressive.

Very nice... looks to have slight orange and ruby hues in a transparent black... nice sudsy tan head that lasts, leaves frothy lacing.  Some sours, caramel and cereal mix with a roasted chocolate in the bouquet.  This feels very creamy and goes down quite smooth.  Roasted coffee and bitter dark chocolate heavily coat the tongue and intermix the mouthfeel quite well.  The roasted bitter finish complements the pull perfectly.  Very solid.

Bottle. Ah, what a classic brew. This pours a cola-colored shade with reds apparent in the dark body. A little tan head sits on top for a bit. The nose is aggressively chewy with lots of toffee and roasted notes. The mouthfeel is nice and creamy with low carbonation and a silky palate. Roasted nuts, chocolate, earth, toffee, mocha all comprise the flavor. Its a great beer.

I have always loved this beer, with its warm and enticingly roasted aroma, reminds me of a tall Irish Coffee on a cold day.  Flavor is what is to be epected, roasted, slightly bitter, fat and rich.  One of my old stand bys.
Draught at Mesquito Bar and Grill. Deep black body with big creamy head. Aroma is of chocolate, roasted malt. Big roasty flavor, chocolate, very creamy. Smooth, very drinkable. Enjoyable.

Wow.  How did I miss this one?  From a small deli in the middle of Union Square in San Francisco this poured very dark, almost  black.  Big fat tan head, and good chunks of lacing.  Nose of chocolate coffee and a nice smooth mouthfeel.  Flavors again of chocolate and coffee, with a hint of vanilla.  Very nice slightly bitter finish. A simply outstanding porter.

Bottle dated best by 8/29/05; sometimes I forget to check. Pours a deep brown with ruby highlights and a rocky, tan, diminishing head. The aroma is of chocolate and coffee with a faint cardboard that fades away. (Ill chalk that up to its age.) The mouthfeel is medium-bodied and smooth with a light burnt coffee bitterness at the finish. The flavor follows the nose: chocolate and coffee with a creamy burnt coffee finish and a touch of sourness. A very clean and easy drinking porter. If its this good 2 years past its "best by" date, I owe it to my tongue to find a fresh bottle.

Appearance: Pours out a clear, translucent dark brown color with a frothy khaki-colored head that deflated rather abruptly leaving a ring of fine bubbles around the glass.

Smell: A fine, hearty scent of dark toffee, bittersweet chocolate, and rum raisin ice cream.

Taste: The taste is not nearly as profound as the aroma. Some chocolate, vaguely coffee-like flavors within. A delectable roasted sweetness permeates every sip. A hint of licorice and vanilla as well, no questions there. Finishes with a very mild hop bitterness.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied, with just the right amount of carbonation. Notably smooth and creamy.

Drinkability: Quite drinkable. I give Fullers London Porter a hearty "fine & dandy"!

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2007 Pours a very dark brown with some ruby highlights if held up to the light. Little head, and the aroma is mostly chocolate and coffee, more so chocolate. Taste is leaning more towards the coffee though. Very similar to a coffee or oatmeal stout in my opinion, but its very enjoyable and does not disappoint.
Lovely dark beer. Lots of interesting flavour and aroma. Highly recommended.
Very nice red look with a fine brown head. Aroma if sweet chocolate and loads of roasted malts. Flavor is again sweet chocolate with hint of rum and flowery hobs. Dry tasty finish.
Bottle; nose of coffee and chocolaye; clear brown with a small beige head;flavor of roastiness, coffee, chocolate, and nuts. Enjoyable Porter!

Bouteille de 500 ml achetée à la LCBO (Toronto, ONT). Arôme: Odeur de chocolat et de café. Apparence: La couleur est brune presque noire. Présence dun moyen col crémeux beige avec une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de chocolat et de malt rôtis. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement crémeuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de chocolat en arrière goût. (Rating #1049)
Aroma is just like hazelnut coffee .  Flavor is similar with a touch of vanilla creamer in it.  Superb.
Sweet malty toasted aroma-dark brown with tan head.  This beer is delicious, with flavors of roasted chocolate malt with creamy vanilla.  It is unbelievably smooth and a pleasure to drink!

Pours a dark brown colour with a frothy thick tan head. Aroma of chocolate malts, coffee, mild hops. Starts with a creamy chocolate and coffee taste. Finishing light to medium body with hop bitterness. Long lasting head and good lacing of the glass.

12oz bottle, served in my new stem glass. Pours a dark brown body with a small, quickly diminishing tan head. Aromas of malt, chocolate, coffee grounds, nuts, dark fruits. Fore is heavily astringent, with sweet malts, chocolate, coffee and nuts coming through on the back of the tongue. Finish is a bit light and watery, roasted coffee and some bitterness. A bit too thin for my tastes, but still pretty good.

1pt. .9oz bottle, $3.99.  Aroma is moderately malty with roasted coffee, chocolate and balance well with some hoppy notes.  Small, foamy, light brown, mostly diminishing head that left virtually no lace.  Dark brown body.  Flavor starts moderately bitter and a little sour then finishes almost heavy bitter with a short duration.  Palate is light to medium and watery flat.  Good roasted coffee flavor and really good nose but Im not that impressed.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2013 Keg (Kaisla, Helsinki) (8:5:9:4:15=4.1)
Sweet aroma through the thin tight creamy brown head, atop a black black thick body. Chocolate and coffee taste - ginger too. Well-balanced and full-bodied taste.
Rerate: 500ml can (Drink Shop, Tallinn) (7:4:7:4:14=3.5)
Lovely sweetish roasty aroma, cakey, and dripping with molasses. Very dark brown, small tight beige head. Nicely chocolatey, its nice to have that without the use of non-malts, almost worth an 8, but alas theres a slight metallic tinge to it. Nice roasty aspects without being burnt. Finish does go back to molasses again a bit. Still such a good beer, but the keg and the bottle are significantly better.
Bottled, Pours a dark brown with a nose of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Taste is much the same. A pretty good porter.
Bottle. Licorice and chocolate milk in the aroma. Malty sweet flavor with chocolate, coffee and licorice. Just a tad thin and onedimensional, but a delicious beer.
From bottle. Good porter. Aroma of coffee and roasted malt. Yellow-brownish head. Flavour and palate are very smooth. Tastes roasted malt, dark chocolate and black coffee.
Outstanding roasted malt aroma and taste. Medium body. Less hops than many US porters.
Very delicious, strong porter with a bold taste that goes well with heavy food.  Smoky and richly malty.  Strong enough to drink moderately, and easy enough to quaff in huge quantities.

Excellent beer! Aroma of coffe, caramel, toffe and a subtle nuts as well. Smooth coffe and chocolate taste, with mild caramel. Dark cola like appearence with little head very enjoyable and would drink every day if I could afford it/
Bottled 50cl. Pours redish brown with a brown head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee and smoked. Full body and strong taste. Taste is roasted malt, caramel, chocolate. Soft and silk mouthfeel
Dark colour with small shortlived head. Taste of chocolate and coffee. A very good porter!

chocolate & coffee, aroma with a hint of nuts so faint that you would swear a squirrell was the master brewer, small, thin head, wonderful malty taste and a nice bite, chocolate aftertaste too, very nice, very, buy this beer

Bottle. 11.2 fl. oz. Black beer with hints of red.  Small off white head. Malty, roasted coffee bean aroma.  Silky smooth palate with a satisfying finish. Subltly bitter flavor. I wish it had a higher abv%, but still pretty good.

500ml bottle. Deep ruby/brown colour - not that dark for a porter - with a generous beige head. The aroma was more restrained than I expected. Some cherryish fruit, touches of woody malt and a hint of chocolate. More chocolate on the palate with roast malt coming through more strongly. Fruit too - blackcurrant this time. The mouthfeel is a little sweet but theres also a vaguely sour, fruity edge. Seems to lack the depth of flavour and bite of the cask version. Pleasant drinking, but give me the cask any day.

Dark brown, almost black, with a dense head and lots of lacing. Malty aroma, with the typical porter coffee/chocolate/vanilla/toffee but also something salty (like hard water), very well rounded. The taste is full-bodied, somewhat sweet, with liqourice, vanilla, toffee, but also (again) peculiarily salty, and with some good roasty coffee/chocolate bitterness and a long lingering finish. Huge flavor. Mouthfeel is thick and dense, with low carbonation. Very large for a porter, and even though it is already smooth & full-bodied from the bottle, Id like to have this one on cask someday.

Bottle. Clear brown colour with large creamy off-white fully lasting head. Roasty aroma with chocolate, caramel and coffee. Very sweet flavor and sweet bitter aftertaste. Just a little too sweet for my taste.

500ml bottle. dark brown, almost black colour with a small beige head that dissapeared quickly. A roasty aroma of malt, along with coffee, and some chocolate and caramel. taste is really good, roasted malts, coffee and a hint of chocolate,. good texture and a nice slightly bitter aftertaste. this was my first porter and it will be hard to top.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2010 [4.13.07 old rating 8 / 4 / 9 / 4 / 19] Delicious...  very rich like cream whiskey.  Tastes of vanilla and coffee.  The malt doesnt taste burnt lke in other porters, very easy to drink.. [10.21.08 rerate  3 / 7 / 9 / 4 / 18] pours a clear rootbeer color with large soda bubble carbonation.   Aroma of roast, coffee and grassy hops.   This beer excels in balance, perfectly balanced roasted coffee, hops, and rich chocolate.  Dry coffee finish.   I love the mouthful, medium and creamy but light and drinkable. . . . . . . . .  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . [rerate 1.6.10] Bottle.  Pours a creamy dark brown with a tall thick frothy light tan head.  Nice creamy full aroma of roast, light grass, cream, hint of fruit, touch of butter, chocolate.  Flavor is great, robust, strong, bitter coffee, dark roast, creamy dark chocolate, nice light hop bite, very mocha like, some grassy complexity, rich alcohol chocolaty bite.  Medium bodied with a full thick mouth-feel, heavy and creamy but very drinkable, sizzling carbonation.  Great rich and bitter dark chocolate aftertaste.  

7.4.8.4.17

Bouteille. Arome de chocolat, de malt torréfié. Belle couleur brune-noire opaque, mince collet de mousse qui persiste, et qui colle un peu au verre. Goût de café, de torréfaction, et soutenu par une bonne amertume. Finale aussi soutenue, en torréfaction, amertume et un peu en alcool. Corps moyen à épais, effervescence légèrement trop forte. Bien équilibrée.

I opened the bottle of my 99th rating and admired the classic look of the beer.  The London Portor pours a dark rich brown, almost black color with a small light beige head.  There is a robust coffee aroma that fills the air and compliments the maltiness.  The head disappeared as quickly as it came, leaving a nice lacing on the English Pint glass.  This porter really coats your mouth and the chocolate and coffee flavors are a nice touch on the palate.  The beer finishes great, without a bitter aftertaste.  This is the best porter that I have tasted to date.
Very nice porter, finally availeble in Quebec at the SAQ. Pours a dark dark brown, nice coffee aroma. Tasty tasty beer. I will defenitly be stocking up on this wonderful brew
Very nice porter! This one was regularly available at the LCBO, so Ive enjoyed it many times. Pours dark brown, almost black. Has great roasty malts with notes of bitter chocolate and coffee.

12oz bottle.  Pours dark brown/light black with a tiny tan head that disappears immediately.  Aroma is roasted malts and sweet chocolate.  Grainy too.  Mouthfeel  is medium to full bodied with a nice creamy taste of chocolate and slight bitterness.  Extremely well balanced.  For some reason I did not have high expectations for this but was incredibly surprised.  This is definitely among the best couple porters Ive ever had.

Pours a transparent reddish dark brown with a small head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and some coffee. Flavour of roasted malt, coffee and bitter chocolate. Nice bit burned aftertaste with  coffe and bitter chocolate. So tasty indeed.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a light brown head. Roasty aroma with coffee & malt. Flavour is salty with liquorice and a faint tone of hops.
Pours a deep dark brown with a thick tan bubbly head. Aroma of roasted malt. Tastes rich, roasty, malty, choclate,creamy. Very Nice!
good beer chocolate coffee nice smoky taste that isnt overpowering but a lot going on but well balanced slight head disolves quickly enjoyed it and will buy it again.  cheers

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2008 Medium to small, off-white foamy head with dark almost black body. Nose is roasted malt and a bit of hops. Taste is coffee, chocolate, and smoke. Pretty good but this beer feels thin in the mouth and the taste seems a bit one dimensional. .

Pours black with a tan head.  Aroma is quite complex, initially with a typical chocolate/coffee smell, but yielding to a sweeter, caramel and oat smell with a bit of a grassy hop smell as well.  Taste is mildly bitter, and seems to lack a bit of the sweetness experienced in the aroma.  Carbonation is quite light, leaving a smooth, creamy mouthfeel.  There is also a bit of a warming sensation in the aftertaste as well.  Overall a nice porter which is a treat for beer tasters due to its complexity.

Black/brown with a nice, light brown head. The aroma has notes of licorice, chocolate and malt. the flavour has notes of coffee, smoke and a brief hint of licorice and a nice bitterness. Its a nice, traditional porter with bite, but I wouldnt mind a bit more complexity.
Dark black with tan head. Chocolate and coffee nose. Lots of deep flavors. Sweet with hints of alcohol. Round, full. Ill take my time with tjis pint.

Got some chocolate and roasted malt in the aroma.Pours dark brown with some red highlights and a medium tan head.Lots of roasted malt,chocolate and coffee in the flavor.Mouthfeel was medium with a smooth roasted finish.

(Bottle BB 01/12/07) Chocolate and roasted malty aroma. Red-brown colour and small, brownish, more or less fully diminishing head with fair lacing. Chocolate, licorice and roasted malty flavour. Creamy, slightly dry, softly carbonated and medium to full-bodied palate. Tasty brew! 26/03/07
Bottled. Full chocolate aroma, sweet and dark chocolate that is. Dark brown colour, with a small brown head. Taste full of chocolate with an appropriate amount of bitterness.
Bottle.  Pours dark brown with ruby red highlights.  Aroma is roasted malt and chocolate.  The flavor is a creamy blend of the finest chocolate and roasted coffee.  One of my favorite porters.

Pours a dark dark brown color, held  up to the light it becomes blood red, a fine beige head dissolves into a creamy, sticky thin layer. Big dark chocolate aroma. The flavor is of dark roast coffee and dark chocolate with notes of black licorice near the end, very very enjoyable. The palat is very good with very fine carbonation, and a finish that is just bitter enough to keep me comeing back, top notch.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2007 Bottle. Pours a dark black, with a strong aroma of coffee. Flavor is very rich, with aspects of coffee and chocolate. Tastes a bit burnt, but in a good way. One of my favorite porters.

Almost black. Tan head disappears quickly. Aroma has loads of coffee. Lovely. Rich flavor... coffee, hints of chocolate, roasted malt. Coffee remains in the finish. Light feel for a porter. Excellent brew, truly recommended.
Coffee and bitter chocolate fades into a bitter or IPA. I greatly enjoyed this porter. Balance is excellent!
Flavor is full and rich, very complex. Chocolate and coffee dominate. Relatively low bitterness.

Deep, coffee-black appearance with just a hint of translucency. Some roasted coffee on the nose but, overall, its surprising that this porter doesnt offer more of a first impression. Smooth palate coaxes you into the brew, with just the right amount of carbonation. Good, bitter flavours of coffee and firewood linger in the mouth, offering a pleasingly long, bitter finish. Not exactly a porter with presence, but still passes the grade.
I nice beer with a very strong taste with hints of coffee. Compared to the "normal" alcohol% at 5,4 it appears much stronger.

Tap. Dark brown in color with off white frothy head. Aromas of burnt malt coffee, grass and toffee. Taste starts off sweet and tart and ends slightly bittersweet. Medium in texture and oily on the palate, it has a pleasing soft carbonation.
Bottle.  Dark brown.  Rich.  Roasted malt aroma.  Chocolate / toffee flavor but subtle. Somewhere between dark and regular chocolate.  Not overly sweet, theres a little bitter in there. Just right.

Bottled.  The aroma is of cherries, dark chocolate, toffee, coffee and malty.  Classic porter appearance, dark with an brown head.  There is a good amount of lacing.  Coffee, caramel and some cherry/strawberry notes in the flavour which is very complex.  This beer has a very luxurious feel to it.  There is some hoppy bitterness in the finish.  This is a truly fantastic beer.
Cask or bottle. This beer is sex and in a glass for me. Had another just the other evening after arriving home from Barcelona. Think, rich chocolate flavour fills mind, body and soul.
Dark and rich. You will notice a hint of coffee and even toffee in the taste. Its easily one of the best beers Ive ever tasted.

A grand English porter that somehow rises above the ignominy of pasteurisation. Clear brown with a terrific head. Rich aroma of coffee cream chocolates and cocoa powder. Thick, phlegmy mouthfeel - lovely. Oodles of dark, lovely flavours - hazelnuts, coffee grounds, toffee, Cola. One of the few pasteurised English bottled beers worth the candle. (Bottle courtesy of Sully at the Sydney RateBeer Jan 07 gathering)

Sampled another Fullers brew. Nice chocolately aroma. Appearance is dark dark brown with a thin lacey head. Mouthfeel is smooth with a little bitter. Flavor is very hoppy and full of roasted chocolate.

This porter is on such a different realm than almost anything I have tasted! Thick blown (black/brown) pour with just a slight tan head with no lacing. What this beer lacks in appearance it clobbers the rest of the way home! Coffee and malt in the aroma. The taste is a chewy blend of cream, coffee and malt with a hint of chocolate. Imagine a coffee float with the same creamy mouthfeel. Wow! I need another. This is the best English beer I have had!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: BB 14 Oct 07 - 11.2oz - A light tan head, creamy in consistency, rises from the turbulent brown liquid.  This looks like a proper glass of porter.  Roasted malt predominates on nose.  The soft, smooth liquid gently awakens the taste buds, leaving a smooth coffee finish.
In my top 5 fav. Dark, rich, not too thick..  one of the best. I love the nutty/ coffee flavor.

The aroma is of toasted molasses. The head is light brown, creamy, with good lacing and mostly diminisihing. The body is black. Teh initial flavor is toasty, bitter hits the back of the tongue, leaves a roasted carmel coffe taste in the back of the mouth. The body is light, the texture watery with soft carbonation.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2008 Decent appearance.  Head kind of thin.  Mild fizzy carbonation bite.  This beers charm is in its malt character: toasty buttery maple/caramel.  Awesome.  Hop flavor is perfectly blended and unobtrusive.  There is a mild bitter aftertaste on the tongue.
Dark brown, smokey nutty aroma. Smooth with strong coffee aftertaste, a hint of the chocolate. Very nice.
I am never disappointed with Fullers.  This is a very enjoyable porter, rich, full bodied, with lots of coffee flavor.  Definitely one of my favorite porters.
Dark of color with a beige head. An aroma with tobacco liqurice and dark fruits. Sweet malty taste with hints of tobacco and liqurice.
2/17/07: Bottle. Sweet molasses nose with a touch of smoke.  Dark brown body.  Roasted coffee flavor with added hazelnut.  Warm, nutty, bitter finish.
pours a great black with off white head.  strong smell of coffee.  taste is all coffee. nice bitterness, a little thin for me.  good beer

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2007 bottle:  OK, I"m a huge fan of Fullers and really like beer, but dont really like porters.  This definitely is one of the better porters, but still has that awful sour taste & finish most porters do.  Great chocolate taste, but this doesnt do it for me.  It has chocolate overtones, but does that make a beer? (for Youngs Double Chocolate Stout it does). Theres some balance between sweet & bitter, but little too bitter, and sour like i said.  If you like porters, grab it.  Fullers has better beers than this.  Improves as it warms but not the creamy brew the label boasts, nor worthy of 99th percentile its getting here.

Bottle 1 pint .09 ounces. Not much head. Good aroma and a roasted coffee malt flavor and a creamy palate.   The flavors are balanced - good bitterness with good sweetness. This is the best porter Ive had.

This beer is a classic.  Pours a dark brown/black with a light greyish brown head.  Typical English beer with a notable creaminess in the nose and the palate.  This beer is not aggressive in any way, but its done the way an English porter should be done.
11.2oz bottle-pours a tan head and mahogany color.  Aroma is dark malt-chocolate.  Taste is sweet dark malt-chocolate/caramel, secondary hops.  OK carbonation.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2007 For flavor this beer is fantastic. 11.2 oz bottle poured a deep dark brown with almost no head, my one chief compaint. Aroma was malty with hints of choclate. Flavor was of choclate and burnt coffee beans, but burnt in a good way. Would of rated it a little higher but the lack of any type of head was disappointing. Judging by other ratings it might have been a bad pour or a flat bottle so I will have to try this one again.

Bottle (Sydney Summer Gathering 2007): At long last this legendary porter passes my way. I actually found myself surprised by its simplicity and elegance. Crystal clear dark ruby beneath a thick off-white head. Chocolate and shiraz dominate the bouquet with some roasty notes to back up. In the mouth, lots of toasty, roasty notes frame a very nice chocloate base that lingers. Very nice.
Black with small tan head. Coffee and chocolate aroma. Creamy flavor of coffee and chocolate. Smooth , pleasant.

NICE!

Not a bad thing about this brew. Porters are climbing up my favorites chart. This one pours almost pitch black brown. Has a nice dark tan head. Not quite as nosie as I like but still good. The taste and drinkability are bother really great. I will be buying wuite a few more of these.
Draught at Bishops Arms, Göteborg. Dark brown, with a creamy eige head. Medium bodied. Quite dry, with a roasty malt character with hints of coffee. Almost stout-like. Nice.

This is a straight up good dark beer. It has a great taste,full body with a nice after taste.If you want to turn your friends onto a good dark beer this is it. Reasonably priced full body, slick feel, average carbonation, long finish. Top notch dark.

Keg  Black beer; small ultrafine yellow-brown head. Roasted, freshly ground coffee, hint at stout sourness, lactic. Cold coffee, with a pinch of cacao and some "light"-sugar. In the finish, t would seem they added some coffee-cream as an afterthought. Dark roasted grains prominent. Medium bodied, grist slickness, carbon-texture. Some alcohol even. It does deliver in on the liveliness - makes one wonder how the cask might be. Shame on the WHOPG for holding that one back!

Rich caramel aroma. Dark deepish red with a frothy stained head. Smooth chocolate flavour, gives a rich warm feel. Smooth casual ale with a wood finish. Would have liked it to have a bit stronger flavour.
Very dark in colour, brown, deep, lacing of the head.  Smells of smoky overtones and chocolate.  Rich taste, again very chocolately, slightly bitter.

Im a big fand of Fullers.  This dark, rich  Porter only helps that cause.  This one pours a deep dark black with a nice tan head.  The first thing youll notice is a strong chocolate flavor but its not overwhelming, on the contrary its sweet yet the beer finishes with nice bitter aftertaste. One of my favorites.  Cheers!
bottle.  Sparing, diminishing off-white head.  Beautiful black body.  Sweet chocotate and malt aroma.  Toaste malt, coffee, and molasses flavor.  Great porter.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2008 Red-brown, tan foam.  Roasty aroma of caramel, rye, a little metal.  Very sweet and bready, some chocolate and coffee.  A bit mild but very good.  Could use a little more carbonation and body. Simple bittersweet dry finish.

Bottle. Translucent blood red body, small unremarkable head.  Delicious chocolate smell.  Bold coffee taste yet easy on your taste buds.  I can drink a lot of this.  Not overy sweet like so many "modern" porters.  Takes one flavor - burnt malt and runs with it.

Tan head with good lacing covers a dark brown beer. Aromas of Caramel, chocolate and malt on the nose. Well rounded balance in this beer. The Chocolate and Caramel sweetness works well with the hint of hops. Goes down so smooth. No heavy alcohol presence makes this easy to drink. Perfect Porter!

Poured to a deep, dark brown color, with medium thick tan head that lingered well and produced good lacing. Very pleasnt aroma of malty sweetness, roasted nuts, chocolate and toffee, all  which carried over well into the taste, where they were mixed just slightly with a hint of alcohol. Mouthfeel was nice and rich for this full bodied beer, which led to a long, smooth finish.

This beer was all it was said to be.

Pours a very deep brown color with a tan head.  The aroma is coffee and chocolate with malty overtones.  It tastes a little smooth at first and then finishes with a bitter coffee/herb flavor.  A very good porter.

Bottled. A deep mahogany with a tan head; aromas of bitter chocolate and roasted coffee; some sweetness initially, then a smooth and dry finish with chocolate and coffee mingling throughout. Warming and satisfying.
Aroma of toffee. Not much bite to it, which may be characteristic of the style. Porters not really my cup of tea, but somewhat enjoyable.

[Sampled at Carlsens in 2005.]  

A nice easy drinkable porter, which runs fast down eventhough its full of ingredients. Fruity coffeechocs in a creamy complex bitter way.

Pours black with red highlights around the edges, with a one inch tan head that fades to a swirling cap and leaves quite a lot of lace.

Smell; coffee and chocolate are the dominant aromas, along with a bit of toffee and licorice. Its sweet without being overpoweringly so.

Taste; The coffee and bittersweet chocolate come out first as with the smell, followed by the toffee and a bit of a toasted flavor, and in the finish theres a touch of black licorice. Theres very little bitterness to this beer. Mouthfeel is medium bodied and a bit dry, and so easy to drink.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Dark brown with very little head.  Tasty molasses smell.  The initial taste is of molasses, and turns a little chocolatey.  The beer feels thick and very smooth in the mouth.  The aftertaste is bitter for a moment and then disappears nicely.  It tastes very little of alcohol, and is one of my favorite beers.
Delicious. This is a full flavored porter. Tastes of chocolate and coffee. Mouth feel is smooth and creamy. One of the best porters out there.
Bottle.50cl. Good Porter but bit thin, chocolate, coffee, roasty, resin, butterscotch, brown, a minimal head, light sweetness, lightly bitter, soft carbonation, long finish.

Bottle said it was good until mid-Feb of 07.  This wasnt a good bottle.  I hope this was just a bad bottle, because I couldnt even finish this.  Some coffee and caramel flavor, but this bottle was either infected or old because as soon as this warmed up a bit I was struggling to drink it.  Strange funky bitterness to it.  Ill def. try this again if I see it on tap.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2008 Draught. Pours dark brown with a nice tan head. Aroma is raisins and roasted malt, with chocolate, coffee, and molasses. Flavor is a slightly sweet but robust porter, with most of the same components and a nice lingering finish. Very well made; recommended.

0.5 l bottle. Dark brown color with creamy tan head. Soft and roasted aroma with chocolade, licorice, tobacco, vanilla, fruity esters and raisins. Soft flavor of charcoal, chocolade, toffee and aromatic malt. Dryer and a bit watery finish with charcoal and coffee. Balanced, pleasant and complex brew.

1000th rater 1pt. .9oz. bottle, best before 26/FEB/06, my guess 2-3 year old bottle.  Pours black as night, with a small white head that turns into a nice thick ringed lacing. The contrast of such a dark beer (zero clarity) and such a white lacing is amazing.  I may be going crazy but the beer is so dark it may actually make the lacing look whiter.  Aroma is strong, nice roasty aroma, probably the best roastiness I have ever experienced.  Actually smells like a burning cig, not the nicotine part but just the part that burns the paper and some tabacco, oh its nice.  Also roasted peanuts.  Nice chocolate and a good caramel sweetness that is distinctively british malt but to its highest level.  Taste is starting to level off with some cardboard coming through b/c of oxidation.  Still plenty of sweetness, chocolate, and some roastiness.  I think this beer peaked about 6-8 months ago in flavor.  The body is starting to thin out as well.  Leaves a charred chocolate aftertaste, low on bitterness.  This is the best non-baltic porter I have ever had.  Will always stick by it.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: UPDATED: SEP 24, 2007 The color was a deep amber.  The head was fizzy and light brown, very thin.  The aroma was namely molasses and roast.  The flavor had a great balance between malt and hops.  There was a distinct roasty flavor.  The palate was full and carbonated.  The finish was slightly bitter.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2007 Second time Ive had this and I felt a re-rate was deserved. Pours a dark brown that allows some light. Looks thin on the pour but is more substantial in the glass. The aroma is sweet, herbal/earthy notes, milk chocolate, light coffee. The flavor is strong, bittersweet chocolate, herbal hop, smokey taste, strong caramel and unfermented sugars. The palate was average. I wasnt as impressed this time around. A solid brew but not amazing.
A smooth porter with coffee and chocolate tones.  Not my favorite porter, but I would have it again.
I love this beer. Very smooth, sweet, with lots of nice hoppiness contrasted by nice malts. Sweet and chocolatey as well as some coffee. Really really good stuff right here..
UPDATED: MAR 29, 2008 One of my all-time favorite beers, It has almost everything, creamy, nice head, all the tones of chocolate and coffee. mmmmm....Im getting thirsty

From the bottle. Yum.  Completely black hole with absolutely no head: some brown bubbles poking holes in the top of the beer but they fade quickly.  Aroma is caramel, toast, dark and strong coffee.  Taste is a rich chocolate bar, some dark roasted malt, a very slight bitterness from a small hop presence that manifests itself as that lovely early-morning coffee bitterness.  Mouthfeel sets this apart:  extremely creamy, little to no carbonation, full and round.
If you like the taste of coffee you will love this porter.  Barely carbinated.  Should not be served too cold.
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2007 Black. Strong chocolate taste. Dry at first when it hits the mouth. Pretty Good. Christmas present.

dark, smooth, easily drinkable porter. Well blended with a nice warm feel. Nice off-white head when poured, taste is a bit more crisp when drank cold but mellows as temp increases. Good all around brew.

Pour is a jet black with a thin tan head.  Aroma is minimal b/c this was served way to cold.  Some chocolate shows up.  Flavor makes up for it thought with a nice dose of coffe and chocolate with a nice roastyness to it.  Smooth and just the right amount of bitters.  Pretty tasty.

From a distinctive embossed Fullers 500 ml. bottle with a blurb and freshness date on the back label.

Poured a black coffee brown with a fluffy, foamy, bubbly topped tan head that settled into a thin bubbly lacing, minimal amount of sticking.

Aromas of chocolate laced coffee and caramelized malts, light fruity esters, hints of charcoal.

Good moderate carbonation and a malty crisp, creamy smooth medium bodied mouthfeel.

Delicious porter taste, roasted coffee with some burnt chocolate, caramelized sugary with a little butter toffee, a soft fruitiness, a charcoal flavor starts to emerge towards the end, and a sweett roasted malty, estery finish.

A great English Porter, tasty and balanced, I love drinking this during the winter months.
Bottle Dark pour with small head. Nice chocolate aroma with some roasted malts. Good rich roasted and chocolate flavor. Good balance with light hops. Great porter.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2008 Pours dark brown colour with a nice, large head, which settles down rather soon. Taste is malty, roasted, bready, with some coffeeish and toffeeish notes to bring some sweetness to it and mixed with dark chocolate. Aftertaste has some round bitterish bite. Alcohol is well hidden. Smooth and full bodied.

This was by far the best porter i have tried.  Not to sweet unlike some i have tried.  I have never had a porter like this one.  I thought I was drinking a sweet stout.  If you like chocolate /coffee  flavored beers you will like this one!

excellent!
aroma is full of coffee.
apperance is wonderful, very very dark ruby red. flavour is full of coffee, chocolate, and a nice sweet smokiness.
overall the best porter i have had.
One of my favorite beers of all time. Chocolate coffee caramel beer is the description I give my friends who are interested in trying it. All love it unless they dislike coffee.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2009 Bottle: Extremely dark-ruby coloured with a small creamy, tanned head; dry, robust roastmalty nose with an aroma of freshly ground coffee; light to medium bodied; dry moderate bitter flavour; fruity, chocolatey-bitter and coffeeish finish. A very rich and flavoursome, very well crafted Porter............ Re-rate (10/08), bottle sampled at the Counting House, City of London: It seems, that this gorgeous brew has become even better: very rich, very flavoursome, very smooth... A better Porter is hard to imagine!

Bottle, 51F. Pint. Rich, very rich malty aroma. great dark appearance witht a great tan head, tons of lacing throughout. Really, really good porter, not too sweet, not too creamy. Just a fantastic winter time brew. Cheers.
50cl bottle. Beautifully dark. Toasted malt, nutty, chocolate, coffee. Such a bloody smooth full bodied brew. A great example of what a porter should be. Highly recommended.

Tan head, very dark brown color, aroma of roasted chocolate. Taste is slightly bitter enhanced by a slight sweetness. Nice coffee notes in the body, some roast. Smooth, but finishes rather sweet and a bit thin.

bottle:...does NOT pour almost black...I dont know what Rynoplasty (below) is seeing...
It pours light amberbrown, and settles a dark clear amber.  Tastes like chocolate and mostly coffee.  Not a lot going on otherwise...creamy, nice palate, sexy bottle, might be good with a steak or burger.  Not my favorite porter....too bitter, not enough flavor.

Pours almost black, with a tad bit of red at the bottom you can see, but not much and with a little less than a finger of creamy head.  Aroma is of roasted malts, coffee and toffee.  Taste is all malty goodness with flavors of the roasted malts, chocolate and coffee flavors coming through.  Delicious stuff.

Drunk at home, 10/12/06. Not sure what to make of this. The head was a little thin, and the body was also a little brackish and oatty for my taste. However, the taste lingered in the mouth well. Not my cup of tea, but it is well worth drinking. One for cold nights around the fire.

After quite a few drinks...
Black w/ a reddish hue. The aroma is burned with chocolate and a faint port-like quality.
The same goes for the taste, but a slight bitterness rounds it off. Overall a nice and very drinkable porter.

500 mL bottle.  The colour of black cherries.    One finger of brown, bubbly head, which dissipates into a film after a few minutes.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate, and dust.  Taste of roasted malt, chocolate, and something a little more tart.  Cant put my finger on it.  Nicely balanced - not too sweet with bitterness in the finish.  Very smooth.  I often find Porters to be too sweet.  This one is great.

500ml bottle - Pours very dark brown with a moderate head.  It has a very good aroma of roasted malt, coffee, and a hint of chocolate.  The flavor profile matches the aroma and throws in a good hops balance.  Full bodied and smooth on the palate, this excellent porter finishes with some mild hops and lingering coffee flavor.

Bought @ Steilacoom Wine and Brew. This beer has got to be the English porter that all English porters wish they were! Long been a favorite porter of mine... Fullers is an inovative brewery, with the origination of the E.S.B. and their take on the porter. Thanks!
Everything balanced, Smooth,Rich,Creamy  With hints of coffee. I enjoyed this Porter

Aroma of well toasted malt.  Pours dark brown with good tan head that settles quickly.  Strong toasted malt blended with coffee and cherry flavors.  Rich and smooth with a hoppy bitter finish.  Love this beer.

Bottled, 500ml, pasteurised. Dark brown, ruby hue with tan head. Quite a smooth and silky beer, no rough edges, quite easy to sip away at. Initial husky coffee note with a touch of licorice and chocolate malt bitterness. Finishes a little sweet and slight, quite a decent porter overall, one to have again.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2007 Bottle.  Best before 29/AUG/05 on bottle, probably should have noticed that at the shop!  Pours deep red / brown color, nice light tan head.  Aroma is roast and licorice.  Taste is licorice and toasted malt.  Nice full, almost creamy body.  Really dry finish, with a touch of bitter.  Age on this one didnt seem to impact too much good or bad.
Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Black - brown head. Chokolate, roasted, burned, nice light hopped, light coffee, dry, smooth.

Bottle.  Maybe I dont have the palate for a porter, but to me, this tasted like a cold cup of coffee.  It poured black and had no head.  It looked like a flat cup of coke and tasted equally as bad.  I had to pour it down the sink.  Please dont let this discourage you from trying porters, but for me, its not my cup of tea.
Dark with a dense brownish head. Licorice, toasted malt, coffee. Flavour is licorice, toasted/burnt malt and tobacco. Pleassant bitterness.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2009 My little spot of heaven.  Pours dark brown with red highights.  Head is tan.  Aroma is of coffee, chocolate, toffee and maybe a little bit of hops.  Flavor is terrific swirl of coffee, chocolate and roasted malt.  Not overly heavy, just good flavors.  Finish is a little bitter but still retains sweetness.

500 mL bottle from LCBO.  App.: deep, reddish copper, fairly full med. tan-reddish head.  Aroma: (cold) milk chocolate and vanilla, a bit of coffee, sweetness, a vinous note.  (warmer)
Palate: med.-full body and med carbonation.  Flavour:  lots of dark roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, a bit of acidity and a solid bitter finish.  A faint hint of apples, maybe.

pours dark with a nice two finger tan head. light to medium body with a nice little bit of lacing. aroma is roasted malt with a little hops, chocolate, and coffee. flavor is some hops mixed in with roasted malt, coffee, and a little chocolate. kind of has a coco bean and coffee aftertaste as well. pretty smooth though a very nice porter one of the best.
good porter taste.  it has been a long time since i have had it and now am deciding to rate
UPDATED: APR 21, 2007 Creamy, smokey, toasty. Well ballanced with nice mouthfeel through the finish. One of the best porters Ive had.
This is a fantastic beer. Dark. Mysterious. Malty, sweet with a hoppy covering and a silky smooth finish. Current fav beer.

This beer is a LOT better on tap.  When the UCI pub existed, I got this beer a lot.  Since then I have only had bottles, and they dont have near the character that the keg has.  Delicious porter nonetheless, with smooth flavors of coffee and chocolate.

11.2oz bottle. Pours dark with a tan head. Aroma of spice and coffee. Taste of coffee, chocolate and butterscotch. Palate is thin but not in a bad way. An atypical porter experience for me, but a good one.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2007 Bottle. Salty and spicy sausage noticable in the soft, smokey, slightly coffeeish aroma. Little tan head over a reddish black, but thin looking, body.

Surprisingly thin in the mouth and especially with regards to the splendid aroma.

Easy, nice, refreshing session porter. Id try drinking this all night.

Re-rate 2nd August 2007: On my second one tonight and it does deserve a better rating than I gave it. Thinner than many a big porter Ive had, it is still very pleasant and doesnt shy away from bitter chocolates. Im so happy to be able to buy this locally now.

Pint+ bottle; pours dark brown/black with moderate tan head that dissipates into thin line, good lacing.  Strong aroma of toasted/roasted malts and coffee.  Comfortable taste with darkly roasted malt, more coffee and just a bit of chocolate.  Nice porter!

The worlds favourite porter.. rich and dark.. compelling words. This deep, dark crimson beauty delivers a malty aroma of epic proportion- baked bread, toasted grains, molasses, and oak. Lovely smell, quite powerful. Toasted malt dominates the flavor along with a subtle molasses sweetness and a hint of coffee. Dry and creamy, medium body. Finish is bitter then slightly-sweet as the molasses and coffee notes linger. While this is not my favorite porter, it is indeed a rich and quite quaffable brew.
great porter. It has a dark, brown pour with a tan head. It has a creamy taste of malt and coffee. This is my porter go to beer. You can not go wrong with a Porter of any kind.

50 cl bottle, Shelburne. Dark black colour, no head, cola=like visually. Burnt malty aroma, slightly fizzy, malt comes through in the flavor with some black cherry, chocolate and nice bitterness at the end. Good standard, although some more interesting porters out there.

Pours a rich dark (somewhat think) coffe brown. Medium tan head. Definite coffee and dark chocolate on the tongue and nose. Slight peat. Its a little creamy on the tongue, and just slightly biiter (although an after effect from the coffe roast flavor) in aftertaste. Generally a pretty well-balanced porter and definitely something pleasant to drink (and drink again). (Bottle Pour 11/2/2006)

massively mild aroma, with smoked salami and sweet coffee. Taste is massive on the tongue, smoked meat everywhere. This has a big palate considering the abv, a well made ale but there is something that tells me I could not drink many of these. Very good noneoftheless.....

Black w/ red tints way down low and thin, quickly dissolving tan head. Aromas of alcohol and chocolate, slightly fruity. Rich, lucious chocolate flavor with a brightness and balanced palate. Very fine w/ subtle complexities.
Body, black.  Coffe malts mild  to strong.  Palate was medium to full body.  Very nice porter one of the best that I have had.

Fullers London Porter
English pint bottle
Best before 02/07, filled up on 11/06
Medium pour in an English pint.

Poured a clear deep dark mahogony brown with a large frothy somewhat lasting light brown head with fair lacing.

Smelt strongly of molasses, coffee, roast, mild chocolate.

Taste was upfront moderate bittersweet dark chocolate with molasses and coffee tones followed by a strong burnt malt bitterness that turns into a clean crisp long bitter coffee finish.  Mouthfeel was medium bodied, oily, lively carbonated, with moderate astringency.

Overall, a classic.  Drinkable, plenty of taste, well balanced.  Just straightforward excellent porter taste.  One of the easiest porters to enjoy out there.
Pours dark brown color, with small brown/tan head that diminishes, but lasts .  Lasting flavor of toffee, chocolate, and coffee.  Rich in flavor, great beer.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2008 A longtime favourite. Pours a brownish black with a small brown head. Heavenly aromas of dark chocolate and coffee. Incredibly rich crystal and amber malting, chocolate and creamy coffee abound. Complex, dark, creamy, satisfying. Good carbonation, doesnt get in the way of the excellent smooth texture and soft mouthfeel. I have yet to taste a beer to match Fullers London Porter.

Edit: Damn you Bells Expedition!
This porter poured out a dark-cola looking with a small,quickly dissappearing head.It has a nice malty aroma and the taste is of chocolate and coffee,as well as malts.A good one.

One of the grandfathers of all porters.  Exactly what a porter should be and perfect for those new to what a porter should taste like.  Definately try this one first before moving on to the more aggressive and experiemental forms of porter.  Great use of hops to help balance the malt characteristics.  Nice roasted aroma and a smooth mouthfeel.  Does not hold up to extended aging at all as I found out with a couple bottles I laid down for a year.  I thought I tried, but before its reached that point, it was a wonderful session brew one can drink all night long.

It poured the color of dark stained oak planks with a tan head. Full rich aroma of chocolate and black patent malts, toffee and hints of French roast coffee beans. The taste is fresh black patent and chocolate malts that hit right up front and become richer as the experience progresses. About midway some molasses and toffee surface to give the chocolate malts more depth. It finishes with a pleasing rich maltiness.

From the bottle, pours a black with a thick foamy off-white head with nice lacing.  Smells strongly of coffee beans and chocolate, with some alcohol in there as well.  Tastes strongly of coffee, porter-chocolate, and alcohol.  Bitter as well, I cant say this is the best porter Ive ever had.
Tastes of roasted coffee and a deep, earthy flavor. There is a redolence of coffee.  Very smooth and comfortable.  A great beer.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2007 Bottle:
Deep red clear colour, with a creamy head.
Aroma is hopy, dark chocolate, coffee. and Wood. Malty .
Flavor is coffee, dark chocolate, dry,
toffe and wood. Medium body and a nice medium finish. Nice.
caramel, coffee, roasty, leather, medium bitterness, full body, creamy, lively, bitter,

(500 ml bottle (best by 7/30/06) from Kappys (MA)) A classic...Pours very dark coffee brown with two fingers of gorgeous tan head. Aroma is rich strong coffee and, a little deeper, sweet chocolate. Palate is exquisitely smooth and silky and the head is creamy and soft. Nice lacing. Flavor is rich coffee and lightly sweet chocolate with hints of fruitiness, cherry perhaps. Light bitterness overlays. A masterpiece of the style, Id say.
Bottle. Pitch dark colour with a creamy thick head. Aroma was smoked, rich chocolate and coffee. Medium body. Flavour was slightly bitter. Slightly bitter finish.
is one of the basic originals to learn on, choc aroma, with some slight coffee, nice not over powering, some biterness

Near black with some red highlights.  Decent size tan head.  Aroma of rich chocolate, coffee and dark fruit.  Flavors similar to the aroma, with a more pronounced coffee taste.  Pleasant, slightly bitter finish.  Very nice.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2006 Poured a dark brown, almost black with a decent size frothy off-white head.  Rich flavour of coffee, chocolate, licourice, toffee, caramel. Amazing finish and mouthfeel. Rightfully positioned at the top of its class. Next trip to the LCBO I will be buying more of these.

Two 500ml bottles shared with CatweazleTroms and Finn at The Dove Street Inn, Ipswich. Last beer in Ipswich before travelling on to Norwich. Medium off-white head over a very dark red-tinged body. Very nice "Kirchenfenster" on the glass. Aroma of dark fruit and chocolate. Solid mocha, cocoa and dark chocolate taste. Finish off with tasty coffee bitterness. Full bodied, but still very refreshing (23.09.2006).

Draught @ beerbistro: Just when I was about to give up and buy a bottle I finally find it on tap and taste it how Ive been wanting to.  Pours pitch black with a good off-white head.  Rich aroma heavy in licorice, mocha, caramel, and coffee.  All those promises come through in the flavour, with emphasis on the coffee and licorice.  Its both simple and complex at the same time, a blend of a few flavours done very well and balanced almost perfectly.  Loved it.

500mL bottle from the LCBO.  Pours black, reddish edges.  Nice head, not too fluffy or large.  Tastes wonderful - plenty of coffee and chocolate, excellent mouthfeel.  Not over-carbonated, not over-strong.  Excellent.  Try it if you find St. Ambroises Oatmeal Stout too espresso-esque.

Bottle, Mild horseblanket aroma with molasses and malt.  Deep dark reddish black.  Tan frothy diminishing head.  Flavor is balanced towards bitter.  Espresso and dark chocolate style, slightly sweet with a bitter finish.  Alcohol not present in the flavor. Good lasting flavor.  Definitely bitter but balanced, not overly hopped.  Very good overall.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2006 500 ml bottle - pours a dark, dark brown; looks black, but when you hold it to the light, it is not quite - reddish/amber accents at the edges and in the bottom of the glass.  Nice.  Tan head fades fairly quickly to a small surface layer, leaving thick lacing the whole way down the glass.  Aroma perfectly balanced - just the right amounts of coffee, chocolate, dark fruits and roasted malt.  Taste is much the same.  Excellent finish with the sweet malt and some bitterness mingling.  Ultra smooth; seems almost like a sweet stout.  The alcohol is hidden well.  The perfect beer after a long bicycle ride on a cool, crisp autumn night.
Bottle 0,5l. Deep, deep red coloured. A creamy head. Rich aroma of chocolate. Complex flavour: Roastedness, caramel and chocolate. A long pleasant finish with fruity notes.

Practically black with red rim. Aroma is burnt with coffee and some liquirice. Some dark chocolate, coffee and burnt flavours enhance the aroma. Not as fullbodied as youd expect but the taste stays with you for some time..

500ml bottle. Pours black with ruby highlights and an initial tan head. Immediate coffee aroma is quite strong and the flavour carries that on beautifully, layering it with the taste of dark chocolate. This is a rich, wonderful porter, quite close to a stout, with a nice sweet fruity note in the finish. And man is this beer smooth! Yes guy!
Aroma is sweet of chocolate and roasted malts.  Appearance is dark chocolate brown.  smooth and easy to drink with chocolate and carmel flavor. It also has a dry roast coffee flavor.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2011 Deep dark ruby colour. Excellent aroma and flavour with lots of chocolate and roasted malts. Taste starts with sweet cream, then grows more complex adding a variety of chocolate flavors (sweet, milk & bittersweet), then roastiness and coffee. Aftertaste is also delectable with more chocolate, coffee, pit fruits.

Without a doubt a top contender to the crown of beers.  Chocolatey flavour, well complemented by a rich consistancy.  Overall great appearance, flavour and bouquet.  Pours a dauk ebony color with a thick frothy head.  Complex, yet easily appreciable by anyone.
The chrons of beer. Chocolate aroma is pleasent to the nose. Taste like a slice of heaven in a bottle.

Aromas of dark chocolate, a little vanilla, bread, discreat smoky vanilla.  Beautifull tanned head, fantastic looking beer.  Creamy feel with flavors of bitter chocolate, butterscoth.  Very nice balanced porter... i suggest this beer with a nice little sweet desert...

Beautiful mahogany-colour. The head isnt very dense, and it dissapears quickly - it makes the appearance 3 instead of 4. The aroma is sweet and malty with notes of liqourice and coffee, but it is not impressively distinct. It is a quite thin porter - too thin, I think! However, the coffee / liquorice taste with a little smoke saves the overall points. Sweet and carefully smoked aftertaste with medium powerful hops.

Bottle. Pours like black coffee with a small tan head. Super chocolatey nose with a hint of plums, which is present in the flavor though not as much as the smooth coffee-like taste. Ends on slightly bitter coffee note (much like a good cup of properly roasted, freshly ground black coffee), leaving a similar aftertaste with some very mild astringency. A pretty stout-like porter actually. Pleasant, great fall drinking.

Bottle. This is one of the finer porters I have encountered over the previous two years. This delight is suffciently complex to pass as a stout. Upon consumption, one immediately notes a distinct flavor of dark roasted coffee. There exists a burnt chocolate taste as well, which is superceded by the coffee. One would be flawed in noting that particular flavor as "smokey." While the color and flavor of the beer are not unlike that of a stout, the aroma somewhat lacks. One can sense the coffee, however, the beer must warm to nearly fifty five degrees before any smell is readily detected. My chief regret is that I have not sampled this on tap yet.
smells just like coffee.. yummy. from bottle, very dark color with a thin tan head on it. really enjoyed it.
Fullers. One of my favorite breweries. I got Fullers London Porter in a bottle. Black colour and a full body. It had a nice burned taste of coffee. Great head.
One of the best Porters ever.  Great flavor, full bodied, and a super taste.
Bottle 1 Pint + 0.9 Pours out a nice Black topped with a great tan head. There is a nice burnt and coffee. Very nice Porter
Superb. Rich taste of chococlate and burnt toast, really good. Pours very dark brown with smallish head.
Dark brown with a small tan head. Sweet chocolate, roast, smoke, coffee. Medium body with a nicely balanced finish.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2014 First rating, from - Initial Rating Date: 9/10/2006 2:52:34 PM
Draught at The Rover Clear dark brown to black color, tan to beige head. Sweet and a bit roasted scent. Thick nice smooth mouth feel. Sweet taste, a bit dry. Roasted.7/4/7/4/15=3.7RerateHad this beers many many times over, though not rerated it it seems. Draught at Bishops Arms Järntorget, on July 29, 2012Black color, tan head. Nice sweet smooth roasted aroma and taste. Smooth full mouthfeel, nice balanced bitterness. Super nice and a beer I can and will go back to over and over just for drinking a nice beer.8/4/8/4/17=4.1Rerate50 cl can from Systembolaget in Ludvika, sampled on September 12, 2013.So nice, black, creamy, smooth. Gives you body, balance, malt, roasted notes. A classic nice highly drinkable porter to just enjoy again and again. Works chilled, works cold, works room temp. Something Iwill keep coming back to for sure!8/4/8/4/17=4.1Rerate500 ml can from Systembolaget in Ludvika, sampled on April 23, 2014. BB 28.02.15.Clear, dark, reddish brown color, teal to tan head. Sweet, fruity, malty, chocolate, apricots scent. Sweet, salty, light roasted, grainy, chocolate taste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bitterness.8/5/9/4/18=4.4

From bottle.  Pours a deep mahogany with dark tan head.  Nose is roasted barley.  Flavor is dark, bitter malt.  Palate is a little thin.  This is a solid porter, but didnt find it breaking any boundaries.
12 oz bottle. Dark brown with a tan head. Nutty, chocolate nose, some light coffee notes. Mildly bitter flavors, more dry chocolate. A bit of charcoal in the finish. Solid.

Bottle.  Nearly opaque dark brown with a medium sized light tan head.  Rich chocolate and caramel aromatics.  Cocoa and coffee bean bitterness over a caramel and semi-sweet chocolate sweetness.  Faint bitter astringency with residual sweetness in the finish.  Mouthfeel is a light medium, fades to a slight dryness.

Bottle
darkest head, predominate sweetness, yet still lets you know its a serious beer.
Gentle on the mouth, coffee, carramel, alcohol, in the background.
goes so well with lamb, its uncanny.

Pretty dark brown with offwhite mostly diminishing head. Lots of cask wood in the aroma followed up by some burnt malt and some spice (cinnamon?). On the palate it feels smooth and creamy, but this is exactly its weakness. The promised spicieness is dominated by the heavy cask wood and the maltiness. In despite of the fairly long finish, it seems not really balanced.

Absolutely magnificent looking in the glass, almost black, but just light enough to see that it is crystal clear. Head is off-white, creamy with excellent retention and good lacing. Aroma of whiskey, vanilla, chocolate and dates, and some earthy tones too. The mouthful is so smooth, again with chocolate, brown sugar, crystal malt sweetness and some delightful fuggles flavours. The body feels very thick and full, almost like there are some oats in there. The finish gives some alcohol, roast and hop bitterness, medium lasting... but ultimately very clean. A remarkable beer.
[bottle from Hacket] Roasted coffee aroma, soem fruit, medium body, bitter dark chocolate finish.

Aroma: Liquorice, burnt, dark syrup, molasses, cacao, cocanut?, coconut, malt. Appearance: redblack, clear but near opaque, beigebrowntinted white head. Flavor: sweet, bitter, burnt (like wood), full-bodied, fantastic. Palate: pretty good, some stickyness, full-bodied, smooth.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2006 Bottle. Pours a very dark violet/burgundy, almost black, with orange at the edges. Head was almost non-existant. Beautiful aroma of burnt coffee and dark chocolate. The taste is almost all burnt coffee which provided a bitter finish, with the chocolate that was very present in the aroma being almost undetectable. I am not a very big fan of the coffee taste of porters and stouts, and this was no different for me, but this is the closest I will come to enjoying one. Mouthfeel is full but thins out in the finish. If you like porters and stouts, this is THE beer for you... but not for me.

Rich and Dark, true to the labelling. Im not sure why this isnt a smoked porter, perhaps its unintentional. It tastes almost woodsy. This porter has head unlike most-- it blocks up my tongue like I just drank something thicker. Overall, a great bear, worth the price. Its got great aroma, flavor, and aftertaste.

1 Pint, 0.9 oz Bottle: Black as an eclipse with a tan head and sticky lacing.  The aroma is tangy, almost metallic, with burnt nuts and soft chocolate.  The taste is similar with burn flavors, charcoal, and rich chocolate.  It has a full feel followed by a thin finish.  The aftertaste is bitter coffee grounds - quite wonderful!

Bottle. Pours dark red/brown with a thick, fluffy beige/brown head. Great, strong aroma; sweet, creamy and roasted with notes of chocolate. Bitter and sweetish flavour with roasted notes. Finish is bitter with strong notes of coffee and a dry end. Slight notes of apple which feels a bit interfering. Could use a more soft body, possibly by less carbonation. 25-08-06.

Pours black, with a touch of redness in the light with a medium slight off white head.  Aroma is a touch small, but with a nice roasted malt, bit of chocalate malt, small amount of coffee.  Flavor is dominated by the roasted malt, with a nice level of bitterness in the finish.  Hops dont really add much flavor outside of bittering.  Mouthfeel is very dry.

Bottle. Pours a pale tan head that lasts till the end with clingy Belgian lace. Deep dark brown but not black - very pretty beer. Surprisingly has a significant coffe aroma and flavour, boarding on a dry stout but excellent marriage with roasted chocolate malt. Subdued hops typical of British interpretation. Bitterness from both hops and dark malts. Wonderful example of a robust porter.

Wow!!Great aroma!!smeeled very inviting.Malty,chocolate,cofee.Nice thick lasing head.Not too big.Just right.The color was a very dark brown,almost black.It tasted of chocolate,cofee,rich.This was almost a perfect beer.The only think I took points off for were the body was a tad light.Just a click light.What a great beer!!I am off to buy a six-pack!!

A very good porter with a compex taste including sweet maltiness combined with som hoppiness. Full bodied with both coffe and chocolate notes. A perfect drink  that goes verry well together with dark chocolate !

Near perfect beer for me.  Poured a very dark beer.  Had a very good porter smell with chocolate and coffee.  It had a great roasted taste with a undertone of coffee and caramel.  All the flavors were soooo well mixed.   GREAT GREAT BEER

Ah...deep, rich, chocolately malt sliding across your tastebuds. Alchohol and cream coming in behind that to wake you up and teach you what a porters all about. Anyone who drinks this be warned: youre going to turn your back on helles brews afterwards!
Yuck!  Too much alcohol aroma and taste.  No distinct flavor to capture the palate.  Not memorable.  And  no need to repeat.  British beers tend to disappoint.

Pours a pitch black with a minimal tan head.  Aroma is big malt notes, chocolate, coffee, raisins, and a roasty goodness.  Taste is chocolate again with a small coffee note, toffee, caramel, big malts and nice hop texture.  Palate is slightly sticky, carbonated, slightly bitter.  OVerall, This is a damn good porter, probably one of the best that Ive had in a long time.  Good Brew!
Bottle. Dark brown with a dark beige head. Very malty aroma with dark chocolate notes. A little caramel sweetness in the taste, followed by roasted coffee and medium bitterness at the end.

Looks very nice. Very black, creamy head. Taste is very thick and heavy. Not that sweet at first, which is good. A little too much cofee flavors, but I get some chocolate as well. A little thick so one at a time.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2009 Almost black body (very dark brown) with some red highlights and a medium creamy off-white head.  Some smoke and black liquorice on the nose.  Viscous body.  Taste is vinous, sweet, molasses and some roasted coffee beans.  There is also lots of tobacco flavour in there that paves the way for a dry herbal finish.  Soft carbonation.  Fuller is for how I want my London Porter glass.

bottle.  Aroma:  Lots of roasted malt aroma, with a healthy dose of chocolate.  Intense toffee aroma.  Smells delicious!  Appearance:  Dark brown, with some garnet highlights.  Light tan head was full and creamy looking and diminished into a nice cap.  Good lacing.  Flavor:  Nice roastiness with touches of chocolate, toffee, and coffee.  Some toasted nut also comes through.  Flavors are good, and they all work together, but was hoping for a little more punch.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Medium carboantion.  A little astringency detected.  Overall:  A good example of the English style of porters.  A good beer, but I was hoping for a little more developed flavor.  Worth seeking out.

Poured a amber, dark black with a thick tan head.  Aroma consisted of chocolate, coffee.  Roasted malt was definately evident in the flavors along with some choclate and mild coffee and caramel.  This was the most BALANCED beer ive ever tasted, just perfect our of a glass from Munich.
UPDATED: DEC 3, 2006   This is a great porter! Tastes of chocolate  and roasted cofee. Probably the best Porter I have ever had.

Bottle courtesy of Ross. Two months past the best before date. Dumping your old beers on me Ross?  Pours coffee black with a nice thick khaki head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, and english yeast esters. Not much carbonation, and with a somewhat thin texture. Flavor of dark roasted malt, mild coffee, with some hints of caramel nicely balanced by the Fuggle hops. Nice little burst of bakers chocolate before the mildly bitter and earthy finish. Some brown ale flavors are hiding behind that dark roast also. This is a British good porter. Full of flavor, easy to drink, not to aggressive or thick.....I like!

A bit light in color and body, this porter does nothing to break the mold, but exemplifies it. A simple malty character that screams of coffee flavors and a little bitterness add up to a well constructed and pleasant drink.
UPDATED: APR 18, 2007 Pours black with light brown head.  Smokey chocolate aroma.  Coffee, chocolate, and roasted flavors, with some fruit.  Very good smokey flavors and smooth.

The Fullers Porter pours a rich black color with a very nice tan head that stays around quite some time and leaves significant lacing. All I got in the aroma was coffee and lots of it. The taste was also very strong of coffee--with a nice taste of bitterness mixed in there as well. The finish was tasty, and definitely sticks around that palate for awhile. Overall a very good porter."

Bottle picked up at Waitrose, Witney. Aroma is chocolate, chocolate and more chocolate great aroma. Poured black with light beige head, wonderful  smooth taste with great roasted coffee, chocolate and malts all vying for attention this is a very, very good porter that I have had before but forgotten about. I am so glad that I have tried it again this is so moreish.

Pours very dark almost blank, tan head. Aroma is quite pleasant, roasted malt and milk chocolate.  Flavor is coffee, bittersweet chocolate, sweet malt, and some vanilla.  Nice creamy body. Complex yet drinkable. Good stuff.
Wow!  This is by far the best Porter Ive ever had.  Very smooth and complex tastes.  Borderline stoutish brew that brings it home.  Highly drinkable and recommended.

Bottle is a little past drink by (April 06). Aroma is roasted malt and milk chocolate. Small head, with slight carbonation (which I think is a plus in a porter). Flavor is big time chocolate, a bit of coffee, some vanilla, some caramel. Finish is creamy and extremely well balanced with bittering hops and a bit of sourness. This is the bar by which I measure other porters.

Bottle, pours black with a light almond head. Nice lace. Ive had stronger porters but this wasnt bad being I was drinking it outside.(Its hot, I always enjoyed a porter or stout more in the winter.) Aroma is very choclate. Taste has the same with a mix of carmel and hops, the finish is all choclate which is my favortie part about this brew. Not my favorite porter but a good one none the less.

pours from the bottle a vcery dark brown with thin, quickly rousable, and lacy oatmeal colored head.  Aromas include roasted malt, coffee (almost kahlua like), with some carmel malt, and something like those Reisin candies.  Just a touch of spice and smoke round this one out nicely.  Hoppier than i expected from an English porter, with a chewy chocolate characteristic, with carmel malt, oatmeal, molasses, and light roast coffee, much like a breakfast blend.    A touch light on the palate, thin and perfect carbonation, but overall very good.

Pours black with light brown head, not much retention. Aroma is mainly of chocolate malt roastyness and gingersnap cookie. Creamy body, flavor was smooth upfront roasty chocolate malt. Nice toasted mocha flavors with an espresso like finish. Drinkable and quality porter.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2006 Bottle. Pint.  Best before 09/Sep/06. Poured a dark rich smokey brown with a fair size tan head that diminished rather quickly with minimal lacing. Taste of roasted hops and coffee very present with a slight bitterness that quickly disappears. A very nice Porter that I will certainly recommend.

Brown bottle, 500 ml, best before date: 24/12/05; eye: black with ruby reflections, nice beige head that falls too rapidly, lacing; nose: roasted malt, black chocolate, and a third unknown scent; mouth: quite smooth almost velvety, quite smooth at the start, then appears the bitterness and the roasted malt, finale where the roasted malt takes over with a hint of vanilla at the very end, the flavors increase in intensity within a given sip, lightly sweet, mildly bitter, full in the mouth, creamy texture, good and nice carbonation, lightly astringent; overall: quite nice even on a warm day after working in the backyard by a 30˚C temperature

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, meilleure avant : 24/12/05; oeil : noire avec des reflets rubis, belle mousse beige mais qui tombe assez rapidement, dentelle; nez : malt torréfié, chocolat noir, une troisième odeur qui mest inconnue; bouche : très douce, velouté même, tout en douceur au début, puis apparaît lamertume et la torréfaction, finale où le côté torréfaction prend le dessus avec à la toute fin une pointe de vanille, les saveurs montent en intensité du début à la fin de la gorgée, légèrment sucrée, moyennement amère, pleine en bouche, texture crémeuse, bonne carbonatation, légère astringence; en résumé : très bonne même après avoir travaillé dans la cour par une chaleur de 30 ˚C
UPDATED: AUG 11, 2007 Excelent Porter, very deep color and flavor, drinks out of the bottle just as well as a glass with a clean taste s it goes down
On Tap.  Super dark with a thin white head.      Strong bittersweet/dark chocolate aroma with heavy espresso notes.  Flavor is dry and hoppy with a smooth bitter finish.  Very nice.

Best bottle ive seen. Pours completly flat but the light carbonation goes with the roasty chocolate and coffe. Very silky and full flavor. Im not a Porter fan but this is a classic. Best ive ever tried in its class
While I am not usually a proter fan, I have to give the Fullers an A+.  It has a beautiful aroma of chocolate and coffee.  A very smooth taste and creamy head.

Bottle (Waitrose): Nice deep black with a long lasting light brown head. Strong aroma of chocolate, with some gentle roasty coffee like notes. Quite sweet in the start, with choc and toffee notes. Finishes dry and roast. Refreshing, moreish and simply a good damn beer.
