Best before December 15, 2006. Black. Modest, frothy, tan cap. Nose of toasted malt, cocoa powder, ground coffee, and cardboard or dry wood. Flavor adds smoke, ash, and subtle, bitter hops.  Dry, roasty, bitter finish. Full/medium, balanced body. Excellent porter.

very good porter
kind of thick,a little like a smoth stout
I didnt think it was as good as the Alaskan.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2007 (Draught at The Rover, Göteborg) 
The colour is black/red with a thin, light brown head. Fresh aroma of milk, chocolate and alot of coffee. Malt, nougat and some sour cream and onion crisp(!). Smooth as hell. The flavour is very smooth, sweet and milky. Medium body. A pleasant taste of Coffe and chocolate. Hops. The bitternes kicks in at the exact right moment. The afterbitterness tastes of roasted coffeebeans. Some crisp bread in both the flavour and in the nose. A perfect porter.

June 11, 2006, 16.9 oz. bottle.  This scrumptious porter packs a wallop of flavor: rich, creamy dark cocoa & vanilla, offset by sturdy hops and pleasant bitterness.  In a blind test, I could easily mistake this for a stout. Complex & satisfying, this is the "real deal."
Pours very dark with a cream colored head.  Nice aroma, coffee flavors were most pronounced followed by chocolate and a hint of smoke.  Excellent porter and will not hesitate to buy again.

On tap at Penny Lane Pub in Richmond. An immensely dark brew with a thick creamy head that stays around for the whole experience.  Taste was roasty, but not in your face. It finished with a nice creamy texture and the slightest bit of a hoppy finish.  Great beer, but just a tad expensive.....

Fullers Porter comes in somewhat of a faceless black bottle, a nearly invisible vessel devoid of any character assuming an equally bereft profile. Luckily, the contents tell a very different story. The habitual rich charcoal hue reminds of a Luddites nightmare, the oily cogs of machinery laboring to erect what in this case seems to be a sooty grey crown that emerges only to disappear as hastily. Smokey coffee and chocolate aromas develop to produce a delicious nose comforted by a dose of soothing cream, the perfect blend for contemplating ones own quenched empire while protected of the pluvious outdoors. The robust flavors of coffee, sausage and green vegetables gives substance to such a remarkable brew, that still caters to the softer palates with its velvety texture and lightly warming alcohol. Brilliantly depressing if youre joyous, but youll find nothing more consoling.

Now this is a Porter to be reckoned with. Im telling you man, I will judge all porters, excluding Baltic styles, by this specimen. Pours coffee  black w/ full creamy tan froth. Aroma of dark cocoa, roasted coffee beans, vanilla, and leather. Full nectar w/ soft residual effers. Dry with complex flavors of dark cocoa, roasted coffee and nuts, leather, cigars, and vanilla bean. The finish is perfectly bittered for your next sip. Overall: Well ballanced, complex, perfection. I wanted for nothing. I loved it, highly recommended.

Mondial de la Bière de Montréal; This is surprising, its a Porter, but it taste just like a Stout. Rich coffee flavor with chocolate tint as well as some orange tint. Rich in mouth and goes down really well. Dark color.

Poured dark brown (some reddish edges when held to the light) with a nice initial head that went by the wayside before long. The aroma was of burnt chocolate and nutty. The flavor was much of the same with a pronounced bitterness. The nut undertones were most surprising, as this rivaled some of the nut browns Ive had (in that sense). Mouthfeel was moderately thick and rather carbonated. Overall, a nice beer. However, this one is overpriced for what you get.

33cl bottle: pours black with brown hue and brown head.  aroma is strong of chocolate malts and exibits a rich bready smell.  the flavor is up front rich and dark with tons of chocolate and coffee with enough hops to balance out, but they are not what is displayed.  palate is velvety smooth.  Excellent brew

So far, my favorite of all time. Wonderfully smoky, not overpowering, smooth, caresses the tongue like velvet does your thigh. Its bold but has little bitterness, yet it doesnt sacrifice anything in its malty goodness. Coffee and a little cocoa, a hint of spice but not enough to interrupt your train of thought. This is a beer for the reward of a hard days work.
Amazingly rich porter. Well balanced, rich aroma, sweet and dry at the same time. A mtruly great beer. Coffe, prunes, port, the works.
Bottle. Creamy lightbrown good head. Mostly lasting. Nice red-brown colour. Malty caramellic aroma. very smoked flavor. Long finish and oily palate. Nice beer but not my favorite.
Black with little white head. Lively carbonated for a porter. The malts are very roasted. Taste of chocolate, coffee & liquorice.  Quite smokery as well. Bitter pleasant finish!
16.9oz bottle: Pours a black color, big tan head, good lacing, diminishing.  Extremey malty aroma, coffee.  Light tasting, bitter, acid, cofffe taste.
Very tasty porter, not too strong tasting with a smooth finish, uncommon for a porter style beer.  Probably due to its lower alcohol content.

Wow! Ma première véritable porter anglaise et je suis tout sauf déçu... Un arôme de torréfaction doux mais au combien plaisant, rappellant grains de café enrobés de chocolat. Un petit arôme fumé à peine perceptible est aussi présent, avant que le légérement épicé du fuggles vienne faire sa place.. Une grande bière!
bottle.  I had such high hopes.  This was good but not the 4.06 average I was hoping for.  Poured near black with moderate brown head.  Nice carbonation.  tastes of molasses and caramel.

favortie beer for awhile, till I got ahold of hops.

smooth, enjoyable, almost fun.

this may be the best beer to hand someone who says they enjoy porters but havent had what London has to offer.  Europe may have gotten something right with this one.
Nice dark colour beer with tan head. Chocalate and coffee flavors. Smooth. Very nice beer.
Very black, delicious looking dark beer. Smells of chocolate. Sticky sweet. Light hops. Choco and coffee flavors. Palate is just a little bit thinner than desirable. Beautiful overall.

Dark red-brown to black with a significant, though fading dense head.   Upon cracking open the bottle, I was struck by the dark fruit fragrances, particularly of sweet prunes and figs.  Directly over my glass I notice dark rich malty molasses and the slightest bit of roasted coffee.  I can hardly remember drinking anything quite so smooth.  the carbonation is so soft leading to a delicate creaminess that few brews attain.  This smoothness is mirrored in the flavor profile.  Sweet dark fruits and gentle chocolate malts avail themselves with only the slightest bit of bitterness, eminating from a conservative floral hopping and a subtle charcoal roastiness.  A slight hint of lactic acid helps to balance this sweetness in fashion similar to colas.  The lingering flavors are first charcoal and then slowly coming back to those prunes and figs.  This is really a fabulous beer, and easily my favorite porter.

Great looking bottle- which really doesnt influence my rating but is still nice!  And it pours a dark red/black beer with a tan head.  I love the aroma because its just really full and rich- its malty with dark fruity smells and some chocolate.  The flavour is similar but the chocolate really comes out more here, along with vanilla, plums, and roastyness.  Its just a great balance of a lot of flavours- its got the sweetness and the bitterness, the dark roastyness and the fruity flavours.  Its smooth, rich and creamy.  This is really is the full package!

Poured from the bottle, a rich brown color with a quickly-diminishing off-white head.  Malty aroma with notes of  toffee, chocolate, and some fruit.  The flavor is  malty and smooth.  The flavors roasted malt, chocolate, and plum combine to create a rich lingering mouth feel.  Perhaps the best porter I have ever had.    Its great that this is easily accesible.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2006 Nice dark color with thin tan head that lingers for just a bit.  Excellent aroma of coffee and chocolate.  Bittersweet chocolate and coffee with a rich, full-bodied taste.  Slightly sweet aftertaste that doesnt last long.  Tastes like a thicker stout with a thinner mouthfeel that goes down very smooth.  Best porter Ive had so far.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2006 Rich dark colour similar to a stout, but not as thick. Strong taste with a hint of coffee and chocolate. Nice finish with no real lingering aftertaste. 

A decent porter.

A very dark brown color with a ruby tinge. Somewhat small, off-white head that diminishes rather quickly.  Nose is raosted malt with chocolate backing it up.  Flavor is a burnt chocolate and a roasted coffee flavor with a slight inappropriate acetic/vinegar taste.  Hop bitterness really only a faint flavor in the profile.  Palate is lively and mostly smooth with a slight watery texture. Finally it finishes with a short and bitter-sweetness.  I really dont see the reall attractiion to this beer; it is a decent beer, but not overly interesting and not overly drinkable.  The acetic flavor may be from oxidation from the long travel, but even without, Ive had numerous porters that I prefer to this one.

Fullers London Porter has a well deserved spot atop the competitive Porter category.  Very bold malt balanced with hops and dark as sin, and the smoothness!  Oh, the smoothness.  An excellent porter, towards the top of my list, but the Sinebrichoff and Rogue Mocha are just a wee bit better.  However, you can find Fullers everywhere, and the other two are harder to get.

Bottle. Pours black with a nice tan head. Chocolate, malt, and coffee aromas. Very nice flavors. Lots of coffee and oatmeal overtones. A little nutty i found too. Finishes warm and smooth. Very good beer.
Excellent porter.  Caramely malts with a very faint hint of hop bitterness. Mouthfeel was a bit watery though.

Black body, fast away creamy head leaving laces; Huge nose with character and depth: milk chocolate, smoked malt, dark roasted coffee beans and walnuts; A very full body again with loads of bitterness, great amount of carbonation; Very bitter finish with great length, loads of bitterness that grows with the length of the finish: Coffee, burnt chocolate, licorice, burnt nuts. Strange balance between nose and body.

Bottled. Dark ruby red colour, mediumsized brown head. Soapy, roasted caramellish malts in aroma, with dark chocolate and toffee in it also. Flavour is roasted malts, dark chocolate, while the aftertaste is like espresso coffee with hints of chocolate and caramel.

Had this at a beer tasting in Philadelphia and at least some of the tasters liked this best ... better than the 1845 or the 2005 Vintage.  Big chocolate and coffee nose, dark almost black with a firm head that vanishes, leaving good lacing.  Big taste for a porter ... chocolate, coffee, dark malt, and enough hops to provide a good bitter balance and a good bitter finish.  Good mouth feel as well.  Porter by far not my favorite style of British ale, but this one works very well.

10-Apr-06 (18.6 oz bottle: $2.89 at Holiday Wine Cellar in Escondido, CA) Best before 03-Apr-05.  Having just sampled an aged Arcadia London Porter, I just had to put it up against a similarly-aged Fullers London Porter, even if it isnt bottle conditioned.  Its still sweet and wonderfully malty, but I noted a significant amount of chocolate when I tried this previously, and while still quite chocolaty, this is more raisiny and more earthy here, a plus in my book.  Roast isnt dominating and bitterness is fairly mild actually, so this just really allows other flavors to shine.  I really love that the smokiness emerges in the finish rather than just staying consistent right from the sip; adds complexity and more intrigue to the flavor this way.  Sweet, fruity, malty, chocolaty, smoky aroma is excellent.   Medium-full bodied and gently carbonated for an incredibly smooth and luxurious mouthfeel.  Medium ruddy-brown with some transparency through the center of the glass.  A full inch of creamy, light-tan head shows solid retention, taking several minutes to settle to a filmy layer.  Considerable patchy and ringed lacing decorates the glass.  This has to be one of the best porters available in the USA, and pasteurized or not, its permanently in my top ten for the style.06-Oct-04 (18.6 oz bottle) Very hearty and robust porter that boasts a strong chocolate flavor, lightly sweet, moderately roasted with a fair amount of bitterness and some smokiness in the finish.  Big, chocolate nose makes for a grand introduction for this beer.  Full bodied, with a creamy and smooth palate.  Dark ruddy brown in color.  Light tan head has good size after the pour and demonstrates excellent head retention with some modest lacing. (8, 4, 8, 5, 16 = 4.1)
Poured dark brown with minimal head.  Aroma was roasted malt with a touch of coffee.  Flavor was coffee, and a touch of chocolate, and slightly bitter in the finish.  A pretty good brew.
Excellent porter. Very complex, dominated by chocolate, coffee, and roasted bitterness. Continues to develop in the finish. Great brew.
Bottle. Pours a black colour with a mediumthick tan head. Dry roasted aroma. Nice dry roasted flavor with hints of chocolate and coffee. Long dry roasted aftertaste.

Pours black with tan, light uneven head.  Aroma is coffee, chocolate and a bit of creaminess, although points are deducted for my personal gag reflex against somewhat bitter coffee aromas (its a long story, and an irrational one, lets leave it at that).  First taste is kind of unimpressive - roastiness, coffee, chocolate.  The finish is where it develops its quality.  The finish sneaks up and has a very well developed roastiness and smokeyness to it that lasts quite a while.  Would be absolutely delicious with a steak.  All in all, pretty good, easy to drink, hearty, unimpressive to begin with but wins me over on the finish.
In a word, Awesome.  Rich flavor with tastes of chocolate, malts, roastiness, and hops.  Smooth to drink and hearty as well.  One of my favorites.

Pours nicely into Tulip Pint.  A taupe head forms richly and fades to a sheet above the dark beguiling brew.  Roasted aromas on the nose quickly checked by sweet malt and earthy hops.  Phenomenaly well balanced with a classic English malt structure.  I know that no one really knows what Porter originally tasted like but in my mind this has got to be close.  Not as hoppy as many American versions and certainly not as thick with roasted malt, apparently those beers are called stouts, which are a spin-off of Porter

UPDATED: APR 29, 2007 I was shocked when I tried this, this being one of the top rated poters.  It was (gasp) weak!!!  Even compared to some decent (not the best) American brews.  It had a rich malt flavor, a tinge of sourness, sort of like an oktoberfest.  There was a little bit of roast, a slight coffee/chocolate flavour.  There wasnt much else.  No noticeable hops, and generally not enough bitterness.  The body was thick but not in a good way.  I will not have this one again, and I fail to understand why others have rated it so highly.  Overall this beer came across as too heavy and with a slightly unpleasant flavour.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2008 Bottle. Pours brown\black with a thick tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, and slight hops to the nose. Flavor is sweet upfront, caramel, coffee-like, roast, with slight bitter finish. Good body, good brew.

From bottle
Dark, opaque pour. Bubbly tan head. Aroma of malt and roasted coffee.  Flavor of malt, chocolate, caramel, and toffee.  Hop bitterness in the end, but not overpowering.  Medium mouthfeel. Creamy and smooth going down.

Very rich porter.  Poured a reddish black with a thick, lasting, tan head.  Chocolate malt is the dominate force here, a slight amount of sweetness to round out the flavors.  There is a substantial hop bitterness but not much hop flavor.  Nicely filling and satisfying.

Strong robust aroma.  It gives a false impression of an overwhelming taste.  It was actually very easy to drink.  Hints of coffee, prunes, and chocolate.  The bitter is perfectly balanced with the sweet.  Finishes like a dry wine.  Id buy this again and again.

Well, this was a really disappointing porter.  Poured ok - dark brown with a minimal tan head.  Rather flat and a little waxy mouthfeel.  A little bland - a little malt and a hint of coffee, I suppose - but it just didnt reach out and grab me.

Pours very dark but not completely opaque with a foamy head that very rapidly degenerates into some lace. Aroma of roasted coffee and malts. Medium-bodied and smooth. Opens with a touch of malty sweetness followed by not much else and mere traces of hops. I found it to be disappointingly and exceedingly bland.

Quite dark, minimal head retention, does produce a good lacing on a pint though.  Aroma is what Id expect a porter to be: roasted, a hint sweet, and a touch earthy.  Taste is well balanced, can pick out the roasted malts along with the balancing hop presence.  A favorite.
Pours like Coca Cola with a tanned foamy head. Bitter with lots of coffee with hints of vanilla. Slightly sour in the finish.

bottle: This beer has a near perfect appearance and aroma. It pours completely opaque with a tan head. Creates brilliant lacing as the beer is being drank. The beer feels incredibly smooth and filling in the mouth. The carbonation is perfect. The taste has chocolate and coffee flavors. Absolutely incredible porter.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2007 Bottle. Been looking for this one for a while. Pours a Very dark brown with minimal tan head that dissapears in little time. Aroma is of roasted malts and coffee with chocolate and some caramel. The carbonation on the tounge is the first thing thats noticeable. Flavor is much like the aroma of roasted malts and coffee with some dark chocolate. Finishes with a nice roasted coffee flavor. My only reservation is that it seems a little over carbonated, but definitly a great porter anyhow.

Bottle: Pours a very dark brown (almost black) with reddish tones and a large frothy light brown head that ends with nice lacing. Aroma is roasted malts and dark chocolate. Flavor is rich and creamy with chocolate and vanilla flavor that finishes with a coffee bitterness. Very smooth and easy drinking. Delicious!

500 ml bottle. Deep red/mahogany body with almost dark red top.  Very pleasant taste, a well balanced mix of chocolate, vanilla and meat broth. The palate is oily with a lively carbonation. Nice aftertaste with a light pleasant bitterness. A classic!

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2008 Bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with reddish highlights.   S thick and creamy tan head leaves nice lacing as it crests the beer for the duration as a thin layer.  A strong roasted malt scent with some smokey hints prepares you for this quintessential Porter.  Faintly sweet upfront with more robust malt flavors dominating before a strong bitter finish reminiscent of coffee finishes leaving your mouth with a pleasant bitterness.  The sensation is smooth and rich, and dry throughout the range of flavors.  Perfectly balanced, I loved this beer, and will make it a staple in my fridge.  Updated 02/8.
Bottle. Dark brown almost black with little off white head. Very british - a little on the thin side - but all in all a pretty good porter.
12oz pour a dark brown almost black with very little head. The aroma is distinctly british and the flavor is deep and that of burnt toast. Very rich and nicely smokey.

Pours a dark, cola color into a pint.  Quickly receding head uniformly gathers around the edge of the glass. Dark roasted caramel, chocolate and coffee notes.  Full with a roasted bitter hop finish that lingers.
Bottled.Deep red-black colour. Brown head.Roasted chocolate aroma. Pleasent roasted chocolate flavour. A hint of roasted finish.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2006 12 oz bottle.  Big 3 inch head.  A tan bubbling cesspool as it settles to a slice of loofa, then to doily.  Deep ebony color.  Aroma of 7-Up with just the faintest coffee and chocolate; more as it warms.  Licorice and a little smoke.  Taste is bitter and sort of chocolatey.  Coffee comes through in the middle.  Creamy but not rich.  I didnt get the alcohol I expected but higher ABV might help.  Hoping this would be close to the Alpha Klaus but just so-so.
Bottle Very dark brown to black body with a medium brown head. Aroma is coffee, and chocolate. Taste is coffee, chocolate and malt with a nice touch of bitterness.
Clear dark cherry body with a thin creamy off-white head. Aroma of dark roasted malts and molassas. Flavor of coffee with light bitterness and chocolate malt, but with a decent helping of molassas.
A coffee aroma with plenty of chocolate.  The taste is sweet and that of coffee.  The bitter aftertaste is perfect.  This is up there with the Anchor Porter.

A rich coffee aroma with chocolate and malt. A quickly diminishing head with little lace. Light sweetness and excellent bitterness make this beer a true drinking pleasure. Creamy full body with soft carbonation across the tongue. Finishes with that bitter you gotta love. Id love to be able to make one that is just a little sweeter. Man this baby is good.

Deep ruby color. Aroma is roasty and sweet  chocoate and toffee. The flavor is full of roasted malts, chocolate and a hint of coffee and smoke. Slightly bitter aftertaste that lingers with a roasted coffee taste. Smooth and creamy on the palate. An outstanding porter.
Awesome black body with a light ivroy head.  Excellent chocolate malts and some creams, maybe some coffee accents as well.  Good coffee accents in the body, great smooth ending.

Pours clear, very dark red brown (nearly black) with a small short lived head. The aroma is complex and a perfect blend of chocolate malts, roasted malts and earthy hints of yeast and vanilla. The aroma is so delightful you will want to breathe it in often while enjoying this porter. The flavor is exquisite - mild coco wrapped in sweetness supported by roasted malts and coffee, finishing dry and clean with a slight bitterness. The mouth feel is very smooth and creamy yet without coating. A lingering aroma of chocolate malt and coffee finish off the delightful experience. Fortunately Fullers London Porter is readily available and reasonably priced. Its complex flavor and aroma profile beg to be enjoyed as a solo beverage or as a dinner dessert.

I was shocked to discover that I hadnt rated this beer yesterday so I made a point of picking one up tonight. Funny thing is I have had this several times since I joined this fine community. Pours a genre defining near black color that is nonetheless brown. A lovely pungent aroma of coffee and chocolate assaults the nostrils with joy. Strong coffee flavors dominate this beer but a rich chocolate finish brings things back around in a lovely sweet fashion. The mouthfeel is creamy and smooth and the lingering chocolate flavor is a delight long after the beer is finished. This is proof that a beer doesnt have to be loaded with alcohol to be rich and complex. A great beer that is fairly easy to find.

Dark brown reddish pour with a light tan head. Awesome aroma roasty of chocolate and coffee. The flavor is toasty, with chocolate and coffee notes coming though quite nicely. Very malty on the tounge with a warm bitter coffee finish. This is a great porter, the best Ive had so far. Very well balanced and great for the colder months.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2006 This is the beer that turned me on to other beer styles besides mass produced lagers.  Small disappearing head.  Mouthfeel  is wonderfully smooth.  Creamy texture, complex flavors. My first porter/stout and probably the best Ive tasted yet.

12 oz. Bottle: pours a beautiful translucent ruby red with off-white medium sized head which disappears quickly. Some mild lacing. Chocolate, cherry, raisin and slight wheat notes in the nose. Malty chocolate/espresso taste then charcoal with a very smooth finish. The full mouthfeel followed by such a clean ending makes for a solid porter. Yummmm.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2007 Øl (50cl) købt i Føtex for 15 kr.

Øllen er brun med flot brunt skum. Duften er brændt, og smagen er endnu mere brændt. Eftersmagen er maltet og meet brændt.

Tør og humlet og flad.

Duften er maltet brændt
Bottle. Light brown creamy and lasting head. Wauw. Dark red almost black body. Again wauw. Liqorice aroma. Smooth coffee liqorice hops flavor.

Bottle.  Clear brown-red body under a quickly-diminishing thick off-white head.  Dry malty aroma - toffee, chocolate, charred wood, and a light rummy raisin thing.  The flavor is also dry and malty - wood, chocolate malt, plum skin, and some dusty roast bitterness.  I wish this stuff was sweeter, it would feel more satisfying.

What a fantastic nose of rich roasted malts. A very comlpex beer with fine array of malty flavours.Coffee and caramel are there too, with a slight hint of fruity acids from the hops...a crackin beer, very satisfying!
A very dark brown with a small tan head. Sweet chocolate, roasty and even a bit of berry scent. Mild roasty, a touch of smoke, chocolate, coffee, fruity, nutty. Quite tasty indeed.

Bottle - Pours deep black/mahagany with a great frothy tan head but the head fades fast to nothing. Mouth feel is a little too watery. flavor is there and deep but not with the complexity that Id like hints of cherry pie, taffy. roasted malts. Good porter. love the bottle, but still searching...

Bottle.  Almost translucent brown with a second long tan head.  Aroma of rum chocolate raisin wood (brandy).  Lots of dark chocolate, dry roast malt, very toasty.  Could be a little fuller bodied, but, quite solid nonetheless. modest finish.
Molasses, chocolate, toffee, caramel, smoke?, and burnt brown sugar.   Very rich and creamy palate. Moderate floral hopping, especially in the finish.   Very well done... a true classic of the style.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2011  Deep black-red, thin tan head. Rich aromas of chocolate, molasses, and stewed plums or cherries (like port). Velvety smooth mouthfeel, very full-bodied, complex palate with chocolate, brown sugar, molasses, some smokey ash, and an earthy element-- but somehow it is more than the sum of its parts.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: 6 Pack.  Pours a very dark brown with a tan head.  My first taste was astounding.  This is a porter?  This is unlinke any porter I have ever had.  Reminded me a lot of Guinness Stout.  What is with the 11.2 oz bottles though?  Cant spring for the extra .8 oz?

Aroma was mostly wood with some chocolate. Black body with chocolate head. Favor was a good blend of chocolate, wood and got a roasted coffee and mild sweetness. Not an over malty sweet porter that was good for a change.

One of the better porters that Ive had.  Due to the high rating and my hatred of European, especially English, beers I was expecting to be disappointed again.  I was wrong.  Pours out gorgeous thick black and with a big frothy light brown head.  Aroma is a little chocolatey and a little "sam smithes"y.   Texture is great.  Really smooth and soft.  Flavor is a bit smoky, slight chocolate, and mildly bitter.    Not as much mocha or chocolate as wanted but everything is well balanced.  A finely made porter.  I could dig drinking this in a pub but i still like more "aggressive" porter like Gonzo or Stone.  Probably one of the cheapest 4.0+ beers, too, at $3 a for a 17oz bottle.  Highly recommended.
A good porter. Dark and roasty as it should be. To me, a good porter should become more smooth as it warms, and this does exactly that. Was it the best porter Ive ever had though? Probably not.

This beer is delicious...pours a dark brown with a bit of deep red...slight fizzy head.  The aroma is of rich chocolare.  Taste is light  with a perfect chocolate and coffee balance.  Mouthfeel is somewhat heavy and dry.  Ill be keeping an eye out for this one for a long time to come.
pours a lovely deep dark colorless color with only a hint of foam.  It is one of the most perfect mixes of sweet and dry. A runner up for my every day beer!
Le mélange de malt dans cette porter est assé présant et cest un bon mélange. Riche, crèmeuse et délicieuse.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with hints of mahogany and red in the color. Lightened coffee colored head. Smells very sweet and ripe like plums or with a slight chocolate smell. Tastes chocolatey and rich with coffee flavors becoming more pronounced in the finish. Not too carbonated, nice full body. This stuff is great!

Bottle from the Blind Pig, Champaign. Given the general decline of Blind Pigs tap list, Im forced to go with their bottle options. A decided note of plum and chocolate on the nose. Mouthfeel is fairly lush and creamy, and the 5.4 ABV is rather refreshing and makes the beer highly drinkable. Notes of semi-sweet chocolate, prune, and a hint of Jolly Rancher like sweetness. The chocolate overwhelms everything else; I really dont get too much coffee notes here. Solid and worthy of some esteem, although perhaps not 4.08 esteem.

on tap at BierStube in Moline.  a nice surprise to finally get to try this one and best of all it was on tap!  rich chocolate aroma greets the nose and the pour was a dark brown with a seemingly ruby edge.  flavors were well balanced chocolate and a bit of a coffee finish.  low carbonation.  great beer!

Very dark brown pretty much black pour, thin head that stayed but stayed very very thin. Aroma was of coffee bigtime. First sip it was like a chilled coffee, with very dark chocolate, but not very sweet at all. Tougher than some stouts Ive had. A little on the bitter side also.
"Pour a dark dark brown, with a medium head. Wow the aroma was strong coffee with a little chocolate. Taste of malts cocoa and coffee, little sweet. Full body with a perfect finish. "

50 cl bottle. No yeast at the bottom. Dark allmost black colour with a great large head. Great aroma of smooth coffee, chocolate and hints of roastedness. Wonderfull smooth flavour of roasted malt, coffee and hints of chocolate and liquorice. Ends smooth bitter with a very long aftertaste. This one is a really great traditional porter.
Pours cola with a small, fading, tan head. The aroma is sweet caramel and toffee, some roasted notes. The flavor is roasted and chocolates, dry with a bitter end. The mouthfeel is smooth.
Fullers London Porter is a must for any porter lover.  I especially like the hints of chocolate in this porter.

Bottle. Bottled 8/29/05. I was very surprised by this beer. Very nice, creamy dark chocolate aroma. Also nice hints of coffee and liquor. Poured a nice ruby brown color. Nice medium size off white head that lasted the whole beer. Good lacing as well. First thing I noticed when drinking was how creamy and smooth this beer was. Very nice. The taste was just like it smelled. Hints of creamy, dark chocolate, coffee, caramel and liquor. Nice smooth finish. Little to no aftertaste. One very nice beer. I look forward to trying more Fullers brews.
A great and rich English Porter.  I rich creamy and thick head.  A mahogony color.  Complex flavor with hinst of coffee and chocolate.  A superb drink.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2007 Love this beer Good flavor an earthy balance of coffee and licorice with spice. The mouth feel could be fuller but that taste really hangs in there, very full. If the carbo was softer,  this shit would totally kick ass.
Dark brown with little head. BB date 6 mos ago. Nice balance of malty chocolate with a mild coffee finish and oddly a hint of cigar . Nice

Pours a dark rich brown, has a malty chocolate smell something that you could just sniff all day. I let this one warm up a bit which did wonders for the smell and taste on the tongue. Once it hit the palate it tasted of rich dark coffee, chocolate, and slight tabacco...a beer that would pair very well with english candies such as (Picnic, Twirl, or Flake)

Black pour that can be held up to the light to reveal a deep red mahogany.   Aroma has a crisp quality to it along with the roast chocolate and malts.  Being a  bit thin on the palate really detracts from this beer.

black pour w/ almost no head....strong coffee and chocolate aroma with a very strong coffee and chocolate flavor....great flavor for a porter, but there is not much else to say about this beer unfortunately....falls a bit short of my expectations

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2006 Quite chocolatey, very smooth.  The aroma is absolutely fantastic, hard to describe, but I smell chocolate and fruityness. Well balanced taste, good aftertase in the mouth, not all that exciting but a wonderful beer.
Bottle.  An aromaof coffee, roasted barley, and coke unfurls with the opening of the bottle.  Flavour is an execlent blend that is subetly sweet.

Draught at Isabellas in Dubuque, IA. Clear dark dark brown with bubbly tan head. Smells and tastes of black licorice and brown sugar.  Alcohol flavor also seemed more prominent than the stated 5.4%. Moderately carbonated.

Lucky number 700!  Ive been meaning to try this one since the beginning, but finally picked it up to celibrate the end of the semester.  Bold aroma and a beautiful pour.  Strong with a coffee flavor to it.  no bad aftertaste makes this beer smooth and nice.  A winner.
Dark brown with a small tan head.  Nice lacing.  Roasted coffee/chocolate aroma and taste delivers what it promises.  Lingers nicely on the palate.  Great beer.
Very dark brown in colour. Smooth awith some nutty and chocolate malt. Im not sure how close this is to victorian porters, but for a modern variation it is very good.
Dark in nature, almost black.  Not much of a head.  Coffee and chocolate smell.  This is a bold beer yet smooth.  The finish was smooth for such a full taste.
Dark nearly black, opaque.  Thin tan head.  Aroma is of chocolate, malt, coffee.  Smokey.  Full bodied, slick.  Flavor is of malt and coffee.  Well balanced through and through.  No poor aftertaste.

One pint, 6oz brown bottle purchased from Armanettis, Mundelein, IL. ABV 5.4%. Expiration date 8/29/05 and bottle opened 12/1/05 so beer already expired.   Clear dark brown hued porter having diminishing off-white head with spare lacing.  Complex aromas of chocolate, coffee, prunes, raisins, and toast. No discernable carbonation.  Medium bodied that starts dry with  roasted malt and finishes dry with lingering light bitterness and expresso flavor. Though beer was expired, no notable off-tastes. Good drinkable porter.
Small, tan, creamy head; black opaque body. Faint, roasty aroma. Deep, sweet, roasty taste, leading to an aftertaste of coffee and licorice. Very harmonic and balanced; not too complex. Great!

KegBrown color, with a thick cap of brown foam. Hop and roasted malt in the nose, light note of coffee. Much better taste: roasted malt and coffee, cappuccino! Good body strength, and very interesting quality of malt, not too much on the bitter-roasted side. Good balance with a residual sweetness. The hop is completely overwhelmed in the body; it comes up later in the finish. Not complex, but a very good example of dark ale (stout?).
(Bottle 50 cl) Pitch black, close to opaque, with a small, discreet head. Dark, burned flavours with a distinct bitterness that doesnt linger all that long though. 0040302

Pours black as hell, with a huge, creamy tan head. Head dissipates down to a pretty respectable level. Yummy milk chocolate and malt aroma. Flavor is very heavy with coffee with cream, hazelnut, chocolate. Seriously, this is like an iced mocha from the coffee shop. Bitterness tastes like coffee bitterness. Finishes with cream and hazelnut, and some coffee bitterness. Mouth feel is good, but thiner than most porters Ive had recently. Very good. Seriously, this is like desert.
This beer had a nice brown color to it.  It tasted a bit like coffee.  This beer had a nice smooth taste to it.

Deep brown with a nice nutty aroma.  Very creamy consistency, and smooth mouthfeel.  After a recent trip to London, I absolutely love anything Fullers, especially this Porter.  Great for a cold rainy day.

Amazingly rich and creamy, like a mouthfull of chocolate ice cream.  Tastes like coffee, chocolate and roasted nuts.  While this is very tasty, it doesnt have the complexity I expected.  But, the more I drink it, the more impressed I get.
UPDATED: APR 17, 2006 Had during a beer tasting party.  Poured dark brown with smells and tastes of coffee.  very impressive.
poyrs dark with small shortlived head. Chocolate, roasty & coffee aromas with a  thick malty porter character. A very good porter

Nose of soy sauce, dark chocolate/mocha, sweet roastiness. Very minimal head. Almost opaque dark brown. Flavor was less complex than I had expected, a strong coffee flavor with some chocolate and nuts, yet the finish is somewhat watery. A very decent porter but I like Baltika 6 better.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2005 Deep brown with a nice tan head.  Smells of dark chocolate and nuts with a little caramel.  Flavor is smooth with lots of chocolate and dark malts with little hops. FInish is still smooth with a bite of bitterness.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2008 Bottle. Had it at a higher temperature this time, and especially the aroma improves. Chocolate, coffe, mocca and a roastiness comes through much more pronounced at a more decent temperature. In the flavor it also has a hint of vanilla and beef stock. Original rating 6-3-7-4-15-3.5. (060224)
Bottled at Newcastle, Aalborg, Denmark.
Brown, almost black, with a tan head. Nice lacings. Mild aroma of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Full bodied with roasted flavor, chocolate and coffee. Quite smooth. Dry roasted and bitter finish. (051030)

Bottled.  Pours dark with a quckly fading foamy tan head.  Molasses dominates the nose with traces of cocoa and mild spices.  Taste is chocolate and toffee with burnt wood in the background.  The palate is nice and smooth.  A fine porter.
Black with a lasting tan head, lacing with small bubbles. Chocolate aroma with some in the taste as well coffee. Smooth on the palate.

Bouteille-Noire opaque aux odeurs de café et de toffee. Goût chocolaté et malté. Très douce au palais et sec.--Bottle-Black with coffee  and toffee aromas. Chocolate and malt taste. Very sweet in mouth and dry.
Heavy, smooth and very true to the Porter taste . Drink slow and enjoy the porter

Classic, ideal porter. Pour is black that turns lighter to a brown hue as it thins. Nose is sweet of toffee, coffee, and mainly chocolate. Mouthfeel is silky smooth. Flavor is lavishly creamy and sweet with chocolate malts dominating. Hops are negligible in this porter, but it is so enjoyable that you forget about them and smile.

A very good porter, traditional in style.  Dark brown in color.  On the nose: definite roasted & chocolate malts & a fruity essence though slight to me.  Medium in body and in holding a head and maintains a particular drinkability.  Good to see a porter that remains a porter - not a stout or imperial stout.
Bottle. Very nice, sweetish liquorice aroma. The colour is almost black with a red hue. Nice, semi-creamy, light brown head. Nice liquorice/salt/coffee flavour. Very late coffee aftertaste.
great scented brew-ha. one of the best scents ive scented. Nice and creamy.
Dark brown with a dark beige head. Very malty aroma with dark chocolate notes. A little caramel sweetness in the taste, followed by roasted coffee and medium bitterness at the end.

Poured with large light brown creamy head with some large bubbles in amont the tiny ones.  It was mostly diminishing and exhibited some very nice lacing.  Can only see through this brew if I hold it right up to a light source and then it has a very dark dark plum type of color.  Looks very nice.  Aroma is of coffee, raisin, chocolate, and licorice.  Initial flavor was lightly dry and slightly bitter.  Finish is moderately bitter and drying with a nice long duration.  Great aftertaste.  Body is full and texture is syrupy with soft carbonation.  Finish has a very very light alcohol presence.  I dont taste a lot of complexity here.  The beer is very up-front and candid about what it wants to taste like.  Palate is exceptionally smooth.  Very nice and well balanced porter.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2006 Bottle. Dark brown, thick tan head. Malty aroma with coffee, chocolate and caramel notes. What I really enjoy about this is the awesome taste of English licorice. Excellent porter

Bottle.  Pours deep brown, almost black with an edgy tan head and tiny fizzy bubbles on top.  Fragrant floral hop and sweet caramel chocolate aroma, slightly roaste malt and molasses notes.  Dark and bitter roasted coffee, chocolate malt, a bit smoky with fruit hops, chalky chocolate and a lingering bitter hop aftertaste.  Dark and thin, silky and fizzy palate.
Robe noire aux reflets brun acajou surmontée dune mousse blanche qui sestompe. Arômes de café et de diacétyl. Saveurs de caramel, de beurre, de sirop dérable et de chocolat.

Pours black with a large brown frothy head.    Very chocolately aroma with caramel, coffee, vanilla, and floral hops.  Excellent flavors of fudge, coffee,  and licorice along with very well balanced hops bitterness.  Extremely smooth and creamy on the palate with a very pleasurable mouthfeel, but it is a bit thin.  Overall, I can tell why this porter is rated so high.  Ill have another!

Just so damn good.  A wonderful session beer.  The slight diacetyl yeast character is delightful, manifesting as a slightly butterscotchy finish.  Incredibly balanced.  Nice use of chocolate malt and fuggles to create a dryness to go with the malty yeasty sweetness.  A classic.

Pours a beautiful, almost opaque, dark mahogany with a tan head that clings to the glass with some nice lacing. Malty, roasted aroma with hints of coffee. Smooth, full mouthfeel, almost chewy. Flavors of roasted malts and coffee, fulfilling the promise of the aroma. Finish is refreshingly dry, with a lingering mild bitterness. Beautifully balanced, just a wonderful and classic porter.

There was an air of overwhelming when i saw this in sainsburies, being rated as the best beer in britain, is a high status to have. (actually i stand corrected not the best beer in britian). Aroma is smoked and roasted malt, with coffee and pale malt notes. Taste is very similar with a roasted long finish, drish too. Well to say im disapointed may be about right, this is a decent beer, but it lacks complexity, yeasiness and a good few other things that need to be had to make a good beer in my eyes.

A Mes rate: 
Aroma of choclate milk and coffee with some slight vanilla. Almost black in the body with a rocky light brown head that lasts a little better than most of the other Fullers I have tried. Flavour is roasty chocolate malts and more coffee. Very creamy and drinkable. Well balanced but not overly complex but hey, it is pretty fine stuff.

A great malty porter with a roasty smokey flavor.  Good head with a deep dark brown color.  Has a coffee/toffee flavor nice explosion of the malts. Smooth creamy feel this was a great porter and loved the aftertaste.

Poured from the bottle, a dark red black with a large rocky head. The aroma is strongly caramal, though the flavour is most definitely chocolate (I enjoy the difference). Oh so smooth in the mouth. I can see why this is rated so highly.
UPDATED: DEC 3, 2008 Dark brown, thick tan head. Malty aroma with coffee, chocolate and caramel notes. The taste is roasty malt with a bitter finish. Excellent porter.

12 oz bottle.  Thanks to Slob for setting me up with this guy.  Pours a very dark ruby, almost black with a small tan head.  Aroma of dark chocolate, coffee, molasses, and soft floral hops.  Flavors of dark molasses, chocolate, coffee, and hops Some oxidation present, with some of the hop bitterness a little downplayed, almost 1 year past the best before date.  Finish is all chocolate with some light hoppiness.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with soft carbonation, and oily.   A really nice English style porter.
a lot of head,  flavors were chocolate and vanilla.  Very pleasent and light.  A good hearty beer with a nice light mildly hoppy finish.  Good

bottle 22/nov/04 12oz. pours  black with thin head. aroma is fairly weak but there is a hint of coffee and chocolate. a subtle hop charecter. tastes coffee chocolate a slight roastieness. very smooth with a light hop bitterness.
Bottle.  Dark brown/black look, a very malty and hoppy flavor, which reminds one of coffee and cream.

Bottle, at No. 5.
Dark brown with brown head, mostly disappearing, modest lacings. Aroma moderate malty (burnt, brown sugar, coffee) and hoppy. Flavor moderate sweet and bitter, long duration. Medium body, watery/oily, soft carbonated.

Bottle.  Pours out a very dark brown, almost black with a thick tan head.  Aroma is strong on coffee and chocolate.  I taste bittersweet chocolate, black coffee, roasted malt,  a little sweet cream and a bit of smoke on the malty finish.  Full bodied on the palate, and very smooth.  Delicious brew, my favorite porter thus far.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2006 From the bottle

Pours dark with an ample tan head. The aroma is molassas with hints of peat, pumpernickel, and smoke.

The flavor is coffee, bitter chocolate, and subtle spices, not too salty and pleasingly dry despite the molassas aroma; theres a decisive red-wine flavor to the front side of the finish. Mouthfeel is good, and finish is pleasing; this one goes down smoothly.
Deep black colour with a medium brownish and lasting head. Sweet malty aroma and a rather complex taste of coffee and chocolate and spices. Full body with a smooth palate.

The aroma is chocolate and coffee along with deeply roasted malt and hops. The appearance is a dark reddish brown with a nice head. The flavor is also full of deeply roasted malt and coffee. The bitterness in the aftertaste is just right. Smooth palate. Its pretty good.
Pours almost black with brown head. Delicious aroma of roasted coffee. Coffee, chocolate malty flavour with caramel. One of my favourite easily obtainable beers

Pours a dark malty color with a thick creamy beige head.  Looks a bit like Coca Cola.  Smell is complex.  Very smokey scent, with hints of roasted coffee,caramel,vanilla and fudge.  Taste is smokey, like beef jerkey, with hints of caramel and thick sweet cream.  The first few times I had this beer, I thought it was average and overrated.  However, the taste grows on you and you learn to appreciate the complexities put into this beer.  Very good porter.

Pretty surprised this is a top 50 beer. Aroma is pretty nice, with some chocolatiness and maltyness. But the taste is really unassertive, boring... Im not a fan of british hops, and this is a perfect example why. They really do nothing for the beer. Bitterness is near non-existant and hop flavors are basically not there. Palate is pretty watery and thin, too.

Pours a coffee black with a nice tan head. Coffee mocha aroma. Taste is extremely smooth, coffee, chocolate, with a clean bittering that goes perfectly with the beer. Very good brew. Maybe because its also a smooth drinking tasty combo of my 3 vices... coffee. chocolate. beer. Mmmm.
user_location: Waco (Buckle of the Bible Belt), Texas, USA

text: 16.9z bottle.  Best before 29 Aug 2005?  Dark, almost opaque with a tan head.  Roasted coffee and caramel in the nose.  Smooth in the mouth with chocolate and caramel notes, but the lingering flavors are big.  Black coffee, and dark roasted malts followed by a dry, bitter hop flavor.  Dark, smooth and rich.  This is a prime example of the style, regardless of the dating.
Pours balck with  thin off white head. Nice aroma with a bit of sweet chocolate and coffee. Quite refreshing dispite its heavy looks. A good porter above average

Pours a balck with ruby tones when held to the light. Thin off white head.
Aromas of chocolate ( fudge), black cherry, Coffee
Effervescent mouthfeel with a bitter coffee taste. Smooth slightly dry finish.

Bottle in the UK.  A rich deep nose of coffee and a hint of spice.  Very black with a quickly dissipating head, but that could have been the way I poured it.  When you taste it thats when it becomes a winner.  The mouthfeel is stunning - smooth and steady, and it seems to roll around your mouth of its own volition, hitting each taste zone as it goes.  As it goes down your throat it leaves characters of dark malt - the usual raisins, chocolate and coffee with a teeny bit of licorice.  But in the lingoring finish these all blend into a harmonious richness that leaves you wanting more.  This is a good un.  I like this brewery, and this is one of the two best Ive had from it, if not the best.
Nice dark color with a small tan head.  Distinct coffee flavor that is wonderfully satisfying.  Goes down so smooth.  The best porter Ive ever had and possibly the best beer Ive had.

Aroma of roasted peanuts over slightly sweet malt.  Appaears a brown-reddish color with a dark tan head.  Flavor is roasted peanuts, roast coffee, a slight malty sweetness.  Palate is light, smooth, somewhat still, yet somehow appropriate.  Overall, this beer is greater than the sum of is parts, though I dont seem to be quite as taken by it as the average rater.

Bottled. Pours a dark brown, with a tan head. Aroma is of roasted malts, bread, hints of coffee and chocholate. Taste is dry, roasted malts, bitter chocholate, and just a hint of ground coffee. Medium bodied, and a long roasted aftertaste

On draught.  Thick and dark with a creamy head.  Very smooth, very chocolately.some smokiness.  Goes down nice and easy.  Despite being so heavy looking, its quite refreshing even on a balmy summer night in Florida.
To me, this is the reference standard when it comes to porters.  roasted malty aromas and flavors and a long lasting creamy head make this beer a joy to savor and drink with a good friend!

Bottle from Sainsbury. Really dark ruby colour, lasting tanhead, lovely roasted malt aromas and flavours, choc/coffee, not too sweet, with dry grainy charcoal finish. Good dark beer with some acids on end and touch of liquorice

Bottle poured a clear brownish black with a brown head and brussels lace.Aromas of mocha, coffee and roasted malt. Palate is smooth and creamy. Flavors of cocoa, and roasted malt then the coffee flavor sneaks in the finish. A decent porter but Ive had better.
Smoky aroma. Dark thick appearance, white head. Lasting carbonation. Smooth flavor. Moderate carbonation, moderate aftertaste.  Not a bad drop. Very drinkable.

pours a dark brown/amber color...  mildly carbonated.. very smooth a little watery for a porter... has a nice scent but not a heavy one... a lil toffee in flavor... I enjoy it... its pretty smooth... Im however at a bit of a loss as far as descriptive words go.
Great beer.  Another favorite from Fullers.  I have to mail order it, but what the hey.  Great color and aroma.  Wonderful taste.  Beautiful head.  Gotta love it.
A truly great porter.  It has a great chocolately flavor and finishes off smooth and stong.  i enjoyed it immensely.

Bottle. Pours dark brown w/ fluffy light tan head. Nose is very dry and metallic. Coffee overtones. Taste is dry, bittersweet chocolate. Very delayed coffee "blast" on the tongue. Palate is velvety and lingering.

Bottle; Poured a jet-black color with a nice light brown head. The smell is of a great malt mix with caramel standing out. The flavor followed the same malt mix with chocolate, caramel and roasted nuts detected. Full bodied with a great creamy texture.
This is a classic. Well-balanced chocolate, smoky coffee, and some toffee. It got me through an otherwise boring summer, so it will always have a place in my heart.

Dark chocolate and roasted grain aroma.  Huge light brown head with good lacing.  Very dark brown colour.  Flavour is slightly sweet with moderate bitterness.  Soft, creamy texture with a long finish.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2006 Re-rate. Bottle from Waitroise in Bath, if memory serves me. Red-brown with a layer of dirty beige foam. Toast, coffee, and Cheerios®. Breakfast! A nice husky grainy aroma. A touch of sourness, but at a good level. Lots of chewy dark bread flavor--leaves a pleasant lingering dry toast flavor, mingled with a little bright sourness and earthy chocolate. Medium body, enough to feel hearty, but not thick. Quality and character within the framework of restraint. 

(Rating from 8/15/2005, Falling Rock Taphouse, Denver) Very dark ruby with a smallish cap of head. Buttery-toffee aroma, with just a bit of roast. Buttery sweet flavor too, with a bit of sourness. Just a bit of burnt toast in the finish. A bit winey on the palate, but still fairly smooth. I had high hopes for this. Its unique, but not in particularly good ways. I can tell my rating is way out of line for this beer. I will have to give it another shot sometime. (6,3,5,3: 13)

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2006 Poors 1 hair above pitch black.  Rich coffee malty body with a rich frothy head.  Fantastic lace patterns.  Somewhat sweet, very smooth and rich.  Most porters get old after 1 or 2, this one keeps getting better.  One of my top 3 favorite beers of all time.

Very dark red-brown, little head, just a ring of foam floating on still liquid.  Aroma was strawberry, yeast, molasses and cocoa. Taste is chocolate, smoke, peat, malt, molasses, cherries and dark fruit.  A wonderfully complex flavor.  Mouth feel was flat but not too thin.  Reminds me of St. Peters Olde Style and Salopian Entire Butt, 2 porters I thoroughly enjoy.  Because its more of an old recipe style, meaning flat and sweet, it doesnt measure up to my Porter benchmark, Samuel Smiths Taddy, which is stronger, more carbonated, and fuller-bodied.  As far as Fullers goes, I still prefer their 1845 Ale.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2006 roasted chocolate, coffee aroma.  nearly black color.  medium sized tan head with some big soapy bubbles.  dark chocolate and intense coffee flavor.  sweet.  hops round out the finish with grape flavors.  sharply carbonated.  excellent cold and warm.  very good.

Vanilla bean, sweet chocolate, bready malts and a slight hint of fruity esthers makeup the inviting aroma.  The body has an almost nutty overtone that ties it together.  The chocolate malt in this is just scrumptious, working nicely with the subtle roastiness and creamy mouthfeel.  Very enjoyable from start to finish!

UPDATED: APR 30, 2009 Now this is what i like! Dark color but just enough to see through its dark ruby red color, beutiful red-brown head that laces through out the glass, and a sweet delicous taste that screams (yes, screams) LONDON PORTER!!! I like this beer alot!


rerate: if you can find this fresh on tap, almost untouchable...
Great porter, dark chocolate/coffee flavor, smooth and silky texture,  very dark color (almost black),  lingering finish that is almost too oily

At last - the elusive London Porter is mine! 500 ml bottle, bought in Denmark. Very dark reddish brown colour, large tan head. Aroma is first and foremost dark chocolate, but also rye bread, leather and oak. Flavour is again chocolate on a nice roasty background, decent hops linger in the aftertaste. Clearly a first class beer - Im sure its even better cask conditioned.
On tap.  Very dark black with creamy tan head.  Aroma is lightly sweet roast.  Taste is earthy and smooth with milky chocolate and light roasted finish.  Wow thats good.

Pours black with ruby hues and a dark brown fully receding head.  Aroma of red wine and chocolate.  Taste is quite sweet, vinous with subtle roasted malts. There are continous notes of raisins and coffee. Carbonation is low and the mouthfeel is thick and oily.  The finish is lingering and has alot of roast with slight bitterness. This beer is quite complex, but Im not sure how well it meshes together.
Quite good; sampled from a hand pumped keg (cask? probably keg, US location). Just the right combination of bitter and sweet.
Bottle.  Pretty darn tasty.  I have not really liked many of the Fullers/Youngs/Samuel Smiths (I dont know why, but I clump them together) that I have tired so far, this one was very good though.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2005 Bottle: Pours a deep dark brown with a thick pillowy layer of tan head. Chocolate, coffee, and smoke are in the nose. Lots of roastiness. Very silky textured, goes down smoothly. Lightly carbonated. Flavors are mostly chocolate and coffee, but there is a good bit of molasses sweetness to it. Finsihes like it starts; smooth, creamy, and rich. Good stuff, cheap, and widely available.

Bottled.
Brown coloured with a solid beige head.
Roasted aroma of cocoa and chocolate with notes of liquorice.
Roasted flavour of chocolate with notes of liquorice, coffee and smoke.

Bottle. Dark brown, almost black colour and light long lasting head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate and roasted malt. Very light carbonation, but a finish you can taste minutes after your last sip. Great.

A good porter.  Not too rich.  Good taste with some bitterness but not much..

Available at Downtown Wine & Spirits in Somerville, MA
A deep rich brown that pours with a light brown head that is long lasting.  The aroma is of coffee and chocolate malts.  A nice smooth flavor with the taste of roasted malt with some bitterness.

12 oz. bottle:  Transparent deep brown with ruby/amber hints, mostly sustaining tan head.  Aromas are of coffee and roasted malts.  Flavor is similar, lots of coffee and cocoa.  A nice beer that can be found almost anywhere.

Bottle.  Dark, ruby-brown, with a small tan head.  Aroma is
very roasty, with strong coffee and chocolate.  The flavor is very
rich and roasty, with a taste similar to the aroma.  Has a slightly 
roasty bitter finish.  I would like a little more carbonation and
the flavor could be a tad bit more solid.  Great beer though.

Bottle.  Foamy brown head that was nice but faded too quickly, leaving a bit of lacing.  Strong shot of espresso flavor and bitter chocolate.  Very smooth, with flavor washing over and no irritating carbonation.  Would like some more body, but great all around.

pours a deep dark brown, with a foamy layer of tan head that clings on the sides of the glass.  aroma is engulfing, i could smell the coffee and chocolates from about 8 inches away, and upon further inspection, found some brown sugar and a tad of molasses.  amazingly smooth texture, very creamy and silky, but not a very full body, creating a kind of oxymoronic palate.  flavor is very nicely balanced, the coffee coming on early and also again late, with a generous amount of sweet chocolate and candi sugar through the middle.  just a tad hoppy in the finish, but the smoothness is just amazing.

Pours dark brown/mahogany with a very thick frothy off white head.  Pleasant chocolate/coffee/cappuccino aroma.  Flavours are just as good, once again coffee and chocolate.  Only downside: I found the finish a bit tart.  Very good stuff.

Pours a dark brown color.  Smells of chocolate and roasted coffee hit the nose.  Taste is coffee, roasted malt, and chocolate.  A bit of cherry flavor sneaks its way into the whirlwind of flavors.  A great porter!
A dark brown  pour that with a small off white  head....does have some lacing.  Aroma has hints of chocolate and caramel.  Taste is like a big shot of strong coffee and chocolate.  Very good.

Bottle. Pours very dark brown, almost black, with an average light brown creamy head -- it looks great. Aroma and flavour consist of mainly chocolate and coffee with some roasted malts. Flavour is lightly bitter and sweet. This is one of my favourite readily-available beers, I try to always have some in stock. A top-notch Porter.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2005 Dark black body with a nice tan head. Aroma is chocolately and creamy. Flavor is the same, some cocoa in there as well. Very little roast and coffee. Light bitterness. Last time I had this it felt a lot smoother and had a much more creamy feel. It came out as it warmed but not to the same extent. Downgraded from a 4.5/5. Still a great Porter.

Standard by which I rate all other porters. Just heavy enough, with great chocolate flavor and hint of cherry under that. Like candy in a bottle. I get tired of it after a while, drink this just  a bit in winter. But its very good.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2005 On tap into shaker glass, Pints Pub.  Buttery caramelly smell.  Dark ruby brown with yellow tan head.  Spotty sticky lacing.  Buttery caramelly malts with a nice bitter hop presence.  Some dark cherry undercurrents.  Finish is a bit weak, sweet, and dies fairly soon.  Good body (lighter side of medium).

Dark body with quickly discipating head.  Very rich darl flavour with tastes of malt, caramel, chocolate and burnt molasses.  Prickly sensation on sides of tongue with nice chocolate aftertaste at the back of the throat.  Excellent beer.  This is one of my favorites!
Black colour, thin white creamy head with some lacing. Hints of dry fruits and chocolate. Slight liquorice taste. Medium bitterness. Hoppy and malty.

Pours medium brown with coating of film. Lots of roasted grain, nuts and coffee in the aroma. Flavor is all nuts, mostly almond though. Bet a shot of Amaretto would be nice in this. Nice body and mouthfeel.
Dark black/brown/red, strong coffee and chocolate notes in the nose and mouth, very fine ale.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2005 Bottle (500ml).  Regular stock at LCBO in Ontario (Yay!).  Looking forward to having this on cask when in UK next.  Pours black, strong roast flavour, enough hops to balance off, slightly bitter aftertaste, but it works.  Classic standard porter.  I always have a few on-hand.
I had this on tap.  A black, opaque brew with a strong burned grain flavor with a nice hop aftertaste

Poured a deep brown, almost black with a well-retained 1/2" creamy white head.  Very pretty pour.  Aroma consisted of primarily roasted malts, with chocolate, coffee, toffee, and halzenut present.  Flavor followed the aroma, and those flavors coated the mouth very well.  Smooth sustained coffee finish.

Bottle.  Pours dark, dark reddish brown and opaque until held to light.  Gives rise to a thick tan head that diminishes leisurely and leaves some lacing.  Sweet, dark malt aroma with dark brown sugar and molasses dominating the nose among hints of coffee and chocolate.  Sweet, roasty flavor, milky smooth with cocoa, coffee and prominent hops in the finish.  Full body, initially flat on the tongue with a late rising creamy carbonation.  This is indeed a fine Porter.

Bottle: Coffee black, medium beige head, frothy, dies quickly, quite nice lacing.   Coffee nose, burnt malts, subtle earthiness.   Smooth, yet subtle, coffee and roasted malt blend.   Slightly sweet lactose like tinge as well.   Moderate body and mouthfeel.   Clean finish, very smooth, soft chocolate notes on a bed of coffee and burnt malts.   Very tasty!

More of a sweet stout than a porter to me. Pours a dark Brown, small white head. Aroma is sweet, of caramel and toffee, some coffee in there as well. Flavor is roasted coffee, chocolate and almonds, very smooth.

Thanks Chuck!  Pours to a fairly dark brown color.  With an off-white head that laces pretty well.  The aroma is VERY nice.  Dry roasted malts.  Coffee, light chocolate.  The palate is very creamy and dry.  Light bitterness.  The flavor is chocolately, coffee, grassy hops, really tasty.  More porters should strive to be like this one.  Theres a bit of lactose type sweetness to this one.  I like this one a lot.  Very good roastyness.  The palate is very well balance to the flavor.  I could drink this a lot!

pours a a nice dark color w/ a red hint in it and a nice light off white head laces well stays well carbonation bubbles are light.  A bittersweet chocolate smell very dry.  Palate is pretty dry but coats pretty well.  Flavor is a dry chocolate mocha flavor a little bit of sweet malt back and a very light hop in the finish.  Overall a well made beer but more of a dry stout than a porter in my book.
Dry coffee malt and finish.  I see how many people could like this brew, but its too dry fo rmy tastes...to each his own I guess.  Not bad but I wouldnt go out of my way to get it again.

Pours a dark, dark ruby-brown with almost no head and no lacing. Smells nutty with wisps of chocolate and dark malt.

Tastes nutty with bitter chocolate undertones. Roasted malt falvors as well. Bitter finish. Smooth and tasty. Medium bodied beer but rich tasting and complex. Very, very good porter.

Best Before 29/AUG/05
Served in a Nonik

Poured with a thick frothy tan head, but faded to just some whisping.  Dark brown with ruby highlights. Pretty light carbonation.  Dark chocolate, mild roasted coffee, maybe some prunish notes in the nose.  No hops.  I get the chocolate and coffee flavor also, but in the end it has this undesireable something that I find in most Fullers brews.  Its pretty think in the mouth, and the finish stick with you for a bit.

Not a bad beer, but I wont search it out again.  Wouldnt turn it away either.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2005 This is a nice Old World styled porter.  It has some nice coffee notes among its malt characteristics but could use more.  It’s just a little light in the mouth feel--is probably much better on tap.  A  good mass-produced porter when there’s nothing else beside Guinness, Beamish, or Murphy’s.
dark brown/black with off white head.  Aroma is invitingly burnt, bitter,.  Thick, creamy mouthfeel with taste of burnt,chocolate, bitterness, Smooth and enjoyable.

Bottle.  Best before date:  09/02/05.  Very dark mahogany pour with thick creamy dark sandy head.  Roasty, chocolatey nose with a little bit of coffee, yet creamy at the same time.  Medium-bodied but still pretty rich.  Pretty smooth and creamy going down.  Tastes like carbonated dark coffee with hints of dark chocolate.  Nice bitterness.  This is overrated.  Ive had better porters before.
Bottle, poured black with a thick of white head that left wonderful lacing. Body was black. Aroma of roasted malts and coffee. Medium mouth feel with smooth coffee finish. Nice.

Dark brown with creamy tan colored head fading quickly, bitter chocolate, roasted coffee, dark roasted malt aromas, medium-bodied palate with bitter chocolate, coffee, burnt toast and dark roasted malt flavors, in a mellow malted dry finish.
Excellent porter.  Very well balanced with chocolaty, coffee, vanilla, roasted malt and a touch of bitter.  Finishes as smoothly as it starts.

Bottle. Poured a dark black with an average rocky light brown head that lasted most of the brew. Aroma was heavy roasted malt with a chocolate tone. Flavor was complex with the same roasted moderated sweet but moderate average bitter finish. Medium to full body with creamy texture. Very good brew.

Bottle. Best Before Aug 29 2005.  Pours with an inch thick head made up of large bubbles on the sides, and rocky creamy bubbles on top.  The head fell to something that looks a lot like a dense nitro head.  Aroma is quite robust, vanilla, both pale and dark malts show through, clean earthy chocolate and coffee, ever the slightest notes of alcohol, a touch of hops to that meld with the underlying sweetness to make somewhat of a bittersweet aroma.  In the flavor is where some toffee and dark chocolate note hit you.  Beer finishes with a lasting bitter roastyness.  Body is quite thin, but very sticky with flavor.  Very good.  Deserved of the high rating.  Excellent dark beer.

Bottle poured black with thick off white head and good lacing.
Light aroma of sweet roast malt and chocolate.
Good light medium body, easy drinking with a roasty, coffee  flavor and burnt malt finish.
My first taste of Porter was a good one.  The almost black color and the chocolate nose, with the smokey chocolate and coffee flavour.  This has become a staple in my fridge.

The pour is almost black with a red glow.  Nice frothy tan head that gives off a malty almost chocolate aroma.  Light and creamy to drink chocolatey sweet with roasted coffee flavor.  Just bitter enough on the finish to make you say wow what a great beer!  This is one delicious beer a beer that I have a can truly say I love!

Great presentation consisting of a dark brown pour with a very creamy head.  The aroma is highly complex with soy, caramel, chocolate, coffee and vanilla.  As far as the taste the soy was overpowering for me.  Perhaps the bottle I had was sitting to long.  The Sam Smith Porter had soy in it as well.  Perhaps I will learn to like that aspect of Porters.  Right now I dont.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2005 Bottle. Thin head with good lacing, body is a nice dark ruby. Light creamy, vanilla aroma. Taste is roasted coffee with just a touch of bitterness. Balanced sweetness with just a touch of vanilla. Hints of caramel. Mouthfeel is soft, velvety but a little too carbonated- the cask version blows this away, which is hard to believe because the bottle version is pretty darn good. Earlier Rating: 4/26/2002 Total Score: 4.3ReRate: Off the hand pump at Falling Rock. Thin head, very dark brown. Great aroma of toffee, molassis and roasted malts. Smooth, creamy palate. Taste is light roasted malts with tons of chocolate, some bitter hops coming through also towards the finish. Excellent, world class beer.

Deep chocolate brown ale, light tan creamy head.  An enticing and rich nose of roasted vanilla beans, milk chocolate, buttery toffee, oatmeal, and light coffee.  The taste is practically the same as the aroma, with the lush roasty malt integrating almost perfectly with the back end hop bitterness.  Medium bodied, pillow soft carbonation, silky,drying, bittersweet finish.  Just an outstanding porter that everyone should try.  Its well deserving of its high marks...
Black with a small tan head.  Aroma of toffee, nuts, coffee, and a bit of smoke.  Full, creamy feel.  Full roasted coffee flavor, with some smokey, nutty notes.  Great Porter.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2005 Aroma of toffee, coffee, and something sour.  Small tan head that dissipated quickly.  Mouthfeel is very full and creamy.  Strong coffee flavor, along with raisins, chocolate, figs and toffee.  Very roasty, smooth and easy drinking.  Extremely delicious, a beer I always find myself going back to.  .

Bottle. Opaque, dark color with slight head, but nothing overwhelming. Strong sweet malty taste with hints of licorace, chocolate and dark roasted coffee. Definite roasted coffee bean notes as well as malted chocolate and just a bit of raisen in the taste. Very great beer...the tastes really work very well together with no particular note overpowering the others.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2005 Refined graininess of barley malts roasted to varying degree, a handful more raw, others java-black. Aroma light sweet malt and medium chocolate. Taste bitter coffee and cocoa notes, terrific drinkable medium-full body and feel. Dark brown, fine beige head. 500 ml bottle just cool in a  tumbler. Very good!
Bottle. Tasty stuff indeed. Perhaps without the complexity of the cask version, but still nice, fairly full bodied, roasty porter, smooth, round. Lots of flavour, but not overly complex.

Drink by 4-2-05.  This poured a deep, dark brown (walnut).  There was a lite brown head.  The aroma had toasted malts, coffee grounds, nuttiness, and an almost creamy nose.  Very full.  The flavor was very mellow.  Toasted malts, lite hints of espresso and chocolate that were more apparent as the brew warmed, and even a subtle sweetness.  The body was very smooth and creamy.  Held the flavors together very well.  This was most drinkable!  You could really have this as a session beer and/or drink all the time.  Nice.

Poured dark, dark black with a nice size tan head and good lacing.  Aromas of chocolate and some licorice.  I tasted major roasted chocolate with a hint of coffee and licorice.  Not too complex, but brilliant.  Smooth oily-watery feel, full bodied with light carbonation.  This was the perfect compliment to live Jazz and comfortable chairs.

Coppery brown, slightly translucent body. Large creamy tan head. Rich sweet bourbon, chocolate aroma with some very light flowery hops? Flavor has the same bourbony chocolate body with a lactic acid and coffee finish. While its nice and full, it still seems to be missing something to complete it.
dark w/ little head.  malty & chocolatey aroma.  full bodied, nutty w/ the taste of roasted barley.  rich but drinkable, a very good porter!

Pours clear and ruby, with a black look when tilted away from light. Supreme frothy  tall off-white head. Sweet sticky lacing. Rich, rich coffee and tea aromas, backed with light chocolate and strong dark malt. A tiny waft of alcohol and cherries. Flavor begins mellow, with a light touch of honey and wheat. Finishes bitter and dry. Strong roasted malt smack and toast in the aftertaste. Very fine bubbles. Palate is sharp and smooth, but a little watery, yet leaving a lingering coating on the tounge. A much appreciated refreshing brew after a long day on the road.

Pours black with small creamy tan head.  Nose is very chocolaty and of coffee. Sweet.  Flavor is an explosion of robust maltyness with caramel, chocolate and a fine smokiness.  Very satisfying.  As it warms there is a pleasant bitterness that creeps into the finish.

super dark black with a thick head initially.. smell is rosted nuts/chocolate/coffee...flavor is very very smooth, very thick and creamy with a slight bitter finish.. probably the best porter i have ever had

Black with chestnut highlites supporting a creamy tan head and a good amount of lacing.  Classic porter aromas of roasted malt, toffee, chocolate with some added hop aroma at the back of the nose.  Flavor is smooth, well-balanced and follows the aroma but with some additional intensity.  Those Fuggles hops cant be ignored and they add a nice bitter touch to the otherwise lasting but clean finish.  There are a number of great porters out there but this one certainly deserves to be counted as one of the best.
Nutty, semi-sweet bakers-chocolate-like taste, thin head, but it is smooth and I will say this one does the trick when you cant find your favorite impossible to find world-class porter!

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2006 This is the only porter Ive had. When I first opened it I thought "what the heck is that great smell?" Well Im assuming its hops and this beer is GREAT. Ive never had a beer quite like this. I drank it down fast and wished I had bought more. Big tan head, silky creamy mouth feel and great malt and hops flavor balance.....a must have. 

RE-RATE: Its still the best porter Ive had. and Ive had a bunch now.

Thus far, I have never had a Porter that comes remotely close to comparing with this one.  Pours black cherry red when held up to the light, with about an inch think light tan head.  The aroma was heavy butterscotch, chocolate, and caramel x10. I was not expecting that fullness in the nose at all.  Made me so anxious to taste it, I got the chills HAH. The taste is dry chocolate and roasted malts, but with an immediate chewiness in the mouth noticable even before swallowing.  Definately can taste the flavors that are in the nose.  The mouthfeel is what sold me on the perfection of this Porter.  I couldnt believe how creamy it was. My tongue was confusing it with the thickness or smoothness of melted butter.  Can taste mellow hop notes as it finishes.  All in all, I havent decided, but this very well be my favor brew to date, everything just fit right with it.

very close to perfection. BIG foamy, creamy, rocky light tan head that lasts, with lots of lace. Very fragrant - loads of chocolatey, roasty, malty, hints of leather and dark earth. Very smooth and creamy mouth filling. Well balanced flavors that taste the way it smells. Very dark mahogeny brownish red. Excellent!! Had a bottle last night at Bodega.

Body is a nice garnet, head is tan and small.  Aroma of toffee, butterscotch, bitter coffee, and some chocolate.  Flavor has notes of bakers chocolate and caramel, a lot of coffee roastiness, but the palate is quite thin.  Finish is dry and sweet.  Rather disappointing.
Medium to full body. Creamy mollases,coffee,chocolate. Good head that quickly diminishes. Soft carbonation and long bitter finish. Almost as good as Sam Smith Porter.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2005 (12 oz bottle) Pours almost completely opaque ruby with almost no head at all.  Smells strongly of sweet malts and cocolate.  Caramel and roasted malts rule the taste.  Good bitter finish.  A little to sweet.

Ive had this both on tap and in bottle.  Delicious either way, but prefer tap.  less carbonation on tap and the flavors are mellowed out too.Very dark porter (atleast darker and richer than St. Peters Old Time Porter)  Earthy hazelnut, caramel, mild chocolate notes.  Mild bitterness, nice finish.  Cheers!

Roast, chocolate and caramel w/ a slight hint of citrus on the nose... and the same on the mouth, this beer poured a deep brown color w/ purple/red hues; thin lasting head and lacing.  The mouthfeel was creamy, but slighly watery, well-rounded and full.

Pours a very dark brown, aroma of molasses with a hint of coffee. Very dark in a glass, head keeps well, very balanced flavor or strength and bitterness. No lingering after-taste like some domestic (USA) porters. Best Porter I have had to date.
A smokey chocolate wonderful, Im a pale lager lover, but this may change everything. I figured I perferred stout to a porter, but this porter...mmm this porter

Bottled. When I first tasted this beer cask conditioned, it turned my world upside down, regarding how a porter could taste. On bottle it is not nearly as good, but still excellent. Sweet malty aroma. Flavor is full of caramel and roast. Good carbonation. Very smooth session porter, evenhough it is a bit on the sweet side.

Much stronger orange tint than the average porter. Typical pleasant aroma, with a strong element of cocoa - but in the sense of Nestle Quik as opposed to "real" cocoa. Flavor is definitely more complex than the typical porter. Here the Quik element is gone and smoky malt flavors meld with TRUE cocoa elements and great bitter fuggles. Finish is crisp and refreshing.

Dark dark red, roasted malty molasses aroma is nice. Smooth creamy mouthfeel...damn...the bottles empty already! Well balanced with a mildly tart roasted coffee finish. Definitly my favorite Porter, but not my favorite kinda brew.

Pours deep reddish brown. Dark reddish brown, good head, med. bubbles, last through full pint. Very subtitle aroma. Flavors are chocolate and caramel in a smooth, silky body. Finishes will light bitterness coated in caramel.

Clear, black-ruby with a nice, foamy head that formed good lacing.  Aroma was strong toasted malt with some English hops and butterscotch.  Spicy, melanoidin malt that was in good balance with bitterness that came from both the malt and the hops.  Roasty caramel apples (not acetaldehyde).  Medium body with perfect carbonation.  Surprisingly gentle finish.  This is world class stuff.
Dark dark with small shortlived head. Chocolate, roasty & coffee-like with the thick tangy malty porter character. A very good example of the style.

Dark brown, almost black, with a big frothy creamy head. Aroma is hazelnut, chocolate, cinnamon, nutmeg and cocoa. Flavor is chocolate and coffee, roasted malts, caramel and plums. A hint of nuts and smoke on the finish. Really nice mouthfeel, smooth, a bit thicker than the average porters Ive tried.

Somewhere between black and brown, sweet aroma. Taste is a nice blend of chocolate, coffe and malt. Very smooth, very nice mouthfeel. Goes great with deserts or is a great desert on its own. Excellent brew.
