Roasty smoky flavor.  Not sure how it looks -- drank it out of the bottle, but Ill give it the benefit of the doubt on that one.  Flavors are roasted malt, coffee, no hops, smoky finish.  Amazing texture -- very thick for a porter.  Delicious.

Dark ,dark mohagany brew with the rich roasted aromas from the malts catching my attention right away.Chocolate and fresh roasted coffee are right there on the tongue,I had this in London and didnt rate it then but it is just as good now.Nice lingering aftertaste and good body.
Black-brown.  Head lasts 30 seconds.  Chocolate raspberry grains.  Winner!  Coffee chocolate tart finish.  Ill try this again soon.  Im thoroughly impressed with the (accidental?) tart fruitiness.

Dark and oily looking. Minimal head. Nice looking beer. Coffee aromas. Smooth and creamy palate. Nice coffee toffee tobacco roasted sweet flavors. Smooth English malts. Nice on the palate, not too thick not too thin. Very reasonably priced.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2008 [18.6 oz. bottle] Dark brown pour with red highlights and a light brown head. Very malty and toasty coffee aroma with hints of toffee, caramel and brown sugar. The taste begins with a nice coffee flavor that gives way to a sweet middle and a roasty malt finish that leaves a little bitter flavor in your mouth. Very smooth feeling.

Pours a dark brown color with a red tint and a thick and creamy off white head.  Cereal like aroma of malts with hints of toffee and roasted coffee.  Very smooth body, little carbonation and a strong coffee flavor with bits of roasted malt and a nice underlying hoppiness in the finish.  A bit thin of a body...but a better than average porter.

Pours black with thin dissipating head. Aroma is very sweet with lots and lots of carmel. Flavor is mostly of roasted malt. Finish is clean. Nice medium body. Smooth. No bitterness. Quite disappointing. Read SilkTorks rating and youll understand exactly what I mean.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2006 Black color (only with direct light does a hint of ruby redness shine through) with a medium sized off white head. Aroma is full of roasted malts, with coffee, figs, oak, vanilla. Flavor is Malty, slightly sweet, chocolately, faint coffee notes. I admit that I am not usually a porter fan, but this is nice.
This is more of what british porters should taste like.  A true benchmark brew.

Pours a deep, dark reddish brown with virtually no head. Aroma of coffee and malt. Flavour is an explosion of complexity, coffee, roasted malts and general yumminess. Palate is faultless, smooth and rich. The archetypal porter.

Dark brown color, creamy head, slightly smoky and browny.
In fact, this is all brown here.
Cream and chocolate palate on a low carbonation and a slightly thin  and grainy aftertaste.
O.K. porter to me!

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2007 (Rerate, prev 2005/1/22, 7-3-6-3-13) Near black colored, strongly roasted sweet aroma with licorice, chocolate and smoke, fine aroma. Medium bodied. Flavor starts with strong coffee and roastiness, ends with more dry tones. Burned malts last in aftertaste.

This beer is well done, deserving of its high marks.  Smelled of molasses and roasted malt.  Poured a dark brown with a small, off-white and fizzy head.  Taste = damn good; very roasted, with a prune/plum like quality underscoring the flavors.  Enough said.  Good beer.

Very dark brown with a tan head that subsides quickly leaving a ring of bubbles. Strong nose of roasted chocolate malt, molasses, some fruit (prunes). Rich flavour of chocolate, molasses, coffee and prunes. Smooth and very well balanced. Lingering bitter(just enough) hop finish.  Mmmm... this is a delightful porter.
A very nice chocolatety brew... typical English bitterness in the background balances the sweetness quite nicely.  One to visit over and over again.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Deep dark brown witha  tan head thats quite thick. Roasted nose of molasses and coffee. Rich mouthfeel with a light dry finish. Flavors of roasted coffee, molasses, light hops and some fruit. An overall chocolatenss makes this a great beer!

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2005 Dark brown, off-white head. Not too thick and crisply carbonated. Feels light on the tongue but has an intense flavor profile. Bittersweet chocolate, roasty malts and coffee, raisins, and a nicely balanced bitter hop finish. Very good.

Bottle. Under a short lasting off-white head, this beer appears dark brown. Coffee, chocolate and some sweet notes in the aroma. The taste is roasted malts, coffee and some fruit (plum?). A little nice bitterness in the end. A great porter.

from the bottle best before 10/17/04. pured a deep mahogany, with a nice tan head. aroma bitter sweet chocolate, toffee, roasted malts, plums and prunes, hard time taking my nose away from this one. flavor, toffee, chocolate, raisins, honey, malts, cherries. mouthfeel was  a nice and smooth and just enough bitterness
Bottle from Sainsburys. Pasteurised. Rich aroma of smoke, spice, coffee, malt. Smooth mouthfeel, tastes smoky slightly sweet. Roasty malt finish.

18.6oz bottle. Best before 14 Feb 05. 51.5°. NB Worthy glass.  Dark brown, nearly black with red tint. Small off white head that subsides quickly, leaving a small ring of foam and bubbles. Great nose of vanilla, chocolate, roasted malt, it has a rather sweet nose with some subtle hops notes of a more floral nature.  Taste is roasted/nearly burnt malt with a fruity/hoppy base.  There are notes of coffee, vanilla (oak?), herbal (almost cola-like), fruit peels and a slight sourness.  Even though this has the nose of a big beer, the mouthfeel lets you know that it is not, which is one of the only weak points in this otherwise wonderful beer.
Aroma was a wonderful raisen, smokey chocolate, taste was fruity malt, but disappointingly thin. Judging by previous reviews I got a bad bottle, but Id take the Bells porter over this any time

Pours dark brown with a flufy tan head. Sweet chocolate aroma. Taste is big on coffee with average amounts of hops. Big time coffee in this one. Rich, full mouthfeel. Lacing that lasts forever. Great porter.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2005 English beauty. Diacetyl out front on aroma yet not over the top. Taste tells a different story. Buttery chocolate malt enhanced by that classic English sourness and bitterness so well delivered by moderate carbonation. English yeast fermentation provides the classic result. Its been a long time since I last had this one. How many times did I say classic? One more time! Serve at cave temp in a clean pint glass.
WOW this is a wonderful porter.  Pours a deep brown with and small tan head.  Has a wonderful coffee aroma with a maltly flavor.  This is a adamn good porter.

Pours an almost opaque  black with a medium head. Aromas of roasted chocolate malt and a touch of raisins. Drank this at room temperature to capture the full flavour of roasted malt, a nice burnt taste and coffee.

Bottle.  Got this one on trade from kaggie97, thanks Kevin!  Pours a dark cherry color with a nice thick head.  Not a jet black beer, but a deep black cherry with decent lacing.  Nose is awesome with raisins coming quickly, sweet and strong with coffee and burnt sugar.  This beer smells like those wonderful raisin cookies that my wifes Grandma Walters used to make with the sweet dough and raisins mixing wonderfully.  Body is medium, which surprised me a little as I expected more from it.  Little to no carb (its an English brew, what should I expect?) and I believe that is a fault.  Taste is of coffee sweetness when it hits the buds, then sort of slides into a coffee bitterness and a nice creaminess as it warms. You definitely need to let this one warm to a decent temp.  I was too eager... Beautiful long finish on the flavors, burnt malts and roasted bliss, but no real hop flavor.  Good overall taste, but Id like a little more hops.  What else is new?  Still a quality, kick ass porter.

Pours a deep dark ruby, almost black color. Nice roasted coffee aroma. Rich aroma. Delicious. Deep rich roasted coffe like bitterness. Wonderful burnt, roasty flavor from start to finish. I was wondering if this was really that good. It is.

Had it on Draught, Dark brown with tan head,smells of licorice and coffee,Smooth flavor of black and chocolate malts rounded  off with a pleasent roastiness full mouthfeel
Awesome porter!

Very dark appearance with a garnet edge.  Toffeeish,  roasted  chocolate malt aroma shifting slightly to dark fruits.  Exceptionally smooth, full bodied taste with subtle carbonation.  Medium length finish.
A very rich and smooth taste, with  an full boddy off licorice flavors. Overall this is one off my favorite beers.
At first a smooth taste rushes your tastebuds followed by the cool flavor of coffee with a hint of chocolate,

Aroma:Cofee chocolate
Oeil:Black small head
Flavor:Cofee a chocolate smooth
I just dont get why people find this porter so fantanstic.  Yeah, its good- very smooth, everythings integrated really well.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2005 Cask, hand-pump at the Swan in the Rushes, Loughborough. 
The best porter Ive ever had, and one of the best beers, full stop. Malty, chocolatey aroma, with a superb, complex flavour of malts, caramel, chocolate, coffee and more. Full bodied, creamy. Fantastic.
Bottle, 11/01/05
Question; Is the bottled version as good as the cask? Very close, but the cask has it by a nats.

Pours dark with a deep ruby shade when held to the a light. Light tan head with minimal retention (Possibly a bit colder than it should have been).  Excellent aroma of chocolate with some hint of mocha and caramel.  Full of body. Pleasant finish with minimal bitterness.  An excellent porter!!

Well, what can I say? This is quite simply one of the best beers available on a regular basis in Ontario, and is a fantastic beer by any measure. Whats even better is to be able to drink it on cask draft from Dora Keogh in Toronto. Its an amazing multitude of flavours - nuts, coffee, chocolate, malt, caramel. Quite simply one of the best porters, and one of the best beers. Period.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2014 Bottled.  Theres a lot of debate whether us British raters are more realistic when it comes to rating Fullers products (and Sam Smiths) and that raters elsewhere think the beers are better than they are.  I had this beer on cask many years ago and remember really enjoying it.  Ive looked for it on cask this Winter but to no avail, so I had to drink and rate the bottled version.  Well in my opinion the US raters and others have got this right.  It is a beautiful porter, full bodied, robust, call it what you want, but call it good (or even great).  It is black as night and has a short-lived off-white head and leaves no lacing.  The aroma is scrummy with loads of malts, lots of coffee and some chocolate.  Those qualities are replicated to better definition in the taste.  It is very full bodied, very flavoursome and very dark tasting.  Again coffee and burnt malts come through; together with a little chocloate.  An excellent drinking experience.  It doesnt matter that the beer is dead.  Hell, I would wager that a BC version would not be as good, given the general quality of most English BCAs.  This beer deserves its reputation on this site and its awards.  I will continue to look for it on cask in my Fullers light part of England.  Ive heard it sells for a ridiculous price in the trade and therefore pubs have to sell it at inflated prices, but it may just be worth it.  Score 4.4Subsequent ratings scored 3.8, 4.1 and 3.8. Average becomes 4.0
The best porter available?  Perhaps, but this beer hurts in the bottle, get it on draught or handpull and it shines.  Highly drinkable and wonderfully complex for a porter.

best before 23 NOV 04 550ml bottle. 
deep dark burgundy color, aroma is strong mocha.  i was expecting a lot from this top 50 brew and was not dissappointed.  body was meduim to full. this was very easy to drink and enjoy.  there was a long bitter coffee finish.  very nice.  probably the definative beer of the style.

Bottle. Deep brown color, tan head that left decent lacing. Aroma was potent and malty, chocolately, very nice. Rich chocolate malt flavor, nice smoke and earthy notes along with it. Smooth mouthfeel, nice chocolatey finish. An outstanding porter.
A dark and pleasant porter. Low carbonisation makes it an easy to sip beer but for my mind it is not distinctive enough to be classed as a great. Good but not outstanding.

Jet black hue with a large creamy light brown head.  Rich coffee and dark chocolate aroma.  Coffee and roasted malt flavours with hints of coco and toffee.  A full bodied beer of some complexity.  A high quality porter.

12.11.04  bottle.  Ill be darned, this stuff is sneaky hard to find despite its gazzillion ratings.  Deep maple colored brew with average tan head that lingers.  The aroma is striking alike that of those Goetzes creme filled caramel candies: lots of vanilla, cream, and caramel sugar.  A bit on the nutty and sweet side with an earthy undertone.  Not a terribly exciting flavor profile, but nicely balanced, certainly complex, and very likable.  Alot of vanilla, nut, and milk in flavors; vinous, milk chocolate.  Quick to finish with a nice bit if coffee bitterness and an alcohol trace.
Black body with beige head. Roasted aroma with some coffee and chocolate, hints of bitterness. Flavor is complex with both sweetness and bitterness in the taste.
Personal favorite: Beautiful chocolate colour, splendid hints of chocolate in the flavour and more that I am too inexperienced to really describe. Very smooth.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2005 Black, beige lasting head. Low carbonation. Roasted aroma with lots of licorice (and coffee). The flavour is dominated by licorice. Notes of coffee, roasted malts, chocolate. Some underlying malty sweetness balanced by a touch of fruit (black currants?). Dry rather short finish. Smooth, velvety palate. Allmost sticky. Archtypical London Porter. Perhaps a lack of depth?

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2006 The bottled version nearly holds up to the cask version. There are some notes absent though, such as the fresh coffee aroma that greets you in a perfectly poured and conditioned pint. Apart from that it has all the complexity and enjoyment of the fresher version.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: UPDATED: DEC 7, 2004 Pours black with a smallish head.  I was struck by the uniqueness of the aroma--roasty, chocolatey, and theres something else in there I cant put my finger on.  But I like it.  Very good slightly roasted, mostly sweet flavor a tad smoky in the finish.  If only one porter could exist, Id want it to be this one.

Great stuff, vineous scent and plenty of mocha. Highly drinkable in that its not harshly carbonated and just the right amount of bitterness. Seems like a great, solid-quality beer, although Ill need to try some more porters for comparison.

Pours black as mud. looks thick and has trouble keeping a head. Suprisingly its very carbonated when you take a mouthful. Very creamy. A very unique porter. chocolate and savory.  In no way sweet. very interesting beer. Try this one.
This is good.  Very good.  Lots of roasty chocolate flavors in this one, as expected.  Very well-balanced, almost creamy texture.  Got to give credit where credit is due.
Cask @ The Victoria pub (lancaster gate) and bottled 500ml. Black with small tan head Toffee aroma. mild carbonation with coffee aftertaste. Smooth. An excellent porter

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2006 Dark dark amber. Smells a tad fruity. Taste fruity at first(prunes maybe) then gives away to very dark roasty/coffee flavors with a touch of chocolate(maybe). Nevertheless an outstanding and tasty brew that is in the regular rotation.

Vinous chocolate and coffee aroma with hints of vanilla and leather. Dark but still visably clear and ruby and color. Excellent dense rocky head. Ever so smooth in flavor with some smoke and a powdery cocoa finish. Drink a pint and go back in time.
UPDATED: JUL 19, 2005 Bottle. Black with tan creamy thick head, coffee, chocolate, roast malt, leather, sweet and dry with some hops. Yes a really good winter beer and even better than Old Peculiar.

overall tasty brew, just kinda run of the mill though.  nothing really stuck out that made me want the 2nd bottle i bought.  chocolate and roasted malt dominated the taste, with hops and creamy coffee lying underneath itall.  pretty smooth, but lacking.
Dark brown(almost black) color with a small tan head. Nice aroma of roasted malt, dark chocolate and coffee. Flavor of chocolate malts, coffee and then a nice hoppy finish. Excellent.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2009 A dark, smoothe pour. creamy taste. damn. what a bad a-- brew. The aroma and taste is like sticking your head in a bag of fine coffee. Infact, I think I will go do that right now!
Wow. Was leary because I didnt really dig the stout, but this stuff was top notch.  Very smooth, creamy and chocolatey taste with nice finish. Great texture. One of my favs.

Poured a dark black (with some reddish tint) with a smaller off white head. Aromas of mocha, coffee and roasted malts. Very good aroma. Chocolate heavier in the taste. Nice bitter finish. One of the better porters Ive had - very good.

Dark brown body topped with a rich beige bubbly head that unfortunately did not last for a long time. Rich and complex aroma dominated by roasted coffee, dark chocolate, brown sugar, and even molasses. Although the taste is very roasty, we can easily recognize the the Fuggle hops flavors. Mouthfeel ends with a long and superbly dry/bitter finish. I love Porters, and that one is definitely a top notch! Perfect on a Sunday night, in order to relax before the week to come...

Looks great, smells great, tastes great.   mmm this is what I been looking for in a porter.  Love that roasty coffee with  chocolate flavor. Just a liitle dry but not overly so, and yet still creamy. Smooth and silky.  Oh yeah this is Good!  Not the least bit overrated.

Decent sized head.  Creamy on top.  Light carbonation and decnt lacing.  Rich aroma with coffee, dark chocolate, some hops and a hint of toasted marshmallow.  Color is a very dark reddish black.  Flavor is very roasty.  Lots of roasted grains, more coffee.  Flavor is a little thin.  Dry palate.  Finishis dry and bitter with a nice lingering roasted aftertaste.  A good porter but I dont think that it should be rated as high as it is.
UPDATED: NOV 4, 2005 REVIEW #1. Very smooth, dark porter without an aggressive bite which can be a turn off. Nice bitter finish leaves you with nothing but satisfaction.

Poured dark reddish black with a good looking tan head. Aroma of chocolate malt and coffee, which was evident in the flavor profile as well. Great mouthfeel, with a nice amount of bitterness in the end.
Bottled. Pours very dark, average sized light brown head. A roasty, faintly coffelike, pleasing aroma. Creamy and smooth; very smooth finish. Tasty.
12 oz bottle.  Dark ale, modest head, decent lacing.  Roasted, dry, bitter beer, a little brother to Guiness.  Silky finish.
Very dark body and head, and a stiff musty aroma with a very , very, very dry and slightly thick flavour.  Overall OK, but slightly overrated.

Dark appearance with ruby highlights, aroma of coffee and chocolate. Flavors of coffee, fruit, toffee and a hint of smoke are well balanced, making for a smooth experience and nice finish. One of the better porters Ive tried, really gets good near the bottom of the glass as it warms.

Bottled.  Very dark with a fairly large beige head.  Aromas are earthy, roasted malts, coffee with some licourice.  You really have to get your nose to the beer to get the full aroma!   Flavours are dry, oaty roast malts, earthy with some sweetness and chocolate.  Fruity and dry on the finish.  Porters can sometimes be a little thin - this isnt.  Come on Fullers, make a bottle conditioned version.

Pours very dark, but not quite as dark as Anchor or Stone porters with a roasted toffee aroma. Crisp on the tongue and in the mouth, with a lingering caramel, cafe aftertaste. This is my first try and Id say its a toss up between Fullers and Anchor for my top porter of choice. Ill def. have to see what else fullers has to offer. Great Brew.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2004 First, let me say that this is one badass looking bottle, mostly black and big. Poured into Samuel Smith Imperial pint glass. Pours black with red at the edges, thin creamy tan head that lasts on top. Smell is chocolate, coffee with cream, light hops and paper, similar to an Oatmeal stout. Very cream mouthfeel that feels excellent. Sour/bitter in the beginning. As it gets further along, there is chocolate, dirt, and a little sourness with a dry coffee finish. Easily the best porter Ive had. (Ive since had Alpha Klaus, though this is more to style...)

This was my first tasing of this beer.  I have not had much from this company before. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle the beer poured a dark black color with a large tan head. Barely any light shines through its murky depths. The aroma is strong with chocolate. The texture is thick and oily. The flavor is heavy and thick with malt and chocolate. There is a light bitterness on the finish. The beer is overall much sweeter than I expected. I think that this helped endear it to me.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2005 Strong toasty aroma,and really nice dark appitizing appearance with a small beige head.Really strong malty bitter treacle taste,Im not getting chocolate,just a really nice roasted malty flavour.Definately a good Porter...amoungst the best.

Well what can I say this porter is damn good, not quite as flavorful as MacTarnahans Bourban Cask BlackWatch  porter but still really good, this will probabvly end up being my second highest rated Porter.  Creamy Beige head and thick lacing.  Sweet chocolatey aroma.  Smooth and rich taste in mouth, lots of coffee and chocolate flavor, excellent.
UPDATED: DEC 27, 2009 This beer is so good!  Lots of flavor.. nice roastiness, good balance.. not too strong on the tongue.  Great mouthfeel.  This is an excellent beer!
Black with a creamy head.  Smelled a bit like coffee.  Tasted a bit like coffee and chocolate.  Nice,  smooth and very filling.  ill drink this again.

This poured almost black into the glass with a healthy brown head.  Nice burnt chocolate aroma.  Very creamy in the mouth with chocolate and caramel tastes, rosted malts with a hint of smokiness.  It leaves a good feeling in the mouth.  This is what porters should be.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2006 Bottle at the Old Joint Stock, Birmingham. Finally I get to sample this legend which has returned to English shores. Nice dark brown/black, with a creamy beige head, and pleasant choc aroma. Toasty flavour: mild roasted oats and choc. Lightish, very drinkable, very smooth, but didnt blow my head off. Drinkable and tasty - very pleasant, but I must admit I was expecting the earth. Ill try again (while I still can). RE-RATE - Ive had this manytimes since, and it is a real quality beer. Much better than nearly all other Porters Ive ever supped, and one of the most reliable fall back option beers ever.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2005 Pours a very dark mahogany with a modest sized light tan head.  Smells big and robust. Smells smoky and dry with chocolate malts and sweet toffee.

This is one BIG porter! Rich and full bodied! Seems to be lacking a bit of complexity up front on the palate but makes up for it on the mid-palate and the finish. Cocoa, chocolate, coffee, toffee and light fruits.
One of the better beers Ive sampled.  Not my favorite, but Id drink it again.  Very full flavored with ample complexity.  Plenty of roastiness which I like.

Black and stark in the glass, but looks somewhat watery.  Ample roasted malt notes, lots of chocolate on the nose.  Tons of flavor of the same, with a hint of chicory and tea.  Smooth and long on the palate.  A benchmark for porter.
Coffee! Thats what took me so long to think of. It reminded me of coffee by the smell of it, taste too. Nice and smooth. A very professional porter. Well put together with a mild after taste.

Bottle @ Akkurat, Stockholm. Offical tasting with represetatives from the brewery.Had this as cask before being a Rater. THAT is a beer to walk miles for. Quite good botteled as well with aroma of coffee and smoked ham. Full bodied. A nice chilly days beer.
This porter is a so smooth it is a delight! Very tasty but a slight sour aftertaste. Excellent with burgers or prime rib!

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2005 seeing the high rating on this one i had to get one and  taste if for myself.i must say it is a very good porter.nice smokey taste,and very pleasing aroma.although i personally like my porters a bit thicker overall,this does not disapoint for sure.
re-rate:i think i was a little hard on this tastey little porter.this is my second bottle and im really enjoying it.

Another great porter.
Not much chocholate flavor,but a smooth smokey,and slight coffee flavor.
Smoke dominates in a good way.
Very good balance.

Dark ruby brown with a tan head. Rich chocolatey aroma with plenty of roastiness. Smooth and roasty, nice cocoa notes. Freshly roasted coffee comes through quite nicely. Well balanced and very tastey. Cant believe I over looked this for so long.
god damn this is good pours a creamy brown head that makes my mouth water. has a bit of coffe flava that definitly wakes me up definitly one of my favorites

I cant believe I waited this long to try this one.  First of all, this one deserves its top 50 ranking.  Pours dark ruby with a big, creamy tan head.  Aroma of big malt, chocoff, slight dark fruit.  Tastes malty, roasty, with tons of chocoff, nuts, and corn flakeyness.  The palate is firm, bold, complex, with a semi-dry, roasty finish.  Very well balanced, nice complexity, and an awesome beer.  I put this one just behind Dogwood Impy and FFF Alpha Klaus as my favorite porter of all time (so far).

Poured a dark ruby with a large soapy tan head.  Aroma was of roasted malts, cocoa, and coffee.  The flavor was excellent.  Man what a beer.  My mouth watered when I saw it, and even more so after the first taste!  Very malty, lots of rich dark chocolate flavors and a mild hint of coffee, among other less describable perfections.  The palate was very smooth with a good bit of carbonation.  Slightly dry bitter finish.  The only thing that would make this beer better would be me not having a cold and being able to experience more of the taste which is amazing.  Wow, what a beer.

Tap
Opaque color, medium expresso head slowly vanishing. Sweet raisin aroma. Medium-bodied. Coffee flavor, roasted. Long chocolaty aftertaste. Expected fuller body.
UPDATED: SEP 22, 2004 A beer best enjoyed after a solid, filling meal, replacing both coffee and cognac. Very dark, very filling and strong. The perfect companion for a  restful evening.
Black with a big head. Smoky aroma from coffee and chocolate. Flavor brings coffe, milk chocolate and some licorice. Smoky and with a bitter finish.

Bottle: Pours a dark coffee like colour, with a medium beige head.  Has a strong coffee smell with a mild sweet molasses background.  Initail Malt flavour with a chocolate aftertaste.  Has a watery bitter finish.  Overall an excellent brew!

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2004 Ive never had a porter before so I wasnt sure what to expect.  It pours cola colour and smells of caramel a bit malty and a bit of a sweet coffee.  Smooth taste, slight carbonation on first taste... but gets even smoother after that.  Great!  Even better on re-rate after having a fantastic Mill Street Porter.

Nice roasted malt taste with just a subtle hint of bittler dark chocolate. I was actually a little surprised at the level of bitterness. Very flavorful. However I think I like Fuller’s 1845 a little bit better overall.
dark brown nearly black, rich creamy roasted chocolate coffe smooth all the way to the finnsh

Color: a somewhat clear russet brown, head: 1/2" of toasted tan. Nose is on the burnt side, very roasty and sharp, bitter, hot, with flavors of pepper and espresso.
Mouthfeel is warm, texture is smooth, hops are hard to notice. Malt stands up proudly, though, in all its lushly roastedness.
This is quite a consumable porter, a very flavorful session ale, to say the least. Finish is sweet and nutty, and lasts just long enough. 
A darn good porter.

The attractive bottle poured forth an equally attractive nearly-opaque black brew capped by a moderate creamy tan head.  The luscious aroma contained hints of dark fruit, plum, and rich coffee, but was most strongly reminiscent, in my opinion, of delicious buttery bread toasting in the oven.  Yum.  The flavor had all of the above and more; a sublime blend of dark chocolate, espresso, and roasted breadiness delivered in a delicately sweet package.  Full and creamy in the mouth.  A truly awesome beer, and most certainly my favorite porter to date.

Bottle. Medium sized tan head and fine-medium sized bubbles. Mostly opaque, carbonated and a dark brown hue. Malty, caramel and roasted coffee aroma. Flavor was chocolate and roasted coffee from start to finish. Smooth mouthfeel. Good lacing. A very good Porter IMO. Well worth a try!

Strong, roasted, pleasant aroma.  It pours very dark, almost opaque.  A thin tan creamy head sits nicely on top.  The initial taste is very complex, with flavors of caramel and chocolate dominating.  The body is rich, and the carbonation is slightly below-average.  The finish is bitter and on the strong side.  Not a beer for everyone, but definitely a wonderful porter.
Dark brown, almost black. Roasty, chocolate nose. Flavour is coffee and roasted malts, a good juggling act here between sweet and bitter. Soft and smooth in the good way. Great beer. Bottle.

From the bottle.  There was a substantial head upon the pour, and it dropped gradually to a creamy bed on top of the beer.  The colour is quite black, opaque for sure, with a slight hint of red.  The burnt aroma, supported with a sweetness,  is enticing.  It draws one in.  Palate is thin but creamy-feeling.  The carbonation is biting at first, but it mellows dramatically.  Flavour is expected for a porter...its a beer I can chew.  There are many flavours working all at once that I find myself pausing after each taste to take account of them all.  Porter could become my new favourite style aside from the fact that there is a poor representation in Ontario.  Ive brewed better porters but for the everyday consumer in Ontario, this one works.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2005 500ml brown bottle. Deep brown in colour, mahogany highlights. Holds a decent tan head - creamy and frothy when first poured, then settles to a light layer of soft foam. Chocolate and coffee aroma with some roasted notes and light suggestion of fruit which quickly faded. Rich roasted malt taste with chocolate and coffee bitterness.

The London Porter pours a dark brown with ruby highlights.  It has a smallish brown head that quickly goes down to a thin film and then completely disappears.

Its aroma is chocolate and caramel malts and some dry, chalky toffee / butterscotch.

The flavor is acidic, bitter chocolate with some caramel malts and a strong butterscotch flavor.  The butterscotch became a little overwhelming as it warmed - both in flavor and aroma.  It has a chalky, slightly bitter finish.  It is thinner than I expected and under-carbonated.

Overall, I was expecting a lot from this, and was very disappointed.  Ive had much better porters.  I wonder if I had a bad bottle - it is 3 months before the best by date though.

(on bottle)100 overall? Well, by all means, this must be the mother of all porters. Roast and coffee is two things that pops up in both sent, mouth and finish. Not very complex in turms of levels but it´s difinite use of a few strings makes it fantastic. And I just love the watery mouthfeel, real porterstyle and makes you soak into a new and a new...

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2006 Classic Porter smell and look. Roasted chocalate overtones and great malty, toasty and roasty mouthfeel. Well rounded and balanced with ample chocolate and coffee notes. Worthy of its praise.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2006 Nice mouthfeel, but nothing to go crazy over.  Smooth. It does lack an edge, but is a very palatable brew.This is a smooth, decent porter, but way....wait, let me use all caps for badly need emphasis...WAY overrated.  There is no way on this earth this ale warrants a rating over 4---absolutely no way.  Its good, but only because its on the positive side of being close to average.  Theres definitely some good choco-coffee flavour but definitely sans the character that ALL of the best examples exhibit. All the dark malt flavours are there, and its nice, but the oomph is missing.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2005 Pours  a transparent reddish dark brown with a small head. Aroma is of delicious roasted coffee. Taste is of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Very tasty, slightly burnt aftertaste. Mouthfeel is full and round but not that thick on the palate. Bold and delicious, leaves a nice lingering coffee taste. Simply delightful. Highly recommended.
Dark brown almost black...smells of chocolate and coffee...tastes thick and chewy...a fuller (hahaha) bodied beer than I expected...finishes is sweet and a little apparent alcohol...

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2004 Dark amber, nice offwhite head. Aroma from coffee and cocoa. Flavor is coffe, cocoa and chocolate. I really like the Fullers beers, but expected this one to be better. I have to look for this one on tap somewhere.
A rich smooth ale with a lovely chocolate malt taste. Ideal for sitting and sipping on a cokld winters night. This is however no session ale and would be hard to drink in quantity
Black beer with a brownish head. The nose is roasty with ints of chocolate. At first sip I tasted bitter chocolate followed by a roasty hoppy bitterness. Quite nice.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2006 Black with a tan head. Aroma is chocolate and roasty with hints of prunes and figs. Has a nice rich mouthful. Starts with a chocolate taste, then moves to a more fruit taste, and finally comes back to a dark chocolate finish. The chocolate malts really dominate most of the taste. Has some roast and fruit in there for a nice compliment to the chocolate. One tasty mother fucking porter.
UPDATED: APR 9, 2005 Black color, coffee roasty aroma, spicy taste, full body, smooth bitter finish. Love it, almost as good as a Limfjords porter.

Bottle: Pours to a dark ruby black color with a small tan head.  This porter has s rich, roasty aroma of coffee, dark chocolate, cereal, dark fruit, raisins and honey.  The aroma is not very pungent.  At the first smell, Im not really expecting much in the way of assertive taste.  But man does that change when I go ahead and drink this beer.  The first sip explodes in my mouth with unsweetened dark chocolate (chocolate malt) and tingling carbonation.  This is quickly followed by coffee and slight bitterness from the fuggles hops.  The dark chocolate malts come through again in the finish with their roasty bitter chocolate flavors.  This is an excellent porter, no doubt about it though Id love to try it on draught because I think itd be better.  My bottle seemed to have a little too much carbonation compared to other ratings.  Plan to try again and re-rate.

Damn, this stuff is good! Its right up there with Anchor Porter, and Ill have to drink them together to decide which I like better. Definitely one of the best beers around.

Opaque brown/black color, wonderful roasted malt aroma and flavor, perhaps overpowering the hops a bit. I cant even begin to list the different aromas youll get out of this one, and I think it will be different each time depending on where you are, what else you can smell and what youre eating. This is easily one of the best beers you can get.

Pours a dark opaque black with a brown head. OOOOH. Nice Fresh Sugared Coffee Aroma.The Palate/Mouthfeel is just a little watery but just enough to add to the overall affect .  The Flavour explodes with Nuts, Freshly Ground Coffee Beans, and some Woody, Earthy overtones. The Flavour never lets up and finishes delightfully round and sweet. This Brew is Malty, and roasty at that, but not too hoppy insofar as I can decipher, and therefore a true example of this style.There also exist abundant Lacing on the Glass. If you wanna a Java Jam, reach for the Fullers. Cheers!
Deep black color, medium tan head.  Nice roasty aroma of coffee.  Very good roasty flavor with malt and hops. Medium body with a very smooth and creamy mouthfeel. Very nicely done, very enjoyable.

Pours a deep black with a thick tan head. The aromas are full bodied and many, coffee, chocolate ripe dark fruits and roasted dark malts to name a few. The taste and mouthfeel are extrordinary to say the least. Rich chocolaty and coffee notes,figs, raisins with some nice hopping thrown in for balance. Balance actually says it all for this beer not to much of any one element but plenty of elements just the same. A damn good drink!
deep dark brown. big powerful dark chocolate aroma. intense flavour of dark chocolate and roasted malts (very very intense). silky smooth. finish is bitter. great stuff.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2005 This is really an outstanding porter because of the sheer number of flavors that work their way out to your tastebuds.  It pours almost black - but not quite - and some ruby shows around the edges of the glass.  The nose is big and pleasant.  The head is as creamy, thick, and lasting as one could ask for.  Then theres taste:  Theres the fruity hoppiness (often hidden by the "burnt-ness" of porters), coffee, chocolate, toffee, roasted flavors.  None of the flavors are out of balance.  Most of them share equal time.  This beer is either simple in a complex way or complex in a simple way.  Either attribute is a very positive one.  A true classic among porters and beers in general.  This is the king of my beerlist until proven otherwise.
got a bottle of this at the grey lodge. pretty dark and thick, some cocoa powder in the aroma, rich with some oat and faint stewed peach. more roast flavours than expected. good stuff
Rich and creamy aroma.  Roasted coffee and chocolate flavors. Small head.  Just keeps getting better as you drink it.
Very dark but not opaque with a strong roasted chocolate toffee aroma. Flavour is toffee and chocolate with a nice roastyness.

Burnt amber to dark brown in color.  Simple, froth and thck tan head.  Ample lacing of the glass.  Aroma is trifling at best.   A hint of malt sweetness and a bit of fund. Taste is altogether better.  Puckeringly slightly tart, backed by chocolate and roasted oats.  Nice, medium palate makes this emminently drinkable.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2008 Medium brown hue with a tall, frothy, light tan head that has a scattering of larger bubbles.  Licorice, earthy tones such as peat, near burnt popcorn and some butter all come across first and with great force.  Oaky, dry, tannic as well.  Oddly, I get some iodine as well.  The hell?  Is this a porter or an Islay single malt?  OK, no, the similarities arent strong to the point of confusion, but they are definitely present.  Chocolate, light coffee, prunes and dates along the lines of more typical porter aromas.  The flavour begins fairly sweet and tangy (like milk chocolate and salted butter mixed together) with a light nuttiness.  Mid-palate finds a tinge of soft acidity and wanders into a still sweet finish with the illusion of dryness through  roasted malts and perhaps some tannins.    Buttery elements have all but disappeared at this point, but the odd peat and iodine aromas still lurk in the background.  An unfortunate dose of soy sauce crops up with significant warmth.  Perhaps its a bit papery, too.  The texture is a bit watery, carbonation soft...feels a little under medium-bodied.  Somehow pleasant on the surface, but there are a lot of aromas sneaking around that Im not to terribly fond of at the moment. 50cl bottle, bbe 17/08/08.

Pint bottle, goblet.  Chocolate, coffee, wheat bread malt (M); dry, floral hops (L); oak, butter, smoke, prune aromas.  Deep purple body with a creamy, tan, lasting head.  Moderately sweet, moderately acidic flavor becomes a moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter finish.  Lingering coffee aftertaste.  Medium body, oily/watery texture, average carbonation.  The bottom line is: a porter I enjoy?!?  Wow, thats a neat trick!

Roast Roast and more Roast.  Outstanding.  Pours black wth a thin head. Rich and creamy with a smoked aroma and flavor that invades your senses.  Plenty of coffee mixed in as well.  I understand why everyone is so full of praise for this porter.

Dark, reddish brown.  Little head that dissipates rather quickly.  Very little lacing. Very nice sweet smell of plums, molassas. Stong smokey flavor, charcoal, dark roasted coffee comes through also.
Very smooth feel, carbonation feels very fine.  Slightly bitter but appropriate trailer.   A justly highly rated Porter.
Would be a regular in my fridge but for the $3.20  price.
Bottle, Brewtopia 04, Very dark black, Coffee and chocolate aroma and after taste. Good Rich beer

This beer didnt live up to the high rating it has been given. The flavors were very mellowed without any character standing out from the rest. Some roasted/burnt malty flavor with the balance of hops, some chocolate too. Faint leather smell in the nose. I would prefer Anchor or SN porters over this one.
Dark blackish brown color. Rich roasted coffee aroma. Full, rich taste with some good hop flavor and roasted coffee and chocolate. This a great well balanced brew! Fullers makes one hell of a beer.
Very Dark Coloring.  Strong Beer.  Heavy tastes of Chocolate and Coffee. Definitly worth trying this one.

Thick, tan head. Smells of coffee, chocolate, leather (in a good way).  Wonderfully thick and complicated on the tongue, with vanilla, oak, and powerful coffee and chocolate flavors, quite bitter at the end.  I can only drink one at a time but thats enough.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2004 Huge chocolate, roasty aroma. Clear dark ruby-brown with off-white head that diminishes to cover with some patchy lace. Chocolatey sweet upfront subsumed with roasted malts. Lingering mocha coffee in the finish. Perfect balance between sweet chocolate and roasty bitterness. Body is medium but feels fairly light and refreshing in the mouth perhaps due to low carbonation. Easy to drink. This may be the quitessential Porter. Bottle. Thanks OKBeer.
Pours a nice black color with a light tan head that leaves moderate lacing. Amazing aroma of chocolate and coffee. This brew has a great sweet start with chocolate tones and ends rather bitter.
This is a truly wonderful porter.Rich,creamy body with a great chocolaty,coffee,liquorice taste.Lovely mouth feel and a bittersweet aftertaste.This brew is pure enjoyment.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2005 Bottle:  Aroma is dark chocolate and vanilla.  Pours a dark brown (actually dark reddish brown with a little tranparency if held to the light) with a small tan head that doesnt really last.  Flavor is a nice blend of chocolate and vanilla that finishes with roasted coffee .  Coffee aftertaste.  Nice smooth mouthfeel.  A very good porter.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2009 Bottle. Very dark brown beer with a big beige head. Aroma of vanilla hits you right away followed by a richer chocolate and a slight roastiness. Roasty flavor thats light and creamy. Very easy to drink. Theres a light bitterness on the tongue. Low carbonation. Nice balance and an extremely well made beer.

Strong aroma of roasted malts, licorice and coffee. Dark brown-black coloured with a thin off-white lasting head. Taste is again those roasted malts, coffee in perfect balance with some liquorice. Creamy and very smooth mouthfeel. Absolutely great brew.
Clear dark brown color, short brown head. Aroma of licorice, roasted malts, coffee, black chocolate. Taste is smooth coffee, licorice, bit smoked, bacon. Creamy mouthfeel, which is superb.
Great porter, very poundable but expensive date at 5.4% ABV. Evenly balanced, a great training porter.
Pours an almost opaque dark brown. Very subtle aroma of chocolate, malt and coffee. Taste is very mild as well, smooth. Not as rich as I had hoped. Quite good, though.
Sweet aroma.  Not as dark as some porters, but it grows on you.  Slight smokiness in the flavor.  Overall the flavor was not quite as strong as I had expected.  A very nice porter nonetheless.

can something smell like roasted chocolate? that is the aroma of this beer. had out of the bottle, not much head, a very dark brown, not quite black beer. has that great burnt rich coffee flavor i love in a good porter.not too sweet, a good balance in the flavor. goes down like a two dollar whore on dollar night. this is very good.

Spare and diminishing head on a dark brown, ruby tinted beer. Strong malt aroma with aromas of bread, molasses, chocolate, prunes, coffee and smoke. Full creamy body with a light oily edge and a touch of grit. Long chocolate finish and flavours that fulful the hints from the aroma.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2005 You dirty brits...you make my mouth happy. Great brew. This rating will be a little skewed because this was tasted after a series of beers over 8%. However, the parts I remember were retarded. Nice head and lovely lacing. Dark dark black. Looks more like charcoal water than beer. Smells excellent. If yuo have ever had a Belgian beer on tap you will notice that the beer has a very distinctive chalky yeasty flavor and not the full and fruity flavor that it has in the bottle. This beer also has that. Smells flat and chalky. Tastes exquisite.Round and robust, however the roastiness of the malt is exceedingly rounded over by the flat yeasty flavors that predominate. This is brew reminds me of Anchors porter, only with a much more rich mouthfeel. Give it a shot youll like it I promise.
G-rat

Pitch black with some red tint in it. Big frothy tan head... Beautiful.
Coffee, chocolate, brandy in the nose, aroma could be more penetrating.
Lots of coffee in the flavor, very balanced bit a little metallic and watered out. Id love to try this from cask. This is so overrated!

A fantastic porter. The potency of both the aromas and the flavors of chocolate, coffee, and roasted nuts is stunning. The flavor integration is well worth noting too... they co-mingle, rather than just hit you one after another. Id drink this all the time if I could get it locally.

A good, creamy ale.  It is my "go to porter" when I cant find anything good or new in my area.  The coffee flavors are perfect for an early evening brew.  My first rating and couldnt have happened to a better beer.

One of my current favourites - nice to see it readily available in these parts (in bottle - still only a few taps around).  Pours almost pitch black, lots of chocolate and coffee hints in aroma.  Am always surprised how chocolaty it tastes on the first sip – flavour subsides as you drink it, but still very smooth and enjoyable.  Pleasant finish – overall, a great porter and a great beer.
This is very good ale.  Creamy, smooth, chocolate goodness with hints of coffee.  There are hints of hop but the malts are wonderful in this ale.

Very good porter.  Black with very little dark tan head.  Subtle aromas that included coffee, chocolate, and roasted malt.  The aromas carried over nicely to the flavor.  Rich coffee and chocolate flavors with a very smooth mouthfeel.  It also has a good aftertaste for being a porter.  This is a great beer.

Top Pick Porter. Looks, smells and tastes like a chocolate liquor, although a bit bitter, with some coffee. My daughters were almost tempted to try it. A rich taste, aroma and colour - worth every penny. The bottle suggests after a meal, but I was most pleased with it before one.

Excellent porter, one of the best, very little head, slight lacing around the glass, basically black in color, coffee & chocolate in the nose, very drinkable & smooth, medium-full body, flavors of coffee, dark chocolate & nuts, nicely balanced with a bit of a hop character, smooth finish with more coffee & chocolate notes, great porter
Rocky head, moderate lacing.  A pleasant aroma of coffee and chocolate.  Palate is pleasant with chocolate and nutty flavor, medium to full body.  Subtle hop flavor at the end.  Very nice beer.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2004 Embarassed to say that this was my first porter I tried, but Im glad. Awesome beer. Very strong coffee aroma. Dark appearance with smaller head. The taste of coffe was strong. A sort-of sweet malty flavor. Very good.
This is a fantastic porter. Richly satisfying flavors. roasted coffee, toffee, and molasses. Fuller makes good beer.
It reminds me of a stout with hints of chocolate and coffee.  It is a great beer, smooth creamy, from beginning to end.

OK, yeah, it is a well made, tasty porter.  I've had it before.  I just can't for the life of me understand why it is held in such high regard here.  Not that there is anything wrong with this beer, it is in fact quite good.  But there are countless other examples of this familiar flavor profile that are nowhere close to sniffing Top 50 status.  In any case, deep blackish ruby, nice head that faded almost completely.  Nose is roasty, coffee and chocolate notes.  Flavor is roasty, chocolate, and coffee, with a hint of fruitiness from the hops.  Nice beer, exactly like countless others.
Thanks, Ig, for this one!  My favorite porter yet...nicely balanced and more complex than other porters (not just the same old coffe, roasted malts, chocolate).  I detected a faint bit of licorice?

Pretty good beer.  I drank it really fast for some reason; I guess it was too good to wait on.  Close to a  chocolate stout, but I guess it's a porter.  Who knows...  Long lasting head.  Nice and chocolately with that always present bitterness.  Well done, and I believe it would be even better fresh out of the tap.
Very very nice - hard to believe I hadn't tried this one yet.  Nice balance of sweetness and chocolately bitterness.  Great medium body and deep ruby color.  Mmmmm smells like sweet spirit.

I just looked this up under the best category. I've had this in the bottle (not cask) and its a nice chocolate stout, but it aint that great and it aint a porter for gawds sake. Nothing like it - just a soft chocolate stout.

If you want a type specimen for Porter, look no further. Garnet in colour, with a tight creamy head. Aroma is dark chocolate, roasted grain and caramel. Flavour is same with good Fuggles bittering and a dry bitter finish.
UPDATED: NOV 11, 2005 Malty, coffee nose, slightly nutty; roasted, coffee flavor, slightly acidic; moderate body, well balanced; nice porter.

Draught. Thin head, dark body. Nose is slightly sweet and malty. Lacing is very nice and med-high. Medium mouthfeel with a good tongue coating. Taste is of clean roasted hops, toffee, and sligtly spicy. Solid from start to finish.
Pours dark brown, with a thick tan head. Strong coffee, roasted aroma. Coffee, roasted malty, creamy flavor. This beer is excellent. One of my favorites.

(bottle) Black with quickly fading tan head. Aroma of coffee. Flavor initially is coffee with hints of black chocolate. Finish is somewhat smokey and bitter with definite tobacco notes (like an expensive cigar). Excellent.

Dark brown body, almost no head, what is there is tan and leaves fast. You really have got to let this warm to appreciate the flavors. The nose is very chocolatey with vanilla and dark fruits. Palate is slightly grapey vinous with lots of plums, chocolate and a nice restrained roasty bitter finish. Hints of coffee and licorice in the finish. Smooth medium mouthfeel with friendly cleaning carbonation. Complex malt flavors as it warms and remarkably balanced.
Description by company is pretty accurate. Smooth,strong, rich and creamy, its very good. Poured out of bottle with no head. I like it.

thinnish light tan head.  nice strong coffee/espresso aroma. a little bit leather smell too.  lacing has long hang time.  black at center, amber only at the far corners.  nice coffee start, then hop, then burnt malt.  me likey.

Thick, black and chewy.  Smells of strong black coffee from two feet away, upon closer inspection bakers chocolate is predominant.  Tastes as good as (and just like) it smells.  Coffe and chocolate dominate, hops claw andatch their way through but do not overpower.  Mouthfeel is thick and complex, leaves the sensation of a good desert in its wake.  Phenomal beer worthy of its praise.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2004 Pours a rich brown with a hint of red.  Generous creamy tan head.  Roasted coffee bean and chocolate aroma with a malty twinge.  Medium-bodied and smooth on the palate.  Mocha and chocolate malty overtones, but I think it would taste better with a little more hops.
A nice brew - beautifully black, nice malty aroma good mouthfeel... but the taste was a bit weaker than expected.  A fine porter, but doesn't deserve its high rating here.

Bottle.  Dark mahogany-brown, almost black.  Chocolatey, roasted malt aroma.  Medium-full body, moderately carbonated.  Some caramel notes beside the more obvious roasty, dark chocolate flavours.  Some hop bitterness at the finish, which could use more length.  An enjoyable and tasty beer thats quite good, but not great.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2008 Black with rathershort lived, bubbly off-white head. Rich aroma dominated by caramel, licorice, malt and coffee. Flavour continues the coffee theme, with lots of bitterness, a hint of smoke and a long aftertaste of chocolate and coffee. Ratebeerwise this should be in the mid range, but I just love it so much theres no way to rate it lower. I apologoze to the fine Englishmen who dislike Fullers pub strategies (for good reasons), but when they put the porter in a bottle or can and send it abroad, they are onto something...

Great looking beer, a dark yet not opague brown with a fluffy brown head.  Smells like those chocolate malts, baby, yeah.  Mouthfeel is full but surprisingly light; this is super drinkable stuff.  Light coffee notes, burnt toast, a little bit of smoke, maybe a hint of dark fruit.  Finishes clean and dry.
Not as good as I expected after reading the ratings. The aroma and appearance are great, but it seemed a bit thin to me. Still, it's very good.

Wheee!  I'm impressed!  Dark brew, thick but kinda fizzy head that dissipates after a few minutes.  Bold, yet non-bitter chocolate taste with a nice bite.  Rich and full flavor.  I'm very impressed with Fuller's beers that I've had.  This is an exceptional job - one of the best I've had from this style.  The brewers managed to put a lot of flavor into this beer without going overboard on the sweetness and smokey flavors that you find in most porters.  Nothing here is blown out of proportion.  It's just very nice!  I wish  I hadn't passed it up on all of those occasions.  In the process of becoming a hop-head who loves a good IPA, I've forgotten how good  a properly engineered maltier beer can be.

This is an example of a brew that excels in its said style without all the acrobatics. Pours a deep charcoal with ruby highlights when light hits. Conservative head but leaves a nice ocean water lace thereafter. Nose is of chocolate and dates, with smoke overtones busting through like a bonfire at the beach. Tastes of coffee bean, with the strength of expresso, bit of semi-sweetened chocolate and a buttery-smooth middle. Finishes with blanket of smoke on the back of the tongue. Nice solid medium mouthfeel, leaves this another winner from Fuller's. Classy, sexy and seductive and enough brains to keep you interested for time to come. I'm marrying this one.

Dark black appearance. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, and licorice. The flavor is slightly bitter with some bitter coffee notes, dark fruit, chocolate, and smoke. The aftertaste was very smooth and slightly sour. This was a very nice porter.
UPDATED: OCT 19, 2004 Rich flavor, the chocolate malts are definitely dominant. Reminds me of ice cream. If you're in the mood for a rich, dark beer, this goes down quite nicely.
UPDATED: MAR 31, 2004 Wow.  Avery top notch porter.  Does not get much better than this.  Tons of flavor yet not as overpowering as a stout.  Great brew

Very dark brown pour, borderline black. Rich and creamy tannish head, and sheets of fine lacing.  Very pleasing aromas of chocolate, roast malts, a woody aroma as well, maybe oak, and the Fuggles come through a bit. A slight hint of caramel in there, too. Chocolate malts dominate the flavors followed by the caramel and roasted malts. There is almost a coffee like character there along with that oak that was in the aroma. Nice and creamy palate, thick, rich body and a wonderful chocolate filled bitter finish. This is a damn fine example of a porter, and I'm extremely happy it's available here again.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2007 Theres a dearth of Baltic porter in Canada now so I decided to try some of the British offerings so I got six Fullers at the local. I cant say I like it as much as the sweeter, fuller bodied, stronger Baltic porters but this is a very good example of the traditional British porter and a superbly produced beer with excellent quality. Im quite satisfied with this as an interim substitute.

This impressive embossed  bottle had a freshness date and write up on the beers  awards. Poured a luxurious rich clear dark mahogany looks almost cola- ruby when glass held against a strong light. Large cascading puffy brown head that stayed for a while then dissipated to a beige lace that stayed to the end of the drink. It has a moderate amount of effervescence .

Smells of chocolate and Caramel with hints of wine-like berry. 

Starts rather sharp to the tongue accented with dry hops and carbonation then builds into a creamy medium-full bodied mouth feel punctuated with a balance of musty chocolate semi sweetness and  hops...finishes  smooth  with a pleasant dry-cocoa after taste that is not as tinny as dry stouts. All in all a very good drink and a fine porter.

Yet another that slipped under my radar - had this one SO many times. Solid product. Joe, why did you slight this one? Did it fuggle with your mind? Soft, luscious, and full of flavor. No problem drinking this one.
Very dark brown with a nice medium beige head. Strong roasted malt and coffee aroma. Nice coffee, malt, and chocolate flavors. Medium body, moderate carbonation. Very nice.

My favorite porter, by far, and one of my favorite beers of any style. Wonderful coffee- like taste, perfectly balanced. There is no better tasting beer that I can think of. Medium body, not as thin as many other porters. Sometimes hard to find fresh around here, but when I do, it's a joy to behold.
DraftAlmost black pour with a minimal head. Kind of thin mouthfeel and not enough hoppiness to be a good porter. Sweet, sticky and chocolate all the way around. Nice lacing.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2009 Wow, this was incredible. Aromas of chocolate and coffee from beginning to end. Head was a thick cocoa pillow of goodness. Flavours the same, with dark chocolate and espresso, with a bit of vanilla bean. Very creamy and smooth in the mouth. Body was an attractive dark brown. Go out and try this one!

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2007 (Bottled) Very dark reddish brown with a large, beige and foamy head. Quite strong, a bit earthy aroma of roasted malt, lots of  coffee, salty licorice and hints of smoke. Burned-roasted-malty flavor with smooth dark coffee, and a sweetish-malty breeze in the middle. The finish is roasted and slightly ashy with medium bitterness. Very smooth, medium to full-bodied palate with soft carbonation. Definitely one of the best British brews. Truly excels in achieving a perfect balance between sweet maltiness and ashy burnedness, while being low-ABV and enough earthy-licoricey to be interesting flavorwise.
Nice coffee and dark chocolate flavor.  Frothy head, a very good porter, but I still prefers Stone's.
This beer is really, really fabulous. Aroma has a strong coffee smell, with hints of cocoa and caramel. This is a fine example of an excellent Porter.
Dark with a reddish hue, coffee sweet aroma. Creamy, smooth feel with coffee flavors, perhaps a hint of chocolate.
Bottle: This beer kicks serious Ass! i'm kicking myself for passing on it so many times in the past. full bodied, creamy, bitter-sweet. In a word-exceptional.

Bottle - Poured a deep black brew with a nice head but lack some retention. Carbonation is average with a medium body (I was expecting a richer and ''fuller'' body). Aroma of chocolate is very subtle. Taste is a mix of roastiness, chocolate, and coffee with just enough bitterness at the end. Overall, this is a good beer but I still believe it might be a bit overrated.
Brown with a tan head, sweet malty aroma with traces of coffee and roast. Roasted coffee and bitter chocolate. Some smoke and saltiness? Very lightly acidic. Well rounded and tastey.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2005 Knowing that this beer is currently number 26 on the Top 50 list, I was quite anxious to taste it.
Pours a tall tan head on a dark brown body. Aroma is nice though a little weak, malty with tones of milk chocolate. The flavor is quite full and complex. Roasted malt, coffee and liquorice with a bitter hoppy finish. Definately a good beer but way overrated in my opinion!
UPDATED: FEB 23, 2004 To be honest i prefer the samuel smith porter.  this is definately a great beer but a little bitter for my tatse
Great color and finish.  My favorite porter that is out there.  Wonderful on tap.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2004 Wonderful color.  Sitting down with this beer, I was expecting a better experience.  Even though the beer was great, it lacked a certain ambience that one gets from other porters.  Perhaps it was just the bottle I ordered.  Greasy palate, kind of watery.
This is a beautiful beer! Everything from the aroma to the appearance to the wonderful chocolate creamy flavor. This is what a porter should be.
Deep, dark brown, almost black, with tinge of red.  Foamy tan head. Luscious chocolate and coffee aroma and flavor.  Rich, full-bodied mouth feel.  An exquisite drink.

500 ml bottle.  Deep, nearly black brown color, with a midsized brown-tan head.  Not much lacing.  Slighy watery looking.  Smells very much like coffee, lots of roastiness, a bit of sourness.  A tiny bit sweet.  Tastes of some light fruity sweetness, roasted malts, coffee, and chocolate, a little bit more sourness, a touch of hops.  Pleasing bitter finish.  Mildly carbonated, and a little  watery in the mouth.    On one or two occasions, there's been something slightly off-putting in the aroma on some whiffs, but maybe it was just me, or the bottles were a bit off.  Still, it's a really nice coffee-ish beer!

I was really surprised how good this beer was.  I'm always a little biased against imported beers as they often seem to suffer on the voyage over, but this was about as good a porter as I could hope for.  Well balanced, malty and enough bitterness to support it.  Easy to find too which is a bonus.  Just watch the best by date.
WOW!  This is one hell of a porter!  Strong chocolate and coffee aroma.  Very dark brown color with small tan head.  Good Choc. expresso taste with a little hint of berrys.  Awesome

This is a perfect porter.  If you are one of the lucky ones who is able to get this on tap (try the Goat Hill Tavern in Costa Mesa, CA), you'll wonder why it's not available in more locations.  Excellent chocolatey flavor - a treat for Maltheads everywhere!

deep ruby color with a medium/small tan head.  coffee and licorice, with a little chocolate maltiness in the nose.  very buttery and creamy body, malt backbone with some residual bitterness at the end. however, i would like it to be thicker.  finish is extremely smooth with a pleasant aftertaste.  if not the best, one of the best porters i've had.
DEEP dark brown color, lots in the nose, fruity , bready,  even anise in there! Big and round with a superb dry toasty finish! The Benchmark!!

Dark black with a huge ass walnut color head.  Aroma of walking through a forest where it just rained and there is a bakery baking fresh bread.  A very nice smooth chalky nutty base, smooth like a fucking criminal with a solid foundation of nuts .

Dark, dark amber brown.  Aroma is beautiful caramel, butter, slight dark fruit (rasin/plum), hints of coffee.  Flavors match the aroma without the fruit sweetness.  Killer coffe notes.  Nice mild bitter finish.  Best porter I've had.

What a great porter! Excellent roasted malt aroma and flavor. Extremely well done porter that borders on the porter/stout line on flavors. This is one of the best porters I have ever had, give me more!

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2004 Thick tan head that fades quickly over a ruddy-black liquid.  Espresso aroma along with some bitter chocolate and toasted grain.  I didn't find it tasted nearly as good as it smelled, although clearly I'm in the minority.  The body was quite a bit thinner than I expected.  Lots of coffee and burnt sugar in the mouth with a long roasty finish.  Improved greatly as it warmed.

The first beer I've tried thats rated higher than 4 on this site. I gladly give it a consistent rating. Pours black as pitch but not nearly as thick. The small white head fizzles away shortly but leaves behind a fantastic bold roasty aroma. This beer balances a myriad of heavy flavors perfectly: fresh black coffee with a hint of chocolate and a hefty but not overpowering malt taste leaves you with a dry nutty finish. A wonderful beer, and I'm happy to have been lucky enough to try a fresh bottle for once.

Extremely black with tiny, tiny white head.

Roasted sweet smell without being overwhelming at all.

Fantastic tatse. Cold coffee, roasted nuts, chocolate... yummy as hell, I want more NOW!

Good mouthfeel. Not too carbonated, which is fantastic, because this is a thick/filling beer.

YUM, I want more now, super-drinkable.
UPDATED: MAY 3, 2004 darker in colour, kind of rubyish with a thin white head lots of bubbles. The nose is very malty and robust. The taste is very bitter with a warm chocolate front.

It poured dark brown almost black color with a bit of a reddish tint. It had a great aroma of caramel, toasty, burnt sugar and coffee. In the flavor it had much of the same plus some nice fruitiness and a compexity that is hard to describe. It had enough roasted grain and hops to keep the sweeter tendencies under control. It was smooth and full of body and had a nice mouthfeel. It was a perfect balance of many flavors. Great porter

Aroma: Soft medium slow roasted malt brushed with hints of English bitterness. Dark brown, woody look, foamy head. Just right mix of bitterness with very nice malt. This Porter has great texture, good mouth feel. One of better balanced beers on the market. I can not stop to think of euro style full roasted coffee that used best selected grains. This porter is same. Highly recommended.

Wow.  In the words of Will Farrel, "Simply stunning!"  It poured a deep brown, and a ruby when held to the light. A beige head developed and lasted for a while.  An intense aroma of cappuchino assaulted me.  I'm not a coffee drinker at all AT ALL, but this was just so good, that I might convert!  Wow, I can't believe the amazing flavours and texture.  This is A-Class stuff, no doubt about it!

ive had this in the the uk on tap, states in the bottle and on tap:
its truly an amazing porter, this is a gold standard to me. bringing great british brewing together with a classic porter style. as we all know all the fuller beers are delicious and this is no exception.  nice hoppy character with the blend of choc malt. go to chiswick in london and try it at the brewery...you wont be disapointed.

Dark mahogany coloring. Clear with a thin tan head and nice lacing. Aroma was very nice. Chocolate, malt, sweet caramel and a good balance of noble hops. Taste was lighter than I expected with a medium body and small bubbles of carbonation. Definitely dry with toasted malts and chocolate. Finishes well with a pleasant aftertaste. I'll buy again!
An excellent porter.  Nice dark brown color with a large tan head.  Excellent malty /roasty aroma matched by a balanced and rich flavor.  No harshness here.  Nice mouthfeel.  Complex
UPDATED: FEB 16, 2005 From a Bottle.A dark chocky porter,nice body,not too heavy,goes down smooth,quite boring in the end for me.

Deep ruby colour with a thick frothy and rocky tan coloured head. Decadent dark chocolate aroma with roasted coffee notes. Roasted coffee flavour with a dark chocolate bitter finish. Mouthfeel is rich, thick and lightly chewy but soft and smooth.
Reall enjoyed this brew. I like Fullers beers. Full bodied, with some roasty notes to it. Dark brown in color, tan head. Well done.
Dark brown, tan head. Yummy dark carmel like aroma. Full bodied carmel malt flavor with roasty undertones. Well done and delicious.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text:
Mmmm, coffee. Coffee with alcohol, none the less.

Pours a very dark brown with a nice head and some serious lacing.

Smells like coffee! That's almost always a good thing.

Tastes like coffee as well, with some toffee and something else sweet tossed in there just to throw me off, I'm sure. The taste is nicely balanced with hops but isn't bitter at all.

Mouthfeel is a bit on the watery side, but still good because of the nice mineral presence.

Very nice porter.
Dark dark amber frothy light brown head. Chocolaty burnt aroma. Light carbonated body. Burnt robust coffee chocolate flavours malty nice bitter.

Can't believe it took this long to get this! Pours a reddish brown with a medium light tan head. Nose is caramel, sweetened malt, and a hint of chocolate. The taste is smooth. Chocolate, malt, light roasted notes, very little bitterness. Finishes very smooth. Good beer, but I think a little overrated.
Nice deep color with a tan head. Very smooth taste with a hint of licorice. Will buy again.

Pours almost like a hazelnut brown ale but drinks almost like a stout. Rich deep brown colour preceeds a tantalizing roasted chocolate aroma and a smooth chocolate coffee taste. Lingers nicely with a slight bitter aftertaste - truly enjoyable beer.

I can see why this is the best rated porter.  More of a brown porter than a robust porter.  Awesome deep brown with amber highlights, clear and a great tan head which stays for a while- lacing is also nice.  Great aroma- chocolate malt dominates with some crystal malt in the background- with no hops.  Flavor is smooth and clean with lots of chocolate and dark malts with little hops.  FInish is still smoth with a touch of bitterness.  This beer is by far the best porter I have ever had.  Very well done.

(Bottle)  Pours a dark brown (almost black)with amber highlights and a small tan head.  Better to have this one warmed up a bit to get more of the flavors and complexities of this wonderful porter.  Has a delicious coffee, roasted malt, and molasses flavor.  Great brew!

A Christmas gift from my brother-in-law and his boyfriend. I was underwhelmed and feel this is overrated. I like some robustness and some meat from my porters and this one was too delicate. Has a strong, rich milk chocolate aroma. Deep, deep ruby red body with slow carbonation and a small, light brown head that is mostly dissipating. Great lace. Subtle, yet rich and complex. Somewhat oily. Perhaps I pulled it out of the refrigerator too soon, as I think it would be better served colder. Luckily I have 5 more to try. Although this brew is worthy of any Porter lover, it is not as good as the MacTarnahans Bourbon Cask Aged Blackwatch Cream Porter I had earlier in the evening.

Beautiful dark ruby/black, quarter inch tan head. Smells of malts, nuts, chocolate, coffee. Nice coffee in the flavor, slightly metallic, a good balanced bitterness in the finish. Quite a smooth beer. A little cold at the moment. Can't wait til it warms up a little bit. But even this cold the flavor and bouwuet are awesome. Almost seems like its a draft. Awesome beer.

Smelled like a brewed pot of coffee from right out of the bottle. Deep black pour with a thin lacing tan head. Tastes like a cup of cold coffee with some molasses and roasted malt. Very well balanced, and a very good beer to have on a cold day trying to keep warm.

Tasted in Toronto from the LCBO.  Tasted in English pint glass.  Pours very well from the bottle with a consistent and well maintained creamy white head.   Colour is dark, almost black, but with a slightly reddish brown hue when held to the light.  Aroma is very strong - chocolate, sweetness and a hint of alcohol.   Taste is very nice - strong roasted malt chocolate flavour with a slight molassis ending and a very subtle burnt bitter finish.  De facto reference model of the porter style.

sweet coffee smell with chocolate or moka. 
Deep black in clolour. Sweeter tatste than expected, but 
there is ncie bitter chocolate coming through. A bit thin also.
UPDATED: JAN 11, 2004 A surprisingly viscous pour gave way to a nice thick, rich head and a deep coffee aroma. The taste was heavily malted with coffee lingering in the palate. Fine stuff.

Opaque brown in colour with a tightly bubbled, off-white head. Aroma of dark chocolate and coffee with vinous undertones. Early bitterness is quickly balanced with malt and a silky mouthfeel. Lovely, lingering flavour of dark chocolate and coffee.

bottle-best by mar 3,03.  Thanks again to Whaleman for hooking me up with this high rated brew.  pours a deep burgandy color when held up to the light.  very very mild carbonation.  Nice english toffee and chocolate aroma-slightly smokey.  flavor is very similar to the appearance, but kinda thin i thought for such a high rated brew.  I think alpha klaus takes the porter cake here.

Beautiful pore, black as coal. nice chocolate head with lots of cocoa aroma with roasted coffee scents. Hint of alcohol and a very small smell of citrus. Head didn't last long though, and neither did the beer!
Mild taste of ashes and chocolate. Very nice porter!!

Beautiful dark chocolate color. Thin head, fine bubbles and lacing. Excellent roasted malt aroma-like a grainy cafe mocha. Tastes like it smells, perfectly balanced and very smooth with subtle, earthy Fuggles hop in the background, and roasted chocolatey malt flavor with touch of bitter coffee up front. No bad aftertastes. A model porter.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2004 This is a rock solid Porter and stands on top of the Porter hill for a reason.

It pours a beautiful midnight black w/a good head, if a little thin with bigger bubbles than I'd expect and a bit weak on the lacing but that's just nit picking.

Taste is a pleasure from the moment it hits your tongue. No harsh hop attack here, the bitterness only serves to compliment the fruit and roast undertones. It starts smooths and only gets smoother as it works it's way across you pallette. The finale is great with hints of an alcohol warmness (supprising for it's average ABV) that finishes the movement.

Overall I'd highly remcommend this porter for any porter lover. This is one that even a Porter neophyte could love, not overly challanging but deep and complex.

Two thumbs up!
A porter drinker's porter. Rich, smooth, chocolate notes,  roasty malts.

Clear dark brown with ruby hints. The head diminshes quickly and is tan colored. Glass lacing is decent but not outstanding. The aroma is quite chocolately and a bit fruity, like a cabernet. The flavor is roasted malt and chocolate. The body is incredibly smooth! Quite yummy stuff.

Incredibly smooth porter, with a velvety taste to it.  Lightly hopped with a nice chocolate taste that's not too overwhelming.

Colour is blackish but has a dark ruby hue when held up to a light.
Nice dark brown black colour with a soft chocolate coloured head.  Excellent mouth feel. Pleasantly roasty but it is not overpowering. Hints at chocolate. A nice porter that I will try again.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2004 great aroma, some specialty chocolate pastry. mm, the taste is a bit off to me though... it's a bit too acidic for me, strange, in a way that is similiar to great divide's saint brigid's porter. otherwise, there is a body too thin anyway, like killian's red. flavor: roasted coffee, chocolate/caramel. semi-sweet. hm, overrated? i'd rather have anchor's porter. UPDATE: i had this after a rogue chocolate sweet stout and i can say that this is definitely roasty and dark, smooth and cremey, chocolately and delicious. acidity? none. watery? yes. i'll bump it up a bit, seems like a gotta fair bottle :o)

Smells of wheaty rye bread and coffee notes.  Beautiful dark brown color with small short head, but i poured it pretty cold.  Deep coffee flavor with chocolate, rye and some dirt (but in a good way) hints.

Dark ruby colour looks fantastic. Malty and vinuous aroma. Big black coffee taste with some underlying fruitiness. Fairly roasty and thick. Just the right amount of bitterness and not too overroasted. Beautiful, exceptional, what Porters and Stouts should aspire to be. Thanks Clark VV

As I pour this beer fruit notes escape from the glass.  As I stick my nose further in I get roasted notes of coffee and more of the fruitiness.  A thick light brown head tops this fairly clear beer, which is dark brown in color with ruby notes as it is held up to the light.  This beer has an incredible creamy mouthfeel to it.  It is lightly sweet with a roast character in the finish.  There is a very good balance between the roast character and the fruit notes.  This is a wonderfully balanced beer, certainly one of the best Porters out there.  The smooth creamy body of this beer is amazing.

I've been loooking at this beer in the store forever and always seem to turn my nose up at it,first it was because it doesn't look that great then because it is always there and easy to get so i figured this weekend i would finally try it.Nice black color,small uneventful head that had a decent amount of staying power but nothing spectacular.Roasty malt and coffee aroma with a bit of chocolate,maybe a slight hint of fruit.the flavor was much better then expected,malty and coffeeish with a nice semi-sweet chocolate taste and a faint fruit presence,the fruit being a dried fruit maybe plum or raisin.but since i don't eat either one i'm just guessing from what i know of the smell of the two.The after taste is malty and coffee with a light chocolate hint.This is a damn decent brew,makes me wish i picked up more then the one,but hey it pretty easy to get.
Rich with a subtle chocolate, coffee flavour.  Goes done easy and leaves even easier.  Did someone say smooth, yes.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2009 New bottle rating. Woody sweet nose with some tobacco and milk chocolate hints. The taste is lightly roasted with wood and coffee. Overall, a pleasant easy drink, but fairly light and thin. Not as sweet in the bottle as I thought on tap. I have had this on tap and am not as impressed as I once was. Still a light body, but it has a sweet note that distracts and it is fairly thin its body. Old rating follows. Nice light porter. Best I have had in a bottle. Nice balanced and complex flavor. Has some roasted noted and a nice woody feel. A dry coffee finish complements the solid beer. Would love to try this on tap.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2004 This impressive beer is obviously brewed using magic. I imagine a wizard in some London castle churning the stuff out from bubbling cauldrons. Had it on tap and was impressed by the thick, creamy head. I think that if left alone the head may have lasted forever. And don't even get me started on the perfect coffee color of this magnificant brew.
