Alright, if I seem a little over excited let me just explain that this was the first porter I have experienced on draught and until now I have not understood the true potential of a porter. I am already a big stout fan though so I can cetainly appreciate the chocolate malt flavor  and the rich malt aroma that acompanies this beer but what I was not expecting was the perrfectly balanced crisp hops finish. That finish dazzled and delighted me like few beers every have. This is a beer that knows what it is doing and does it very well. I think the greatest single aspect of this beer is the way it matures in the glass. With every sip it seems to evolve, to develop deeper and more meaningful complexity. I understand from the buddy who shared this experience with me that this beer might take some time to grow on you. I say, if you are going to let anything grow on you let it be Fullers London Porter.
definitely creamy.  initially sweet and caramelly until the hops take over.  the slight bitterness gives way to  dry, subtle coffee-chocolatey-goodness in the end.

Clear mahogany red color glowing in the glass with a frothy tan head that left good lace.  Nose of tea, coffee and chocolate.  Very smooth mouthfeel.  Lots of dusty bitter chocolate in the taste, with vanilla, licorice and an almost smokey nuttiness.  Smokey bitter hop finish.  Much better warm.

Pours black with small head.  Very strong roasted malt aroma.  Sweet chocolate, roasted coffee flavor.  Very small amount of bitterness, just enough to balance.  Very full body.  Excellent mouthfeel, creamy.  Dry finish.  Vey nice beer. The best porter I have had.
Really great stuff.  Smooth, chocolate flavor.  I had all of these room temp while Pheasant Hunting.  What a great experience!

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2005 I was planning to drink the Dolle Dulle Teve 10 as my 600th rating, but suddenly this one came up. Clear dark brown coloured. Complex aroma and flavour, malts, coffee, cocoa, bit smokey. Complex and nevertheless very smooth and easy-to-drink. Very nice brew.

Color is cola with ruby tint; massive beige head, rocky and long-lasting, with sticky sea-foam traces left in its wake...Wonderful, slightly winey aroma full of sweet and roasted goodness, with hints of chocolate and assorted other goodies...The flavor is a fine mixture of ingredients: coffee, chocolate, a slight nuttiness, and fruit flavors as well (dates come to mind).  Roasty bitterness comes through in the finish, with a light lingering dryness...Body is moderately full, and the layering of flavors really stimulates the palate while delivering this rich bounty with an elegant smoothness...This is extremely satisfying---one of the best from this outstanding brewery.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2005 The dominant aroma is of roasted malt, reminds of the aroma of a dry stout like Beamish.  Minor aroma of red wine.  Black with a red tint in the light.  The head is small but thick and leaves a heavy lace on the glass.  Several flavors, most prominent is the roasted malt again.  Also coffee, some chocolate, and fruit.  Unfortunately, all of these flavors seem to be holding back.  This beer is thiner than I would like.  Still very good, but maybe not 99th percentile good.
Great Porter.  Coffee, chocolate, and malt flavor.  Finishes creamy, smooth, and dry.  Recommended.
Everything about this beer is great...I'm not a coffee/chocolate drink person, so I didn't fully enjoy the taste...however, it was still a good beverage...

Poured out of 18.6 oz. bottle, bought at Liquorama in Upland, CA 10/5/03.  Pours a silky-looking dark cola brown with a hint of red.  Sudsy, beige head that lingers.  Clear body but so dark that very little light passes through it.  Aroma is malty deliciousness-- creamy, caramelly, smells a lot like a box of Cracker Jacks.  A little too soft for my liking, but still very alluring.  Taste is immediately of dark roasted malts and some nuttiness.  Dark malt flavors grow and grow, having just enough sweetness on the back end to keep it tasty.  Whereas many porters make me think, "Ok, this is good, but it should've been a stout," this one is a truly definitive and unique kind of beer.  Not as much like a  coffee or espresso as most other stouts and porters; it has a whole 'nother thing going on.  Obviously shares some similarities with a good stout, but this doesn't feel like it's any sort of compromise at all.  Active carbonation and even some acidity in the mouthfeel; thin-to-medium body but interesting texture, almost chewy and oily at the same time.  Long finish with nuttiness, bitterness, and mellowing maltiness, as well as a hint of sourness that grows.  Very complex stuff, revealing new layers with each sip and second of its taste.  For me, this beer at once defines and transcends its style.  Special, special stuff.

dark black and ruby highligts, cramy tan head. rich roasted malts, coffee, and dark chocolate etc. but with an almost intagible extra dimension and depth that seperates its self from the crowd. more intense as it warms, but it never loses that velvety smooth feeling.

My 100th rating!!!  Pure black coloring.  Aromas of chocolate malts and coffee, with a slight roasted tinge to it.  Flavor is SO complex - dark coffee, chocolate, and a very surprising and nice bittering in the very end.  Aftertaste is bitter with lingering coffee.  Truly awesome - topped in my mind only by Sam Smiths Oatmeal Stout.  It's good to be king!

A lovely vineous, chocolate nose and, in my opinion, fairly standard appearance for a porter start off this highly anticipated brew.  Flavor is very rich and smooth.  Really quite delicious and harmonious, with a nice roast flavor in the finish.  A very well made porter.
As usual with great porters, pitch black with a little fruity flavor mixed with roasted malts.   Awesome beer.
UPDATED: MAR 19, 2005 Bottle. Coffee aromas with background smokiness. Slight acidity. Instead of the smooth balance of the cask a thin biting finish.

Medium sized tan head with white highlights. Beautiful clear mahogeny color.Malty, caramely nose, Licorice and chocolate notes also. Med/full body, great creamy mouthfeel. Chocolatey, roasty, fruity flavors with a slight hint of tobacco, tastey. Finish is dry, somewhat roasty. Nice porter.

I just pick this up off the shelf for a lark. I was so very impressed. The taste is smooth and very enjoyable. I would highy recommened this Porter to anyone wanting to venture into other type of Beers. Go find this one.
Lovely roasted caramel and chocolate aroma and flavor.  Very smooth and drinkable.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2003 Dark red in color when held up to light.  Little head that fades.
Aroma of chocolate.  Mouthfeelis perfect - very soft, good carbonation, and expectionally smooth.
Flavor is chocolate and caramel.  Creamy and rich.  Kinda like a snickers w/o the nuts. 
There is something in this porter that sets it apart from all others.  My originial thought is the brown malt or maybe the blend between the grains is in perfect balance.  I sure wish Fuller's would would share the recipe.  Definately, my favorite porter to date.

A wonderful porter! Deep dark ruby colour. Excellent aroma and flavour with lots of chocolate and roasted malts. Pleasant long dry bitter finish and very smooth. Highly complex and drinkable at the same time; a greatly balanced beer.

Very deep brown color with a great aroma of chocolate and a full creamy head. Intense roasted black malt flavors dominate. Underlying sweetness leads up to a smoky, bitter chocolate character with a good hop finish. Outstanding.

Pretty thin looking body for a porter, 55% opaque. Head is tall and fluffy.  Aroma is heavenly with milk chocolate, malt, and maple syrup. Mouth feel is medium bodied.  Taste starts with sweet cream, then grows more complex adding a variety of chocolate flavors (sweet, milk & bittersweet), then roastiness and coffee. Aftertaste is also delectable with more chocolate, coffee, pit fruits, hickory and nutmeg. This is a very complex beer, but never overwhelming. It drinks easily and directly allowing the brain and taste buds to just enjoy the flavor.  Purchased in a 500ml bottle at Chevy Chase Wine & Liquors in Washington, DC.
Best porter I have ever had. Full flavor and a very nice mouth feel make it a very satifying brew. It tastes like a regular porter but with all of the best flavors turned up a few notches.
Dark brown in color with a large frothy head. Aroma lightly sweet, some roasted malt. Flavor is outstanding, chocolate, caramel,lightly sweet then dry. Extremely drinkable.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2008 This is one of my favorite Fuller products and favorite styles of beer.  Pours a nice deep amber color with a good head.  The look of this beer with a lamp behind it was picture perfect.  The flavor was a perfect blend of sweetness and bitter.  I buy this one regularly.

Dark maple syrup in color with a lasting-splotchy off-white head. Fantastic slightly overdone chocolate-chip cookie and milk aroma. Earthiness comes out upon warmup. Slight sweet with burnt malt coming out on the chocolate finish. Great porter.

Bottled. It poured with a medium sized tan head which was long lasting and contributed to the good lacing.  Lots of chocolate and coffee with some underlying hoppiness.  Lots of chewy flavors in this beer.  I will try this again.

haha wow, this is a really good brew.  there seems to be too much carbonation in the beer at first, but that quickly disolves.  this is a very rich porter that is one of the best porters ive ever had.  there is a reason it has a 4.15/5.00  great beer.

A really robust porter.  I poured a dark brown/amber color with a nice biege head.  Aroma had hints of malty goodness and sweet chocolate and caramel notes.  Initial taste was robustly malty and finshed with a creamy coffee taste with a mildly sweet maple syrup notes.  This beer was fantastic.
Clear dark amber coloured beer.Coffee and chocolade aroma.  Wonderful creamy, coffee and roasted taste. It has a nice bitter coffee aftertaste.
Pours with creamy head. Beautiful dark brown colour. Moderate bitterness. Roasted coffee taste and beautiful aroma. A pleasure to drink  great porter.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2004 Very good.  Poured dark with a lot of bubbles.  Practically no head developed when I poured it.  Very rich taste.  This is a great porter.  For some reason, I think this brew tasted better straight from the bottle...

Pours a dark dark mahogany color with a little red tint.  Head is absolutely gorgeous--2-3 cm tan that persists and is with large bubbles.  Beautiful lacing.  Probably the best looking beer ive had to date.  The aroma is a roasted coffee one.  The start feels a little over cabonated and maybe a little bit watery, but I dont think this is the case, seeing I just got done drinking a DFH WWS.  Taste is amazing.  Very roasted coffee taste.  Very pleasant to drink.  I know why this has such a great score.

Pours beautifully into the pint glass, and then into my mouth.  Nice dark brown, with great lacing.  I smell roasted grains, a pleasant and welcoming nose.  Very smooth, with strong hints of coffee, ending with sweetness.  A very very tasty beer.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2004 Draught at The Bishops Arms, Gothenburg, Sweden.
Very dark with a lovely head.
A lot of aroma from coffee, chocolate and prune.
A very smooth, soft and fresh palate.
Smoky flavour with chocolate.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2012 Poured a dark reddish brown color with a medium sized creamy light tan head.  Roasted chocolate aroma with some dark fruits as well.  Slight chocolate and roasted malt taste.  Creamy mouth feel.
Amazingly smooth and drinkable porter, a world classic. Deep brown color and quite small fluffy head. Lots of black chocolate, malt and coffee in the aroma and palate. The Porter.

Hearty porter, I sampled it in Upstate NY on a camping trip.  They told me it was the last set they had as their distributor was stopping shipment of it.  Hearty and delicious, a meal in a glass.  For a porter, it was pretty heavy feeling in the mouth.  A little pricey (12 for a 6 pack where I was) and possibly impossible to find now brings it down in my ranking a little.  For a lot less money, I can sacrifice flavor and pick up a 6er of Yuengs.
UPDATED: MAR 12, 2004 Totally awesome. Very dark pour, full retentive head.  Roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate. Velvety mouthfeel. Perfectly made. So good...

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2004 Beer pours (in Chimay glass) a dark brown liquid that, when held up to light, can be seen through with a generous, off-white head that quickly collapses leaving a thin film of head.  Aroma is of very, very rich coffee with a touch of sweet molasses.  Flavor is a creamy smooth malty coffee with a faint peanut character.  Absolutely no hop flavor detected - a big plus.  The beer is incredible, outstanding - WOW!!  This beer can be sipped or quaffed in mouthfuls with reckless abandon.  No alcohol flavor/aroma detected.  Smooth and creamy, although the head needs to be more substantial, and the beer could benefit from being opaque - otherwise it is perfect.  Sampled at 71 degrees Fahrenheit.

Bottle- "Best By" date:April 27 2002.  Poured on 7-17-03.
 Fantastic smelling blackish-red liquid with thin khaki head, smells absolutely marvelous, coffee and hops, tastes the same with a bit of raisen and a touch of wine.  Very very nice.  Perhaps my favorite beer EVER.

10+ for aroma...soy sauce...BEST EVER!  Black with off-white head.  Flavor was of burnt coffee and chocolate.  This is a great beer... my only complaint is that it was just a little too burnt tasting... don't read too much into that though because this is one of the best beers I have ever had!

(sampled draught at Bishops Arms, Stockholm, Sweden) Dark brown, almost black with creamy pale brown head. Coffeish aroma with some gentle hops, dark chocolate and smoke. Flavour is awesome; black coffee, cacao with a pleasing bitterness of soy and english hops. A great and complex porter.

Chocolate, coffee, burnt sugar, and sweet malt give this reddish brown porter its fragrance.  It doesn't have much head, but has a nice, small lace.  Starts sweet on the tongue, but finishes with a medium hoppy bitterness.  Clean but slightly alcoholic finish.  Creamy, thick.  This is a wonderful beer--quite possibly one of the top five or ten in the world.
I prefer a bit more hop in my porter.  This was definately creamy and smooth especially on hand pump.  Since I also prefer a bit more carbonation this was not gonna score high for me.
nice chocolate flavor, perfect looking beer, nice fat head and dark brown color, nice and smooth my only wish is that it would have more alcohol in it

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2003 A red brown color.  It has a very small cream-colored head and big bubbles.  The smell is coffee, malt, and milky.  Super smooth and creamy with exaggerated coffee flavors.  Did I say creamy!  It's like having some very good dark coffee and milk, but with a malt and alcohol kick.  Excellent!
This is an excellent porter - very smooth - but coffee aromas and flavors overwhelmed.  I'll have to give this one a second chance in the future.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2005 Dark ruby/brown color, the head was moderate but creamy. Aroma quite pronounced and chocolatey. Medium to full bodied, lightly carbonated, fudge and coffee flavors. The finish was smooth and mellow, just a little bitterness. Everything just seems to work so well together that this porter will have to be my benchmark for the style. An almost perfect beer.

Crystal Clear, it is hard to see through it this beer is so dark. Red black in color with a small but nice head that died young. Aroma of bitter chocolate and molasses. Medium bodied with a perfect balance between the bitterness of roasted malts, hops and the sweetness of malt.  Chocolate, burnt sugar and a mild malty sweetness. The flavor comes on strong right way followed by a clean finish. This is the perfect porter

A very wonderful beer from Fullers..who make lodss of wonderful beers.Lovelly dark, dark garnet colour around the edges of the beer, great coffee and creme head  that does not last but leaves luxurious lacing down the glass.The aroma is perfection for a porter.
Wonderful tatse  akin to thebest coffee ( Blue Montain) and Perugia dark chocolate..lovelly stuff

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2004 simply one of the best porters in existence.  roasted, malty, smooth, rich, vanilla, chocolate. shy of a high score only in the sense that it is not the most well rounded.  and so rich, a 20 oz bottle is best shared.

Smoooooooth stuff.  Rich choco-coffee aroma, but the taste is so wonderfully smooth.  It leaves a touch of fizzyness on the lips as it slides by and  downwards.  The choco-coff-ay taste is so perfectly intertwined in the smoothness of the palate that it seems to gently wash in and fade out.  great stuff!

I'm actually surprised that this beer has managed to rate so highly. Most of the dark beers don't do well unless they're over the top. I guess for a porter, this is definitely an assertive example, especially with hops that surprised my with their strong presence in the flavor profile. The hops start out bitter in the front and built during the middle only to fade into the finish and linger for a bit afterwards. A bit of burned bread is dominate in the middle of the flavor and while I'd be surprised if smoked malt is part of the mash, something's making me think of a campfire. A surprisingly good example of what a porter can be.

This one pours an almost opaque ruby-black, with a moderately sized cookie-brown head.  Definite toasted malt aroma, with a little cookie sweetness mixed in.  Tastes wonderful, has a nice silky mouthfeel.  Start a little bitter-sweet, and finished a mite sweeter.  I loved it.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2007 This is a great porter, but sometimes, since its an import, youll get a six thats skunked. This happened twice to me with this particular selection, and so I can understand why one of the raters said it tasted like hard liquor: if its slightly skunky, it does indeed taste very hard. But this is one of my faves, despite its setbacks. Its very smooth, and could almost pass for a creamy stout.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2003 Gorgeous dark ruby brown color. I wish women came in this color. Starts out with a bite of coffee liqueur, then hits some great flavor notes, including chocolate, raisins, rum, cherries and smoke. A prototype porter.

Black body that reveals garnet glints when held up to the light. Thick light brown head. Nose of  sweet  coffee, molasses and prunes. Taste of sweet coffee, brown sugar, prunes and raisons. Smooth mouthfeel. Though lacking in the bittersweet chocolate aroma and flavor I've come to expect from porters and stouts, this beer was very enjoyable
Dark almost opaque color. Very smooth and very good. Full bodied. Malty, coffee, chocolate flavors. The head left way too soon though.
Dark brown, thick tan head that didn't stick around. Impressive lacing. Big malty aroma with coffee notes. Taste is roasty malt with a bitter finish. A very good porter.

Deep mahogany brown, thin tannish head that evaporated far to fast but leaves impressive sticky, spotty ink-blot lacing. Smell is deeply roasty/toasty malts with a slight burntness with notes of hazelnut, dark toffee, and coffee. Taste is a fair amount of roasted malts, burnt-like toast and coffee, a bit acidy in the middle into the end where a tiny little fruityness slips in, finishing with a hoppy mellow dryness that balances well. Feel is medium to thin in abundance, no real richness or heftyness to be found for my idea of a robust porter. Its a solid porter by many means and quite a good drinker, I was hoping for more though.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2004 Pours a very dark garnet. Foamy head with a good bit of splotchy lacing. Nose is slightly bitter with a light touch of chocolate. Notes of bitter chocolate and coffee with a slight bit of astringency. Mouthfeel is smooth but a touch on the watery side with a healthy does of carbonation. Slightly bitter in the finish. Disappointing considering the high ratings it has here but still a very good porter.

Rich sweet nose on this one.  Color is deep black with little head.  Flavor seems to lack any real distinction to me beyond the malts.  The texture here is very nice, smooth all around, with a slight chalky aftertaste.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2004 Bottle: Ligth brown head, black body. Aroma; liqourice, tar?. Full body, soft. Nice balance between sweet and bitter. Liqourice, coffee-bitterness and notes of smoke....
Cask: Seductive and impressive! Black colour with the most creamy head ever. Milk chocolate, liqourice, lightly raosted coffe beans and a balancing restrained bitterness. Full and very smooth. (8,5,8,5,18)

Dark reddish/brown hue, small tan rocky head, some lacing, medium to full bodied. Heavy roasted malt aroma with hints of molasses, dark chocolate and espresso. Somewhat of a ruby port quality to it. Very nice. The flavor matches the aroma and has just enough bitterness to balance out the heavy malts. Beautiful mouthfeel, creamy and oily, soft carbonation and a moderate alcohol finish. Hint of smoke lingers on the palate. An exceptional beer.
Sort of a milk porter: very well balanced between malt sweetness and roast. No hops flavor. At first it reminded me of licking a cold BBQ grill, but in a good way.
Very smooth and malty.  I'm drinking it 2 months after the 'best by' date and it's still excellent.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2004 Lovely Coco flavor with light hints of vanilla and Blue Mountain Coffee!   Not an overly monstrous coffee and chocolate finis.. dry and roasty!  Great Stuff! 
Hats off to the brewers at Fullers that originated this fantastic London Porter. I am very impressed by this beer; I believe it is one of the best porters that I have ever come by. What a nice rich malted flavor with hints of coffee, chocolate, toffee, & motor oil, Ok, maybe not motor oil. Very nicely put together.

Very dark brown color with a substantial light brown head. Rich slightly roasted aroma of chocolate. Rich and crisp roasted flavor of chocolate/cocoa and coffee is slightly bitter. Similarly, finish is clean and roasted and a bit dry. Palate is medium-full bodied, fairly smooth, and silky.

I was really impressed by this porter, thin white head, dark dense appearance, smells strongly of coffee and roasted malts, the flavor is a delicious blend of nuts caramel and chocolate. This is a fine example of a porter.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2004 Rave reviews for this beer? I don't understand it. Are we talking about the same beer? I wrote the name down when I tried it, so yes. True this is a complex beer, but it tastes like something I don't like - hard liquor. It tastes like they literally put hard liquor in it. Bleh. If I want hard liquor I will go and drink that, but I want beer. Overall, the taste is overpowering and repulsed my taste buds. My beer connossieur friend Travis also agreed that it was not a good beer. This beer, along with Hoegaarden and Blue Moon of Kentucky is a beer I have no desire to drink again.

Let's re-cap. The aroma is beerish, but misleading since it doesn't really taste like beer. The appearance is the best thing about it, for it looks good. The flavour however tastes of whiskey and the palate of chocolate and coffee. My overall impression is very negative on this one. I really don't think it deserves a 99 rating. Second rating: The first rating was unfair. This beer tastes better at a slightly warmer temperature, which brings out its enjoyable porter attributes more and somehow makes it seem smoother. Still not deserving of a 99, but quite good and tryworthy.

Porter-brown with a light tan head. Aroma is roasted malt and chocolate with an alcohol presence. Very smooth and creamy. One of the creamiest porters I've had recently. Crisp and only slightly bitter. This is one of the finest Porters I've had the pleasure of knowing. I'm not real high on English bottles but this is an outstanding example. Flavor is rich and nearly perfect for it's style. Chocolate stands out with hops complimenting roasted malt.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Has a very dark brown color with some carbonation and a roasted/chocolate smell.  Taste is roasted malts/chocolate and finishes with a slight bitterness.  Overall a very good porter.
This is a serious brew. Strong choccolate notes in the flavor. It is still not too heavy and it surely lives up to it's name.

London must be one tasty town to have an excellent porter named after it.   I can see myself in Picadilly Square at the Shagadelic Pink Pussycat Lounge enjoying a London Porter while chatting to a groovy bird.

Dark brown w/ creamy tan foam. Rich roasty nose w/ lots of burnt coffee, bitter-sweet chocolate. Lovely thick, velvety feel. Very robust flavour: Sweet chocolate & fruit (prunes?, raisins) up front; roasted coffee in the middle. Woody (Oak), lightly acidic, earthy finish.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2004 Mmm...this is porter! Dark brown color, with a small off-white head. Both aroma and flavor contains  a well balanced mix of coffee and milk-chocolate and still it does not get too much of the same as with other porters. Well balanced indeed! Yummy yummy!!
UPDATED: MAY 21, 2003 A very good porter . Dark brown color with the classic coffee aroma. A good balance of alot of flavors. Finishes smooth with a nice bitterness.

This was a great beer all around.  From the dark brown color, to the coffee and chocolate aroma I wanted to drink this beer right away.  I wasnt dissapointed either.  Excellent flavor and feel.  Finished well.  Can't wait to try some more.
Dark brown with a small tan head. Smells like coffee and chocolate. Smell as if you were walking into a coffee store. Medium body. Taste sweet and coffee more like a stout.
One said "Smells like opening a bottle of chocolademilk". Pours with a fine lacing head. Flavor has first chokolade and later a little laqurice. Great bitterness.

Wow, this beer alone has made Porter high on my list.
It had a great aroma of caramel, toasty, burnt sugar and coffee. In the flavor it had much of the same plus some nice fruitiness and a compexity that is hard to describe. I think burnt marshmallow was in there. It had enough roasted grain and hops to keep the sweeter tendencies under control. It was smooth and full of body and had a nice mouthfeel. It was a perfect balance of many flavors. This is one to try.
(Bottle) Thin, beige head and deep red/balckis body. Slight aroma of sweet malt. Flavours of charcoal malt with botter smoked finish. Good.
wonderful slightly reddish and dark brown color. chocolate and coffee flavor, full and smooth. well balanced, not overpoweringly sweet. better served slightly warm. best porter I've had.

beautiful in the glass, a deep brown almost black colour with a nice bubbly tan head. aroma is mostly smooth caramel malts. chocolate and caramel malts in the flavor with a slight taste of the distinctive fuggles hop flavor. nice full body without being too stickily sweet and syrupy. smoked finish. excellent example of a porter.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2011 Original Rating, 3/25/2003:  Looks wonderful, nice and black with just a little head.  Chocolate and coffee aroma.  Lemme taste the goods... oh yeah... thats the stuff.  Heavy on the malt, definite chocolate.  Wow, this is THE porter.  I must find a place that sells large quantities of this.  Truly a marvelous beer. 9/5/8/5/18

Re-rating, 10/29/2011:  "THE porter... Truly a marvelous beer."  Sweet Loki... This is why its important to go back and revisit those beers from your early experiences.  Dark reddish brown color with a medium head.  Light coffee and fruity aroma.  Bitter chocolate/cocoa flavor.  Light roast notes.  Slightly chalky.  Medium mouthfeel.  Nowhere near the Nirvana I initially thought this was, but better than I expected the downfall to be.  6/5/7/3/14

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2004 good porter.  it's very rich and complex, and I've managed to drink it at the proper temperature purely by accident.  Brown to red brown color, no opacity although very dark, with a nice aroma, perfect body, more than pleasant smoky finish.  I need a fine piece of prime rib to go with this beer.  Tried it again comparing against Sam Smiths, and Fullers is far better IMO

Smelled a little alcohol when I first opened it, but mostly got an aroma of rosted nuts. Almost like a chocolate milk flavor, and in texture as well. The alcohol in the nose is not at all present in the taste. Very, very rich.

Bottled. Almost black with red brown highlights. Moderate beige head and good condition. Big booming aromas of licorice and chocolate. Complex and ever evolving in the mouth, starts with licorice and chocolate, moves on to a woody tartness and finally a tinny roast barley note. Leaves the mouth with an oily coat and a chalky throat. Licorice when you burp.
Overrated.  This average porter is malty and bland. Not that great, but easy to drink.  Maybe I had a bad batch or an old bottle, but I doubt it.
deep brownish red.  roasty, toffee-ish mocha aroma.  lots of roasty flavour with raisins, toffee, bitter chocolate, coffee and a balanced finish between roast and hop.  very nice.
A solid dry porter dominated by chocolate and roasted flavors.  Very smooth.  Allow this one to warm, as the flavors are better pronounced at these temperatures.  This is an excellent porter.
Outstanding. Flavor is full and rich, very complex. Chocolate and coffee dominate. Relatively low bitterness.
My favorite porter. Taste of chocolate and coffee all around. Well rounded. Gets better with every sip. Don't serve chilled!
This porter has a rich enjoyable flavor with taste of the chocolate malt coming through and a lingering smokey aftertaste.  I look forward to enjoying this beer on a regular basis.
Definitely dark, definitely smooth. One to finish the night. Puts hairs on your chest.

dark red brown body topped by a thick off-white head that leaves tons of lace on the glass.  Lacking in color for a porter.  Roasted, slightly smoked malt aroma with a slight fruitiness.  Roasted malt flavor with coffee accents and a good strong roasted coffee finish.  Full bodied and relatively smooth.

I have my serious reservations that there is a better overall porter out there than the Fullers London Porter. Its pours a generally black color into the glass with an occassional ruby spot here and there in the light with a small, not long lasting dark tan head. The aroma is chocolate malts, roasts and molasses. The taste is very silky in its chocolate malt approach. Nothing of an overbearing chocolate attack, but more like a coating...thin, yet fullfilling and round. Very little carbonation, just roasted malt, and a whole bunch of care and a great recipe. Some hopppiness evident right at the finish, good countersweet finish...very nice.
wonderful toasty, roasty aroma. Crisp, clean and slightly chocolaty. A top notch porter.

I LOVE THIS PORTER! it's every thing I love about a porter. Rish rosted choclate taste, full body ,not too bitter, great color. Smells great when you're pouring it into the glass. My favorite part is about half way down. that's when the most of it's flavor shines....I am a porter man!

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2009 Flavors are of smoked chocolate, and very very rich.  Palate is left tingling, and caked with a sweet chocolate taste.  Not as smooth as my favorite porters, but still has a magnificant fullness.
Dark color.  Very roasty, and coffee-like flavor, with slight chocolatey sweetness.  Not too thin, but still goes down easy.

I tink this may well become the standard that I measure porter's by. Deep reddish brown with a nice full head. Choclaty nose. Strong roasted malt flavor in front with slight bitterness in the finish. Surprisingly light mouthfeel for something this dark.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2003 (Bottled) Deep brown color, medium head. Roasted, chickory/coffee flavor, some barkiness, with a noticeable hops presence. Make sure you have a clean palate before drinking - taste suffered significantly when I didn't.

Almond, malt and chocolate nose. Dark brown - reddish color with a medium, hazelnutbrown, foamy head, leaving brussels laces. Light roasted, malty, chocolatey bitterness, very almond like (nutty). Light long lasting profile. Thanks a lot Captain Cougar!!!

Toasted peaty nose, dark opaque brown color, low tight lacy head. Deep roasted malt taste. Almost smokey. Maybe chocolate in the middle. Dry expresso bitterness that lingers forever. Thinner than expected and kind of monodimensional, but fun and certainly enjoyable.
This is what a porter should be to me.  It has great color and a slight coffee/ chocolate flavor.  Easily drinkable and very deserving of the accolades it has received.

Best by February 8, 2003 (September 10, 2002 tasing notes):  Absolutely delicious with delicate yet substantial chocolate and a hint of coffee flavor. Hugely refreshing for a porter; re-thinking Anchor's rating (Hmmmm... Nah!)

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2003 This is a classic porter, a standard.  I've had a few different porters between the last time I had Fullers, I now think I can appreciate how good it is.  I can really tast the chocolate malts.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Very little bitterness.  Delicious Beer.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2003 Over all, this is a very nice beer. Almost no carbonation in the bottle I poured. It had very little head. It was very dark in color to the point of being unable to see through it. It goes down very smoothly with little after bite. The taste lingers for a while then fades. And the GF gave it a so-so rating over all. Hmm and I thought I was beginning to teach her something. Im Himmel gibt es kein bier darum truinken vir es heir! In Heaven there is no bier that is why we drink it here!
rich sweet vanilla aroma, full bodied lavishing licorice and bitter choclate, a liquid dream

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2003 Best porter I've ever had.  There's a lot of silkiness going on here.  Silky molasses, coffee, roasted malt flavors.  Has a lingering chocolaty, cocoa smoothness.  Makes me want to explore English beer, and I've never liked English beer. Rerate:  Reminds me of a fine dopplebock.  I would like to compare this to Ayinger Celebrator.  I think they would taste similar, and the Fuller's would be better.  ReReRate:  I just finishing this thing up, and it is truely awesome.
Bottled.  Light bodied aroma. Creamy, produced nice head.  Hints of Chocolate but more coffee than I typically like.  Very light in hops.

Pouring this beer is half the fun, I love to watch the bubbles rise and form the head. The head is thick and long lasting and sits on top of the dark ruby red beer. The aroma drew me right in and I had to taste it right from the bottle. I couldn't wait for the head do go down and I wasn't disappointed by the rich chocolate taste. Palate is smooth with no aftertaste other than the wonderful residual chocolate flavor. I my have just replaced for Youngs Double Chocolate, my ex favorite beer.

Very dark ruby pour, medium tan, creamy head, slowly diminishing to leave good lacing.  Aroma is strong, with dark choocolate, roasted cofee, and caramel taking the lead.  Flavor follows, with the coffee taking the initial lead, followed by hints of caramel, and finishing with a long lasting dark chocolate taste.  Very solid mouthfeel, light carbonation on the tongue, and that long lasting flavor keeps you remembering what you just drank for a while afterwards.

This beer has taste.  The smell of chocolate and cream are backed up by the intense taste.  This is coffee, chocolate and beer combined at its best.  This will be my dinner tonight.  I will likely not buy guiness again after this wonder.  Goes down so smooth.  This will be the warm-up beer from now on.
Dark brown, light tan head.  Aroma is hard to come by, a little malt, some sweetness.  Nice coffee notes in the body, some roast.  Smooth, but finishes rather sweet and a bit thin.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2006 Tan head, very dark brown color, aroma of roasted chocolate.  Taste is slightly bitter enhanced by a slight sweetness.  No aftertaste.  My second favorite porter next to Great Lakes Edmund Fitzgerald.
An excellent porter. It's color is extreamly dark, it's taste is pleasing, not sweet but bearing a hint of chocolate.

Tan, creamy head, mostly diminishing.  Fairly dark mahogoney, but so dark as most porters I've had.  Wonderful aroma of coffee beans and chocolate.  It makes my mouth water.  So smooth drinking my jaw dropped after the first sip.  Sweetness gives way to light coffee to acidic coffee finish.  This stuff is fantastic.  Not only that it is a bargain, it was only 2.79 at my local store.  It is easy to see why this porter is rated so highly.  For once this isn't a case of people being afraid to rate something poorly because everyone else has rated it well.  This is a well crafted beer, one I'll drink many times in the future.
I thought this was overall a very good porter. A little flat and dry, with slightly choclately undertones, did not leave a bad aftertaste.
Run of the mill porter, no strong caramel or chocolate tones, but fuller bodied (hence the name!) and mild!
Nice roasted aroma.  Roasted and chocolate malts throughout with a slight sweetness.  Almost a light stout.  One of the most enjoyable porters I have had, and I am not a big fan of the style.
Oaty in aroma with a great deep dark black color with a brown head. Dark roasted malt flavors maybe a bit too dry in the finish for my taste that day.
Id better have another bottle if I want to say anything that hasnt been said below.
This lived up to the rating.  Loved every drop.  Good head. Great taste from the blends of malts.  I will be attempting to home brew this soon.
Black, lasting brown head. Pleasant roasted nose. Great roasted malt profile. Thin bodied

This porter is wonderful.  Very drinkable indeed.  Nice dark brown with ruby edges.  Excellent Roasty nose.  Start is very malty/roasty.  Good bitterness balance that is perfect.  Clean dry finish with a nice roasty aftertaste that does not go away.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2012 My best porter to date. Full deep dark color. Nice head which didnt last long.  Rich Flavor lingers. This beats USA Porters to date. A 2012 Christmas beer.  The rich drak color and warm taste of roasted malt keep you coming back.  Still a great one.

Two tastings. One on draft and a bottle while bottling some homebrew Porter. The homebrew sucks :-). My all time favorite Porter was the wrong thing to use as a yardstick. Oh well. Fullers is good stuff.

This is a very rich beer with well rounded flavors. The head remains nicely and is very rich and creamy. It has a very robust full feel in the mouth and the coffee-like finish is sublime. It is a very nice beer to drink on a cool evening.

Pours a deep deep blood red, almost brown, but hints of burgandy. Nice sized head. Smells of sweet smoke with a little chocolate and coffee blended together. Tastes of dark chocolate with a harmony of coffee with a perfect finish of crystal malt. A bit too mild to be perfect, but damn near. This is one tasty beer!

This was definitely a rare find at the Plez U convenience store in Clemson, SC.  By far one of my favorite porters to date although its quite overpriced where I found it.  Awesome roasted chocolate and coffee flavors and as rich as Id expect any porter to be.  Pleasantly sweet in aroma and taste.  This beer is pretty much deserving of all the hype.
thick malt flavor, dark chocolate lingers in the background.  good stuff
Thickly roasted malt tastes with added wood-nut tones.  Mild with a nice caramel aroma. Completely solid.

(24Dec2002--bottle) Nice beer.  Very well-balanced, but somewhat timid.  A frothy, lumpy, coarse, quickly receding, somewhat persistent and lacy head.  Perfectly lively and persistent carbonation.  Dominant aroma is coffee, with light notes of honey and malt.  Dark ruby color.  Flavor is simple; dominated by coffee, with light maltiness.  Somewhat astringent.  Perfectly balanced bitterness and sweetness.  Thin mouthfeel.
Light Chocolate and cocoa aroma. Big chewy flavors.  Dry at the end. The standard for the style.
Very tasty, neither the coffee or the chocolate overpowers the other. Wonderful malt/hops balance. Definitely worthy of its rating

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2003 Excellent porter. Creamy, chocolatey, coffeeish=delicious aroma. Good solid malty flavor in addition to the coffee and chocolate flavors. Finishes with a hefty dosing of hops; more than Ive come to expect from an English beer. A little bit watery in the finish. Impressive stuff this is.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2004 Warm darkness (eyh!?)
A flavor of ash resting on a bed of roasty malt and sublime chocolate. Evident, but shy, bitterness, and just enough sugar to slip down easily. Good one.
UPDATED: JUN 23, 2004 Vinous and complex.   Dark ruby brown.  Don't even think about drinking this below about 55 degrees.

I like porters and this was a good one. A deep dark brown color, with a deep brown/black head, it hads hints of coffee in its smell. But the taste was great. It was a dark smooth taste hint of coffee and a sort of nut flavor was detected in this great brew by Fuller, Smith & Turner.
This porter has a slighter chocolate taste compared to other Porters and Stouts and a stronger alcohol aftertaste that does not overpower. I had it on tap and it was extremely good.

Im not a lover of Porters admittedly but even if you normally cannot tolerate Porters yourself, Id recommend trying this one.  Theres a nice balance in this I cannot articulate, but I will say that its not too sweet.  This category of beer will always be the preferred of a minority who, for some reason like syrupy, extremely fattening beer.  A drink of obese English pigs in dark cellar bars.
Its big and roasty and rich with an exquisite mouthfeel, but the undertones - charcoal/creosote and brandied raisons, seem at odds with each other and with the brew.
One of the finest porters that you can get.  Wonderful chocolate malt taste.

Near-black in colour with red highlights. Extremely minimal head. Aroma of bitter chocolate and toasted malt. Wonderfully smooth mouthfeel, and a perfectly balanced flavour of roasty malt, chocolate and coffee, finshed with a mild hoppiness. Yummy!

Poured a rich dark brown, with small creamy head, rich roasted malt aroma, wonderful roasty malt taste with chocolate and coffee, with just the right hop bitterness in the finish, a true delight to drink
A very good porter.  Chocolatey, roasty, and moderately fruity.  Dark, creamy, and sweet.  No head for some reason.
A dark red almost black beer with a fine light brown head. The aroma is fruity an slightly smokey. And the flavor is smokey but very mellow - nice but very mainstream for a porter.

Bottle- One of my new favorite beers. Strong aroma of coffee and chocolate. Deep burgundy color with very little head retention. Smooth, velvety chocolate flavor smothers your taste buds and excites the senses. A world class beer from a world class brewery.
Truly, an amazing beer!  Full roasted with loads of bitter sweet chocolate, caramel, and toasted barley.  Found a large glass to hold the whole big bottle.  Fantastic!

dark brown with a hint of red color, head is frothy beige and lasting. aroma is huge malty and chocolatey with some fruitiness. flavor is very chocolately with a hint of coffee in there. also some bitterness in the finish.

This is with out a doubt, true porter!  This is what it is all about!  A dark rich color with hints of chocolate, and coffee.  And slight taste of a nuttiness.  Smooth and creamy.  I will drink again, and it is now on my list of top ten.
Chocolate coffee aroma.Smooth coffee, chocolate,vanilla and oak flavors.mild hop finish.
UPDATED: FEB 23, 2003 very nutty but fruity aroma, dark amber color, tan head disappered quickly...strong coffee and smokey flavors

Despite its high rating, this porter completely surprised me. Dark with a thick, too thick creamy hot chocolate head that soon settles--the first whiff reveals that this is a robust porter--one with a sharp coffee and chocolate aroma that is perfect--absolute heaven--and concealing in a tantalizing manner the initmation of alcohol. The smoky, roasted flavor is amorphous and sharp (black patent malt proliferation??) The sharp flavor will take some getting used to, but this beer projects as a winner on camping/fishing expeditions. A pleasant surprise and a beer I will no doubt rate again in the not so distant future.
This classic porter is a stand-by when I want a good dark porter with a lot of body

Smells of chocolate, coffee and tobacco! Dark chocolate colour, a touch of garnet around the egde, almost no head. Chocolate, coffee and roasted malt flavour. Dry, rich and roasty(Yum!) So glad to finally try this Porter on tap at Smokeless Joes.
Dark brown, coffee and chocolate flavours, nice long malty bitter finish.  Outstanding.

Lighter, yet just as refreshing, as the smell of the first drippings of coffee on  a sleepy morning.  The deep copper browness blurs around the edges, laced with a light thin head. The taste is very mellow and deep, mellow and deep. The hint of milk chocolate, dark milk chocolate that fades to bitter sweet in the end, tells the tale of a splendid porter.

One fine brew.  Pours out to a dark as night color in the glass with a minimal head.  Smell is that of roasted fruit and malt.  Taste is that of roasted malt, hops and as someone else said, licorice.  I detected a plum-like taste as well.  The finish is smooth and begs for another sip.

One word:  Delicious.

DEEEP dark rich color coupled with a nice head on top.  Complexity is right on, kind of sharp at first, sweet and maltylater on.  Well roasted flavor with notes of chocolate and coffee.  Lingering bittersweet finish.  A VERY good porter
Now thats good stuff.  Great roasted malt and chocolate aroma.  This is the most complex porter Ive had til now.  Chocolate, coffe and roasted malts notes that seem to go on forever.

This beer rocks.
Aroma of cocoa and coffee, caramel and brown sugar.
Beautiful, very dark, sparkling ruby hue. Medium sized, creamy, tan head. Mostly lasting with excellent lacing.
Flavors of roasted nuts smothered in dark chocolate, toffee,  buttery caramel. Perfectly balanced. Not sweet. Slighty salty, rich with hints of espresso on the backside.
Lively carbonation. Full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel. Long, slightly bitter and salty, dry finish. Excellent Porter. Another triumph from Fullers.

Somewhat disappointed, given the ratebeer reputation of this one. I found the flavor to be rather thin. It had pleasant roasty chocolate malt notes, and hints of coffee flavor, but just not enough to make it really interesting. Also found it to have a slightly chalky aftertaste which wasnt terribly bad, but wasnt a good thing either.

Very dark and rich.  Pours with a coffee-like roasted aroma and a thick tan head.  The flavor is minimally sweet but plenty robust and smooth.  This porter is very well rounded and a great example of the style.

BB Oct.21 02;Dark mahogany with a oat colored decent head.Rich,clean malts,small roast,and slight coffee aromas.Palte is soft and oily.Rich maltiness,cocoa,roastiness borders bunt(which I like)followed with a deep dark coffee finish.Very little,if any,hops detected.Been a couple years and it was as good as I remembered.Drank right out of the closet.60 degrees.I couldnt ask for a better temp.Head has disappeared but the flavor is more pronounced now.Excellent blend of malts.You can taste all three.A fresh sample(case)is wanted for this winter season.

Dark black color, medium head. Nice chocolate and coffee aroma. Full bodied porter. Deep roasted malt flavor. Rich complex flavors; cocoa, chocolate, and coffee. Smooth taste. Slightly sweet. Well balanced. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and round. Aftertaste is slightly bitter. Very Nice beer.
Great porter.  Not quite my style. but still very appreciable.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2005 Sweet and chewy nose is your first clue that this is going to be a tasty brew! Smooth & rich mouthfeel is very enjoyable on the tongue. Chocolate-caramel-coffee with a tinge of rich hoppiness. Sugary malts make it a little cloying, but the flavors that stick to your mouth counteract that negative. This beer is so damn flavorful, in all the right ways. Cask at Falling Rock: Smooth and nicely balanced. Rich and roasty. Big chocolate exudes throughout. Wholesome yeast note with a light fruitiness (prune and pear, perhaps).
Well, the commercial description says it all. This beer is full of flavor but light in body.  Nice.

A very nice beer with lots of flavor.  Excellent dark brown porter color with a nice aroma.  Easy to drink as it is not overpowering.  Crisp smooth and precise.  I really enjoyed the draught version of this.
Roasty smell with coffee aroma,a deep brown like a high school freshmans first dime bag it.  A very light head.  The fire department was too late, it is oh so burnt and i like it.
Awesome porter.  Great burnt coffee flavors.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2007 2nd Re rate Has become my standby at the local pub when nothing new to try. Just does not do it for me anymore to rate this lofty of a rating. Tasting kind of sour lately - too many times for it to be a bad keg Previous 4.6   1st Re rate: Had from a bottle for the first time - previously only had on draft.  Does not stand up as well bottled up - still a great Porter - but not worth a 5.0 as I had rated before in a bit of sophomoric euphoria! Did not have that same frothiness or chocolaty undertones.   Original    Draft - Reminds me of a chocolate milkshake - my first choice at the local Pub.  The standard by which all other Porters are rated against in my book.

Mmmm, the label says rich and dark which it is, but not the richest or the darkest porter Ive had. Its been a while since Ive had good rich beer, and this is nice. Coffe-like smell with a touch of sugar.  LOTS of coffee flavor, gets a bit annoying after a while. There is a very nice roasted flavor - kind of like well roasted sunflower seeds. Nice, well rounded porter.
This is a great beer. The collegues ide shared it with didnt like it, but i find it interresting. Notes of coffee and caramel in the nose. Great stout.
Good God almighty!  What a roasted flavor that was!  Like Mocha coffee.  This beer comes at you, very good.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2012  Oct, 2002. This is a pleasantly smooth and rich chocolate stout - bags of flavour but without much character. All the dark malt flavours are there, and its nice, but theres an oomph missing. [3.1] 
May, 2003. Good chocolate and firm but gentle roasted malts. Very good mouthfeel. Alcohol warmth beyond its strength. Smooth. It does lack an edge, but is a very palatable brew. [3.6]
Oct, 2004 Got this as part of Fullers Autumn Beers pack at Waitrose in Portsmouth. And its a very attractive beer which accompanied a soup very well. It has the roasty, chocolate, coffee notes of a dark beer, such as a stout or porter, though it is sweeter than average, and with a soft, almost creamy mouthfeel. Certainly attractive, though not outstanding or World Class in any sense except reputation. The beer is clearly dead - there is no life in the liquid. It flows across the palate in a very limp manner. The soft sweetness is more inclined to American tastes than British (which would account for poor sales here in the UK, while the bulk of production goes to America). I can understand people liking this on a personal level, but its not, and can never be, a good example of craft beer - regardless of style. [3.0]
January 2009 500ml bottle from Sainsburys. Its been a while since I had this beer. I do like dark beers, and this one is pleasant enough.  Theres a decent range of flavours - blackcurrant, ash, butter, soap, etc. Its quite hop bitter for a dark beer - usually the bitter flavours come mainly from the dark roast, but this has a considerable hop bitterness. Just a little too bitter and serious for my taste. The more I drink this the less I really enjoy it. The first few swallows were better than the later ones as this builds in the mouth. Its certainly a robust beer. I like the bottle, and the sober authority of the label, but the beer itself, doesnt impress. [ 2.8]
April, 2012 500ml bottle from Sainsburys. A nose rich in dark malty flavours - burnt toffee prominent. Pleasant mouthfeel - gentle, almost natural carbonation. Flavours feel fresh and natural as the pasteurising process doesnt impact on dark beers as much as pale. Theres an initial creamy toffee and coffee flavour, soft and attractive, then the bitterness, the cinders and ashes gently come through to provide interest and balance. Very drinkable, very pleasant, and very enjoyable. Perhaps too much bitter ash in the finish, lingering too long, but overall a decent little beer. [3.5]

Best porter ever. This was a hard sell for me as Im not big on the style, but this was impressing. Nose was like licorice and heavy malts. The taste was just strung out on coffee that finished with a kind of roasty flavor. Just wicked cool stuff, even with a dessert.
Has just the correct mix of chocolate malts.  Too many porters have too much chocolate malts, but not this one.

This is terribly complex.  In one six pack, I had the following experiences: the first had this tremendous (and welcome) chargrill taste with coffee in the back; the second bottle was coffee up front, with one of the longest finishes imaginable, the coffee unfolding and showing so many different sides; on the third bottle, I experienced sweet vanilla and chocolate milk shake flavors dried out marvelously by the darker grain astringency.  Each had a remarkable mouthfeel--I think the perfect viscosity for the style.  I cant wait to see what the other 3 bottles will be like.

I think that I may have had an old bottle of this because it didnt appeal to me like it seems to appeal to everyone else.  Nice ruby red/black color, tan/white head, nice burnt flavor, but something makes me like Sam Smiths Taddy Porter better.

Loved the deep, deep red colour of this brew. Strong aroma of black roast malt reminiscent of a heavy stout. Upon first tasting, quite bitter, strong mocha flavour too, mellows to a more chocolatey sensation mid-palate with lingering bitterness. Unfortunately this beer doesnt have a great deal of body, as evidenced by the rather fragile head, its smooth as milk but quite thin. Goes  well with full cream vanilla ice cream and rich chocolate sauce. Thanks Dogbrick.

This really is a great beer.  Definitely should not be served too cold, as the taste gets MUCH better as it approaches room temp.    I noticed bits of coffee and maybe just the slightest hint of choclate.  The head was not as creamy or thick as I had expected.  The color is a deep, deep mahogany, or maybe more of a ruby black.  Will definitely be buying more of this
Black gold.  I wish I could swim in a pool filled with Fullers Porter.  The best porter Ive ever had.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2003 Re-rate February '03: There is something missing in this beer that I thought was there last fall.  Although coffee and chocolate delightfully infiltrate the flavor, this beer seems less full-bodied to me than I once thought. The finish is more dry/bitter than I remember too.  It's a really good beer, but not quite worthy of my original 4.5 rating. September '02: This is quickly becoming one of my favorite dark beers.  Very dark color, very rich tastes, especially of black coffee.  Not much head retention though.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2004 Rerate-  This beer, the second time around was much better than I had expected.  As it warms more flavors of roasted coffee and chocolate come through with just the right amount of bitterness.
Heavy aroma of coffee, but not much of a head.  Very smooth with a wonderful dark roasted coffee flavor.  Like french roast as a beer.
I had my hopes up high for this beer but was disappointed;too much astringency from the roasted malts. Their ESB is stellar and should get this rating
Thick rich flavour, Roasty coffee flavors, apparent without being overbearing. A smooth perfectly balanced porter.
The best of its style that I have had. Thick and very rich, with coffeeish flavors. Probably the most flavorful porter around.
One of the best porters Ive had. Thick, chewy, great mouthfeel. Coffee and chocoalate flavors melded perfectly. Porter Heaven!

A nice brown apperance, with little head.  The aroma is like many other chocolatey beers.  I did not taste this at optimal time -- eating Chineese food and Im sick -- and though I can hardly taste anything esle, I can certainly taste this!  This is the type of beer that will put hair on a mans chest.  Very strong taste, still fairly smooth, and a little bitter finish.  Youll only drink one, :O).

Caramel dark chocolate, taosted grain nose.  Deep mahogony hue.  Yellowish tan head with slight lacing.  Sweetness first, medium full bodied.  Velvety smooth, chocolate, caramel, grains, and a nice hopped bitter finish.  One hell of a beautiful example of a porter.  Brilliantly balanced!Perhaps best of style!

mahogany brown like deep tannin mangrove bayou water, mars red highlights. cocoa colored head is not a major player, stepping aside to avoid the huge updraft of bouquet: michigan cherry and espresso   doppel-chocolate; mockingbird-convincing aromatic mimics of alpenbitter (jagermeister), raisins and backstrap syrup. assertive carbonation and sweetness comprise the first act, dry cola and coffee come next, alot of deep toasty shadings, just short of smoky burnt, and finally a nicely coalescing moderate bitterness. i didnt want to rush into a verdict, so i drank several bottles (hic) to affirm my impression: this is a damn nice porter. maybe one more...
UPDATED: AUG 1, 2007 Pour is dark brown, aroma is overwhelmingly roasted malts.  Flavor is chocolately (burnt barley) with a slight sweetness.  A bit bitter.  Nice balance.

Deep garnet in color and a biege head.  Dark chocolate and espresso notes in the nose.  Dark begian chocolate and coffee with a beautiful bakers chocolate bitterness.  A hint of oak emerges as the beer warms.  Nice solid mouthfeel and very smooth.
Mild burnt aroma.  Deep brown/burgundy colour.  Fairly thin bodied with an oily mouthfeel.  A bit on the light side, but super mellow!!!
I actually did not like this porter. I think it had too little complexity in the palate and a bitter sweetnes wich I did not like. It might be necessary for me to taste it again and re-rate it.
A great porter.  Roasty chocolate taste that lasts after every sip.
Nice chocolate flavor, and i dont dont care for chocolate much. Very good porter indeed.
A nice example of a good english porter.  Not much special though about it.

Just tried this one at the Flagstaff beer festival.  Made a point of having it early so I could actually remember tasting it.  Best porter Ive had.  Flavor and aroma of chocolate, coffee and molasses.  Full mouth feel, almost creamy.  Highly recommended.

Looks great. Dark malt aroma and flavor, a little coffee. Roasty. This is the best porter Ive had, but I have to say Im not especially fond of porters. I have a lot of respect for Fullers, I really like their ESB. I think Porter might be the only style I dont like.
Nice dense head. The beer itself is deep red-brown; this is what porter should look like. The flavor is nice; rich and roasty, not too complex. Excellent.

Pours a deep black with a tan head. Held up to the light reveals a ruby red center growing darker at the edges. Hints of coffee in the aroma.Flavor is roasted malt with a little sweetness at the end. Palate is very light with a touch of creaminess. Very good beer.

For the last couple of days Ive been dreaming of a silky smooth porter, with a milky soft finish. After Sam Smiths Taddy Porter didnt fill the bill last night, I picked a bottle of London Porter today. If only Id bought this yesterday! This is a great brew. Some might call this almost a milk stout. Call it what you wish. Its great and Id buy it again no problem.

This was really very nice.  There is a wonderful creaminess that lasts throughout.  Chocolate, roasted malt, a bit of vanilla (per ecrvich).  The finish is mostly malt with a bit of hoppy bitterness.  Quite delightful.

Very dark red-brown with decent beige head.
Aroma with apples,dried fruits,roasted malt, chololate, coffee.
The flavor is a bit thin in the start but has a good bitterness and lots of coffee and some almonds in it. Long bitter coffee finish.
I think it´s a bit weak for a porter.
Frothy, creamy, and quality describe this Porter.Warms me, wow makes me look forward to Winter, This will be a fine Holiday beverage.
Wonderful brew, very malty and deep with excellent character.  Not the best porter, but very close.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2010 Bottle (BB Sep/10). Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is dark brown to black. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (roasted grain, dark chocolate), with notes of vanilla and paper. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Light to medium body, creamy/watery texture, lively/soft carbonation. I really used to like this beer, and I suppose its still decent enough for what it is, its just kinda simple and forgettable.

Creamy, creamy, and yet still more creaminess. Chocolate, vanilla, oaky, unbelievable. Smokiness evident. A tad too much Choc. malt for my taste, but elegantly done, to be sure. Flavors meld in your mouth wonderfully.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: I worked in the welfare reform industry for the City of Detroit.  Needless to say, after a full 8 hours, I was ready to blow off an 19th century generator worth of steam.  Luckily, the perfect beer to unwind a particularly horrific day of work was Fuller London Porter ... and, more importantly, they had it on tap in a bar next to work.  This is the quintessential British porter.  Intricate and delicious malt complexity -- this beer is definitely balanced towards malt.  Gently hop bitterness.  For any of you who have not tried this beer, do your best to find it on tap somewhere before purchasing a bottle.
Very good beer with a strong roasted flavor. Pretty dark color with a creamy head.  Excellent Beer.
It just does not get much better. Perfectly balance between sweetness and bitterness. Matches a good piece of chocolate cake!
dark brown colour, fine creamy head, extremely rich aroma of black chocolate and raisins, roasted, full-bodied, strong bitterness, long dry bitter coffeish finish - simply wonderful

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2004 Yummy yummy yummy yummy yummy!  Aroma and flavor heavy on the chocolate, maybe some coffee, and smokey tint to the flavor and palate.  Goes down real nice and smoov, too.  This could quite definitely become a new oft-returned-to favorite.  Did I mention le chocolat?  Oh, and yummy.

dark, smooth, easily drinkable porter. Well blended with a nice warm feel. Nice off-white head when poured, taste is a bit more crisp when drank cold but mellows as temp increases. Good all around brew.
UPDATED: JAN 27, 2003 Really incredible!  Very dark with rich, warm flavors. Wonderful roasted coffee bean, chocolate aroma.
Great rich British type porter. No one knows what the original porters tasted like, but Id bet they were close to this. Great bottle, too, especially if youre a homebrewer (caps well)

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2004 Yeah! This is one of the best beers I've ever had. Sweet, rich, chocolate, roasted taste. The taste got even better as the beer got warmer. Beautiful head/lace, and dark dark dark brown appearance. Perfect carbonation. Perfect blend/balance of flavors. The tastes worked together without any individual one overpowering the others. It felt like savoring a really great meal. I considered getting another one, but I had to drive. Great beer!

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2003 Rerate 1/30/03: While still one of my favorite beers, I am adjusting the score down a bit. 7/11/02 (4.7): Every bit as good as I hoped it would be. I hit the jackpot when Andy's North Campus sent an e-mail that they had cases of this for $11.99. Excellent roasted aroma with hints of chocolate. Rich, dark color with a thin head. Hearty coffee/chocolate flavor that neither dissipated nor overpowered. One of the best beers I have tried.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2006 Bottle. Deep Red-Mahogany color. Short, Burnt Off-white head that disappears fairly rapidly.  Sweet chocolate, plum/raisin aroma.  Initial taste is a rich, chocolate flavor with very even dark roast coffee undertones that strike with a not-too-bitter pleasant appeal.  As it goes down has a caramel/hop taste that hits the back of the palate, providing for a full English ale flavor.  Finish has a roasted-copper appeal that lingers, with nutty overtones as it warms.  Carbonation is not a problem in the bottle.  Best Porter out there? Quite possibly.  Make this stuff unpasteurised and unfiltered and Id give it a perfect score.Nitro draught Blah, this was pretty bad, the roastiness shows through, but in a sickly sweet/sour way, with dry chocolate and a weak body, per nitro.  Wont be rating this sample, as this stuff was not meant to be on nitro.

near perfect porter.strikes all the right balances
rich and filling but not heavy, sweet without being cloying,  complex yet still a good session ale.
An excellent porter: substantial without being heavy, sweet without being cloying, and creamier than the average porter.
UPDATED: OCT 18, 2012 Chocolate truffles filled with coffee and a single nutOn the side, some caramel on toasted bread, heated on coalDo you hear the waltz?

Ruby black in color; Head is thin (draft); Clean, slightly nutty nose with proper hints of coffee. Round on the tongue and seems to expand across the palate. Lovely. Flavors swirl around in the mouth creating different impressions from different angles. No hint of alcohol. Very satisfying.
Full, round, satisfying.  Deep rain-forest complexity.  Mulchy, in a good way.

A good example of the porter style; unfortunately, I dont much get into porters (no idea why).  Pretty brew, nice and dark with a coffee-colored head and smells nice and malty, but I find the flavor to be a bit heavy on coffee hints, and I dont like coffee.  The sweet maltiness in the finish shows a nice polish, though.
Damn good porter.  A perfect amount of hops.  Drinks very smooth and leaves the palate as happy as a clam at high tide.
UPDATED: FEB 18, 2004 Dark brown with a full, light tan head. A chocolatey, medium roast aroma and delicious smoke, roasty and cocoa flavors ride a smooth drinkable lightly carbonated body.
man what a porter. very tasty. nice dark color. i loved this porter. i had some high expectations and it lived up to them.
A very drinkable and traditional porter, from one of Londons most historic breweries.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2004 Deep ruby-black color, nice thick head that clings to my glass. Fresh roasted aroma, chocolate-caremel and roasty coffee flavors. Medium body, nice soft creamy mouthfeel, one of the best porters around.
dark brown w/ the aroma & flavor of coffee & chocolate. It finishes very smoothly
A unique and wonderful experience, not just for a porter, but one of the best beers Ive tasted.  A rich, smooth, toffee flavor that marks this beer as a must-have on the island.

Okay, this is my first try at Fullers attempt at a porter, having already sampled their 1845 and ESB. It had a wonderful very dark ruby red color. It created a wonderful dark tan head, but it failed to hold, but that may have been due to the temperature I had it chilled at. The taste is good, with elements of chocolate, coffee and perhaps toffee. The finish is good, it a little lighter than I like for this style. Also applys to the body of it, while good, really not as heavy as I like porters to be.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2004 Dark with burnt-smoky flavours. A decent Fullers beer but nowhere near as good as cask Chiswick, Pride or ESB.

Rerate:

Oh how tastes change. I soaked some sausages in this, then fried them and served with fried red onions, english mustard mash & also some gravy with this a the base. Served the rest of the bottle (at least 350ml), and this was superb, especially with the food..
A very good porter, its right up there with Deschutes Black Butte.  Great chocolate malt flavors and a smooth finish .
This is a great porter, strong, well-balanced, and memorable.
Great aroma!- a fine balance of dark chocolate and nuts; goes down smooth and warms the belly. Its  classic- its perfect porter.
Excellent.  Best porter I have tried, especially in terms of balance.  Nice malt tones, but wonderful smoky, chocolately flavors!
Very good classic English Porter. Full, consistent flavor all the way through (the 6-pack).  A bit expensive but worth the small investment.
Excellent. Dark roast coffee/ dark chocholate flavor. Soft and smooth just a slight hint of bitterness.

Walked into the kitchen, didnt turn on the light, I thought I grabbed a London Pride from the fridge - opened the bottle and was hit w. a burst of chocolate aroma. Jeez, this is a chocolate malt for adults. Great look, flavor, mouthfeel. Fans of bitterness will regret the lack of a bitter finish, but appropriately, the finish is sweet, tangy and clean. A fine after dinner beer, a whole pint is a bit more sweetness than I usually care to drink, but great nonetheless.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2004 Wonderful elements.  The head was enchanting, like a thick ice cream float, and the feel in the mouth an excellent combination of richness and subtle carbonation.  Long finish.  The taste is the usual suspects: coffee, chocolate, roasted nuts.  The aroma is a bit understated.  In the end, I think I prefer Fullers 1845.  //Re-rate, June 2004.  My wife bought a bottle to use in making an onion gravy, since she recalled that the recipe called for some kind of alcohol (it actually called for a sweet wine!).  But the gravy turned out great (with sausage and over wide noodles), and there was over half a bottle left for me to enjoy, and it was much more than I had originally remembered.
I have just found another favorite. I love the chocolate and coffee flavors. Great Porter!!!
Great porter. Wonderfully malty without being too filling. Tastes of dried fruits and burnt chocolate. Absolutely beautiful.
I  loved the roasted malt flavor had a slight chocolare and roasted malt taste

COmplex little porter here with an aroma of dark fruits, roasted malt, and cough medicine.  Full bodied with dark fruits, bitter chocolate, roasted malt and alcohol all making an appearance.  A little perplexing, as I thought it had alot in common with an imperial stout with regard to flavors and aroma.  Clear cola color with a medium head that didnt last.
Bottle.  A very smooth porter that does not overwhelm.  Nice chocolate/coffee flavor in a robust wrapping.

Great porter, and the chocolate/coffee notes are not to strong as in many American porters.  This is the model, along with Taddy Porter. Its also a tremendous bargain, all Fullers products are, you can get an Imperial pint (18.6 oz) bottle for around $2.50 or so...

Dark orange-brown clear  colour with large but quickly dissipating head. Rich aroma including glimpses of candied fruit, chocolate, molasses, malt, coffee and cough medicine but all with minimum sweetness. Medium bodied and quite a delicate and satisfying bitter-sweet balanced palate. The only thing I found slightly  disappointing about this beer is the somewhat weakish finish although perhaps any bigger bodied or thicker a texture would possibly make it too cloying and make it hard to drink more that a half a pint. Excellent after dinner drink along with a couple of bitter (or sweet) chocolate mints.
(Rated 3/5/02: Southborough UK)

Incredibly rich and creamy.  Deeply roasted, malty, coffee aroma.  The first few sips were way too bitter for me, but once I got settled into it, very enjoyable.  Sweet, roasted, chocolate, coffee, with a strong bitter finish.  Excellent porter.  Like you needed me telling you that.

wonderful rich sweet aroma, mixes with scents of coffee, and dark roasted malt.  Dark ruby.  Very well balanced with flavors of of sweet richness, hints of chocolate, roasted malts take over, and finishes with a nice dark roasted nutty flavor.  Well done beer.
Good porter, a little sweet for my tastes but if you like porters this is one of the best.

Very dark, near black appearance with fudge colored creamy thick head. Aroma of dark chocolate and nuts. Tons of chocolate malt giving this porter an extremely viscous body with hints of plums and dates. Easily one of the best porters made.

Amazing, rich, port aroma with a slightly hoppy background.  Deep cola color with limited head.  Slightly woody, port flavor that was sweet and earthy.  Lovely roundness, but more of a liqueur flavor than I really like.
This beer puts the port in porter.  Port aroma, with chocolate/coffee overtones.  The flavor is rich and malty, with alcohol presence noticeable.  Yummy.

What a wonderful aroma - dark chocolate/strong coffee, roasted/burnt malts. A little smoky with a hint of alcohol. Dark brown with light brown head. Creamy, full-bodied texture with soft carbonation. Slightly bitter finish but a really, really good porter. Highly recommend.

A rather sharp dry note accents the rich dark malts of this brew, running strongly through a slightly less than full body.  A splash of hops in the close.  I had this at a dinner party where unbelievably spectacular food predominated and it didnt quite hold up to the challenge.  A fine beer nonetheless.

A very deep garnet, chocolate head that fades quickly, lace is adequate, the nose is that of toasted grains, caramel and semi sweet chocolate. Sweet front, the top light, the finish is dry, hop bitter, lightly acidic, robust and quite a treat for us Dark Lovers , when the World is turning to the Light, I will maintain the Dark.
Pretty good, but a little lacking in the flavor department. Not a bad brew, but the flavor is a bit too burnt for my tastes. The aroma is nice, but Ive had better.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2008 Bottle@Home, Oct 08, 3.4: Strong aroma of chocoalte, licorice, laurel and a bit sugary. Opague color, light brown head, good lace. Light sweet, light bitter, chocolate, licroice. Bit thinnish. Flavorful, nice but bit sugary and not exceptional. Bottle@Home, Apr 02, 4.1: Roasted, coffee aroma. Dark brown/black, off-white frothy/creamy head, good lacing. Smooth, moderate full, roasted, light sweet. Long, strongly roasted, coffee finish.
This rich drink has an initially thick head.  Dark colour with a huge chocolate smell.  Strong, complex flavours combined with good strength and excellent, lasting finish. Great deep flavours.
I thought this to be a nice full bodied poerter, but lacking of any significant flavor to set it apart from other porters.
Not nearly as good as Samuel Smiths Taddy Porter, this is too smokey and not nearly as silky and smooth as Sammy Smith. That said it is still a good porter, good maltiness and strong flavor.
A good porter, but not one of Fullers better beers.  Nice malt and flavor but lacks  a finish.

Had a few bottles of this tonight.  This brew pours a dark red brown.  The huge rocky
light brown head is fully lasting and leaves fair lacing.  The big rich nose is predominately
strong roasted coffee, with hints of caramel, dark chocolate, flowers, grapefruit, spices,
toffee, butterscotch, licorice, cola, and alcohol.  The warm flowery flavor is of course heavily
bittersweet (coffee, coffee, and coffee) with a pleasant citrus inspired acidic bite in the
middle.  The finish is long, rich and bitter.  The full creamy/syrupy body has lively
carbonation and finishes complex - dry, astringent, and alcoholic.  Another really nice
porter.

This is the kind of beer I hope
to bring home everytime I venture
out to try a new brew.  Smells wonderful,
but more importantly tastes great!!!
This is a multi-faceted flavor.  Very layered
and complex.  Wonderful.

Great from the first to last drop.

I reallyd dont have anything to add to what has been said, fully agree with chocolate/caramel/capucino notes in the beer though, malty, tremendously smooth and complex, you can point out several different tastes after holding it in your mouth a few seconds, with a quick slurp it is slightly roasty in mid palate into a malty smooth capucino taste.  Best part is the finish.  

Best slightly chilled.

The deep-colored body resembles worcestershire sauce.  Head diminishes rather quickly.  Lovely, subtle coffee and chocolate flavors, with a proper amount of hoppy dryness in the finish.  As it warmed, the flavor profile changed significantly, towards a sharp bitterness.  I prefer this one a bit cooler than most porters, where the full body of the malt is most prominent.
A very dark and rich porter.  Well worth the Fullers name.  I enjoyed every sip of it.  awesome.
A good porter with a good roastiness, but Ive definitely soured on the whole porter style, as even a good example leaves me wishing I had ordered something else.
buttery nose with chocolate undertones.   Butterscotch and chocolate dominate.  super smooth.  Surprisingly refreshing.  Awsome Porter
Black aroma in a bottle. God head, not so creamy. Mild bitterness. Very smooth and delicious.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2007 RERATE 10/07: Dark red body, nice light tan head, light chocolate nose. Creamy, roasty, chocolate with mild bitterness and a coffee finish. Very nice. I gave this a 4.4 when I was young and naive and will not change it now.

This is a roasty, toasty, burnt porter.  I tried it at 58 degrees F and noticed a big bitter aroma.  This beer comes across tart, almost astringent, with a pleasant bitterness and chocolate aftertaste.  I will say that the price keeps me from buying it often, as there are many local micros with good porters, but nevertheless, a great beer.  As another note, I do wish the beer had a little more body to balance the flavor and hops.

Cheers!
A true world class porter.  Black, chocolately, malty, not too sweet and mildly bitter. Every time I imbibe it reaffirms that this is indeed my favorite porter.
Does Fullers make a bad beer? Wonderful roasted flavor with a bit of sweetness. Great stuff.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2010 Canned:Dark, dark brown with a thick, creamy head. Fruity, slightly smokey aroma. Full-bodied.  Sweet, roasted flavour with notes of coffee and liquorice . Late, chocolatey finish. Liquid dessert.
Absolutely the very best porters Ive ever tried.  Lots roasted chocolate flavors.  Extremely silky smooth.  Very easy to drink.

Very suprised by this beer, dark and chewy like a fine stout. The chocolate undertones are terrific. This is is by far my favorite porter. Well balanced, smooth, and oh how I wish I bought more than one bottle!
This stuff impressed me big time, i am a big fan of the esb as well but for a porter this is the best i have had, roasted flavor and its start is creamy and its finish is smooth
Another good berr from our friens overseas.
UPDATED: JAN 10, 2013 Dark brown with a big tan head. Aroma and flavor of roasted malts and coffee. Light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, average carbonation, long coffee finish.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2007 Very dark ruby in colour. 
Rich, roasty and very flavourful. Still velvetty soft, and very drinkable. 
Complex and well balanced.
This beer is like a jawbreaker. The longer you sip the more flavors you get. Best warm. Not for the sauna.
the best porter ive ever had, certainly a benchmark for the style
