Sweet roasted chocolate aroma, thick coffee/chocolate flavor, pleasant finish.  Starts off good and gets even better the more you drink.  Excellent brown porter.
This just became one of my favorite porters. Just loads of chocolate biscuit flavor in here. Its like drinking a cookie or something. Silky smooth finish. A fantastic effort from fullers.
UPDATED: AUG 15, 2004 rich roasted chocolate. smooth, thick.  a top porter
The best beer Ive had, hands down.  Great mix of flavors and a wonderful body.
Very prominent roasted chocolate flavor, if you could solidify this stuff without freezing it you could eat it like a candy bar.  Nice smell, good malt/hops balance.  A good beer.
Probably the best porter I have ever had.  This wonderful beer is the reason I am in love with the porter style.  First class all the way.

Didnt know how to rate this one! Great porter, so good that I wanted to rate it against a belgian trappist. Other porters have nothing on Fullers. Makes me think I am pretty good at rating beers! Glad to see everyone else thinks like me. anyone who gives this a rating below 3.5 has had one to many!
I kept thinking chocolate milkshake. I did not get the coffee flavor of other porters. An excellent version, but I would only drink a couple of these where with some others I would drink more.
Classic, Traditional Porter flavor.  Carmel creaminess and coffee flavors are perfectly balanced.  Truly wonderful.
One of the best porters i have had. Excellent chocolate flavor.
Thin head that quickly dissipates.  Toasty, black coffee, earthy/herbal/grassy aroma.  Black coffee and bitter tea flavor and an earthy catfish-like taste.  Very interesting and tasty stuff.

Just stellar beer. Shuck out the bucks, because there arent many better. Aroma is somewhat milk-shaky, perhaps from lactose.  Flavor is not so burnt as to be unenjoyable.  Fairly dry. A good fire and a good Fullers to all!
This is roasty and full flavored.  Hits the spot on a cool evening.
Great roasty aroma accompanied by a wonderfully dark complexion. Great roasty and malty tastes but the finish is slightly bitter and unpleasant.

Dark, almost opaque body below a persistent, creamy tan head, mild lacing.  Imparts a roasty and malty bouquet, comprised of chocolate, coffee with cappucino highlights, and an underlying earthiness.  Medium-bodied and smooth, the flavor follows suit, containing roasted coffee and malted chocolate flavors, complemented by bittersweetness and ripe, almost sweet, sugariness. Finish is dominated by sugared coffee, leaving a mild, long bitterness and aftertaste.
nicely balanced porter
Yum. This is a rich typical porter. Nice and roasty and thick. Fullers is one of my favorite breweries and Im not often disappointed by them.
Nice bold aroma, excelent dark color almost bordering on stout, superb flavor.  Kinda of a cross between a mocha and beer.  Definatly one of my top 10!
Definitely a british porter rather than an american, as it lacks the harsh roastiness that plagues many american porters. Some vinious notes, but they are balanced, a very good porter.
smooth, malty, chocolate - one of the best in this style
A fabulous porter. Very smooth beer loaded with sweet chocolate malt flavor. One of the best beers of this style in the world.
These dark, sweet, malty, with strong hints of coffee, chocolate to cooking marinade tasting beers will take some getting use to...how do you drink more than one.  Very interesting beer though.

This is an excellent porter.  My favorite of the Fullers line so far.  It starts of a bit thin, but thats quickly overtaken with a warm, roasty chocolate coffee flavor.  The taste is left lingering for awhile.  Highly recommended.

On the red side of black, decent off white head, sweet roasted malty aroma, with some hints of chocolate. Little shot of hops and roasted malt on the frontend, has a light-medium winey body, chocolate notes all the way through the middle, ends with another shot of hops(nothing to strong mind you) and some nice roastiness...nice porter, fairly creamy delievery, maybe a tad astrigent?This is good but Anchor still has my heart up to this point...but a must try for porter lovers......
it had a smoked taste to it,but pretty damn good.
UPDATED: OCT 24, 2013 The chocolatiest of porters.  Not as good as I remember during my impressionable  years ten or so years ago.  Lots of toffee and fruitcake flavors.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Poured with a thick, tenacious tan head.  Mildly sweet, roasted aroma.  Tons of dark coffee and a hint of dark chocolate.  Finished with a firm mocha bitterness.  Very substantial, yet for all the body it was not heavy.  A benchmark for the style.
Chocolate lovers beware- you wont be able to stop!
Wow! Easily the best porter Ive had.
Very good porter. Not as nice a head as expected. Very rich chocolate and coffee flavors. Smooth from statrt to finish.
Great coffee taste and aftertaste  that lasts and lasts.
a very memorable brew!

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2006 July 2001:  The heavenly chocolate/toffee aroma could be a bit more pronounced, and the flavor is if anything a tiny bit too smooth; otherwise, a near-perfect brew that reminds me of why I fell in love with porters in the first place.  Following on the heels of an Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Urbock, this has been one of my top beer nights ever!  The majority IS right when this beer is concerned. 9/5/9/5/19 4.7

March 2006, 330 ml bottle from Julios Liquors in Westboro, MA (February 2006).  Little pop to the cap but near-perfect pour, with a largish lasting fine-bubbled soft brown head atop a slightly viscous deep brown body....VERY light almost nonexistent nose, touch of grass and touch of chocolate  -- as it warms, touches of burnt caramel and chocolate arrive, but it never really becomes distinctive....Chocolaty, balanced roasty-sweet body, light woodiness and grain, dark chocolate and espresso, some nice earth-tones emerge along with a bit of vanilla as it warms....quite smooth, somewhat lifeless but lightly sticky body, reasonably full.  

This is one of those early favorites that stuck around my top 10-20 list for my first five years on the site, and as its never been available in VT, I never bothered to re-rate it.  Still solid for a mainstream, pasteurized product coming from England, this is no longer a great beer in my estimation; whether it has truly lost some lustre in the past half-decade, or its just my tastes that have changed, I cant say.  Current rating is for this recent sample.
A great tastes that sticks with you.  A real pleasure to drink.
Coffee-cream, chocolate maltiness. Fairly easy drinking. Lack of bitterness may disappoint some.
Beautiful,rich nose with loads of roasted malt. Thick and coffee like.Hit me like a ton of bricks. Layers of flavor finishes smooth with a butter toffee hint.

Good - smelled enticing, initial pour - exciting - however head died to a set of larger bubbles quickly.  Lacked the silky mouthfeel that I have come to expect from porter - taste was a nice roasty finish - aftertaste was slightly overdone - all-in-all a good brew, top 5 but well behind Anchor and Samuel Smiths porters.
user_location: Palm Beach Gardens, FL, Florida, USA

text: UPDATED: MAR 12, 2004 Impossibly chocolatey aroma with lighter notes of roasty espresso and date.  Dark brown color, clear, with a lasting, creamy head.  Semi-sweet chocolate also dominates the flavor profile, which becomes roasty and develops hints of caramel and nut towards the finish.  Medium body.  Bubbly mouthfeel, moreso than I recall from samplings gone by.  Certainly very tasty, and seemingly possessed of class as well.
My first porter, and still my favorite. Very impressive.

A definite global top 5 Porter. Full chocolate malt aroma and body; dark ruby red color; smooth mouthfeel with a mild Fuggles hop presence. I still lean to Sam Smiths Taddy, but this is right up there.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2005 Near black colour.  Chocolatey, vaguely nutty aroma.  Fairly sweet, milk chocolatey flavour.  Only a hint of roast.  Moderate body, hint of earthiness.  Finishes with some chewy, molassesy accents in the chocolate.

A great porter - and close to being definitive
for the style.  Rich, with caramel and chocolate
flavors, with just a hint of hop bitterness.
Nicely balanced.  Medium bodied and opaque black.
If youre looking for a good porter, look no further.
